description:
I came for dinner on a Saturday and there was a decent crowd inside, but not insanely busy. My friends and I were seated right away. The interior feels very cramped and disheveled, and there could've been better use of space. Service was good and prompt.

I ordered the Miso Ramen ($9.75) which comes with pork slices, green onion, seaweed, bean sprouts, and corn. Mine also had bamboo shoots in it for some reason. The meal was tasty, but it wasn't anything exciting. The ramen prices are fair and I had a good experience overall.
author: Winnie Y.

description:
Our experience was mixed as service was good but the food did not deliver. 

We came in immediately after they opened at 11 am (not entirely sure if this is a good or bad thing) but we were greeted by a good fellow who let us choose where we sat. This is a first time here and sadly will be the last.

My wife ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen with the Avocado roll that was part of their lunch special and I had the Miso Ramen with California roll as my side. The rolls arrived fast which was a red flag to me but cannot judge whether it was made fresh or not. There was a weird plastic like texture from the sushi and it was very cold (later realizing it may be last night's leftovers and was refrigerated). 

The Ramen took some time and when it arrived at our table was warm. Having just opened, we expected nice hot broth along with smooth and tender noodles. This did not happen and despite finishing the dishes (Mama did not raise me to waste), we did not enjoy the food. 

Ultimately, we will not be returning to this location as the service cannot make up for the food that we had. We are currently nursing an upset stomach. Better to not come immediately after they open as this location may have issues with freshness.
author: David L.

description:
If you're looking for a relatively cheap bowl of ramen, Sawaii has that.  If you're looking for a good bowl of ramen, I would go elsewhere.  

The price range here is about $10-12 for a bowl, which is cheap compared to the plethora of $15+ ramen joints popping up around the bay area.  Unfortunately, pricing is the only place where Sawaii "wins".  

I ordered the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen.  While the portion size was nice, the flavor was lacking in many places.  The flavor of the soup did not live up to its glorious and flavorful name - it was actually quite bland and dull compared to most other ramen shops.  There was no fat cling on the noodles - usually for tonkotsu soups, there is some amount of fat in the soup that allows it to cling to the noodles and bring flavor into your  bites, but there was none of that going on here.  The pork chashu was also hard and flavorless.  The noodles were on the softer side, which I didn't particularly enjoy either.  Altogether, the bowl of ramen was disappointing and underwhelming. 

TLDR Service and pricing was really great, but the food wasn't.
author: Tim L.

description:
Affordable Ramen bowls in the heart of the outer Sunset District in San Francisco, Saiwaii Ramen is located in the old So Noodle restaurant. My family and I came late on a Friday evening and luckily for us it wasn't super busy as our party of five waited mere minutes to be sat. Saiwaii doesn't just serve ramen, they have sushi rolls, sushi, donburi, and other appetizers. It was rather chilly outside, as it tends to get cold late at night in that area, so we were all down for their Ramen specialties. 

I saw another table eating a reddish ramen bowl with plenty of fried chicken chunks floating on top and I was sold. I was so glad I order the Spicy Mala with karaage chicken, sliced pork, one half of a soft boiled egg, nori and plenty of ramen noodles in spicy soup. I loved the spice and overall flavor of the dish and the karaage chicken bites were crispy to the bite despite the fact they laid them in a bowl of noodle broth. The meal was so filling, but it was also the right amount of food for famish diners. Others my group went with the Tonkotsu Ramen, and Miso Ramon and the Unagi Don. Everyone seems satisfied by the meal, especially since everyone's dish was under twelve dollars.   

Saiwaii has great service as our meal was deliver less than ten minutes after we ordered and to keep customers entertained they have The Food Network playing on the flat screen television screen above everyone's head. I can't wait to return to Saiwaii Ramen whenever I have a noodle and soup craving and I'm in the neighborhood. Affordable prices, solid amount of food that tastes great, and a nice ambiance, you can't go wrong with selecting this fantastic ramen joint.
author: Jason F.

description: I ordered under uber eats and it came right on time. Got the chicken katsu and the Philadelphia roll. All ok. I'd order again if I was hella starving. Cuz it's pricey. 18$ deliver fee was like $4.
author: Jray M.

description:
Yummy ramen place on Irving.
Street parking available.
Small amount of seating.

Friendly staff. Fast service.

This place offers both ramen and sushi. Many items to choose from. Prices are ok, not too expensive.

Order was garlic ramen with a side of pork belly. Broth was good and garlicy, but was not spicy at all even though I ordered medium. Noodles were ok. Pork that came with the ramen was a bit tough and bland. However pork belly was very delicious and tender.
author: Michele G.

description: Always order chicken karage miso ramen. All I need.  I have to revise my review, it seems to have new owners or someone cheap has taken over. We used to order spinach and salmon, which enough to share, now it's hardly enough for one person to eat. Service was good thought but servings smaller
author: Michael A.

description: The staff and service was good. We ordered the grilled tongue, spicy tonkatsu and seafood ramen. It was alright. The grilled tongue was cold and not tender. The ramens were lacking a bit of flavor. The broth looks flavorful but looks can de deceiving. It was a bit bland. The spicy tonkatsu ramen does not come with an egg. That's an addition charge whereas other ramen places the egg is included.
author: LZ T.

description: I used to come here often to eat lunch since it was near by and convenient. This place has changed since I last came here a few years ago. I recently came here back for lunch with my husband, we were seated right away. I ordered the lunch special which was choose a ramen and roll. I ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu with the salmon avocado roll. Our food came out fairly quick, but I was a bit disappointed in the ramen. The ramen was over cooked so the ramen tasted soggy, the ramen came with a ton of spinach, a little bit of mushrooms, two slices of pork and some garlic. The spicy was an oil, which I thought was a bit too much. I was also disappointed the ramen didn't come with corn or egg which it used to from what I remembered. Also the sushi rolls were alright, presentation could have been a bit better, the rice was messy. But all in all service was good, I cant complain for the price I paid with plenty to eat, but I wouldnt say its the best ramen in town but def would come eat if I was in the area and craving ramen. The area gets busy so parking can also be a pain, its all metered, but depending on the time it may or may not be easy. Generally I dont see this place jammed pack, so walk'ins are pretty easy to come to this place to eat.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Came to Saiwaii because my brother was craving ramen and my parents just wanted to go somewhere somewhat close to home. I officially feel like I've probably been the ordering the wrong ramen in all my previous visits.

Being a creature of habit, I routinely order the spicy garlic tonkatsu. This flavor, as highly recommended as it is, always seemed to waver between underwhelming and decently good. So this time, I changed it up - I opted for the spicy mala and I thoroughly enjoyed it.

Though I wished the karaage was served on the side (cause soggy deep fried foods are not my favorite), I thought this ramen was great value for $11.75. It featured a soft boiled half egg, 3 large pieces of karaage, another 2 thick slices of char siu, and a helping of other toppings (roasted seaweed, spinach, green onions, etc). 

We also shared two rolls - the panda roll and the paradise roll. Runaway favorite was the paradise roll! Despite only having 6 pieces, the combination of eel, crab, avocado, and fried sweet red onions really hit all the right notes, flavor-wise and texturally - sweet, creamy, savory, crunchy, etc. I also loved that it wasn't slathered in sauce/mayo. The panda roll was definitely more delicate with the butterfish topping and asparagus cores, but it was still pretty good.

All in all, good meal this time.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Decent ramen option in the neighborhood! Not particularly cheap or expensive, acceptable variety of options on the menu, but good portion sizes. The staff were friendly. 
The chicken karaage was a little fatty for my taste, but I wouldn't be opposed to going back!
author: Kim B.

description:
Not bad...OK to come to if you're in a pinch and want some quick ramen (I don't know about the sushi here, since I didn't order that). 

Came here on a Tuesday evening. No wait (doesn't seem like a "wait" kind of place). We ordered the spicy garlic chicken ramen, spicy mala ramen (both mild), and a side of chicken karaage. The spicy chicken broth and boiled chicken was a little on the less flavorful side. The spicy mala, which has tonkatsu and karaage in it, was tastier. I'd come back for that. Noodles were nothing special, but did the job. The chicken karaage was huge, but needed a little more flavoring for me! Overall, the food seemed to taste like Chinese food because of some of the additions to the ramen, the karaage sauce, and the karaage batter (I'm not sure if that's a good thing or a bad thing for ramen?)

Service was speedy and waiters were friendly!
author: Jazzica D.

description:
It's weird to think that someone like myself whose benchmark for good noodles was instant Shin ramen as recently as five years ago could become a ramen snob, but here we are.

I usually judge ramen on two criteria: the first being the broth and the second being the noodles. There's some overlap between the two since they should complement one another. Saiwaii aces the first mark, as their take on Tonkotsu hits the nail on the head: rich, hearty, exploding with umami (and spicy--I'm hopelessly addicted to spicy broth). The noodles are solid, with good mouthfeel, but I prefer mine more al dente.

Service here is outstanding and comes with a big smile. Prices are very reasonable. Probably the best ramen place I've been to in the Sunset.
author: Andy C.

description:
After a long day, we ended up doing UberEats for Saiwaii Ramen. I ended up ordering the dragon roll, which has shrimp tempura, avocado, eel, and crab. About 35 minutes later, we received our order! 

The sushi roll was very filling despite how small it looked! I believe it's because the avocado and extra proteins make this particular sushi roll very dense. It was somewhat hard to taste the crab, as it was overpowered by avocado, eel, and shrimp. The avocado added a creamy taste to the sushi, while the eel gave it a savory feel to the sushi. The shrimp tempura added a nice crunch to the sushi! Overall, a wonderful choice from Saiwaii Ramen! 

I would recommend Saiwaii Ramen! It can be a bit pricey, but there are still some options that are more budget friendly!
author: Liselle L.

description:
Ate here for lunch and wasn't disappointed. Came here with a group of 6 on a Saturday afternoon and had about a 15 minute wait. This place is pretty small, so I'm sure waits can be longer some time. 

The ramen had great flavors, though the meat was a little fatty-er than I usually like. We also ordered a few Sushi rolls and they were all tasty as well! Service was great and prices were fair. 

Would recommend and come back again.
author: Lauren P.

description:
If you are in the area during lunch, Saiwaii Ramen has great lunch special deals!

For $11.50, you can choose the type of ramen you would like (Tonkotsu, shoyu, miso, shio, or a few other more special types for an added $2.50) and a set of their sushi rolls.  That's a great deal, considering the ramen itself is typically $9 already.

As for the ramen, my sister and I each got the Tonkotsu ramen.  The noodles and large portion of seaweed were delicious.  However, we felt that the cha siu was a bit hard.  The broth tasted okay but lacked the rich, fatty consistency of really good Tonkotsu ramen.  I feel like you're better off putting in the extra couple of bucks for the more premium types of ramen that they offered.  It wasn't terrible, but definitely lacking.  We also got the salmon avocado roll and spicy tuna roll.  Both not bad and I liked the slight spice of the spicy tuna roll.

Service was pretty good and my tea was refilled.  The wait time seemed a bit longer than expected and multiple tables were just waiting for the food to come though.  Not the best spot for ramen, but it's decent.
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
I had the spicy garlic pork ramen (what seems to be their specialty, at least according to Yelp) with extra soft-boiled egg. I wasn't impressed with a cold egg. Sadly, the pork belly was chewy and tough.

The tempura was mostly taro root. Tempura for me is all about variety, so...

The salmon-avocado roll was also blah. It was slightly refreshed after I squeezed my lemon slice on it. 

Service was friendly and attentive.

(I'd love to visit more often since it's the closest Japanese restaurant to our home, and Japanese food is my favorite. Hope the kitchen can figure things out! )
author: Camille L.

description:
Average. Will come back but the style is not authentic but overall tasty food.  

We came here on a rainy Wednesday night. It was busy but not packed. We ordered one spicy tonkatsu ramen, one regular tonkatsu ramen, kaarage, and spicy fried chicken wings. 

The tonkatsu broth was good. It wasn't rich or oily like I like, but tasted like a good flavored broth. The sliced pork was a little dry. The noodles were perfect. Slightly chewy and not clumpy. 

The kaarage came out fast. It was super crispy and not oily at all. It could use a little seasoning tho or some sort of kick. 

I would pass on ordering the spicy fried chicken wings again. I didn't really care for the glaze and even though they were fried, they had a soggy consistency to them. The spice level was average, not too bad since I can't eat really spicy.
author: Junella T.

description: Came here because I was down the street, and wanted a quick ramen fix thinking that it was decent. I haven't been here in years but honestly don't remember the ramen being so bad! The tonkotsu ramen had thin, flavorless broth. The pork belly was very odd-it had grill marks and was TOUGH. Like, we could not chew off just a bite of meat; the entire slice had to be choked down the hatch. It had an unpleasant flavor, too. I left my second piece untouched. The highlight was the green onion and bamboo, but even that had an ant on it. I don't know, given all the other ramen choices in the sunset it was a shame I wasted my meal on this place.
author: May L.

description:
This place was great. I enjoyed it so much that I came here twice in two days. The broth was nice and hearty.. and spicy!!! I love my food very spicy, so usually when people warn me about a spice level, I have to find out for myself. On my first visit, I got the Spicy Garlic Pork Tonkotsu with spice level EXTRA. Oooooof. It was amazing but very spicy. If you're not accustomed to really spicy food, beware! On my second visit, I got the Spicy Garlic Pork Tonkotsu with spice level Regular. It was less spicy but still a good amount of spice. I loved it. 

I will definitely be coming back the next time I'm in San Francisco. :)
author: Andrea M.

description: Amazing hospitality and food. The ramen and sushi is to die for. When a restaurant uses real crab meat for their California roll or any of their speciality rolls instead of imitation crab, then you're at the right place. A must go to if you're in the city.
author: Mike C.

description: Sawaii is a solid ramen place in the Sunset - and you can really use a warm bowl of soup in the notoriously foggy and cold neighborhood. The interior is a little small, but the restaurant wasn't too busy when we went so it didn't feel too cramped. The atmosphere is a lively, bustling one which is fitting for the fast-paced nature of a ramen shop. My favorite ramen from their menu is the Spicy Garlic Miso, which is a wonderful combination of intense flavors. The spice isn't so overpowering that the flavor of the miso and garlic disappear. Definitely a place to check out if you're in the area and in the mood for a hearty bowl of ramen!
author: Alicia G.

description:
One of the best ramen places to go to. 
It does get packed here and the line does get long depending on the time of the day you go. 

I usually order the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen and order the extra pork belly with it. This place has the best pork belly! It's so juicy and the gelatinous texture and taste that comes with it is to die for. 

The parking situation can get very frustrating but what do you expect? It's the sunset and you're in SF so make sure you drive down there earlier to look for parking.
author: Lakeen W.

description:
Place - Easy to find. There are many tables inside, but tables are too close each other. Clean and simple. 

Taste - I ordered Spicy Garlic Miso Ramen. It is just ramen nothing special. Soup was simple. Not hot and not that spicy and not rich. Soup was warm. It felt some spice or herb that I don't like. Noddle was thin, just like market noddle. Ingredients were simple. My boyfriend ordered seafood ramen. It tasted more spices. It had some simple seafood. We also ordered side unagi don. It was pretty good. 

Price and Service - Price was reasonable and Service was goos.
author: Da Won L.

description: The chicken was still pink and the pot stickers dont say what the filling is. Its green stuff. They also burnt pot stickers. 10/10 would not order again.
author: Laura D.

description: My fiance and I always order the same three things every time we come - spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen, spicy garlic miso ramen, and the Saiwaii roll. The Saiwaii roll is pretty simple, but my fiance likes spicy tuna and he likes scallops, so this is a no brainer roll for him. I personally think that the spicy garlic tonkatsu broth flavor is much better than the spicy garlic miso, but to each his own! It's rich and has a good amount of spice that makes it more flavorful but doesn't make you feel like your lips are on fire. I haven't really found another place that offers a spicy garlic tonkatsu done as well, so for this reason it gets four stars. Wait staff is also nice and works pretty quickly, which is always a plus.
author: Nicole M.

description:
The ramen is pretty good here. Good portion for your money.The wait isn't long and they have a variety of options. Customizable level of spiciness and many add on options such as karagge or fried chicken and pork belly. I like their pork belly a lot, flavorful and tender! The broth was pretty good as well.

However, I'm not a huge fan of the sushi roll but I've only tried their roll once. But other rolls might be good! 

IG: @dreammieeee
author: Dream-Suphada L.

description:
Friendly waitstaff and I think the owner of the restaurant. The place is small so it can be crowded easily and hard parking since the restaurant is located in the busy section of Irving. 

The spicy garlic ramen was good (approximately $9.75) and I added the kakuni which was $5. The broth was tasty, ramen was nice and chewy and portion was generous. The disappointment I have is that the place charges for the egg which was never case in any ramen I visited before. Other than that, the chicken karaage and gyoza were all tasty.
author: Kay D.

description:
Sorry, just not good soup. Crazy how busy this place is. 

First, they really jam you in here, takes 5-10 minutes until they take your order. Before that you'll be outside freezing or opening the door and freezing half the restaurant (waitress had the door fully opened for a while). You're thinking "well, at least there's some warm soup coming sometime, I hope" as you cry into your thick winter coat that you have to keep on. 

Noisy place, don't bother bringing anyone you want to talk with (unless you are fluent in sign language), drunken kids barely old enough to drink yakking up a storm about every other table. 

Have to say, their unagi roll is pretty good. Maybe some of the other rolls too. But we came for the soup. 

Tonkatsu and miso soups barely any difference in flavor, though the tonkatsu surprisingly has tastier broth. Noodles picked up little of the flavor, the chashu was really bad, but the one shining light was the decent vegetable portions. 

For a ramen place, especially this popular, I'm really shocked it was so mediocre. There are several places in San Mateo that blow this place away, and I'm still surprised that the chashu was terrible, how do you make bad chashu? 

Seems to be a Chinese-run place, like many "Japanese" places here. Wish we had gone to Marnee Thai across the street to celebrate, but live and learn.
author: T J.

description: $11.75 lunch special of ramen + sake roll! Stopped in with a friend on a staycation day, and this is my new favorite lunchtime ramen spot. Sake was fresh, ramen noodles were a great consistency, broth felt warming without being greasy. He got chicken katsu + veggie roll + salad + miso soup for $9. Katsu was crispy and the portions were more than what we could finish.
author: Sarah M.

description:
This place has gone downhill... As you may see from my check-ins, I have been here multiple times. (10+) Initially, the food was not bad, although the service was meh. 
Now the food sucks and the service sucks as well.

Yesterday, after waiting for 40 minutes we get seated down. First thing I notice, the table wasn't even cleaned properly from people who had eaten before us. That alone is disgusting. I cleaned and moved on.

We were starving so we order right away and asked for water. Spoiler alert: we never got water. 
After a while, my GF asks for tea and the waiter brings us tea instead. Asks me if I want tea. I say "Yeah, sure. I also want water though..."
Leaves...
After another 5/10 minutes, he brings my GF's food, while I am there staring at her eat. After another 3-5 minutes or so, he brings my food. I had ordered a large donburi with pork cutlet thinking it would come with curry. Boy, I was wrong. No curry. But that's my fault for not knowing, I guess. 
The plate looked like someone had jerked off on the cutlet, with egg white spread on the cutlet and some green onion and pink ginger. 
Everything was sweet as hell, with overpowering onion and ginger taste. Worst of all, the pork was drier than the sand in the desert of Sahara. 

I hadn't eaten anything all day, so I was starving. Although unpleasant, I had no choice but to eat. So, I asked the waiter to bring me a side of curry so I attempt to eat the food. 
He says there was going to be an extra charge, which... okay. I agreed. He brought curry, which was an absolute disgrace to the word curry. I took roughly about 4 spoonfuls of curry and managed to finish the food. 

I asked for the check and he added extra $3.5 for literally a quarter of a portion of disgusting, store-bought, premade, crappy curry. However, it's just money... I'll make more of it in a lifetime, so I paid and left. 

My sincere question is: If any individual can cook better food than your restaurant, why and how are you even in business? Why is there no respect and love for food and more importantly for paying customers? I get it, you are busy (for some weird reason) but hire more people and give customers the service they deserve. It's not about running around and looking busy but about asking if the food is to their liking and if there is anything you can do to make my experience at YOUR restaurant a little better. 

Needless to say, I am done with this place. Never going back again. 

In my book to mess up a rice dish with curry means, you don't give an absolute damn about your customers and think that just because you have traffic, you are good.
author: Ashish N.

description:
I was craving for some ramen and I decided to try this place because it wasn't too far from my school. I brought my dad with me to this restaurant and I was worried that he wouldn't like it because every ramen shop I ever brought him to, he just dislikes them. 
I ordered both of us the same lunch combo, miso ramen with California Roll and Yakitori (grilled chicken on skewer) for our appetizer. 
The California Roll came out first and it wasn't too bad. But the miso ramen was SO DELICIOUS THAT MY DAD SAID THIS IS HIS FAVORITE NOODLE PLACE. I WAS SHOOK. HE SAID THE NOODLE WASN'T SOGGY AS HELL LIKE EVERY OTHER PLACE. I was surprised that the chashu was really grilled though lol. 
The Yakitori wasn't all that, the presentation was 10/10 definitely! But the chicken was SOOOO GOD DAMN DRY LOL! My dad and I was very disappointed ! 

Overall, I will definitively come back for the ramen.
author: Kristi A.

description:
Great ramen at affordable prices but expect to wait a while for your food. I ordered the tonkasu ramen and it was great - there was the right amount of noodle  to ramen ratio, the two slices of pork are mouthwatering and tender and it comes with seaweed (wakame), negi, and kikurage. My friend ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen which is the most popular item at this place. I tried it and it was also great - not spicy at all if you indicate you want minimal spice and has more flavor in the broth than the tonkasu ramen. 

My only complaint is the wait I came here on a Wednesday with my friend and we waited 30-40 minutes for our ramen to come. But overall this place is worth the wait!
author: Christina G.

description:
Decent bowl of ramen; a popular spot in Outer Sunset, which doesn't have a ton of ramen options. Good lunch specials. 

Tonkotsu ramen was well priced, but didn't have a ton of toppings.
 It had seaweed, memna, chasu, but no egg :( The broth was good, but not super creamy or remarkable. The noodles were really well cooked. 

The service was a tad slow when the restaurant was really crowded, but they have a small staff, so it's understandable.
author: Amanda C.

description: We had their to tonkatsu ramen.  The cha su (sliced pork) was old, and you can taste that it was frozen, and reheated and way pass it's expired date.  Even with the spicy broth it didn't cover up the bad smell from the meat.  The broth was beyond tasteless. A ramen from a package has more flavor.  The Karaage too tasted weird.  Looks and tasted like old chicken.  The only good thing about this place is the service.  Unfortunately,  you will not have return costumers if you're serving old meats.
author: M H.

description: I really like the broth here. Granted I'm not sure what authentic ramen tastes like so I can't compare but this is amazingly good. I came from San Jose and did not regret. Coming back soon. Only downside is the store is quite small. It's not a big deal, though. Also the pork (chashu) is quite thick compared to other ramen places, I like my pork thin but it was still good. For spice level, I got regular. It wasn't spicy for me. Will definitely get the highest spicy level next time :))
author: Vy N.

description:
Came Sunday night around 7pm and had to wait an hour because they had a large party. The waiters are very nice even though they seemed stress because of all the tables they have to manage and the 24 Yelp orders. 

I got the regular tonkatsu ramen which was okay. The broth was tasty but felt like it was missing something, an extra kick. Good amount of noodles and toppings.decent prices for a bowl.  

Overall, good service and can't complain about the ramen.
author: Sharon L.

description:
Great food, but not so great service. I got the Chicken Ramen and loved it. But, keep these in mind:

-If you ask them to make it spicy, they give you this sauce when they give you your meal. I pretty much dumped it in my bowl since I can usually handle spicy food. BIG MISTAKE DON'T DO THAT. This was the only meal that made me tear up. That sauce is insanely spicy.
-I needed water cause of the insanely spicy meal, but their waitresses were hard to get ahold of. 
-If you ask to add mushrooms, they put in Enoki mushrooms. That's the one kind of mushroom I don't like. Not their fault, but I wish I knew what kind of mushroom they would add.
-The place is pretty small but cute.
-They take credit card.

I would probably go back. I just wouldn't put that sauce in my ramen again.
author: Remy B.

description: Very good ramen place! Probably one of the best in the sunset. Service is fast and they are nice, told us to take our time when they were about to close. Very fair price too. Highly recommended if you are on Irving and you want to have lunch/dinner.
author: Kevin R.

description: Wonderful service- they also have vegetarian ramen that's not currently on the menu. Y'all need to add that so people know... it was amazing! Best vegan ramen in all of sf. Ask for it extra spicy
author: Sharon D.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night and the place was pretty full. The music that was playing in the background was hip and the place had a strong/great smell of garlic, which made me really hungry. I ordered the tonkatsu ramen and added a dollar for the egg. Sadly, rather than receiving the nice gooey egg, I got an egg that was on the verge of being a hard boiled egg. Thus minus a star. However, the prices for ramen was only 8.95. Thus plus back the star.

My friend got the garlic tonkatsu ramen and hers was super yummy. There was a great taste of garlic and it tasted a lot more flavorful than the regular tonkatsu ramen. She got regular spiciness but I think that was already too spicy. So if you're not a fan of spiciness, it might be best to get mild.

We also got the soft shell crab and it was ok. It would have tasted better if they fried the crab at a higher temperature and made the batter more crispy. Nonetheless, still a good place to go to try!
author: Victor L.

description: There isn't a lot I can say about this place because I just like it so much. This restaurant is small and sometimes there is a long wait but I think it is worth it. I always get the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen. The flavor is always just the way I like it. The noodles are nice and chewy. There ground pork and the chashu pork in the bowl. I come here often so I don't have to tell you if I'd come back because I've been coming here for years.
author: Ada N.

description: Came here yesterday with a big group and loved it! Friendly waitresses, and DELICIOUS ramen- probably the best I've ever had! I ordered the garlic chicken miso ramen with mild spice and it was amazing.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Been here a few times always in hopes for better...
Tonkatsu ramen really salty with thin slivers of pork.

Pork belly is where it's at... deep rich flavors reminiscent of long marinated process.

While they have sushi, it's not their specialty.  Who comes to ramen joint and have sushi?  Even though a large portion of menu detailed sushi.
author: David H.

description: I came here for dinner with my friends. I like that they give us free tea. I ordered the pork ramen and it was very yummy.  However,  the portion size is a bit small for guys.  My 2 guy friends also ordered ramen,  but they were still hungry. 1 guy asked for extra noodles and a small donburi on the side.  My friend ordered the volcano roll that cost $10.95, but came with 8 small pieces of sushi.  It was smaller than the usual sushi pieces from other restaurants.  They should make them bigger considering the price.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
We came here after a day of walking at the Golden Gate park and everything was pretty average. I had the tonkatsu ramen and a side of fried calamari. It wasn't super delicious that it stood out from the other ramen places I've been to, nor was it super bad either. Everything was just pretty average. 

What I really liked about this place was how all the people working here seemed friendly and welcoming (at first!). BUT toward the end of our meal, I felt like we were pretty rushed to get out.
author: Averi E.

description:
It gets busy here during lunch time. I'm surprised by the great customer service i received from the only two servers. You could tell that they were trying their best to please all their customers. 

I've opted for the lunch special, which is a regular sized ramen and a 6 pc sushi roll for $2 extra. The spicy tuna roll had much more flavor than the California roll. 

Tonkatsu ramen + egg - good standard ramen. The noodles itself were a bit undercooked. I enjoyed the yolk from my egg. Perfectly cooked! Not too runny, not too "powdery". I have had better ramen, but this isn't the worst I've tried. 

Chicken hearts - recently I've become a fan of chicken hearts. I was pretty disappointed with the chicken hearts I got. The chicken hearts were flat, almost the texture of jerky. It was rubbery and unsatisfying. 

If I was really craving ramen during lunch time on a weekday, I would probably come here.
author: AJ C.

description:
If Yelp gave 1-10 star ratings I'd give this place a 7.

I got the spicy garlic tonkatsu with a soft boiled egg. Temperature wise, I couldn't tell if it was because I ordered my bowl spicy or the temperature was really hot or mix of both, but this place's broth felt a few degrees hotter than other ramen shops. Not a big deal, but just something to take note of. The noodles were fine, weren't cooked perfectly though. The broth lacked pizazz. Chashu was average, definitely not bad, but not amazing either.  The soft boiled egg wasn't perfectly soft boiled, but it was fine enough for the average consumer. Service is great, but they don't smile.

Overall...
Noodles: 3.75/5
Broth: 4/5
Chashu: 3.75/5
Soft Boiled Egg: 4/5
Service: 4.5/5
author: Alvin D.

description:
3.5 Stars

---------------------------------------------------------

This is one of my few go-to places that's near me! 

Sawaii offers many different broths of ramen but my favorite here is the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen with extra spicy. If you love spicy (be warned, you have to be able to really handle it), you need to get it extra spicy! The broth was decent and came with chasu pork, bamboo shoots, seaweed, mushrooms and green onions. Unfortunately, the chasu pork was on the fattier side. 

For lunch, they have a special that you can get 6 sushi rolls along with your ramen. Knowing that this place isn't a sushi restaurant, the sushi was expected to be standard. It wasn't bad but not something I'd order again. 

For the appetizers, I've had the chicken karaage which wasn't bad but it was a little heavy on the batter. It tastes a lot better with the lemon squeeze! I've also tried the Hatsu (chicken hearts) which was not worth it to me. It was around $4 for 6 pieces that were super small. 

Service is good! They take your orders quick and the ramen comes out in less than 5 minutes. The workers were really nice and attentive. 

Overall, decent place to get a bowl of ramen on a cold day!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
I live in the sunset, so I come here a lot as it is one of the few ramen joints in the neighborhood.
It's an okay place, but is VERY INCONSISTENT with its quality.
I always default to the tonkatsu ramen, so that's the main dish I'll be judging.
In the past, the broth was thick and flavorful. I actually really liked it!

As of late however, it's been oddly watered down and bland. It doesn't taste rich or even look like it. It kind of just tastes like water with salt.

One night, my boyfriend had the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen (which was also somehow still very bland), and woke up at 3am only to have the meal VIOLENTLY exit his body in liquid form.

Another night I was chewing and thought I'd gotten a particularly tough piece of green onion. I spit it out and NOPE. IT WAS A STRIP OF PLASTIC. They discounted my appetizer...I mean thanks but a $4.25 discount isn't gonna make me feel better about potentially ingesting plastic...Like why is there clear cellophane plastic your food in the first place? that's a huge f*** up right there.

Come here if you're lazy and just wanna get a quick mediocre bite. Maybe you'll be pleasantly surprised and get a good meal. OR you might get a really bad meal and have violent diarrhea.  It's been a crapshoot as of late.
author: Melissa L.

description:
I got the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen, medium spicy with the extra spice on the side which I ended up adding half in. Also added chicken kara-age, corn, and an egg. Because let's be real here, you need eggs in your ramen, or else it'd be incomplete! 

SPICYYYYYY!!! I would recommend medium spicy because the extra spicy is probably going to burn you. I reallllly like the flavor overall, their pork was good, also the chicken was a great idea! This is my first time adding kara-age to my ramen and it did not disappoint. 

Service was actually impeccable for this kind of ramen joint. Our server was super chill. Haha. He understood what I wanted and seemed to be very well informed. 

Would totally come back.
author: Yen P.

description:
I've come here plenty of times and although I don't love the food, it's convenient and close by. They are never really busy, so you can get a table anytime. Their broths are flavorful. Prices are average. About $12-13 a bowl. 

I usually come here when I'm craving ramen. There's not really any other places close by.

One day, I ordered to go and they told me 30 minutes but the food took about over a hour. I went to Adronicos for grocery shopping. When I came home, I noticed that for the tonkotsu noodles they were VERY stingy with the soup. When I heated it up. It barely covered the noodles. The seafood noodles broth was a normal amount. (As you can see from the photos)

I will still come back but definetly will not order to go again.
author: Nancy M.

description:
Overall, I would say this place is a 3 star, but if I were to just rate this place based on food alone... it would be 2 stars. I was actually warned by my friend before that this place wasn't good, but I'm ramen crazy so I had to try this place out. (Seriously though... 3/4 of my last reviews were about ramen...)

I came here on a weekday for dinner. There was no wait or line and was seated and ordered promptly. Usually I see the line out the door on weekends, so I took advantage of the fact that there was no wait to try this place out.The service was very indifferent, it wasn't bad but it wasn't over the top either. 

For food, I got the tonkatsu w/ an egg. The broth was probably one of the most flavorless broth I ever had for ramen. Even though I added pepper flakes later on, the whole meal itself was pretty flavorless and not very enjoyable. The chashu was fatty, and tender. Egg was an extra dollar but it was nicely half boiled. 

Additionally, I got the chicken karaage. This came out like 5 mins after we ordered it, so it was probably already precooked and then double fried to heat it up. Which would make sense since the coating seemed a little thick, but overall it was seasoned nicely and goes well with the sauce provided.

Overall, I probably would not come back here for ramen. They have a large selection of food (from sushi, appetizer and ramen), okay service but the ramen itself was 'meh...I rather not.'
author: Jenny N.

description:
Hmm I gave this place a shot, but it's one of those restaurants that it's only a one time thing. I wasn't really impressed with their ramen (I mean I am a sushi and ramen snob) so it would be really hard to impress me. 

Ambiance: casual
Food: just ok, really basic, lacking flavor, sushi is packed with so much rice, ramen over done. 
Price: $
Service: great
author: Gwen M.

description: Went here one hour before lunch closing. Our usual place was closed. Overall the lunch special is a good deal (Ramen and a 6 pc sushi roll for $11.50) but then you +2.50 for Spicy Garlic Miso flavor and +5.00 for extra meat (2 small pieces of pork belly... seriously!) and still get NO EGG . The chashu was inedible (too chewy!!). Wouldn't crave this ramen. Roll was fine... similar to Safeway. Highlight of the meal was the bacon wrapped mochi which I wouldn't NEED to have again but it was an interesting idea and executed well. Don't need to go back to this place but it was good enough for the pinch we were in trying to find open ramen place  at 2:00.
author: Ricky S.

description:
I came here with a friend on a Thursday night around 6:30pm and was glad to find out there was no wait. Located in Sunset, this place is surrounded by a lot of good food and dessert as well so parking can be pretty difficult if you're here during peak hours. The venue is not too big but they managed to fit quite a few tables in here. 

I ordered the most popular dish: Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen. Yes, it was decently spicy which added a nice touch but the broth was really fatty and oily. Usually the oil and fattyness really adds to the flavor but this sort of detracted from the flavor and made it less enjoyable for me. The noodles here were also really thin and hard and not a good kind of chewy ramen, making the noodles taste very un-fresh (non-fresh?). After trying some really amazing ramen places in SF, Saiwaii Ramen definitely fell short for me and am sad to say I was disappointed with my meal.
author: Catherine S.

description:
AMAZING ramen! Always nice and accommodating staff! We usually hit this place up once a year when we come to town for an event, and we like to pop in their TINY establishment with 8-20 people! We always call ahead, and while we may wait a bit for our table, the staff is always generous when it comes to adding chair after chair. This is the best ramen I've had in the city! they also have some amazing sushi and tempura. I always get the Miso ramen and its delicious!
This place is tiny, but great.
I'll always come back.
author: Nicole P.

description:
Saiwaii is my go-to place for ramen since a long time. No idea anymore how many times I've been to this place... That many! ;)

From all the places I've tried in SF and Bay Area overall this is my favorite. Easy going atmosphere and friendly personnel. Fantastic free tea to go with it.

I normally go for the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen (note: you need to order the egg as an extra). As starters, I really like their beef tongue and in general their chicken karaage. The only think I don't like over there is their pork belly because it's way too fatty. 

Pro Tip: When ordering their spicy tonkotsu you can choose level of spiciness. I love spicy food and their mild level is already more than enough. Go beyond that at your own risk ;)

You can also get sushi over there but I've never tried it.

Bon appetit... or in this case... どうぞめしあがれ (douzo meshiagare)!
author: Nuno S.

description:
This was my go to Ramen spot when I lived in the Sunset! I lived literally walking distance from this place. I became a regular after some time, I think the servers started to recognize me and my boyfriend. Definitely comfort food. 

The Seafood Ramen is my favorite! The broth is delicious. I always get their gyoza as well with hot tea. The servers are very hospitable. I'm always greeted when I enter and leave. Great service!
author: Grace A.

description: A friend recommended this place on the fly so figured ok.  Cute small location. Friendly staff.  Had fried chicken n pork ramen (mild) n could have used a bit more salt. But very delicious. Tried the fried soft shell crab and that's a pass for me. Wasn't as good so ended up not eating it all.  Downside was having to move every time someone at table next to me needed to get up from there's.
author: Monica D.

description:
I'd say this is a solid spot to quench your ramen craving if you don't want to wait in a crazy line for dinner on a weekend like at some of the other spots in this area. Our party of four came at 8 PM on a Saturday and only ended up waiting ~15 minutes.

All four of us ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen because it just looked so good! The flavor in the broth is just outstanding! This dish definitely did pack a kick when we ordered with "regular" spice level so go mild if you can't handle your spice intake, but we found it pretty great. The dish comes with fried garlic slivers on top which just go so so well with the dish. I found the pork and noodles cooked well and every ingredient meshing well together.

The only thing I would say is that the tonkatsu ramen is quite heavy! None of us finished so be prepared to take some to go containers home :) 

Also you must order hot tea! Its got that beautiful toasted rice note which is perfect on a chilly SF day.

Enjoy!
author: Sabina S.

description: Lunch special was great both times we went. Sushi roll and a bowl of legit ramen was $11. Very friendly staff. Family friendly.
author: Steve B.

description:
The service was great but the ramen really did not stack up to that of competitors.

The broth was light and watery which can be good but the toppings really did not mesh well together. 

The cuts of meat were well done and were too hard in texture.

If you want a laid back lunch this is a great option, but if you want the super fatty melt-in-your-mouth hunks of meat and a thicker broth you'll be disappointed.
author: Albert L.

description:
This place reminds me of the former Sawaii that used to be in the FiDi. They sold their sushi for half price at the end of the day. I wonder if it's the same Sawaii. I'm pretty sure they use the same logo. 
We came here once for a very late lunch / very early dinner, and there was no wait time, but it was already crowded. Understandable as there aren't really any ramen options in this neighborhood. 

$8.95 Tonkotsu Ramen - pork, bamboo, scallions, mushrooms:
The broth had good flavor and a milky consistency. The noodles were okay. I would have liked more pork in my bowl though. I think I only received one little piece.

$10.95 Spicy Mala Ramen - karaage, pork, spinach, 1/2 egg, nori:
This broth had a lot more flavor and a nice kick. The egg was cooked well with a solid, but still creamy yolky center. The chicken karaage was good, but parts of it do get a little soggy in the soup. 

$4.50 Yakitori:
The chicken was skewered with grilled scallions, but it didn't have much flavor on its own. However it had a teriyaki glaze on top.

The food is pretty decent and quite affordable. If I had a craving for ramen or other Japanese items in this neighborhood, I'd eat here again. Overall, I consider it a 7/10.
author: Joy W.

description: I may be the odd duck out, but I prefer my ramen to be less spicy and more flavorful (when its very spicy, it is hard to taste beyond that).  Saiwaii has become a favorite.  The ramen is delicious; broth, ingredients, spice and it is not overly salty.  All the flavors can be enjoyed.  And the people who work here are wonderful, friendly and chill.  Service is excellent.  It is small and I can see long lines but worth it. And yes the sushi is good and the beer is cold.  Thanks for reading!
author: Erin M.

description: Can we just talk about how amazing the pork belly is over here? Love coming here.  We came here last weekend and I had the spicy tonkatsu ramen and added the pork belly.  The pork belly literally just melts into your mouth.  I need 10 more bowls of this delicious ramen.
author: Ray P.

description:
To be honest I only ever get one dish here - the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen - but I like it so much I don't feel the need to try anything else LOL. Not only does it have garlic flavor, but there are actual slices of roasted (?) garlic too. It has the perfect amount of noodles, which have a nice chewy texture, and while the two slices of pork are a little on the small side, it's still very flavorful. It also comes with a good amount of vegetables and seaweed so you get a slightly more balanced meal. My main complaint is that the broth is pretty creamy and oily, so I always feel really heavy after eating this. Also egg is an add-on so I tend to opt out to save money :( 

The restaurant is small but they have an efficient turnover rate so the wait isn't ridiculously long during peak hours, and servers are always attentive. Parking is terrible in this area and you'll probably find yourself circling the blocks multiple times but that's to be expected in the city. Solid food for a reasonable price makes this my go-to whenever I crave ramen!
author: KC W.

description:
Stopped by here when I was visiting SF. It was a cold evening, and all I wanted was some ramen to warm my soul.

The restaurant is pretty small with some tables but seemed to have a lot of character. When we entered, we were promptly seated! I decided to order the Tonkotsu ramen without the green onions. It honestly hit the spot! The noodles were the perfect texture. And the broth was delicious - creamy and flavorful. The service was pretty good as well! 

Also, I must add that this place has DA JAMS. They were blasting some throwback R&B songs from the early 2000's, and I was grooving along while enjoying my ramen!! Honestly, I think this place is great and am glad I found it!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
My friend and I love this place. It's PRETTY GREAT :) The wait usually isn't long after 8:30pm and that's when we usually come, more like around 9:30pm. They are still open! :)

The ramen is REALLY GOOD. I love the Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen but my bf is right, it only comes with 1-2 tiny pieces of meat. He usually orders the Seafood Ramen for more meat for a dollar more.

It's usually not enough food for the both of us so we share a roll. The bill comes out closer to $40, about $20 per person. If it's a date night this is an awesome place to be, otherwise, it is a little bit pricey for dinner when you know you can use that $40 and eat rib-eye steak dinner at home for less. I know it sounds cheap but gotta save money to come back!

I WILL BE BACK :D
author: Kimberly W.

description:
Amazing ramen here! We came here on Saturday evening, around 6 and were able to find parking in the area pretty quickly as well as we got seated immediately too. Both of which, I understand are extreme rare cases.

The ramen itself is excellent! I ordered the Spicy Mala and my girlfriend ordered the Tonkatsu ramen. We also got a tempura donburi as well. The food took a little bit to come out, but the place was packed and there was a line out the door starting from 6:30 onwards.

The donburi was good, however, the tempura was coated a lot.

The Spicy mala is the most bang for your buck as it comes with chicken kar age, egg and a bunch of other add-ons for the same price as the Tonkatsu. Also, the spicy broth isn't extremely spicy, but just the right amount!

Will definitely be coming back!
author: James D.

description:
I am genuinely convinced that this Izakaya Sozai vs. Saiwaii is only a thing because Izakaya is so hyped up. I've gone to Izakaya and I found their ramen to be just ok. Not something that I'd crave or come back to. Saiwaii is the exact opposite for me. It's a nice cozy place that doesn't take long to be seated but the Tonkatsu Ramen with Extra Pork Belly is by far the best Tonkatsu that I've had in the city.

I'll probably receive flak for that but honestly, the noodles are delicious (and handmade), the broth is rich with lots of layers of flavor and the Pork Belly is out of this world. I literally think about this Pork Belly at random times of the day remember how delicious it is.

I want Saiwaii to receive more credit for the incredible ramen (and food) that they do have but I also don't want more people to come because I don't feel like waiting in a long line. After ramen, I like to pop over to iTea for boba. Don't know how I leave that much room for this, but I come all the way from Pacific Heights for this ramen. I really do recommend it over Izakaya. I overall think the experience is better.
author: Adrianna L.

description: I love this place but I love Joseph Luong more. Great ramen great karaage great service
author: Yucheng C.

description:
I came here for lunch on a weekday at almost 1 pm and the place was still packed with people! Not too far from TPumps, this little ramen place is tucked in Sunset. My friends and I just stumbled across this place & were sure glad we did so! 

The ramen here is super affordable and cheaper than most other ramen places! I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen ($8.95) which is the pork broth base one. It also came with bamboo shoots, cha shu pork, seaweed, green onion etc. My noodles were perfectly chewy & al dente, and the broth was super flavorful. One of my friends got the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu ($10.95) which was similar to mine expect that it was spicier & had a deep aromatic garlic flavor. My other friend also got the Spicy Mala ($10.95) which came with karaaage in addition to  pork, 1/2 an egg, and seaweed. I've never seen karaage in ramen, & it looked soo good!

Their lunch specials included the different ramen + varieties of sushi you could choose from. The menu also included lots of sushi rolls, nigiri, donburi, appetizers of edamame, agedashi tofu, etc. There were also a bunch of specials posted on the restaurant wall. Service was relatively quick and our ramen came out piping hot. Considering the great price & my happy belly I would definitely come back to try out more things on the menu!
author: Joy W.

description:
Ok, so I'm really surprised that Saiwaii isn't more highly rated on Yelp because I love it. It's one of my favorite cozy, affordable spots in the area with comforting food. I think the ramen here is MUCH better than the offerings at Izakaya Sozai (seriously, stick to their specialties - don't get the ramen there), though definitely a step down from some of the more solid Japantown staples. It's great for the area, though! Not a ton of comparable offerings in the western end of the Inner Sunset. 

I always get the tonkotsu ramen - love the broth! But the sushi here is also solid. The wait staff is great - very prompt and friendly. Food comes out quickly, always hot and fresh. I'll certainly keep coming back!
author: Delia Z.

description:
This place usually has a lot of customers around dinner time. I didn't have to wait at all when I came here for dinner one night. I've been here many times and I typically get the spicy garlic tonkotsu, which is alright. Not too much to complain about but also not great. This time I decided to try the spicy garlic miso ramen. I was very disappointed and wish I just stuck with my usual. The ramen really didn't have much flavor at all, other than spicy. Everything I eat, I love it spicy. Next time you want a spicy ramen here, stick with the spicy garlic tonkotsu. 

Aside from the ramen, I always get the negi hama sushi. It has hamachi in it and even though it's a pretty simple and small roll, I like it a lot.
author: Annie H.

description: Great lunch spot in the sunset. I've had the ramen, chicken katsu, and a number of other dishes over the last few years of coming here. Food is consistently good, and service is on point.
author: Daniel G.

description:
food：yummy yummy 
serviced：should be improved


（i had dinner right there just now, when i got in the restaurant, that is couple in front us. so we probably waiting for table for five mins.
after we sitting down,  1there is a waitress bringing the chopsticks for us/ she forgot to bring the napkins to us.    so when we eating the restaurant was not a full-house already, we tried to put our hands up to ask for napkins, this action probably cause 2 mins, the waiter & waitress never come with us, they both standing beside the counter & looking the kitchen. they always stand behine n never focus on the customers first.      2after we finished our food, we asked for check, the waitress just put down the receipt & to go box never come back to pick up our card & receipt until we call she come!!!)

this is not the first time have dinner right here.
i still remember last time this restaurant was full-house, but the services didnt like this!!!


i hope the owner by this restaurant could see this n warn the waitress and waiter from tonight.  we so disappointed for the services tonight. we were their paying our moner for asking services, plz always respect n focus the customers!!b
author: Yingying C.

description:
I've been here plenty of times so this review has been long overdue. 

-I either order the Tonkotsu or Non spicy Mala ramen. Their soup base is delicious and unlike other ramen places I've been to, they're generous on their ingredients (spinach, egg, cha siu). 

-Service varies depending on the time you dine in. I love coming in at the late lunch time, when the usual lunch crew leaves. I've come during dinner and immediately regretted it. There is so much noise, and I feel like you can't really enjoy eating here with everyone talking over another. 

The servers are patient and make sure to get your order right. Regardless of what time you come in, make sure to look over the menus and walls because you might miss something! After eating at Saiwaii, I love heading two doors down to get my boba fix at Teaway.
author: Erica K.

description:
The Sunset has plenty of options for steamy noodle soup, thankfully so given the typical chilly and/or foggy weather.  While monopolistic competition prevails for pho and wonton noodle soup, the ramen scene is largely monopoloized by Izakaya Sozai and Saiwaii. 

TL;DR: In my opinion Izakaya's ritsu tonkotsu is more authentic and of superior quality, but there is only one ramen on the menu, plus occasional specials if you're lucky. Saiwaii is thus a good alternative in this part of SF, especially if would like more ramen options. Besides the traditional tonkotsu/miso/shoyu, Saiwaii also serves gimmicky spin-offs like mala and seafood. (Also, Saiwaii has way better lighting for food porn! Izakaya is very dim and my pics there always look ugly)

The broth here is alright--not very rich and flavorful, but if you get it spicy enough you will not be disappointed. However it was more oily and salty than I would have liked. In the bright foodporn-friendly-lighting, you can even see a thin film of oil. It sounds a bit gross but it turned out quite tasty, which is why I drank quite a bit of broth and got super thirsty afterwards. Noodles are just alright as well, not quite al dente, nothing special, and a bit too egg-based for my preferences.

The SPICY MALA is definitely the best deal, since it comes with chicken kara-age, chashu, half an egg, green onion, nori, and spinach. First of all, two types of meat included is unheard of, and none of the other options come with egg (though they totally butchered my half egg and I had to turn it upside down for my picture... sad.) The chicken kara age was not very meaty but surprisingly good, as the thick batter prevented it from getting soggy in the soup. The spinach was another excellent addition, earthy and nicely contrasting all the umami. 

I've also tried the SPICY MISO and SPICY GARLIC TONKOTSU, but I think the mala was more unique and better value. I would pass on the extra meat toppings which is an additional $4, which can get you an entire cup of cold brew coffee in SF(!!!) The spicy mala is the way to go if you want more meat and complimentary toppings.

Like most standards for ramen spiciness, spicy is not very spicy: if you like spicy, I highly recommend getting extra spicy. Be aware that the spicy mala is spicier than other ramen, as you may notice with the bright red broth. Extra spicy level on spicy mala is thus wonderful for those who adore spicy foods, terrifying for the spice-intolerant or anyone with GERD. (Fun fact: mala is a term from the Sichuan region for Chinese food, translating to numbingly spicy)

It comes out to ~$14-15 after tip/tax/that weird extra SF tax--a bit pricey for a bowl of noodle soup, compared to the more budget-friendly pho and wonton noodle soup in the neighborhood, but within the normal price range for ramen. (Especially in SF...Where $4 can get you 3 pieces of pork belly, a cup of cold brew coffee, or a piece of artisan toast)
author: Edna C.

description:
Came here with some friends for lunch on a Wednesday. The place wasn't too busy, so we were seated immediately. We all ordered a lunch special combo that came with a bowl of ramen and our choice of sushi from a select list. 

Service was great. Waiter was very personable and attentive. 

Food came out quite quickly and tasted great! We will definitely be returning!
author: AJ B.

description:
I never really go to Irving for food because parking is probably the scariest thing I've ever encountered in San Francisco so I honestly never wanted to bother. HOWEVER. When you're stomach's rumbling and you're nearby then you should treat yourself to ramen here. 

Parking is all on the streets and metered till 6pm. If you come before then then you can try for residential parking nearby if you're not down to pay.

The size of this restaurant is decent. Once you step in, you'll see everything. Bathroom is located all the way to the back and is unisex. Public bathrooms are scary to me, too, but this one was surprisingly clean. 

I came here one night with my boyfriend and he said that their spicy ramen was good. I can't take too much spice so I got their shoyu ramen and an order of their deep fried calamari. Both dishes were good and we ended up leaving with a happy belly for the both of us. 

Overall, come back? Yeah, if I'm ever in the area. Prices are decent for the portion you get.
author: Venus L.

description: This review is ONLY based on their ramen. I tried the shoyu and my favorite spicy tonkatsu. One of the best ramen places in SF despite the competition down the road. The place is very limited seating and gets packed fast but the staff is very attentive and the flavor makes up for the wait. They offer a lot of sides/additions that pair well with the ramen. I asked for extra spicy, corn, and chashu. The spice was a habanero blend which made my soup extra flavorful. The chashu can sometimes be a hit or miss due to the texture. The prices and portion for the add-on was relatively cheaper and generous compared to other places. Overall, the flavor, portion, price, service gets !
author: Dennis H.

description:
This is for ramen only review.  Got the Tonkotsu ramen
-with cha su ($10.95)  Portion wise not generous but still about to fill you up.  Noodle texture is fine but there's no cha sui as described in the menu, just 2 pieces of pork belly which was not melt in your mouth as I've experienced in other ramen places.  The pork was chewy and rubbery.  My friend got the chicken ramen which was made with free range chicken not frozen chicken which was OK , the soup lacks seaweeds or other ingredients.  It got green onions and cilantro.  My friend have to dip into my noodles because his soup was not enough to fill his appetite.  Over all the salt level was high like all ramens  so I can't say how good the soup is.  I don't understand why this place is often packed.  I'll op for many more choices in this area if you want soup and noodles.
author: Mar H.

description:
I first tried Saiwaii about 5 years ago. I remember their ramen being pretty good, so when I was craving noodle soup last week, I decided it was time to revisit. It was Wednesday, December 16th and I ordered delivery for dinner through Eat24. I placed the order around 7:10pm and it arrived around 7:55pm.

*Gyoza ($4.95)
*Gyutan: beef tongue ($5.50)
*Hatsu: grilled chicken hearts ($4)

The gyoza was pretty standard, but good. Totally fulfilled my pot sticker craving. The beef tongue was eh. No smokiness from being grilled or seared. And I found the sauce they used too sweet. Kinda reminiscent of teriyaki. I didn't like it. The chicken hearts were a better. Had a nice chew.

Spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen: very spicy, includes cha shu, wakame, negi, menma, kikurage, ground pork ($10.95)
*add Pork belly: cubes (+$4)
*add Spinach (+$1)
*add Corn (+$1)
*add Enoki mushroom (+$1)

The ramen was okay. They give you a good amount of pork belly as an add on. It came with plenty of toppings. The only thing that felt kind of like a rip off were the enoki mushrooms. It was just one bunch. At $1, I expected at least two. The broth was nice and spicy, but I didn't get a lot of depth of flavor. I was expecting to taste more pork bone and garlic and just more levels of yumminess. The soup was more or less just salty and spicy.

It's nice to know I have more options when it comes to ramen for delivery. I just wish Saiwaii's broth was a little more solid.
author: Elena N.

description:
Would only come back if I'm *dying* to get that ramen craving satisfied... other than that, I would pass. I think this place constantly gets a crowd going only because it's the only ramen place around in this area! 

I tried the tonkotsu and the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen. Both were salty and I found them bland with no substantial flavor. Cha shu was not as tender as I would've liked... it was also a smaller portion than I expected but maybe that's just me! It's a bummer that the egg is not included and it's an additional cost. On my last visit, despite my egg being butchered, it was cooked perfectly to my liking. 

Just FYI, gift certificates do not count for being used as tips. Reason is because they can't take out the money from the certificate and split it among their employees. Personally, that shouldn't be a customer's problem...??! A $50 certificate that was bought with $50 cash is STILL a $50 value to your business. Lame.
author: Kris C.

description: The flavoring was just alright for me kind of bland on the spicy tonkatsu ramen. And the Chicken karage was just ok
author: Sera D.

description:
Yum! Hit the spot on a rainy winter day: top notch ramen (porky, opaque broth!), unagi rice bowl (savory sweet goodness), fried chicken (crisp perfection!) and the pot-stickers. Seated just before the lunch rush - quick, efficient service.

I'd skip the sushi, however. It was serviceable but stick to the heartier fare.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Tonkotsu ramen is great as always. 

I personally can't take spicy but I saw a lot of customers enjoying spicy ramen last night. Perhaps you should try it if spicy food is your thing!
author: Danae L.

description:
My go-to place for spicy ramen for sure!!! It def hits the spot on a cold night! I would say that the wait varies...sometimes this place is packed and you will have to put your name down on the waitlist and sometimes you get immediate seating. 

Parking - There is metered street parking as well as residential parking. 

Service - It's alright. They're always really nice. 

Food - 
I'm pretty picky with my ramen because to me, the broth either makes it or breaks it. I would say that this place hits it right on the nail when it comes to ramen. The broth is never too oily and is always packed with flavor. 

1. Spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen (Regular spicy) - I always get this one!! It's really good!! The toppings come with fried garlic, bamboo shoots, seaweed, green onion, pork, and greens). I would say the toppings pair really well together. Very flavorful. 
2. Spicy mala ramen (Regular spicy) - It's pretty good but I prefer the spicy garlic tonkotsu just because of the broth. It comes with fried chicken, soft boiled egg, pork, green onion and greens. You may think three pieces of chicken isn't much but it will fill you up! It's crisp to perfection but if you leave it in the broth too long, it will get soggy. 

But overall, I def will be back!
author: Coco L.

description:
Came here on a Sunday morning after a night of bar hopping for my friends' birthdays, and I thought the ramen hit the spot. I ordered the tonkatsu ramen, and although it's not the best ramen I've had, it definitely got the job done. 

I was surprised that the restaurant took my large group in so quickly, and although I came in a little bit later than the rest of the group, they brought my ramen out super quick. If you're ever in the area or just want some comforting ramen after a night of drinking, I would suggest checking this place out.
author: Tricia N.

description: Saiwaii Ramen is a great restaurant. Even though it is small, their soup is the best. The also have a variety of other foods. However, if you came for only sushi, you should go somewhere else since their sushi is overpriced. But do try their soup.
author: Deb K.

description:
Worst ramen I've ever had. I didn't know you could over cook pork that badly. Broth was bland. But noodles we're cooked perfectly. And they had great customer service. So I'm chalking it up as an off-day. 

You do get a big portion compared to the other ramen houses in SF. 

Had the tonkotsu ramen with an egg.
author: Jee Mee H.

description: Really good ramen for a really good price. I loved the service too. They were very nice and attentive
author: Stephanie H.

description:
I passed by this place so many times and never realized that this was the ramen place I've been meaning to try but never got around to. I've heard rumors of it getting crowded which makes sense since the place is small. Luckily, I came an hour after opening hour on a Wednesday night so my friend and I were able to get a table right away when we walked in. 

SPICY GARLIC MISO RAMEN at regular spicy and hits the spot for my ramen cravings. The noodles were good and the broth didn't leave a heavy sodium taste in my mouth. However, the regular spicy level might as well be called mild because it barely registered as spicy in my mouth. 

It wasn't particularly super busy Wednesday night but it did take a few minutes to flag down a waitress when I was missing a pair of chopsticks at my table. But they quickly brought it over after I requested for one. I find it strange that they use to-go chopsticks that you get in your takeout orders instead of real chopsticks. It almost feels the equivalent of handing me a plastic spoon for my ramen. No worries, they do have actual soup spoons but your chopsticks will be of the disposable variety.

Overall, I would come back again if I wanted ramen in the Sunset.
author: Diana C.

description:
I ordered the spicy garlic miso and friend ordered spicy tonkaksu
BOTH ARE FANTASTIC!
The waitresses are so nice.
Recommended.
author: Candice L.

description:
Many friends recommended this place so I decided to order takeout from Yelp Eat 24. The first order was a Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu (cha shu, wakame, negi, menma, kikuage) + an egg (+$1) + Pork belly (+$4). The second order was a Spicy Mala (karaage,negi, spinach, 1/2 egg, nori, cha shu).

Order was made on time but when I got home, my Spicy Mala was missing karage and the 1/2 egg - this was why I ordered this dish and the two main components were missing! I even left a note in the Spicy Mala to not include negi - which they abide by but how can the other two ingredients be missing?! The Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu was exactly as ordered... If I based the cost of the Spicy Mala off of what's missing, it should be $10.95 - $4.50 ($4 for kara age + $0.50 of 1/2 egg) = $6.45.

I may consider eating in next time but extremely disappointed about getting ripped off with this order.
author: Judy C.

description:
I've always been curious to try out this Ramen place on Irving st. Always having a long line on cold nights makes this place very appealing. Like most Ramen places, it's my expectation that there would be a long wait and a crowd within, but there was no one there this past Monday. My friends and I sat down quickly and got to order fast.

For our appetizer, we ordered some Nigiris and a couple of rolls. A restaurant that serves butterfish gets a plus from me, and this place do. 

We ordered a ramen bowl each and I got a Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu. Like any other ramen places, you're able to customize your order by adding fixins. I opted to get some pork belly since I enjoy pork wayyy too much. 

The ramen noodles itself was excellent, firm, chewy and all what great noodles should be. The soup base was just ok, nothing really special about it. The pork belly however was a little disappointing. I recommend not ordering it as an add on. I feel that it tasted old and was quickly heated up and put atop my order. 

Quick Rating:

Food: 3/5
Service: 5/5
Cleanliness: 5/5
Decor: 4/5
author: Jan R.

description: This is one of my favorite ramen places in the city! The Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu is 10/10! I'd totally recommend if you love spicy foods. The sushi is here is alright so I stick to the ramen. The service is nice and quick.
author: Angela W.

description: I been coming here for over 3 years. When I first started coming here i would be the only one in the whole restaurant. They have really blown up and gotten so popular since... there's not always a wait but sometimes for dinner there is people outside waiting. This place is solid and I personally love all the toppings. Their egg is sooo perfectly soft boiled and seasoned. If ur looking for a local ramen spot this is my go to.. and I'm Japanese! I get the extra spicy garlic tonkotsu... it's made with ghost peppers so beware.
author: Patrice L.

description: I had a great experience here. We came at a busy time and instead of being awkwardly greeted and told to wait one of the servers enthusiastically cleared off a table for us with a cool, calm and collective sense of urgency. We got our menus, which were very well put together and ordered. Overall the sushi was delicious and more authentic than most places. Again, we felt very welcomed and comfortable here.
author: Lisa B.

description:
Today my fiance and I wanted to find a solid ramen place close by and this place came up.  I got the Kara ramen and she got the tonkatsu, we also added the mini tempura domburi and tuna domburi.  Let me start with the donburies they were delicious,  however the ramen was below subpar.  The broth was good and the egg was cooked to perfection however the noodles were nothing to rave about,  the thing that made me give this place 2 stars was the pork, it was super hard and almost unedible, never have I ever had such horrible cooked pork in my ramen.

I was really hoping that this could ve been that spot to come on those cold nights but I don't think this is it.

It very well could be that they were having an off day, however I will not be taking the same gamble again.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
SERVICE: Straight forward. If the place is packed, you walk in, sign your name on the clipboard, then hang around outside the restaurant until they call your name. Thing is, they won't call it more than once or twice so dont' stray too far. This is not the type of place that will check up on you so if you need something, flag 'em down! 

FOOD: This part is primarily why I'm giving this place 4 stars. The ramen is not out-of-this-world, but it's consistent. I come here a lot because it's in my neighborhood and I have an addiction to noodles. I've tasted all their ramens already (Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu & Spicy Mala are my favs!), thus there isn't much else that surprises me here. I do enjoy their appetizer selection though. Beef tongue, bacon-wrapped mochi, and their chicken karaage is good. Also, if you're a fan of eggs, ask them to add it to your ramen. They pre-cook the eggs so they stay soft boiled when they drop it into your bowl. 

ATMOSPHERE: Dark wood all around combined with the ceiling lights romanticize the place a little. It's a small place anyway so I say it fits quite well with the "cozy" vibe. 

HINT: If you order a non-spicy ramen but you like spicy food, add some white pepper and spicy sesame oil to your bowl. (Condiments are on every table).
author: Greg Y.

description: Came in from out of town & was craving ramen. This place definitely hit the spot. They have good weekday lunch specials. Andrew was our server& he was so friendly and personable. He offered to take our picture & suggested some things to do after lunch. Thank you Andrew!
author: Bryanna M.

description:
This is my go-to ramen place when I'm in the Sunset and didn't make reservations for or want to wait at Izakaya Sozai. The wait is never too bad for us at any time we go. It's never been more than 20-30mins for 2 people. 

They have broth flavors like Miso, Tonkotsu, and Shoyu which is good enough to satisfy my boyfriend and my cravings. I've gotten the Tonkotsu and Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu flavors before and liked both.

They also have sushi rolls. We recently got the Alaskan roll which is like a California roll with Salmon sashimi and lemon slices on top. Lemon slices really made a difference and tasted good!
author: Amanda L.

description:
Small little place and very cute sign :) on the outside. There are several varieties of ramen and we didn't know what to get :O 
I ended up with the spice mala and got some short ribs too. Giving them a 4 star because my din din partner loved it and I would have if the fried chicken wasn't a bit well, hidden..? I felt I was getting the coating and parts I don't know, more than just chicken and that's scary to me Lol! 
So in conclusion, I did love the broth, egg and veggies but would do no meat next time. Gonna try the rolls in the next visit, they look great! *You guys need a Golden State Warriors roll now ;)!!!
author: Tere C.

description: This is a wonderful establishment and I am truly im bliss as I eat this scrumptious ramen that touches my heart deeply. The staff is very friendly as well, and service was constant and pleasant.
author: Sam L.

description:
Came here for lunch since our other place closed for lunch time.  The place is small, but we got in pretty fast.  About 7min wait.  

The favorite is the spicy garlic tonkatsu, so that's what I went with.  I added Chicken karage and had it on the side. I don't like it soggy.  They were super crispy bc they include the skin!  The ramen bowl was surprisingly good!  The flavor was good and it wasn't too heavy.  Regular spicy was perfect for me.  Read a review and it said spicy was really spicy.  No thanks, I like to taste my food.  :). We ordered a side of croquette and it was delicious.  Hot and crispy, perfect taste.  It was a lot of food for me, I couldn't finish.  

They have sushi rolls and yakitori items also.  Not sure about those, but I think there are mixed reviews about it.  Most of the people ordered ramen, so maybe go with what you know? 

The space is small, but it works for groups also.  Overall, I'd recommend this place for some good ramen.  You're on your own with the rest.
author: Lisa V.

description: My go-to spot for ramen in the city. I usually get the tonkatsu ramen. So delicious and filled with flavor. It could get busy here at night and during the weekends since it's a small place, but it's definitely worth the wait! Love coming here
author: Monica-Leah A.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in the sunset to get great & affordable ramen and sushi. 

There is a lot of parking in the surrounding area and the wait, when there was one wasn't too long. They are always super timely and nice, welcoming you and saying thank you when you leave. 

I definitely recommend it and the food is just amazing!
author: Radley R.
