The wait time also kind of sucked considering the worth of the food. Waited for about 40 minutes by the very-crowded doorway and was eventually seated in the very-crowded establishment. Gotta love the quick service though!
author: Krissy L.

description: Love Saiwaii!! Such a great spot. Hardly ever a wait. The spicy garlic miso with butter is my favorite. Would definitely recommend it.  Service is always good.
author: Jason W.

description: Always consistent ,in my opinion best soup in town , that garlic tonkatsu is putofthis world , I've been coming here for 5 years , haven't been disappointed, hamachi Kama one of the awesome options , even thou this time got the salmon Kama ( to die for )
author: Miguel A.

description:
Yes to the Extra spicy garlic tonkotsu with egg!
No to the chicken karage which was mostly fat and batter! Got the job done but nothing to die for!
author: Michelle H.

description:
I've been craving ramen lately and decided to give this place a try.  They do close for lunch, so be sure you check the schedule so you don't get confused when you get there and they are closed.  The restaurant is small, so there may be a wait.

I like how they always serve tea when we sit down.  I love the flavor of the tea and especially great on a cold day especially since its often cold in San Francisco.  I had the Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen with an addition of the Unagi Donburi.  I love the flavor of the ramen and it really hits the spot when craving ramen.  It had the right amount of flavor and it was pretty good.  I was hoping that the noodles would be a bit more chewy because it seemed like it was just a bit soggy.  I love the small donburi that came with it since I love unagi.  

Definitely will be coming back if I was craving ramen while in the area.
author: Teresa W.

description:
This is my to go place to get my ramen fix.  It gets pretty busy and the wait could be pretty long, so be prepare to wait if you want an excellent ramen. 

This place is small but their customer service is excellent.  They try their best to sit you as soon as tables and seats opens up.  

I always order the Spicy garlic tonkatsu extra spicy.  If you can't handle spicy food just get regular or mild.  Their broth is very flavorful compare to other ramen restaurant I've been to.  I add pork belly (extra charge of $4), corn ($1) and an egg ($1) , my bowl usually would cost me about $17 after all the add-onsI know it's a little pricey but it's worth it.

Anytime I crave for an excellent and satisfying ramen, this is the only place I go to.
author: Junaline G.

description:
Spicy miso ramen... That is all. Literally hands down best ramen place on San Francisco. 

As a self proclaimed ramen connoisseur, I have tried countless (seriously countless..) places trying to find the perfect ramen. Well this folks... this is it.
author: Jalahn W.

description:
Sometimes when mistakes are made, things turn out okay. I ordered the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen with chicken karaage. I was initially disappointed when they forgot the karaage as an extra topping and gave me a spicy rather than the regular level of spiciness for the broth. 

After initially sweating it out, I started to enjoy it more and more. It was a good kind of pain that left my lips tingling. My capsaicin receptors rejoiced as they became saturated. The broth itself was super spicy, but it had a rich, bold flavor. The noodles were ever so-slightly undercooked, just the way I like them. Everything turned out well since my karaage was added on the side and stayed crispy instead of turning soggy in the broth. 

There was room for improvement with the cha-shu, which was mostly fatty and lacked any meat or flavor. I found two tiny pieces total. The agedashi tofu was lackluster. It either wasn't fried properly or sat way too long it the broth, which was bland. Shortcomings aside, the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen with a side of chicken karaage is a winner.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
ughhhhhhmmmmm, interesting. friend of a friend suggested this place cuz it is his favorite, and he lived a really long time in tokyo, so he must know right? um, no, not really. 

we ordered shoyu and spicy garlic tonkatsu...with additional veggie toppings and sides of fried chicken... and it was just super duper disappointing! the broth is kinda bland and not thick like i expect tonkatsu to be.. BLEHhhhhHh. oh then, the fried chicken is very super duper lacking in flavor! so sad, cuz i was really looking forward to it since i ran a lot in the morning to eat it. MEEPS. will not be coming back, especially making the trek from soma..
author: Christina L.

description: The best soup! The crunchy roll was delicious! The service was fabulous too! And all accompanied with a hot tea !
author: Ailenez C.

description:
Came here for lunch with friends and it was yummy! 

The husband was frustrated because he had to pee and he hates crazy parking (the parking in this area can be a bit much and it is a circus). Karma chips cashed in and we found a spot in front of Saiwaii. 

The pork belly miso ramen was just what the doctor ordered.. tons of pork belly!! The ratio of noodle to pork belly was perfect. The broth was bomb.. No complaints from me!! 

The husband got the pork don buri... it was gone in a flash :). Side salad was also well liked. 

Overall would definitely come back 

:)
author: Vicky T.

description: Great ramen,  place needs to update Google menu.  Everything was a dollar more expensive,  even add on pork belly.  Ramen doesn't come with egg which was sorta a disappointment.  Also they need to fix the door... It doesn't self close.... That sucks on cold windy day
author: Nicholas P.

description:
After eating at many ramen places over the years, it' hard not to feel they're all very much alike. Saiwaii is no exception. Most seem to have the same spicy miso broth, or garlic broth, or pork belly ....etc. My order tasted like it could have come from any other ramen place.

This little ramen joint is snuggled in the busy part of Sunset, on Irving St. Thumbs up for location, thumbs down for availability of parking. The service was very good. Friendly young ladies greet you immediately in Japanese fashion, and we were quicky seated. The place isn't big, so there's a a  chance you 'll be snuggled up next to a stranger. 

My spicy miso broth (regular heat) was good, but nothing extraordinary. The pork belly was a "melt in your mouth" tender, but the pieces were lacking. Did it just melt in to the broth? Being regular spicy, I could not detect any heat. 

My friend's extra spicy was indeed spicy, judging from the sweat-fest off his forehead, But he also said the actual flavor of the broth was covered by whatever they added to make it extra spicy. 

Overall, if you're close to the area, this would be a good, convenient place (assuming you find parking) to get your ramen fix.

Personally, I prefer Hisago on Geary Blvd. They seating is more spread out, feels more spacious and my ramen came with a generous porion of charred, lean pork. 

http://www.yelp.com/biz/hisago-san-francisco?hrid=Y_rg_u1F36HdHRxLGTD8HQ
author: James L.

description:
Mediocre ramen and sashimi don. Thats all i have to say. We left half of ramen. Broth was bland.
Service was fast and servers were kind though.
author: Iris C.

description:
Just had the tonkatsu ramen. OMG...never had such a salty bowl of ramen before...and no water refills, so thirsty! Nothing special. :(  Ordered an egg as extra topping that was just plain hard boiled (doesnt have that nice golden yolk like at other ramen places). 
My husband got the small unagi bowl to go with his ramen...it was a pile of rice with two tiny unagi pieces. We ate the two pieces and left all the rice.
About to go home and drink a gallon of water to rid that salty taste! I dont understand why people say this is the best ramen house they've been to!!
author: Minh D.

description:
I've been wanting to find my ramen spot since coming back home from LA. I think this might just be the one. 

The place is small so space is limited. Luckily we got seated right away. As this was a ramen place, I ignored everything related to sushi because experience has told me they're never good. They offer the standard ramen, shoyu, miso, tonkotsu, etc etc.. I researched a little bit before ordering that the spicy broths were the way to go. Perfect for me cause I'm a spicy fan. They all sounded delish, but the spicy garlic won my stomach. 

It was very very flavorful and it had just the amount of heat. The egg was slightly runny and not cooked all the way like it should be. Everything about it was wonderful. I ate EVERYTHING, including drinking all of the soup. The portion was enough to make you full.

Expect me to become a regular here :)
author: Fiona L.

description: Good place for affordable ramen but don't expect anything special.  I came here for lunch with my bf and we both ordered the lunch combo with spicy garlic miso ramen and salmon avocado sushi.  To be honest the ramen noodles were a bit hard and the broth was super salty! There were also two small slices of pork, corn, bamboo shoots, bean sprout (oh no... Not bean sprouts), and seaweed.  The sushi was good and we also ordered bacon wrapped mochi that came out a little burnt.  The edges of the mochi were black and started bubbling out so it looked like popcorn.  The mochi itself was too chewy it was hard to eat.  My boyfriend usually LOVES this stuff and when I saw him take one bite out of one and say "ok I'm done" I knew it wasn't going to be good.
author: Linz C.

description: Love going here for the ramen and I love going here during lunch time for the special. Only $11 for ramen and sushi combo. Keep going back here.
author: Francis D.

description:
Saiwaii Ramen is my go-to ramen place in the Sunset district. (Well, it's practically the only ramen place other than Izakaya Sozai eight blocks up.) The restaurant is very cramped, and if there's a long line, there's only room for two to three people to wait inside. Otherwise, expect to wait outside.

The restaurant offers a lot of small appetizers, portioned well for two people. I always order their bacon wrapped scallops. They are yummy! Although there's nothing particularly unique about it, you must admit anything wrapped in bacon is delicious. The salmon belly nigiri is great as well. The rice ball holds together nicely and the salmon is very fresh. But unfortunately, they have appetizers I will never order again, such as their chicken hearts, chicken gizzard, and chicken skin. They were all very burnt, dry, and overall, not enjoyable.

But, this place specializes in ramen so, of course, I always order their tonkotsu ramen! The broth is nice and creamy, not very oily either. The noodles have a nice firm texture. They give plenty of seaweed and the one small but delicious chasu slice has an amazing "melt in your mouth" consistency. I prefer the regular tonkotsu over the spicy garlic one because with the spicy one, I barely taste the broth, even when I ask for it to be mild. Their miso ramen is tasty as well and not overloaded with bean sprouts, which is a definite high point since most restaurants typically use them as filler. And I have yet to try their spicy mala ramen.

The service is hit or miss; sometimes they're very attentive and friendly, but other times, ehh... It also really depends on how busy the place is. But regardless of service, I will continue to dine at Saiwaii Ramen whenever I crave ramen on a chilly night.
author: Priscilla W.

description: Very kind staff and delicious ramen. I went on a Saturday night and there was no crowd. The food was good and prices were middle of the road. I would definitely come back again.
author: Alexis Lynn E.

description:
This review is based on the sushi.

Don't go here for sushi, but they do the fried food right. Sister and I got the  King Kong Roll (spicy tuna with unagi and butterfish) and Sawaii Roll (spicy tuna, crab, topped with spicy scallops). These sucked. The rice tasted old and the flavors were very plain. 

The fried oysters were bomb though...but not enough reason to come back.
author: Michelle N.

description:
SPICY GARLIC TONKUTSO is the best!!!!!
The staff are nice as well.....
YUM YUM!!
We always come back for more!!
author: Dianne Jay S.

description: Short wait on a Friday night for 6 people. We ordered different ramens and loved the spicy garlic tonkutsu ramen, and Las Vegas roll. We also ordered the chicken karaage. Friendly service. Definitely will come back.
author: Neil L.

description: Ordered thru post mates, sushi was warm and now we have stomach aches after consuming 1 each. Chicken karaage was H O R R I B L E. They overcharged $10, hope we can get our money back and we are never ordering from here or dining in as long as we are alive.
author: Chris C.

description:
The ramen and sushi is average here.  I ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu with added chicken karaage.  The soup base is delicious, but the karaage is way too breaded. It's about a 60:40 ratio of breading and meat.  The spider roll was made with lettuce, which kinda ruined the texture of the roll. 

The seating is pretty cramped, but it's good for a late night ramen spot.
author: Lisa X.

description:
My Ramen cravings are always brought on by either weather or feeling under the weather. I stumbled upon this spot driving down Irving look for a Pho place. It was a gloomy day. When you walk in there is a sign in sheet. The restaurant was 3/4 full. 

We got seated near the kitchen right by the POS station. Ramen came quick, broth was savory, pork belly melted in my mouth. The eggs in the ramen were a perfect soft boil. 

Why only 3 stars then? We were rushed through our order. When I wanted to order some Sake it was hard to get our servers attention. No one came back to check on us. Plates were not cleared. The Ramen was REALLY good but they need to brush up on the customer service.
author: Roxanne O.

description: I've been here a million times and tried many different items on the menu, but I would have to say the spicy garlic tonkotsu rises above over all! Add an egg and pork belly and it's perfect! And there's nothing better to top a perfect meal off with than amazing service. Thank you Saiwaii for never letting me down! :)
author: Cassie T.

description: The more ramen I eat, the more I appreciate Saiwaii. It is authentic and flavorful. It has umami!
author: Cat N.

description:
I've come here twice for the lunch special, which is a pretty good value: $10.95 for a bowl of ramen and a sushi roll. $2 extra if you want the spicy garlic. I'm actually not a fan of the spicy garlic - I found it overpowering and I could no longer taste the pork flavor.

In one case, the ramen was overcooked and a little soft, and in the other some of the noodles were undercooked and still stuck to each other. Their tonkatsu broth is not too salty and has a good meaty flavor, and I like their toppings.

The restaurant is small and so can get busy. I've been very happy with the prompt and friendly service here. Overall, the food is decent, but not spectacular. I'd certainly come back, but wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.
author: William H.

description: My friends and I love coming here. I've tried their chicken ramen and seafood ramen and they were both good. Definitely worth coming here!
author: Eileen Joy P.

description: More like 3.5 stars. Nothing wrong with this ramen. A great bowl if you are in the Sunset, and it's open for lunch. Great lunch combo offers. The soup base is good and milky, and the special flavors are there to kick it up a notch. Nice chew to the noodles. The spicy chicken karage ramen was pretty good on my last visit.
author: E. W.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend on a Sunday around 1pm and got seated right away. I got the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen regular spicy and he got the tonkatsu ramen. We both added an egg. The egg was over cooked in my standard but I guess they can't have it runny when they cut the eggs in halves.
The spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen is actually pretty spicy. I think I will get mild next time. The texture of the noodles are good and both broths are flavorful.
author: Ivy L.

description: Had the tonkotsu ramen and mini curry bowl. Flavor of the tonkotsu was creamy with a hint of white pepper. The curry bowl was generous for a side dish and my boys loved everything we ordered. Our food came out quickly and presentation was on point.   Will come back to try other dishes here
author: Daniel S.

description: Love their ramen....wish it was closer and I would eat it daily. Lol.  Spicy garlic tonkatsu and the pork belly is delicious.
author: Fahm S.

description:
Let me preface this by saying that although noodles are my favorite type of food, when it comes to ramen places, it's hard for me to tell the difference. Overall, though, I would say this place actually stands out as one of the better ones! The ambiance is nothing crazy fancy; if you just feel hungry and want to go somewhere more relaxed, this could be an option.

I got the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen. I'm not big on spicy foods so I chose to get it mild. The noodles and broth were kind of a larger portion but since it costs $9.75, it's kind of expected that you'll get more. I ended up eating almost the whole thing! They give a lot of meat, as well. I also tried the curry which comes with rice, in a little bowl. I'm also not a big curry person, but I liked it.

I saw that they have a sushi menu but didn't get a chance to try it...so it looks like I'll have to come back!
author: Krystle L.

description: Great service and awesome Ramen! I love this place because in addition to ramen they have some sushi to satisfy all tastes in your party. The staff is always very friendly. But, be prepared to wait a while if you plan to go during a hot time! I love the spicy garlic ramen with added egg and sometimes corn. I really like that you can personalize your ramen to really get what you want. And, their "spicy" is legitimately spicy, which I truly appreciate!
author: Kayleen R.

description:
We got here around 6:00pm and by 8:00, there was a line out the door. Who knew?

Being the Sniffly Sandies that we were with our respective colds, we opted for a bowl of ramen each (spicy garlic tonkotsu for her and regular tonkotsu for me: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/saiwaii-ramen-san-francisco-3?select=VfF1fmlw6gF6r-P4UmQGbA#x8brkSq5LnVurdhTy09R9A). The spicy garlic was exactly that: spicy and garlicky. The regular tonkotsu had a good broth, but nothing to write home about. The bowls came with green onion, chashu (braised pork belly), bamboo shoots, seaweed, and kikurage (mushrooms). The soft-boiled egg (which wasn't runny at all--boo!) was $1 extra.

We also opted for some hot green tea and it was surprisingly good. I've resigned myself to tepid, watered-down green tea at Asian joints, but this was the real deal; very good. 

Service was pretty good, the food was tasty, and the prices were fair. A solid joint.
author: Adena B.

description:
Great ramen in the hood. We get the moderately spicy ramen with pork belly. We had sushi to share and the rolls were not half bad at all. Fresh fish. Great taste. The service could use a little spiffying. But this place hits the spot none the less! 

The wait can get a little long. So get there early if you can. Otherwise you will find yourself huddled up giants the window staring at those lucky enought to get a seat first.
author: Michelle I.

description:
It was a dark and stormy night....

Well, kind of. I mean, it was raining. And my friends and I were craving a big steamy bowl of ramen, so why not go to a highly-rated ramen house in the heart of a district known for great Japanese eats? 

First off, I'm glad we had a reservation because this place is tiny. It's even smaller when it's packed full of people like on this particular Wednesday night. We barely made it inside and stood shoulder-to-shoulder with some other guests who were also waiting patiently. This was made more challenging by other patrons entering and leaving, and I'm sure that if we didn't have a reservation I might not have as high of an opinion of this place. We were seated quickly though and promptly began out feast. 

Not in the mood to be too adventurous, I went with what seems to be their most popular option: the spicy garlic tonakatsu ramen, complete with some fresh herbs, a lot of noodles, an egg and two slices of pork. The star of this dish is the savory broth, of which I wish there was more. I could eat a bowl of the broth on its own and was saddened that this dish was far less broth and far more noodle oriented than my favorite ramen houses in Sacramento. Another negative was the pork, which was in my estimation about 95% fat. The fat might do wonders in enhancing the flavor of the broth, but there was no meat whatsoever. 

I will take into consideration that on a busy night (which seems to be every night here), the poor chef in back is pumping these tasty creations out like an assembly line and probably doesn't have time to analyze the fat-to-meat or noodle-to-broth ratio. Still, it's what makes ramen wonderful in my opinion. Either way, I'll be happy to give it another shot the next time I'm in SF on a blustery night.
author: Alex L.

description:
My boyfriend loves this place so we went here last Sunday for lunch! It's pretty small so there's usually a wait but never too long. You can always walk around too in the area which has lots of Asian markets, bakeries, other food places, etc. 

My favorite is the spicy mala ramen which comes with huge pieces of chicken karaage and I like the spicy broth. We also ordered the sawaii roll and croquettes. Could barely finish the ramen and took the croquette to go. 

Sawaii roll was pretty good with one piece of spicy hotate on each one and the croquette was a great size and good filling inside. I'll be back here again.
author: Samy L.

description: This is probably my favorite ramen place in San Francisco.  It's so good!  I usually get the Tonkotsu Ramen, and then add spinach and/or egg.  The broth is delicious, and so is their sushi.  I like ordering the negi hama sushi, which has hamachi (yellowtail) in it, or the hamachi nigiri.  I've also tried the other sushis there, such as the Lion King or Spider Roll, but they don't seem worth it for the price.  I was actually bummed when I didn't like the Lion King roll.
author: Eric L.

description:
I went to this place during lunch time and it was pretty packed but I am a fan of this place. Being along Irving street, there is street parking. 

During lunch they have a sushi + ramen combo and this is definitely worth the price! I order the Miso Ramen and I was delightful satisfied with the broth and how the noodles were. This was my first time here and the service was not bad at all for being how packed it was when my friend and I went. I would come here again to try the other ramen on the menu.
author: Loree T.

description:
Spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen (with an egg and pork belly) is my go-to here. I think I've inadvertently ordered it every single time.

The pork belly is melt-in-your-mouth, fill-you-with-savory-fattiness, smokingly orgasmic. The only downside to this item is that because it is so fatty, it can/may leave you in a coma afterwards. If you can't handle it, share that goodness! The noodles are plentiful and the broth flavorful, but don't expect it to be clear (actually, quite the contrary). The chicken karaage is also delicious. Light, crispy, and just the right amount of breading without being overwhelmingly thick or greasy. Good to dunk in ramen broth. The portion is slightly small however. 

On cold days, this is all I want to eat. I will hibernate a happy girl.
author: Shirley V.

description: After my go-to place, Yamadaya, went wayyy off its rockers, I was in search for good quality and low priced ramen in the city that I could continually go back to.  I got the spiciest flavor of the tonkotsu ramen.  The broth was amazingly rich and even though I might try the medium spice next time, it was still what ramen should taste like.  The karage was perfection as well, but the gyoza was not good.  The meat inside was a little too soft and tasted like it had too much spinach in it.  The service was also very accommodating and did a great job balancing all the customers in such a busy atmosphere.
author: A Y.

description:
The first time I came here I ordered the chirashi and didn't even know this place was more known for their ramen! :O totally my bad. The chirashi was alright, I've definitely had better. The fish didn't seem super fresh, but it was decent. At least I didn't get sick. The variety of fish was your typical tuna, salmon, hamachi, etc. No special sashimi pieces. Size was perfect for me (I've seen bigger chirashi bowls), but you might need to order something else if you're really hungry (I wasn't that hungry).

Second time around, I learned from my mistake and ordered ramen. I got the spicy garlic tonkotsu, extra spicy with an egg. What I like about it was the spiciness. Now I LOVE SPICY and everytime I order a spicy tonkotsu, it's never spicy enough for me. I usually have to add the chili seasoning and chili oil provided. However, the extra spicy was perfect!!! I didn't have to add anything to it. Some might not like the extra spicy because the spiciness can overpower the actual flavor of the tonkotsu. I tried a sip of my bf's tonkotsu and it was pretty flavorful. The ramen noodles weren't that impressive though. Not very al dente, but at least they weren't soggy. They still had a little bit of chewiness to it, but not that nice crunch you can get from better ramen places. They give you a decent amount of toppings. I definitely had chashu pieces remaining after I finished my noodles. Their chashu was decent, not outstanding. Now, I ordered an egg in addition to my ramen. They precut it in half for you, I tend to like mine whole. When it came out, it looked perfectly soft boiled so I went ahead and ate one half immediately before the hot soup overcooks it. When I bit into it, it was cold which I never experienced before, but I love that runny egg yolk so I didn't mind too much. I let the other half warm up a bit more in the broth so it wasn't cold, but the yolk cooked a bit more.

Service was decent, your average asian service. The service was real fast. The bowls of ramen appeared before us before we knew it. There was no line both times I've been here and they greet with you a Japanese greeting which is nice (probably because their service is pretty fast). The place isn't that big either, seating can get a bit crowded.

They have a nice variety of ramen too and flavors I haven't had before like mala which I do want to try next time. They also have lunch specials where you can get a roll for an additional $2 during weekdays. For me, the ramen was enough (perfect sized bowl). It left me full but not overstuffed, if I got a roll too, I would have been too full and would have probably passed out after.

Prices are decent $8-$11 for a bowl of ramen. Those special flavor ramens cost a bit more, the spicy garlic tonkotsu was $10.45.

Of course it's located in sunset district so parking can be tough depending on the time and day. Both times I've been here finding parking has been easy to find. (late night around 9pm or weekdays around 2 pm). You do have to pay meter during work hours.

There's better ramen places, but they always have a line. So I'll definitely be back for some quick decent ramen close by.
author: Stephanie L.

description: We got lucky and there was a table available for two in this small but home-y restaurant on Irving. We ordered the miso ramen which was pretty good but not great. We also got the salmon nigiri (price is for two pieces) and that was delicious!! The Las Vegas roll was delicious as well. The calamari may be tempting being only $4.95 but it's not a lot and not really good to be honest. But overall the food was good and the customer service was great!
author: Michelle T.

description:
It was open when we were there.
Spicy Garlic Miso Ramen was not really rock my socks off.
There was no wow factor.
The Karaaga was gistal and found many inedible tissue in the chicken meat.
I was thinking giving 3 stars. 
But,.....
They stared to move the chairs on the table up side down while we were having the ramen. 
What does the mean? Is it "Hurry-Up and leave" sign?
WTF?
I did not like what was going on.
I was still eating drinking my beer try to finish as zoos as I can.
Couldn't you wait?
Do you think it's OK to put chair up side down right next to the customer's table who still having food?
I was pissed.
1 star, and I won't be back here again.
G2H.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I went here for dinner. I waited for almost and hour but it was worth the wait. I ordered the regular Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen with an egg. It was pretty spicy for me. I ended up drinking a lot of tea. The noodles were great. They were firm and had a nice chew to them. The broth was very good and had great flavor. The egg was cooked perfectly with it being a little runny on the inside. 

The service was great. My tea cup was never empty. This place can get very crowded and the wait can be very long.
author: Alexander L.

description:
Saiwaii has a relatively good selection of ramen (including one with chicken broth, which is helpful for non-pork eaters). It makes for a decent late night snack, and they have a few other nice side options. 

Unfortunately, the food is mediocre and the service can be pretty terrible. When we tried to ask a question about taking an ingredient out, the server didn't bother listening to the actual question and just cut us off, then proceeded to cut us off again. It wasn't a busy, so there was no rush to quiet us. Unfortunate indeed...
author: P. S.

description: Good spot for an early lunch on the weekend. I've gotten both the tonkatsu ramen (spicy) and seafood ramen (both spicy and not spicy). The broth is super flavorful in all three. The sunomono with tako and mini tekka don are good starters if you're extra hungry. Service is usually pretty quick, but there has been a wait a few times after noon and the staff is super nice. The music is always on point.
author: Todd H.

description:
Saiwaii Ramen produces the whitest, cleanest tonkotsu I have ever had the pleasure of trying. Very delicate, unlike the many other fatty renditions I have tried. 

I may have not noticed, but I wish there was an option to add some kotteri as this tonkotsu lacks the fatty richness one usually encounters. This can be a pro or a con depending on your taste buds. 

Saiwaii bowls seemed to be a bit smaller than other places, considering I actually finished the entire bowl, plus a basic roll, and an unagi don. Curly noodles are served here, which I found to have a good texture. 

High quality is the M.O. here. 

The miso ramen was extremely delicate and floral - almost ladylike. I would definitely have to say this bowl needed more flavor, more depth. 

Next visit we will be sure to try the specialty spicy garlic ramen bowls, as those seem to be the crowd-pleasers.

Service is prompt. Dining area clean. 

Will definitely be back shortly....
author: Aren A.

description:
I was looking for a new ramen place to try out and me and my mom came across this cute little place. 

She got the chicken teriyaki with California rolls and I got the shio ramen. 

The California roll was okay nothing exceptional. The mi so soup was pretty good. Was the perfect balance not to salty but just right and full of flavor. The teriyaki was good too, again, nothing exceptional. 

The shio ramen though was amazing!! A nice big hot portion of noodles and broth.  The broth was full of flavor and not heavy or to salty. The noodles were the perfect amount of chewy and had great flavor. I ordered an egg and pork belly but was disappointed with the pork belly. It was all fat. I mean I know it's pork belly so I was expecting some fat but there was only a tiny tiny bit of meat. They gave a good portion 4 big cubes but essentially not edible unless u like a mouth full of fat. So there went 3.50 down the drain. But other then that the ramen was really good and filling. 

The service was good too. The lady that helped us explained the different types of broth and was patient with us. 

Overall was a good experience.
author: Xtina C.

description:
Sushi...just ok nothing special. We tried the house sushi.

The ramen....we had the garlic tonkatsu and garlic miso. One vote each on the soup base so it ends up being a tie. 

I judge ramen by the broth and the ramen.  Here, the ramen was not as Al dente as it should be.  A solid 3 star bordering on 4 so I gave the generous vote this time
author: Will I A m.

description:
There was already a wait list before 6PM on a Sunday night.  People eat fast, servers are at their top speed, but still, it is quite torturous watching the happy diners slurping on their noodles while you wait and you wait.  

Once we ordered, everything came fast.  Shoyu ramen had a good flavor and the ramen itself was nice and chewy too. The addition of the egg and the extra bowl of unagi don was perfect.  

Every neighborhood needs a little ramen shop like this.
author: Candice B.

description:
Seafood ramen mild was delicious. I really like the broth. Seafood quality could be better. One of my mussel shells was empty without any meat (not floating around in broth either) and my one shrimp seemed old. 

Broth nice!
Seafood quality, soso.
Overall still yummy and would go back for the ramen!
author: Audrey L.

description:
One of the few places near me that serves (good) vegetarian ramen. There's only one option, but I add different sides every time we go. Service is also good- not that you need a lot when you are simply ordering ramen, but all the staff is always friendly.

The only thing I don't like are the glasses they serve their water in (which is kind of picky and weird, I know). Kind of reminds me of cups from a divey mom and pop diner... so I order sake instead.
author: Danielle L.

description:
One of the best ramen restaurants I've been to. I've been to a few, but this one takes the cake! The spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen was AMAZINGGGG. I can hear the bells ringing and the choir singing Hallelujah again! Ok, so perhaps I'm over exaggerating, but hey when you're in a city like SF, where it's cold and rains half the time, hot soup will be the first thing that comes to mind. That, and a hot shower. 

Getting back to the point, the soup was surprisingly not too salty, which was what I loved most about it. The broth at other ramen places I've been to have been too salty for my liking. Plus, I'm a huge garlic fan, so that's another thumbs up from me! 

The service could use some work though. Nevertheless, I'll definitely be back again!
author: Zandra T.

description:
Spicy garlic tonkatsu! 
Pork belly is a must! 

Pricey for a bowl of ramen but this is the best ramen I have ever tried in SF!
I always get chicken karage for appetizer.
The place is always packed! 
Its a small space so expect to wait a little! 
This is bomb.com!
author: Sandy W.

description:
Not bad, not fantastic either. A decent place to have dinner.

The servers always seem overworked and in a rush to go from one place to another - it's hard to get their attention sometimes.

* Chicken karaage - 3 stars
Solid, not bad, not the best I've had either.

* Tempura shrimp & veggies - 3.5 stars
A nice soft breading. Can't go wrong w/ tempura anything.

* Chicken hearts - 1 star
Overcooked, no flavor - I normally love chicken hearts and this tasted pretty terrible.

* Spicy garlic tonkotsu - 3.5 stars
Not bad. Their noodles were solid, the meat fine.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I wasn't expecting much from this place as my girlfriend said the ramen was meh the last time she was here. But I was definitely pleasantly surprised. I got the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen extra spicy. The ramen broth itself is quite delicious and definitely on the spicy side. The ramen noodles and toppings were exactly what you would expect from a typical ramen parlor.

However, my two complaints (and thus the 4 star review): the pork chashu was chewy and dry so it very much undermined the experience, and there is no egg by default in the ramen which is pretty essential imo.

But all in all its pretty worth the price and would definitely visit again. It's one of the better ramen places in the outer sunset.
author: Jinyan C.

description: Phenomenal ramen and beautiful selection of sushi and other goodies :) Go here for sure!
author: Luke B.

description:
I've come back again and again, and I am here to write a review....again. I've been to Sawaii and quite a bit recently, and whether that speaks to my tendency to eat dinner close to home, or to my growing love for this place, I highly recommend you try it out. 

Sawaii seems to have picked up popularity recently. On a Friday or weekend night you can expect to scribble your name on the whiteboard wait list, and proceed to keenly stare down the diners happily grubbing on ramen on your future table. The harder you stare, the faster the table becomes yours. It's a proven restaurant goer fact. It's worth the wait -- the food is all kinds of awesome. It's hot, savory, flavorful, consistent, unique and exciting. If we're talking ramen, this has become my go-to ramen feeding nest. The tonkatsu and miso persuasions are a sure-fire way to soupy bliss, add an egg and drizzle chili oil on there for added gastro-success.  

For you investigators who prefer a concise list to an oozing paragraph, feast your eyes:

Items that are not to miss: 

- Tonkatsu or miso ramen 
- Mango Tango roll 
- Gyoza (the sauce is practically drinkable). 
- 49er roll (those lemon slices....) 
- Paradise roll (The PILE of delicious fried onion bits on top is practically genius). 
- Salmon skin salad 

I'm salivating all over my keyboard so maybe it's best that you just head over and give it a try. More than 4 people may present you with seating issues, but seating any party below that number will be smooth as them noodles.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
Quality of the food nosedived in our last visit.

I had the seafood ramen and my wife had the tonkatsu ramen.

My seafood ramen was infused with MSG. I was very surprised by this as we'd eaten here many times before and never had they put MSG in any of our ramens.

My wife's tonkatsu ramen also lacked umami. It tasted nothing like it did on our many previous visits. It was thin and flavorless. 

Both our ramens also came without the usual garnishments.

Change in ownership? New cook?

We will probably try them one more time in hopes that we didn't just lose our favorite ramen shop.
author: Gene G.

description:
Food is AMAZING. My favorite is their spicy tonkatsu ramen, with the addition of their pork belly. DROOL. There are a plentiful variety of other scrumptious morsels in the ramen aside from meat; I especially like their bamboo shoots.

I like coming in for lunch for their lunch special: ramen and sushi! As well as better service.

-1 has to be for slow service during dinner.  Took forever and a day to flag down our waiter to get the bill, another to flag ger to pick it up, and another for her to return our card.  It probably took us longer to pay our bill then it was for us to actually eat.
author: Monica V.

description:
omg. I LOVE this place!!!!!!!!!!!!

Spicy Garlic Miso. EXCELLENT!!! I'll upload the pic later, and when you see it, you'll be like "DAMN THAT LOOKS BOMB" ...and it is.

Updated (Here's the pic!): http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ld3VCmkwbS1Qnd4xA6Mw_g/l.jpg

My friend got the Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen. I tasted it and it was very spicy, very different texture in the soup.  All depends what you like. I personally love miso and this bowl was perfect. If I come again and it's still good then I might change it to 5 stars ;) 

One of the top ramen places I love to eat at in the Bay! Anyone giving less than 4 stars, you suck!!!
author: Raquel Y.

description:
Working and living in the sunset can be overwhelming; especially on irving.

Walking out of my office, my train of thought runs like so: thai? Pho? Chinese? More Chinese? Walgreens hot pocket? Tacos? 
Sometimes, too many options can be a headache. Today was one of those days.

The first time I dined at Saiwaii I had a miso ramen. Healthy serving, great broth, noodles were wonderful and service was impeccable. 
Although good, I wasn't wow'd and at $10 post tip seemed like a hefty price to pay on lunch.
Today, while poking through my yelp app I read a tip about the "pork belly ramen that melts in your mouth". I am not sure who posted it, but I owe you a beer.

The concept is simple. Take two of my favorite things (tender pork belly and ramen) throw them in a large bowl and you have a happy Ryan.
The pork belly, as other have mentioned, were HUGE and literally fall apart in your mouth after first bite; this, my friends, is sex in soup form.
I sat next to the window, looking out on to irving, wondering where this has been all my life. It was a moment.

I have only had two items on the menu and this last time warranted a review, that's how amazing it was.
While looking around, portions look large for appetizers and sushi looked good.
Also, service was friendly and attentive.

But, for gods sake, PORK BELLY RAMEN.
author: Ryan L.

description: I came here for ramen about 3 times now and each time, it gets a little less impressive. I've ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu and the regular tonkatsu. Broth was too salty in my opinion and overall taste wasn't great. The first time I came in, I thought the ramen was quite decent. The second time my friend I came for dinner and I didn't want ramen and decided to get sushi, but the sushi chef was out for the night! So I had to settle for a bowl of ramen and I remember not finishing my bowl because of the saltiness. The last time, I was with a hungry friend so we came to Saiwaii. She ordered a tonkatsu ramen and I just had a small appetizer, the agedashi tofu. All in all, everything was just alright.
author: Christina C.

description: With so many good ramen shops in the neighborhood this place doesn't hold up. The broth was bland. The noodles not soft enough. Service was terrible.
author: John N.

description: Love this place! The ramen here is delicious! There's only a couple of places in San Francisco that has good ramen and this is definitely one of them! The spicy tonkatsu is my favorite! A must try!
author: Grace T.

description:
Cold foggy SF days are when you find me here cuddling with my hot delicious ramen in Saiwaii. Coming from SoCal, I rarely ate ramen, because weather down there is too hot to bear anymore hotness entering my body. But it's so fit up in NorCal. I always went to teaway overlooking this tiny dark restaurant hearing rumors about it's expensive dishes. However, I gained some courage to enter one rainy day and experienced the best ramen on Irving. Tucked in between a barber shop and the famous Teaway, Saiwaii was one of those hidden gems. The waiters were EXTREMELY friendly, professional, and welcoming. I remember my first time there and I was a noob not knowing what was good there. The waitress recommended Tonkatsu Ramen, and I hesitated fearing that it would not taste good. HOW WRONG WAS I?!! 

Tonkatsu Ramen (about $7.75): 5 stars. The broth was so fresh and milky in a way that sooth every freezing taste bud on my tongue and warmed up my entire shivering body. They only had 2 slices of pork, which was a shame because they tasted delicious. The soup was filled with saffron, seaweed, and some other veggies. It was definitely delicious. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/saiwaii-ramen-san-francisco-3?select=LRcl5ye1fe2WHCGmpK_MwA
Chicken Katsu: 4 stars. The chicken was very succulent and meshed well with the egg it was fried in. I definitely liked this a lot. It came with rice.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/saiwaii-ramen-san-francisco-3?userid=sd4E5iKUZotDEeiF3cC81Q#CUDT2infN1wBNux142LitA
Chicken Curry: 4 stars. The chicken was also juicy and the curry was very flavorful.It came with rice as well. 

Overall, it wasnt as expensive as rumors spread that it was. It was a very decent price and the quality was definitely on point.
author: Chena N.

description:
I stumbled upon this place after a ramen run at the sunset area. At a glanced from outside to the inside, it looked like a cute little ramen place and that's why my group of friends and I decided to check this place out - after we stood outside the cold and yelped it, of course! 

FOOD:

Here is what we had:

(1) Kobe beef salad: I was excited to see that there was Kobe beef! I've been having day-dreams of Kobe beef for the longest time. Yup, I ordered it and I thought it was okay. The kobe beef salad was $4.95 and it was my fault for expecting too much from it...but, by the price, one shouldn't expect to get high quality kobe beef. For what's it's worth, I give it a 4 stars. The minus one is for the salad dressing - we only got a drop of salad dress :( Maybe it's because it was the end of the night and it's closing time.

(2) Pork belly ramen: first thing I noticed was the shimmer of fat. Delicious! My friend ordered this and with one slip - the tingy tasty broth melted on my tongue. It came with some tempura shrimp and it was the best part! Crunchy tempura and dip it in fatty ramen soup! YUM! 5 stars.

(3) Spicy garlic pork ramen: So, I had this dish, but I preferred the pork belly ramen more. Had some bamboo, sea weed, pieces of pork, it was just a touch of spicy-ness, a touch of garlicy taste, and it's a 4 stars! YUM!

SERVICE: We had a cute little girl serving us- she was cool, asked how we were doing and if we needed more stuff. Plus, she came back and forth to pour me water and asked if my dish was okay - now, that's good service! 5 stars.

**OVERALL: Pork belly ramen - crunchy tempura and dip it in fatty ramen soup! 4 stars for overall!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
Not bad for a ramen and sushi place. Pretty good selection on the sushi rolls and appetizers. The ramen was good and the broth was flavorful, but since I'm not a huge fan of ramen, it didn't really appeal to me. 

Avo Loco- on the menu it says "crab, tuna, avocado, mango". I thought this was going to be a sushi roll, but it came out... as a ball.. it looked like a ball of rice with avocado on top. The presentation was gorgeous and it actually tasted pretty good. It's almost like a sushi, but you just got to break it apart in pieces and eat it. So it looks like a rice ball with tuna and crab filling inside. What bugged me about the crab was that there was still pieces of shell in there. The mango wasn't too sweet either, but the avocado was delicious. 

Overall: Not a bad restaurant for quick ramen and sushi. Not my first choice that I'd pick for Japanese, but overall not bad.
author: Carmen C.

description: The spicy garlic tonakatsu is delicious and abundantly flavored with garlic. Spicy chicken wings appetizer is also packed with flavor and go well with the scallions they sprinkle on top. Prices are fair and the quality is excellent. Service is prompt and friendly.
author: Briget P.

description:
The lunch specials dominate here. Just $9.50 for a bowl of steaming savory ramen plus sushi? 

And the food is GOOD, too. Certainly not the best ramen or sushi I've had, but one of the better options in the area.

I ordered the pork ramen, which was rich, not too salty or fatty, and full of succulent pieces of meat, bamboo and veggies. It didn't, however, come with a perfectly cooked egg, which was a disappointment (I consider this a standard ingredient for ramen). Still loved it though. My spicy tuna roll with avocado was pretty yum as well.

I've tried the spicy mala ramen here, too, which is hot hot hot and decked out with pieces of fried chicken (as well as that perfectly cooked egg I mentioned earlier)! Great if you're in the mood for something unhealthy, but will end up making you feel greasy/sick if you're not.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Tip: Definitely stick with the Spicy Tonkotsu if you are going here. I wanted to branch out and try more (since I know I will keep coming back despite better ramen places in the area... because it's 3 blocks from my house) so I got the Spicy Miso with extra Chasu, corn and spinach. 

Pros: The egg was cooked perfectly. 
Con's: The chasu was way overcooked, not very flavorful and too fatty. 
            The broth was not as good as their Tonkotsu. It just wasn't very flavorful. 

Despite it being beautifully presented - I ended up leaving half a bowl behind (never happens). 

I will return but will come back for my old faithful Tonkotsu.
author: Jessie L.

description:
This place is my "go to" ramen spot.

Appetizers: I've gotten the calamari here and its very good though its a small portion (understandable since its only $4.95)

Ramen: I used to always get the spicy garlic tonkatsu but then I stopped because first of all, it costs an extra $2 (yes i'm an asian and i'm cheap) from the regular tonkatsu. I feel like an extra $2 for spicy broth and some garlic flakes is too much. Also the spiciness is not consistent. For example, one day I ordered it "hot" and it came out medium. Another day I ordered it mild and it came out "hot"... WTF. And when i say "hot", I mean its really damn hot. I'm half brown and this $hit is still too much for me to handle

Now I just get the regular tonkatsu ramen for $7.95 and add a little bit of chili oil and spicy powder (on the tables) and i'm a happy camper. Note that this by no means makes it taste like the spicy garlic tonkatsu (they make a different broth for this than the reg. tonkatsu) but at least this way its consistent.
author: Sheena N.

description:
Love the ramen, hate the wait.  
Spicy tonkatsu ramen is oh so worth it though. Extra pork belly is plenty..happy buddha belly!
author: Jango L.

description:
Saiwaii has become my go to restaurant for when I don't know what to eat.

The spicy garlic tonkotsu is perfect for when you're craving ramen, something spicy or something warm. The flavor is perfect for a cold day when you want something to warm you up. The menu has more than just ramen, including donburis and sushi. I usually order a small TenDon with my spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen.
author: Mabel Y.

description: I've been here a few times. I don't really like the appetizers here, but go for it if you want. The wait could get crazy...the Ramen always satisfies my cravings and I'll always be back if I'm around the area. The service is pretty good.
author: Maggie W.

description:
Update: A kind Yelper let me know that the Spicy Garlic "Tonkotsu" referred to a pork broth and was not to be confused with "Tonkatsu," fried breaded pork cutlet, which I was so eagerly expecting to see when I ordered the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu. Silly me!

I think I'd still give Sawaii a 3. I mean, who doesn't want both the pork broth and fried pork cutlet in their ramen? ;)
author: Vivian W.

description:
Very good for the price!  The extras will eat away at the value but I just have to have the egg for another buck!  Great deal on the 4 buck donburi if you think that one bowl of ramen isn't enough.
This is good enough to save me a trip to the San Mateo Ramen.

Curtis
author: Curtis L.

description: Great traditional Japanese ramen.  Egg is cooked to perfection but you have to order it with additional charges.  Love the mom and pop ambiance and the server was very sweet!  We chose to check out this place for an anniversary date and it did not disappoint!  We also tried some appetizers.  Calamari rings were quite nice although I've tasted better.  Great seasoning and crunch, though.  And we tried bacon mochi.  It was odd for me but my boyfriend liked it so it depends on your taste.  He does tend be less picky than I am when it comes to food.  Overall, would definitely come again!
author: Quyne V.

description:
I am picky about ramen.  My favorite is still Santa ramen in San Mateo.  With that said, I enjoyed my meal.  I had the regular tonkotsu ramen.  

Excellent flavor with ton of goodies in it.  The only thing that keeps me from giving it five stars is its a bit salty.  I asked for hot water to cut it down a bit.  Otherwise very yummy.  Noodles were perfectly textured - chewy but not mushy.  

I also got a green salad- huge.  My hubby got the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen and he liked it too.
author: Lei H.

description: Amazing spicy garlic ramen!! If you enjoy fire in your mouth, go for it... Egg was perfectly cooked! This is now going to be my go-to ramen in the city!
author: Navdeep R.

description:
This place is so very tasty and AMAZING! 
I reside in the Mission and make a concerted effort to visit Saiwaii at least twice a month! (Near the N-MUNI Line stop). 

The ramen is always properly chewy and properly curly. ;.)
The broth is definitely always on point. 
The wait can be looooong and it's a family restaurant with wide screen televisions with intense colours on all the time. Families bring their small children, so, it can be very very very nosy.
The wait staff is always busy and efficient. 
I highly recommend you review the menu before you are seated in order to place one's order quickly. 

The ramen at Sawaii is far better than any ramen place I have ever visited in Japantown.
The spicy ramen is sufficiently spicy to give me pause (which means they are doing it right!).
Also, the ramen presentation is always so lovely aesthetically, well balanced, and composed gracefully. I have not seen that too often at the other ramen places I have visited in SF.
author: Gabriel D.

description: I've been coming to Saiwaii for a few years now.  Typically, it is my go-to for spicy Japanese ramen.  My experiences in past have been good.  Unfortunately, a recent visit from proved overly frustrating.  Ordered out ramen as usually and delivery and taste on par.  However, I had a very hungry child and we had ordered some appetizers that didn't show for about 20 mins after we finished our ramen.  They kept telling us it was coming, but something in the kitchen wasn't producing.  Wouldn't have worried about it had they simply said they couldn't make it.  They didn't offer any discounts either.  No tip for this now past customer.
author: Philip B.

description: Sushi was dry and bland. I ordered spicy tuna roll and it was regrettable. The tuna was not fresh. As for the ramen, it was okay. I ordered the very spicy tonkotsu ramen and my boyfriend ordered the spicy miso ramen. They both tasted pretty okay. I've tasted better ones in Japantown and in LA's Little Tokyo. I would probably come back if I had nowhere else to try.
author: Michelle K.

description:
For all you spicy food lovers, Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen is for you! 

I don't usually order anything else here, so I can't speak much about anything else they have. But, I've been here a few times now and service is very consistent; no complaints here.

Cold or rainy day? Hot pot or shabu line too long? Well, the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen will keep you warm too!
author: Erica L.

description:
I'm such a fan. Homestyle ramen. I'm a ramen geek myself, but sometimes you just need a break from taking food too seriously. :)

Unpretentious, friendly staff, clean environment, kid friendly, fast service, no frills, and great prices! The spicy tonkatsu garlic ramen hits the spot during the infamously foggy sunset weather. It's a pretty small place, so it literally fills up quickly. It closes for a couple hours between lunch and dinner service.

Passable egg preparation-- at least it didn't come out hard-boiled. Skip the tempura don-- barely crispy and the batter didn't cook all the way through. Ick.

Parking is only mildly nightmarish. Patience, grasshopper.
Vegetarian friendly.
author: Vanessa D.

description:
Can't believe I never been to this place and I live so close. Gave it a first try today with my BFF and we loved it! The spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen was very flavor-able, with regular spicy that was just about the right amount to get your tongue excited. We also tried sawaii roll, not amazing but ok. Beef tongue was so good, tender and well cooked with the right sauce. Hamachi belly was a good try too! 
We liked it and we will visit back!
author: Amie Z.

description:
After a productive side project work session at Tea Way, my girlfriend and I needed some much needed dinner. We weren't looking for anything too heavy or expensive and spotted this cute little ramen place a few doors down. We hadn't had ramen since leaving SD so we decided to give it a shot.

I got the regular shoyu ramen which came with a few slices of pork and bamboo shoots. Noticeably missing was the egg however! The soup was a bit over salty for me but the ramen was nice and chewy. Add-ons significant kick the price into the expensive territory so it's best to select only the essentials unless you want to splurge on their famous pork belly cubes. Otherwise it was a-ok for me.

Service was decent but the restaurant is dimly lit making it hard to spot from the street unless you're just walking by as we were. I thought the stuff we left behind in Socal was a little bit better though but Saiwaii wasn't too bad in a pinch. It's consistently busy so they must be doing something right!

Food: 7/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description: Love their Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen. This paticular bowl is my favoriate ramen in the city.
author: Paul K.

description: Ramen is not bad here. I do wish the broth were more flavorful and there were more meat in my tonkatsu ramen. The mini eel donburi is literally mini-- it comes in a tiny bowl with a small scoop of rice and two pieces of eel... Fortunately, the staff is very friendly and welcome you with a "moshi moshi" the moment you want in the door.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Yum. Ate here for lunch on a Saturday with my boyfriend. There was no wait but the restaurant was almost filled. Good service here. They were constantly refilling our tea and water without us having to ask! (Tea is complimentary). 

Spider roll: So delicious, the rice was still hot as we ate it. Came in 5 pieces. 

Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu (mild): We both got this and wow the broth is amazing! Just the right amount of garlic and pork flavor. There were chunks of fried garlic in the soup which I loved! I wasn't a fan of the noodles though because they didn't have that chewy and springy texture that I like in ramen noodles but the broth made it so delicious to eat that I didn't mind too much. I added in corn for $1. 

Overall I definitely would eat here again!
author: Audrey C.

description:
I ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu (mild). It was very delicious! It wasnt at all mildly spicey...perhaps i should jave gotten it at least medium spicey! It seems ordering it mild means adding some red coloring to it haha.

I also had some hot house sake to go with it!
author: Tu-Anh N.

description: Please keep in mind that ton"katsu" is pork cutlet breaded and fried and ton"kotsu" is pig's head soup. So many reviewers make it sound like their ramen had a pork cutlet in it.
author: tomohisa w.

description:
RAMEN? yes please!

but first lets have some of the yummy appetizers! they have an awesome list! i was interested in trying the Hamachi Collar but since i was too  hungry to wait, i opted for the Hamachi Belly instead :) We also had the Ankimo (mungfish liver) which is also a favorite. rich flavors that tease your taste buds- waking them up!

now for the main menu. RAMEN! spicy garlic tonkatsu comes with cha shu (thin sliced pork) but i was particularly hungry when i went so i went for a little extra love in the bowl and asked for some pork belly! yup i said. PORK BELLY!

-YUMMY in my TUMMY! the spicy garlic broth was bold and robust and it was just what i was craving for. it packed a punch- a nice good morning to start my day. the noodles could have been a little better. they were okay... but the piece that really made the bowl was the little extra love i requested. PORK BELLY! just reading those two words sends me back to earlier today to when i had my first bite of that taste explosion! SAVORY goodness- melting your heart. :)

given it's location parking was a little tough. i didn't mind the wait it was expected. seeing women breast feeding children who were old enough to talk was a little disturbing. they were also a little messy and so clean up after them took a little extra time... 

the food is so good however that i know i will surely be coming back.

until next time

cheers!
author: Jerico P.

description: Really great food for a fairly reasonable price. We were seated quickly and received our food quickly. I ordered the lion king roll with a crunchy roll. They were both bomb. Would definitely come here again.
author: Selena D.

description:
This was an interesting place. It's been open in my neighborhood for quite some time. I finally decided to try it. 

It was interesting because (I could be wrong) the owner(s) were Chinese. Sushi chef, Chinese. Waitress, Japanese and cooks, Hispanic. What an interesting mix. Considering we were in the middle of little Chinatown of the Sunset district, I was surprise to see the diversity of customers. 

As for the lunch special I had ordered, nothing unusual about it. I ordered a simple shoyu ramen with California roll. The ramen tasted pretty good but there was something about the California roll and I couldn't pin point what's wrong with it. It may have had a slightly fishy smell to it. Nonetheless, I ate it and I did not feel all that great that night. I can't be certain it was from the California Roll but I couldn't think of anything else I ate that would make me suspicious. 

Overall this place wasn't bad. I'd go back to try other stuff but my rule of thumb is never to try sushi or raw stuff unless a Japanese chef made it.
author: Jane A.

description:
I had the best ramen in the bay area here! My hunt for a great ramen place is over! I tried the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen. And the best decision I made: adding pork belly to it! The pork belly was melt in your mouth, and it had such great flavor! The noodles were perfectly chewy, and the soft boiled egg was the best I've had in the city. The broth was really delicious, too! But there were charred bits of garlic in it that made some bites more bitter than others. 

For my appetizer, I tried the bacon wrapped mochi. It literally looked like bacon wrapped around a roasted marshmallow. Unfortunately, the mochi tasted burnt. 

The service was good. The workers were friendly.
author: Rachel H.

description: The waiting line for this place is ridiculous sometimes but when I finally get my seat and my food... I have no regrets. From their chicken ramen to tonkatsu, to their rolls and apps it really does not disappoint. The ramen is never overcooked or undrrcooked.. you'd be surprised at some I've encountered. They usually have some good specials and be sure to look around at the walls
author: Nikole D.

description:
Not your traditional ramen at all, but super delicious. I'm a huge fan of the fusion style and their spicy garlic is amazingly flavorful and creamy. Even when I'm stuffed, it's hard to not polish off the broth. I wish the meat quality was more reliable though, sometimes it's great sometimes it's tough, which is why I knocked off the one star because, for moderately priced ramen, I'd like it to be amazing every time.

While they do get pretty busy for dinner and hangover recovery mornings, the staff is usually pretty nice and once they even put my name on the list when I called in to ask about the wait. The service is not its best when they're busy and you will have to flag them down for anything you want.
author: Christina R.

description:
Not bad....sa-i-wa-ii...i dont even know how to pronounce your name

This is my third time here....imma just review on their new ramen...the Mala Ramen..WHOOOO!

I believe this is one of their newer menu items...along with 2 or so more new dishes

I order the Mala Ramen EXTRA SPICY....i like how they let me choose my level of spice level

The Mala Ramen comes with karage chicken, chasu pork, spinach, nori and egg of course...a bit overkill on the karage chicken.  I mean I love karage but not IN my soup cuz its gets soggy but nonetheless, it was good.

Imma get into the other things first before the broth...as the broth is VERY important. 
-Sauteed Spinach - yum...garlicky
-Chasu pork - there was more fat than meat...like literally a whole piece of fat with a .5mm lead pencil size of meat
-egg - i dont eat you
-karage chicken - peppery and hot, crunchy when not soaked in my broth but its a nice touch to be able to dip in my broth to have more flavor
-ramen - a bit firmer than my liking but not bad...a nice chew if you may

Now for the broth....that delicious spicy...red...sizzling hot broth...i almost just drool thinking about it....
I believe it is a either a tonkatsu based or chicken broth based with mala seasoning...but it doesnt have the tingling that mala flavor usually leaves behind.  It is spicy but not deathly...its might be a bit salty for some but i like it that way.  It definitely isn't AS much as some other broth i had before but the flavors are there

I want a bowl right now...does that tell you anything?
author: Laurie W.

description: 8pm Friday night. 15 min wait for a table of 3. Quick service. Yummy. Ramen AND sushi?! Yes, pls. Great first experience. We tried the Alaskan roll (California topped w salmon and lemon slices -- one my sushi roll faves), spicy garlic miso ramen (regular spicy was perfect), butterfish nigiri (so good we added the butterfish sashimi appetizer), goma ae (good but a little too heavy on the sauce so it was sweeter than I prefer). Definitely has the potential to become one of our regular spots.
author: Angela W.

description:
I'm honestly surprised that this place even gets five star reviews.
Saiwaii Ramen is extremely mediocre. I've been three times and each time it seems like the place gets worse. The only reason why I even went back was because I had forgotten what it even tasted like. Let's keep it simple:
-Flavorless broth. I ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu, EXTRA spicy. When I got it, BARELY even any spice. Hot cheetos are more spicy than my bowl of ramen was. 
-Doesn't smell or taste fresh. The cha shiu, menma, seaweed, etc, my goodness, all of it had a weird smell and sort of a sour aftertaste. Makes me think they werent fresh at all. 
There are pros though:
-Service is pretty friendly here and there's almost never any wait (considering this place, that's probably a bad sign).
author: S Z.

description: love, love, love!  what more can i say?!  i feel super blessed that this gem of a place is in my neighborhood!  i have since introduced this place to family and friends and will continue to do so because of the warm, inviting folks who work here and of course the yummo-to-the max food!  i love the garlic tonkatsu ramen and the panda roll!  jenny, the owner, and the folks she hires really knows how to provide best-in-class service!  thank you all for blessing me with your culinary delights!  blessings, yan
author: Yan K.

description: Only came here for take out but as other reviewers noted, the spicy garlic tonkotsu is amazing! I added a boiled egg. Perfect portion for a filling meal!
author: Jessica R.

description: Quick stop since we were really hungry and ramen seems to be the perfect place  right in the middle of many, many Chinese restaurants. I ordered the Tonkatsu, with the pork-flavored broth with extra pork belly. To my surprise the broth and ramen were perfectly cooked, and I tend to be very very critical on ramen. I could have lived without the pork belly as it didn't add to the dish. And yes, I will add this place to a decent ramen shop to come back again and agin.
author: Thuy V.

description:
We've come to rely in Sawaii as a neighborhood favorite. Their lunch specials are great (weekdays only). On the sushi side, the fish is really fresh. On the ramen side the spicy tonkatsu comes with quite a few slices of pork belly and a few extras...I usually have them add extra spinach, there are many other options for add-ons.

Seems to be a favorite with families, there are often young kids there enjoying the freedom to slurp without getting scolded. Prices are reasonable. Avoid "peak hours" if you don't want to wait - early or late lunch, same for dinner - but beware they close between about 3pm - 5pm. 

Friendly staff, too.Only docking a star b/c they serve beer but no wine. I like wine!
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
I decided to follow Yelp's recommendations after a dental appointment, so I ended up here for lunch. I had a bit of a hankering for ramen.

This place wasn't busy on Saturday. The waitresses here are nice; this was the first time I had lunch here, so they helped me out with the menu.

I ultimately got the tonkatsu ramen with an egg. It's pretty good for the price, I think (around $9), but I'm not a ramen connoisseur. The broth is a bit too salty, but otherwise very good. I initially complained about the seemingly paltry 2 slices of pork, but the ramen ultimately ended up being quite filling.

My verdict? I like this place, and I think I'll come back.
author: Daniel G.

description:
We've been dying to check out this new ramen place for awhile & finally got around to it last week on a very cold night.  We came in on Thursday night after 6ish & the place was already almost completely packed...but first thing I noticed was that it's fairly small.  

We shared the Agedashi Tofu and he ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen while I ordered the Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen.  The agedashi tofu was alright, but they did give us five pieces which I thought was generous.  Though I didn't specify which level of spiciness I wanted, it was spicy not extra spicy though thankfully.  The broth had heat and garlic..yum!  However, it was a little watery.  My ramen also included ground pork alongside with the three pieces of pork.  Ramen includes mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and green onions as well.  He said the pork tasted different to him than what he's used to and that the broth could have used more flavor.  He wants the garlic broth next time!  Oh, and we both appreciated how they don't put MSG in their food.  So, the only reason why I drank a lot of water was due to the spicy broth, not extreme saltiness.  Thanks Saiwaii!  

Overall it was just okay.  We weren't turned off, but we weren't impressed.  The waitress was by herself for awhile until another one came to her rescue when we got our ramen.  Service was friendly & attentive.  We would be open to trying another bowl of ramen to warm us up at Saiwaii.
author: Cat C.

description: Good stuff......really good stuff!!!!  Spicy garlic tonkotsu for me, Miso Ramen for the wife, Chicken Ramen for my daughter.  Everything was good.  Wish I lived closer.
author: Luke D.

description:
I came here with in a party of 4 on a Saturday evening for dinner. We had called earlier that day to try to get a reservation but were told that the earliest time available was 7:30pm. We decided to try our luck with a walk in and ended up getting there at 5:40pm and only waiting 20 minutes :) 

The staff was super swamped that evening but they were still super friendly! I got the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen with an extra egg. I got it mild spicy but the soup is really creamy, it is definitely not as spicy as it looks! Egg was also good, I loved the texture of the egg white, the egg yolk was a bit more on the solid side since it was cut in half in the soup. Loved the bamboo and the pork in the noodles as well. All in all, a delicious bowl of ramen!
author: Sophie Y.

description:
Getting closer to finding that magical bowl of ramen in the city.

I have been having difficulty in locating a ramen shop that is worth raving about or at least mentioning to out-of-town visitors. The Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen here gives me hope that I should not give up just yet.

The char-shu, noodles, and broth made me want to do a happy baby pose right on the table. I came from a yoga class earlier that day and had been envisioning a sooth, rich broth as means of finding my zen during practice today. Thank you universal beings for blending interpretive thoughts with reality. Next class I will channel Perigord Truffles on everything edible!

So the ramen..... great, awesome, delicious! Just the right amount of garlic and the default is "regular" spicy but for people like me who don't enjoy too much spice, I would have opted for the mild (Mild--Regular--Extra Spicy)

Go to the Sunset and try it!..... It really is not that far.
author: Ryan E.

description: I've had better ramen . I was really excited to try this place because I heard great reviews and food looked bomb, but I was so terribly wrong. First our waiter was so rude, we didn't really understand the ordering part for the ramen, so we asked our questions and she was super rude and wouldn't explain anything. The food wasn't so great, which was a disappointment and the chicken was raw and bloody and when I told her she argued with me that it was cook, like "lady its raw and bloody can you not see?!"
author: Maylene M.

description:
More like 4.5 stars but they deserve the round up. Going into Saiwaii, I had anticipated to try their ramen; little did I know, they also offer an extensive list of sushi rolls as well. My boyfriend and I ordered the spicy garlic ramens as well as the Sakura roll. We missed eating butterfish since our trip to Hawaii recently, and Sawaii surprisingly has many rolls with butterfish in it. As seen in my photo, the Sakura roll was beautifully made and presented. The cucumber wrap was a nice, clean-tasting crunch, and alongside three types of fresh fish, the ingredients in the roll spoke for themselves: it was absolutely delicious!  

I had the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen in regular spicy and it was deceivingly packed with heat! This bowl had just the right amount of al dente noodles and toppings, which included minced pork, fatty cha shu, green onions, black mushrooms and bamboo shoots. All of the toppings complimented the ramen and broth superbly. Typically, I don't drink a whole lot of my broth when I eat noodle soups, but even though it was quite spicy, I still slurped much of it down since it was so flavorful. 

I'm no ramen connoisseur, but I've tried several places in SF for ramen, and right now, I'd say Saiwaii is probably taking the cake on this. Saiwaii's going on my regular rotation list.

Note: don't be a douche and have more than 4 people in your group. This is a small restaurant that isn't meant for large parties. So only bring the people that matter!
author: Diana C.

description: Excellent service, friendly staff, cosy little restaurant, very short wait. Reviews on the spicy garlic tonkatsu are on point- not very spicy, meat pieces so small I almost didn't notice them, nice texture on noodles. Overall, taste was not impressive unfortunately. Also got fried squid- decent sized pieces but batter kept falling off and could have done with some more frying. I love squid but this was lacking flavour.
author: Anushka R.

description:
Finally got my butt back over to Saiwaii and I'm glad I did. It was a little slow in the restaurant with just a couple of other tables, but I arrived at 11:15 and was out of there by noon.

I got the Tonkotsu again with a $9.95 lunch special that included choice of Spicy Tuna Roll or CA Roll (w/ real crab). I went with the Spicy Tuna and added Buta Kakuni (braised pork belly, $3) to the ramen. Can someone tell me why some restaurants call it Buta NO Kakuni and others drop the "NO"?

Anyway, the broth is SO MUCH BETTER than opening week when I wrote my first review. Richer, creamier, porkier. Yesterday at Manpuku in Oakland, I was thinking my cold was still impacting my taste buds, but I had no doubts today.

The pork belly (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=KLlLvBBD5qG9kPcuH8V8vA) was everything that I hoped Santa's would be, but wasn't (http://www.yelp.com/biz/santa-ramen-san-mateo-2#hrid:12Nn5Q4_cF0BXw552GcmAg). Tender, juicy, flavorful. It wasn't the most melt in the mouth I'd ever had, but the 3 medium sized chunks were certainly a welcome addition to the bowl.

Which was good because the 3 chashu slices were not. Tough, chewy (in a bad way), and bland. Meh.

Noodles were just as chewy (in a good way) as last time (I specified firm, which threw the waitress for a loop) and they also seemed to be more generous with the toppings of seaweed, bamboo, wood-ear mushrooms, and green onions (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=n85j9sz86778Z165xQfSPw).

The Spicy Tuna Roll (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=u1qMizhHw3UAUDxApzgkDw) tasted pretty good except for one thing . . . it tasted more like Tekkamaki (http://www.bento.com.sg/uploads/products/91/_MG_4728.JPG) that is to say, NON-spicy tuna. Should have tried the Aji off the specials board.

Service was very good with constant fillups of the complimentary tea and the ocasional check-in. 

Ramen: 4- stars
Spicy Tuna Roll: 3 stars
Service: 4 stars

I'm torn. Do I average my visits or use the latest? What the h*ll. 4 stars.

It's too bad I only seem to get out here when I have a Dr's appointment at UCSF. I want to sample the other broths sooner than 5 months from now.
author: Andrew C.

description: This place is super yummy, I ordered the spicy tonkatsu ramen. I didn't think the spicy tonkatsu ramen was spicy but very tasty. I usually like my ramen noodles with a little bite to it, but it was soo flavorful I didn't care. They have a GREAT lunch special menu. My bf and I came and both got the ramen and 6 piece sushi lunch for only $10.95 ($2.00 up charge for their more popular ramen flavor) soooo worth it!!!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I have eaten at Saiwaii several times since its opening in August, and from the beginning I honestly believed that Saiwaii was going to thrive.

The broth and noodles have only gotten better - the broth more flavorful and the noodles more bouncy.  My favorite is the extra spicy garlic tonkotsu.  I love the abundance of green onion and the broth that is just the right amount of creamy.  I believe it to be better than Katana Ya and plus, there's parking.  There's also a big screen television that has the big game on, or sometimes anime.

I have not ordered any sushi here, because I prefer ordering sushi from restaurants with a sushi bar.  Plus, it's a ramen restaurant.

Some nights you'll have to put your name on the list and wait to be called.  I was right - Saiwaii is thriving.
author: Vivian H.

description: There's PLENTY of ramen places in the city so I'm glad that this place hasn't gotten super crazy just yet, although having a location in Outer Sunset probably helps. The size of the ramen bowl you get is great for the price you pay, and their garlic tonkatsu broth is spot on. I always leave Sawaii feeling full and with my tastebuds happy!
author: Grace C.

description:
Pro:
I was really surprised by the service. Having been to many ramen places, the last thing I expected was good service. They were very friendly and totally on top of it. I never ran out of tea and they constantly checked up on us making sure that we had everything we need and that everything tasted good. I had the tonkotsu ramen. I liked the broth a lot.
