It had just enough salt. Even though I love salt, I usually find the broth from most ramen places too salty. 

Con:
The noodles could have been better. They were a bit pasty and lacked the nice chewy texture that you'd expect from ramen. They also charge $1 to add half an egg. I've never been to a ramen place that changes for the egg. It usually just comes with the order.

Would I go back? Yes, but not in a hurry.
author: Andy W.

description:
Great lunch spot!

We happened to stumble upon this place on a foggy afternoon,
I was impressed that at 2pm we actually had to wait 5 minutes to be seated!

- Small and cozy joint, larger tables are shared
- Friendly and fast service, seems like there would be a daily lunch rush
- Lunch specials are a pretty good deal with ramen+side for $9.95
- Tea and waters refilled plentiful
- Credit Cards no problem

Tonkotsu broth was deliciously thick and milky!
Spicy Miso had heat but also flavour, def on the hot end but not uncomfortable!
Ramen was springy and fresh, neither clumped together nor too soft!
Side of salmon/avocado rolls were not bad
Side of curry don was pretty delish, more spiced, less sweet
Fried chicken skins ($3) were perfectly grilled crispy and perfect with lemon
*for ramen, splurge a whole $1 and ADD THE EGG, you'll be grateful.

My friend asked if it was possible to make her spicy miso vegetarian
and the lady was totally sweet about it and said "of course!". 
Looked awesome, and my friend said it tasted veggie, so yay for veggie options!
It was just a quick stop for us, but I'd definitely come back!
author: Jade T.

description: Nothing special. Typical Chinese noodle shop masquerading as a Japanese ramen and sushi shop. They say "welcome" in Japanese, but that's where the Japanese influence ends.  Don't expect much. Overly reliant on spicy tuna in the roll section. Think about why that is.
author: tout le monde a.

description:
Been here a couple times out of desperation for ramen noodles. Only place in walking distance that I can get to that opens during the day. All the times I've been here, the ramen has been okay, not great but not horrible. The service is slow and the place is pretty small so it's always cramped.

 Do not, for the love of God, order their sushi rolls and appetizers because they are so overpriced and the portions are tiny!! NOT WORTH IT. 

But what really made me post a review is this atrocity. I'm paying $9+tips and tax for a bowl of ramen AND THEY TRY TO SKIMP OUT ON ME on the two slices of chasu in my noodles? that's a big no no. Won't be coming back here again
author: Iris W.

description:
This is a small, petite restaurant. It may get crowded during the later hours, however, it is well worth the wait. It is hard to accommodate large groups but then again, they can. Just be prepared to wait for a table.  

The best thing here would be the ramen, hands down. Out of the ramen, spicy garlic tonkotsu is the best. Not only is the broth spicy, but that extra flavor of garlic gives it the extra punch. Even though the toppings are $1 each, the egg is the best deal. it is perfectly cooked and has great flavor. Definitely recommended. 

The sushi is okay but not something to get here. Also the don is good but not as good as the ramen. If you order the ramen, you can also add a small don for $3-4 more.  

The service here is great. They refilled our water frequently and were really polite. This restaurant is also good because it is conveniently located near all the major bubble tea shops. This is great because I want something sweet after a salty dinner. Overall a very nice place to eat. Yum!
author: Jessica E.

description:
I love the seafood ramen. Hands down probably the best seafood ramen I've had so far. I came in again last night and wanted to order it and they said they were out because of the lunch time rush. Well, that's really not good for business. If I wasn't with my friend I think I would of left, but since it was her first time I just sat there and ordered something else. 

She got the mala ramen, and I got the spicy tonkotsu ramen. It kind of made up for it, but I didn't like the pork, so I added chicken to it. The sushi and appetizers are decent.
The service is okay too, since they're so busy, they have to maintain their new customers first and then yourself. I always have to flag them down.. Not so good. 

Just be prepared to wait outside in the cold ass weather, because it gets pretty packed in there fast. So get there right when It opens. I usually wait 10-30 mins each time I come.
author: Lisa K.

description: I had the spicy garlic tonkatsu, following the recommendations of others. It wasn't bad (adding the egg was essential), but I've had better spicy ramen in the bay area and elsewhere. We happened to be there later in the evening, when the restaurant got deliveries, and were disappointed to see boxes of ramen noodles arriving in waves. I'm sure most ramen places don't make their own noodles, but this delivery coupled with the fast service made me wonder how much of the dinner was fresh.
author: Anneke D.

description: I went there once back in 2010 and at the time wasn't impressed. Therefore I hadn't returned, until last night when I decided to give it another try (which was something I had been wanting to do actually). I got there around 9pm and I had to wait for a table, a good sign. When I was seated I ordered the spicy garlic miso noodle (along with a grilled squid which was pretty well-priced here compared to other places serving this). This time the noodle and the broth (which I ordered the spiciest level) hit the spot. I've become I bigger fan now, maybe I'll start coming more often. Service was overall nice and friendly also.
author: H K.

description: I got the spicy garlic miso ramen with an egg. I really liked the roasted garlic and green onions. Good flavor. The service was good and super fast! They always are packed which is a good sign. We also shared the Spicy Lava roll which was basic but flavorful and the fish was fresh.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Sawaii has always been one of my favorite spots for ramen in the city and especially in the Sunset district. I can't speak to the sushi really but if you're looking for ramen on a typical gloomy/foggy/cloudy evening meal that'll satisfy your ramen cravings, this is a great place to do so! I love their broth here and the quality of the noodles. There are a ton of items you can add to your ramen to either spice things up or add more flavor.

I love their spicy tonkatsu broths here - both the Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu and Spicy Miso Tonkatsu Ramen specials are delicious! I'd say the Regular Spicy usually does does the trick for me - I'd say it comes close to a typical "Korean spice" level for those of you who can handle typical Asian dishes with a good kick to them. The portions are quite generous here and the ramen usually comes with two good sized portions of cha sui (pork loin most often) and your various veggie additions (seaweed, bamboo shoots, garlic, among other items). The broth stands out with its milky, creamy, and flavorful consistency. Bowls go for about $9-11 since I last went back in Fall 2014. For those of you looking for a starter, I highly recommend the Soft Shell Crab - made fresh and every bite is as delicious as it sounds. Once again, I can't really speak to the sushi, so I'll leave that up to you to decide.

Wait times aren't horrible although I'd say you can expect a 30 minute wait for three to four people. I don't recommend a group larger than that since the place is pretty small (although table turnover is relatively quick). Then again worse case scenario, it's an excuse to grab a quick boba...just saying. Flat screen TVs on either side of the restaurant allows you to catch up the Giants game and/or other sporting event of the day! Staff here is super friendly which is also of course a plus.

All in all, a great ramen spot and one of the few specializing in ramen on Irving aside from Izakaya Sozai. When in doubt, Sawaii will meet your demands from a quick departure from Karl The Fog's frequent appearance.
author: Cheston W.

description:
***Solid 3.5 stars***

Saiwaii is my go-to ramen place in the Sunset.  If you don't mind fighting old Asian men for narrow angled parking spots on Irving Street, Saiwaii could become your go-to place for ramen also.  I've been to Saiwaii at least a dozen times, and it always delivers, figuratively speaking.  

The place itself is as crowded as Irving Street on a Saturday.  The waiting area is barely big enough for 3 adults, which means that you'll probably have to stand outside.  Otherwise, be prepared to dodge the opening and closing doors, while getting evil glances from the waitstaff and the patrons.  The restaurant itself is very small, so you might have to rub elbows with your neighbors.  Last time I went there, I was talking to a young couple at the table next to me.  It's very tough to eat ramen gracefully; it's even tougher to have a conversation with strangers while slurping your noodles.

I always go for the spicy garlic tonkotsu ($10.45), and I ask for them to make it extra spicy.  It's a big bowl of ramen with a couple of slices of pork, bamboo shoots, crispy seaweed and a bunch of other goodies.  "Extra spicy" has a lot of chili powder, but you can adjust the spiciness level according to your tolerance levels.  Also, there's chili powder on the table for that extra kick, should you ever need it.  I always add the pork belly ($3.50), which is not as fatty as it is at some other ramen places and corn ($1).  I love corn, so I add it to everything, but it really complements my ramen.  

The two women working there as servers are all business.  They could be a bit less than friendly, but it's hard to blame them.  They run around and bus their own tables, so there is little time to smile.  Sometimes it seems as though they ignore you while you are waiting for a table, but that's only because they are.  I was surprised at first, but now I kinda expect it.  So, stop whining, shut up and eat your ramen... I think you'll enjoy it.
author: Yan G.

description: I ordered Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu with extra Pork Belly and egg. At first, I was hesitant to add the Pork Belly ($4) but after I took the first bite... Holy $hit, it literally melted in my mouth no joke... Overall it was a great experience, will definitely go back...
author: Phil L.

description: Not the best ramen I've had by a landslide, not the worst either. If you want Ramen Dojo status ramen, you will not find it here. But if you're really craving ramen, and aren't feeling particuarly picky about the quality, this is a decent option. I've had the spicy garlic tonkotsu twice now, and it was ok both times. The noodles are "meh," maybe 1.5 steps above the ramen noodles you make at home. I like spice, so the broth fulfilled my spicy fix. The broth is not nearly as creamy or tasty as top notch ramen places, but again it is a step or two above the 25C packaged ramen you make at home. They have a lunch special that is pretty good---ramen and a sushi roll for $10.95 (however, the spicy garlic tonkotsu is extra $). Convenient location if you live in the Sunset, and fast service.
author: Diane G.

description:
I went back and was amazed that all the suggestions from my previous review had been adopted, waiting list sign up (there was no wait this time), and best of all the tonkotsu broth had much better flavor this time. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/VfF1fmlw6gF6r-P4UmQGbA/l

Remember to check the white board of specials posted above the kitchen. This week the specials include: ankimo appetizer ($6.25) and 2 more ramen toppings ($3 each) - pork cheeks & buta no kakuni (braised pork belly). The kakuni was delicious, big thick cubes of melt in your mouth fatty pork belly. Excellent flavor!

Also any fans of Yo's Sushi Club might be glad to know that Yoshi Fujita is the sushi chef here, although the menu choices are limited to 8 rolls for now.

Hours: daily 11am-3pm, 5-10pm (Fri-Sat 5-11pm)
author: Luis C.

description:
when you hear some mid age chinese ladies outside saying good things about the japanese ramen, you got a problem.  and here it is:

Tonkotsu broth tasted like chicken and miso tasted like oily light shoyu water.  Noodles were overdone, soft egg was soft but no flavor.

spicy chicken wings overdone as well, had boring chinese style sweet&sour bland heat.

karaage batter bland, chicken inside bland and a bit dry.  came with some ponzu/soy togarashi sauce that didn't work.  lemon is all you need, maybe some kewpie.

even some japanese places have subpar ramen, chinese...forget it.  some chinese can make good sushi but yakitori, izakaya dishes and ramen, please leave it to real deal japanese folks.  #kokekokko, #halu

peace out
author: Kevin L.

description:
For Northern Californian standards, it really is 3 star worthy in the sense that it is A-OK.

A-OK meaning that it is:
1. Edible, kind of tasty
2. A nice venue
3. Served quickly/warm/hot.
4. Is affordable.
5. Really just A-OK

In comparison to Santouka, Daikokuya (The LA brat in me) and several other ramen places in California, Saiwaii's meager broth and somewhat thin and undercooked noodles just don't cut it for me. There is a certain umami flavor that good ramen needs, and saiwaii has yet to have found it.

I had some $9.95 ramen + sushi roll deal - split the tonkatsu ramen and a California roll with a friend - and they brought out an extra bowl so that we could split it more easily. Yay for excellent service!

I admit, it was satisfying after a long morning/day of Black Friday shopping, and their service was quick amiable, but after knowing what good ramen tastes like, I just can't go back.
author: Colleen M.

description:
Craving. Yelp. Embark.


Boyfriend and I arrive, it's packed but no wait thankfully. Small hole in the wall restaurant but I don't care I just want ramen. 

We ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen and the spicy garlic miso ramen. Oh and an order of the chicken wings. The chicken wings were awesome but they only came with 4 (wtf) and the ramen was good. Both of our ramens tasted the same....... They were kind of flavorless but whatever I'm starving.

Basically, I'll come back if I'm craving it but this is not a place I'd really think first to show my friends.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
A favorite for Ramen (spicy chicken) and their special Sawaii Roll (spicy tuna). The staff is always kind, even when hurried (which is often), but they remember us every time we return. 

This little place has been open for a couple of years but has recently enjoyed a boom in popularity. So if you arrive around 530P through 8P, expect a wait time of 20 minutes or more for a table. We tend to arrive about 15 minutes before closing, so we usually slide right in. 

Once you sit, grab an Asahi Beer and put in an order for a salmon skin roll (they'll make it extra crunchy upon request) and baked mussels to while the short time allowing your spicy Chicken Ramen to simmer. 

While we don't live in the neighborhood anymore, we make extra efforts to visit often. I haven't found a comparable ramen yet.
author: Kimberly N.

description: I dont know why this place doesnt have better reviews. First off there is NO MSG in their ramen! Thank you for not using msg!! I love the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen ($10.95) or the Spicy garlic miso ramen ($10.95)! So good, so filling, perfect for a cold day. & always very friendly! A great place to bring friends!
author: Kristen W.

description: Friendly serve and nice place! Those sushi still having an improvement. However, there ramen were must try! I will come back for sure.
author: Cheukee L.

description: Quality ramen spot considering the lack of options in the neighborhood. The spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen is definitely their signature dish and their chicken ramen is decent if you cannot handle the spicy richness of their best ramen. The other dishes are decent, but can be hit or miss. It's a small place so expect to wait on those cold & foggy outer sunset nights. Good neighborhood spot.
author: Jared C.

description:
They serve an above-average bowl of ramen here. The broth is a 9 out of 10 and the noodles are 7 out of 10. As an experienced ramen consumer, I would put Sawaii Ramen near the top of my list. Favorites include Izakaya Sozai and Shin Sen Gumi.

Get the Tonkatsu Ramen ($8) plus an egg ($1) and the pork belly ($3). The bowl you will receive will make you happy and if you're a ramen-lover then you'll taken back to the time you've had your first gourmet ramen meal (maybe). The portion of food is ideal and you don't need any appetizers. If you're still hungry, there's many other good food dispensaries close by to check out.

Try coming during a time when it's not busy--the line can get long.
Go to nearby Tea Way afterwards for some tasty tapioca drinks.
author: Marlon T.

description:
Came here around 7PM on a weekday, it wasn't very crowded when we came in (half of the tables were filled) but by the time we ordered, the place was almost full.

Ordered:
$7.95 Miso Ramen http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=YvhyIgXupnWNIX1OmAp-Ww : chashu, corn, seaweed, bean sprouts, bamboo shoots...
$7.95 Tonkotsu Ramen http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=3pLUyfhzAkBjM9b_8QWiww : chashu, seaweed, wood ear, green onions, bamboo shoots...I think I prefer less green onions or chopped into smaller pieces.

I would have to say that Tonkotsu broth tasted a million times better than the Miso broth. The Miso broth was too salty for me but Miso is normally salty. The ramen was chewy. The various toppings were really good too. The ramen can make you thirsty but the waiter will pour you tea all the time.

I'm glad I didn't try this place right after it opened even though I really wanted to, fellow yelpers say the broth was bland. When I came, the broth was flavorful. I'm glad they improved because if I went the first time & it sucked, I probably wouldn't give them a second chance. Since my experience didn't suck, not only will I come back for more, I would recommend this place to others.

Staff was nice, extra star for that.

Yumm, I think I'm craving for more ramen as I type this.
author: Kylie L.

description:
Every time I stop by this place i always order  the shoyu ramen. The shoyu ramen broth is very flavorful and comes with some bamboo, mushroom, and pork belly. The noodles are nice but not really sure if its homemade but tasty otherwise.

I would definitely recommend.
author: Arda S.

description:
It's a yummy local ramen shop. My usual is the pork belly ramen. The amount of ramen is average, you will be close to full if not full on a normal day. The broth is yummy and semi-creamy. However, you will be super thirsty after, so be sure you will have access to a bathroom within the hour. The pork belly is fatty, super fatty, the two pieces of pork belly that you get, you will have about half a slice of meat total. If you really want more pork belly, order extra.  

The sushi is alright, pretty reasonably priced. 

If you want to avoid standing outside in the sunset cold, reserve a table ahead of time.
author: Jess W.

description: I love this place. The best Ramen in the city. The pork belly, unbelievably delicious. Tonkatsu OMG delicious. Yeah, it's out in the  Sunset, so what make the trip. Yeah there is sometimes a long line. So what, wait.
author: Gary B.

description:
Service is fast and quick!
 Had the edamame it was quite disappointing because it was extremely salty, could barely finish it. 

I tried the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen in regular. It had a decent amount of heat I should have gotten the extremely spicy one. It had nice tender pieces of cha Su, there were bamboo shoots, wood ear and some other stuff. The noodles were nice and chewy and cooked to perfection. 

This was a decent bowl of ramen compared to the ramen I had in Yokohama. That bowl of ramen was the best I've ever had!
author: Stella J.

description: Delicious sushi rolls: volcano and mango tango! Great for take out!
author: Ally M.

description:
Easily the 2nd best ramen in San Francisco - a friendly, family affair with tight seating and great food! The kind of slurp and go place you go for a warm, comforting bowl of ramen.

Onto the Ramen:
- The have 3 varieties - Tonkotsu (what you should get), Miso and Shoyu
- You can get it three levels of heat (mild, medium, and hot) - get medium if you like heat - HOT makes it unedible.
- The noodles - fine - about average
- The broth - the thickest, creamiest, cholesterol rich, umami packed goodness you can find in SF.
- Seriously - the broth. Rich, luxurious mouthfeel - like just out of the oven mac and cheese velvet crossed with a seaweed/mushroom/miso umami, with a hot chili and cayenne pinch
- They have decent appetizers - all the usual stuff
- They take reservations sometimes - depends on who you get on the phone
- Always a 30-45 minute wait at busy times (Friday/Saturday dinner) - so plan early!
- There is an amazing irish pub two blocks down that I go to when I am waiting
- No corkage
author: Vivek S.

description: The ramens pretty good. Not authentic but close enough when u want a quick fix! Sushi was pretty good too! Customer service on point. But super busy a lot of times! And the place is tiny.
author: Jade T.

description:
Incredibly place for some fine ramen! And its a yakitori place? Win Win Situation here. Of course, with any ramen place it's good to go early or go when you know there shouldn't be so many people. Firm believer in their Tonkatsu ramen special during lunch! Their californian roll is super delicious as well! Can't go wrong with the Dragon Roll either! It's one of those places where the ramen is balanced well with the sides; there's not too much ramen or sides, and the soup is just right for you to chug down. 

Definitely got hooked up with the servers and boss there! Lunch Specials were indeed worth the price, and of course once you get parking you're set to go!
author: Chris S.

description:
We lucked out and only waited like 5 min for lunch! First time here and did not know that there is a sign up sheet at the front door for a table. Was a little confused about how to get the hostess's attention. 

Service was friendly and prompt. I had the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen with pork belly and my friend had chicken ramen. Both broths were very flavorful. The pork belly was so tender and almost melts in your mouth. The spicy garlic was not as spicy as I'd like but it was creamy and had a solid garlic flavor. It was a good first ramen experience for my friend! She finished the whole thing...every drop of soup was gone!
author: Bonnie S.

description:
3.5 stars

My brother and I were craving for ramen tonight and we decided to drive down to Irving to see if there were other options for dinner and load and behold Saiwaii Ramen was opened. 

We were greeted at the door and I thought the decor was nice. Looks comfy. My brother ordered the Ramen + Combo (unagi udon) & spider roll. We waited patiently and the waiter offered us tea which i thought was nice. Even though the restaurant was semi full our order came  pretty quick. 

Miso Ramen - Noodles are really good but I thought the broth was kinda bland. It was missing something. I just dont know what. But still good. Maybe it would have taste better if i dined in.

Unagi Udon - Good. Jessica C posted a pic of the Unagi Udon and wrote "Best Ever Unagi Udon?" hmm...i wouldnt say its the BEST EVER! haha. You cant really go wrong with unagi over rice. 

Spider Roll - $5.95 for 5 pieces is a good price. Just enough rice and tempera. Yummy!

Overall, I thought Saiwaii Ramen was pretty good. Definitely a good option if you dont want to drive to San Mateo or dtown for ramen. Great friendly & attentive service. Since they only opened three week I see potential and I wish them the best. Next time I will dine in instead of take out for the full experience.
author: Carol Y.

description: Came here for the first time with my friend and I love their lunch special. You get a roll of your choice to go with your ramen and it was so tasty. I honestly never kmow which ramen to pick and have no preference so I always pick any random ramen that sounds good. At this place, I decided to go with the shoyu ramen and I absolutely loved it! It was so tasty and the server was very polite and quick. The wait time for the food wasn't that bad either even though there was a full house. Definitely love this place and will be coming back for more.
author: Sarah G.

description:
Good standby ramen shop in the sunset, always satisfies the craving. 


THE SLURP:

Some broths are better than others here, I recommend the Tonkatsu or the garlic Tonkatsu. The miso is a little thin. Toppings are done well, pork is fatty with a little char. The noodles are great, springy with that nice stick to them, the broth clings nicely. 

Sushi here is surprisingly good, but the appetizers we've had ( chicken skin, chicken wings) have been lackluster and under seasoned. 

THE VIBE:

Casual neighborhoods vibe, nothing fancy.
author: Patrick T.

description: Came here recently after finding them on yelp and ordered the pork flavored ramen and friend shrimp and veggie tempura. I loved the milky texture to the ramen and the veggies and shrimp were good. Decent price and good service!
author: Brittany G.

description: Loved the Spicy garlic tonkatsu but thumbs down on their yakitori it was bland and their chicken gizzard was flavorless.
author: Shishie S.

description:
I absolutely love Sawaii Ramen! My friends and I visit this joint in-between our breaks for class periods to grab a bite of ramen before our next class starts. It's really delicious ramen for a really good deal. Especially during the lunch hours. I probably visit Sawaii maybe once every other week. 

I've tried just about every ramen on the menu and I love them all. My all time favorite is the Shoyu Ramen. The noodles are cooked so that they are still a little hard and not too soft so that the broth softens them while you're eating. Although, the meat is a little lacking. The meat is good, but it's comprised of mostly fat than it is meat. Nonetheless, still good. Service is pretty fast and generally the waitress who always works there has treated us with nothing less than kindness. Although, it tends to get busy during lunch hours sometimes, but not always. 

Highly recommend trying Sawaii Ramen out!
author: Jessica X.

description:
Just order the Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen. Bring a handkerchief.

The Yakitori? Meh...

#spoiledEastVillageNYCStMarksIzakayafoodsnob
author: Geezy B.

description:
So delicious! This is definitely the best ramen i have ever had. better than the famous ramen houses in NYC or any others i have tried. This time I opted for the spicy garlic miso. Which basically meant there were slices of fried garlic on top of the spicy miso ramen. It was scrumptious. The egg was perfect.

I went a little after noon and had no trouble finding a seat.

Great service and great ramen.
author: Zoe D.

description: Their Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen is pretty heavy.  Whenever I eat here, I never remember anything special about their ramen besides the pork belly.  I can probably eat the pork belly alone with a side of rice! This is probably my last time coming back to this place.
author: Lynn L.

description:
I love this ramen place! I just wish they expand cause it is so popular that tables get fill up fast and the restaurant is pretty small. Though the wait is not that bad.

I usually get their spicy garlic tonkotsu(regular) which is just the right amount of spiciness. People who can handle their spice, don't be afraid to get the extra spicy. It is intense. The price is pretty decent and okay customer service. Just wish they have more waiters because I have to ask for water a bunch of time instead of having them constantly refilling it for you.
author: Tu N.

description:
One of my favorite ramen places in SF! 

When it first opened, my family and I tried this place out. Their broth was watered down and their portions were smalll!

However, we came back a few months later and they perfected their ramen broth! I always order the Tonkatsu Ramen ($7.95) with Pork belly ($3). The broth is so flavorful I can't resist drinking it all! Also, the pork belly is so tender it melts in your mouth. 

Minus one star because their spicy soft shelled crab appetizer ($7) is not good at all! It was super salty and we had to send it back. They remade it and it was tasteless. Definitely pass on this one. 

Minus another star because I went here recently and they are still pretty stingy on their char siu pork. Also the noodles were soggy. Maybe they were just having an off day..

Overall, great place for ramen and very convenient if you live in the Sunset! Definitely recommend!!
author: Daniel S.

description:
I was too hungry to wait for Izakaya to open for lunch, so I decided to give this place a shot and get my ramen fix. 

I got a lunch special and had the Miso Ramen with some tuna rolls to share with a friend. And while it was all ok, it was just... ok. There was nothing spectacular about anything we had that stood out in my mind, or that would make me want to go back to this place in the future. 

So it's a fine place to stop by for lunch to get some quick ramen, it's nothing special.
author: Chris T.

description: AMAZING!! I love eating Ramen soup. So naturally, I had to go to a Ramen restaurant. It was soo delicious. And I asked them to add an egg in there as well, and they did that for me. And they put a lot of noodles in there! Yay! This place makes me want to spice up my own Ramen at home by throwing in veggies and eggies. ;)
author: NericePhotography L.

description: I love this place its so good! My favorite is the chicken ramen- make sure to get it with a soft boiled egg- an extra dollar but so worth it! The broth is delicious and the noodles themselves are chewy and yummy and they give you a good portion. The staff is very courteous and friendly and the ramen is prepared quickly but still with good quality. I come here all the time and i am always craving it. The portions are decently sized- if you're hungry you can finish the whole thing no problem. If it's a weekend evening it will likely be pretty crowded because its not too big, so get ready to wait bit.
author: Sophia J.

description:
In our unending hunt for ramen we finally came here. This place is a really good option for SF ramen. Not the best in the bay but definitely one of the better ones in SF. We even noticed a local celebrity pork chef here during lunch on our visit. I guess that attests to the slim pickings in SF or how decent this place really is. 

Service was great. Wish the char siu was a little less fatty/gummy. But the egg. The egg was perfectly cooked. Soft boiled and still a little runny. Broth was slurp worth. Noodles were good noodles. Good decent spot. I will be back whenever I'm in need of a ramen fix and in the area.
author: Augusto M.

description:
People make mistakes.

I come here often every now and then, last time I came here, everyone on my table had FOOD POISONING.

Called in and reported it and they said this was their first complaint ever and said we may be allergic to their ingredient... We are all regulars, really now? All of us had mud butts the next day and they wanted us to bring them some sort of hospital note from the doctor. Come on now! Every evidence had been shat out and flushed away. All of us are not related and it's not our first, second, not third time coming here. Not to mention, the soup tasted a little different that day; it tasted more salty than usual.

VERY disappointed. Cheap!
author: ABC Z.

description:
Came here with a few friends this time because our reservation for another place had a 90 minute wait times.

I got a tempura roll cause I had my avocado and crunchy foods craving. I also got the small unagi don as my main couse because I wasn't quite in the mood for a full dinner.

The tempura roll was pretty good, smooth fresh avocado! Who can resist? My unagi don was a small bowl of unagi drenched in a healthy portion of kabayaki sauce over white and puffy jasmine rice. The unagi was quite flavorful and the rice complemented it well.

The service was quite slow, like the last time I was here and we had to ask a few times before we got our napkins and refills for tea. But, they had a full house that day and only two waitresses so I couldn't blame them.
author: Anna F.

description:
The first time I tried this place, there was a 30min wait for dinner. There was 4 of us. I ordered the spicy miso ramen with pork belly, egg, and corn. It was very rich and filling. I thought it was delicious!

The next time I came here with my friend during lunch time and there was no wait at all. I ordered the lunch special Tonkotsu ramen with egg and corn and spicy tuna roll. I liked this ramen alot better! It was flavorful and rich but it wasn't overbearing and didn't make it bloated. The egg was cooked the way I like it, cooked white with runny yolk. 

The service was ok. There was only 1 waiter. It was hard getting his attention just to get more tea. There were only 3-4 other tables but not everyone was asking for things.
author: Jean T.

description:
service was quick, but the server was sort of pushy when it came to ordering. she came back 3 times to check if we were ready to order, with a minute or two minute intervals between each visit. 
I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with an add on of "pork belly cubes." but when they say cubes, they really mean bricks. the pork belly chunks were huge! I was sort of feeling iffy on getting an add on of cubes for $3.50 because how big are these cubes going to be? they were gracious with the pork belly serving, I got about 3-4 big chunks with small slices too. but no worries, you get your money's worth for that pork belly. it was tender and flavorful. 
if anyone is going to have to pick an add-on, definitely try the pork belly!
author: Shirley T.

description: I've been around SF looking for ramen and this place is by far the best. Today I got the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen, add pork belly and egg. A comforting and satisfying experience.
author: Jacqueline O.

description:
This could sound snobby but as a New Yorker, I've had much better ramen than this. My husband and I followed the suggestion from our fellow Yelpers and ordered the popular spicy garlic miso/tonkotsu ramen - they were not good. The broth was watery and there wasn't much taste to it. We couldn't taste the tonkotsu flavor and had to add soy sauce to give it some flavor. The miso broth was a little better but I wouldn't say it was good neither. 
One thing they did good was the texture of the ramen noodles but other than that, meh.
author: Gracie T.

description:
Came here with a large group and despite the small size of this restaurant, they were able to accommodate us and serve us promptly. 

Ramen was super tasty. The calamari was also delish. No MSG! They also have a pretty good selection of sushi.

Would go back :)
author: Dinah O.

description:
Japanese Ramen has three essential pieces that differentiates between the top tier or not. At minimum two or of three should be meet in regards to 1) broth 2) noodle 3) chasu pork.  Here's my opinion regarding the Spicy garlic tonkatsu:
1) broth - good distinct flavor with a kick. Not overly oily
2) noodle - clumpy and slightly over done which gives a soggy taste.  Without it being separated the noodles are not evenly cooked. The best have strict cooking times making it al dente.
3) chasu - tough and thin. Should be mouth melting tender. 

Final thoughts: two stars for food plus one for good service. As of now, the south bay have the best ramen places.
author: Jack H.

description:
By far, one of the best ramen places in San Francisco. I couldn't stop thinking of it ever since I tried it. 
I ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu. The soup base was perfectly made. The noodles were good.
My friend and I waited an hour and a half for it this place and it is definitely worth the wait!
author: Annie H.

description:
I'm usually not a big fan of ramen, but I have to admit that Sawaii Ramen is pretty good! I ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu in mild and it was perfect, not too spicy but just enough so that it still has flavor. I wish there was a large size because it didn't fill me up and I ended up getting a sushi roll with it. 

What I like about this place is the variety they have, Sawaii doesn't only concentrate on their ramen, but they also promote their rolls on the wall. The appetizer list is large enough with decent choices too. The service is good, the waiter comes by and makes sure the water and tea is full and it wasn't hard to order a second time. They also accept more than 2 credit cards which was nice. 

What I don't like about Sawaii is the wait for a table and how cramped and small the restaurant is. It was so cold outside and we had to wait outside because there were only enough space for a couple of people to stand in.
author: Maybo L.

description:
My hubby and I wandered in here one evening after being starved all day. We noticed there was a long wait list of people already trying to get a table, so our overall wait was about an hour to be seated.

Once we were seated, we were so hungry that we went with the most popular ramen on the menu, the roasted garlic miso spicy ton katsu. We both opted to get it medium but I sure wish I had gotten mild. Normally, anytime I order medium at other places, it's medium..here it was BLAZING hot. I was unable to finish most of my broth and my husband was sweating up a storm by the time he was finished with his.

Overall, I could definitely taste the roasted garlic in the broth, but the potions seemed a bit small for the $10 a bowl price tag. The service seemed a bit rushed and slow, considering it was packed. I just forewarn people if you do and normally can tolerate medium spiciness, to first try the mild. 

Overall, one of the better ramen places in the city besides, Katana-Ya, Sozai and Miki in my opinion.
author: Petra S.

description:
I need to move to the Sunset. It's has the best restaurants in the city! Well, if you're into amazingly fresh Asian food full of flavor...

We made a last minute reservation, and I was glad we did - the place was full on a Tuesday, and we snagged the last table. As soon as we got there, I knew I'd love it - super cute inside, very intimate, small, nice lighting, and has a cozy feel.

I ordered the seafood ramen, and a negi hama roll - OMG YUM. The sushi roll was good, (not to die for), but the ramen was SO F-ING good. And they're known for the ramen, anyway. The chunks of fish in it were soft and juicy, the prawn was giant, and the scallops were perfect. And the broth. I want it again! It was SO flavorful, fresh, and perfectly spicy.

Also, everything was pretty affordable - for two orders of ramen, the negi hama roll, two pieces of negi hama nigiri, the uni don (a HUGE bowl of uni, rice, shiso), and a bottle of unfiltered sake, it was around $60.

Can't WAIT to come back!
author: Jessica C.

description:
so obsessed with this ramen place. absolutely delicious, have been going here for years.
spicy garlic tonkatsu is divine. I crave this food. keep it up Saiwaii!
author: A. R.

description:
My boyfriend and I come here quite often because 1. it's affordable and 2. their ramen is one of the best I've had so far here in San Francisco.

What we both usually order is the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen (for me: regular spicy, for him: extra spicy) and the price for that is around 10.95 I believe per bowl, but we like to add things such as an egg, extra noodle, ka chu, etc. Extra toppings are a dollar each, while extra meat will cost you $4.

I cannot describe how great their ramen is and I definitely recommend it to ANYONE. If you're not a huge fan of ramen, there are sushi rolls and other dishes you can order from them and they all taste just as great! There are lunch specials as well if you want to save a bit of money! If you go there on a good day (early in the morning) you don't have to wait for a table, but there is a waiting list if it does get pretty busy.
author: Trisha L.

description:
Finally a good ramen place that doesn't have a long wait!  I order the spicy Tonkatsu and happily slurp up every bit everytime I'm here.  

Just enough garlic with DELICIOUS pork belly (I don't care that it's mostly fat) and a perfectly cooked egg, I'm sad that this place is so far out from me.
author: Jane N.

description:
I came here after getting rejected by the ramen festival--almost 2 hour wait and no ramen in sight.

The service is quite friendly. The chicken ramen--do NOT get. There are shreds of chicken in it (are these leftovers??)

Actual ramen noodles were not memorable. I just remember my noodles seem to have been sitting in my bowl for a bit before soup was poured into it, because they were stiff and difficult to pull apart. 

I tried some of the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen had a pretty good flavor. But I'm not sure if I was just starving or if this place was actually good.

I was not too thrilled about the amount of food they provided per order. You have to add a lot of "extras" to make it a real bowl of ramen. 

There are more other foods besides ramen to try out, like sushis and salads, however this place did not wow me.... And I was hungry.
author: Adorable T.

description: Love their lunch special :) Ramen comes with sushi, dine in only tho. My new favorite ramen place!
author: Melissa G.

description:
I recently came here with my family and was at first skeptical as to how good this place is due to the 3.5 star average review. This place definitely exceeded my expectations.

I got the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen, and I was blown away. The soup base was not too oily and had a pleasant level of spiciness. The garlic flavor was amazing, they deep fry it and the flavor really gets into the soup base.
I also tried to spicy garlic miso ramen and it was quite good as well. I personally prefer the tonkotsu soup base over the miso though.

We also got the:
Agedashi tofu: This was just okay. The portion size of this was rather small, and there was nothing special about how they prepared it. Considering the price though, they definitely could offer larger portions for this...
Spider roll: The spider roll was quite delicious, and the crab was deep fried so the roll was crispy and had a nice texture.
Rainbow roll: The fish was fresh, and the portion was rather generous, although not particularly cheap.
Spicy tuna bowl: I got the spicy tuna bowl as a side to my ramen. It was quite good - their rice is very sweet and the spicy tuna was good as well (they didn't dilute the spicy tuna by mixing it with mayo or anything that some places try!)
Chirashi don: My dad got this, and although it doesn't look like much there is a good amount of sashimi in this. They do put too much rice, however, which is good for those who love Japanese rice.

Overall, the food was great. Do expect a wait though, the shop is very small and tends to be crowded. The service was on the weaker side though, as the waitress / waiter were both too busy running back and forth to take care of the customers properly.
author: Michael L.

description:
Most likely, you are coming to eat at Saiwaii Ramen for their ramen. 

I've dined at Saiwaii Ramen twice. I tried the tonkotsu ramen on my first visit and the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen on my second visit. 

Of the two, I enjoyed the tonkotsu ramen much more. I thought the broth was very flavorful, and the chashu pork was tender and delicious. On the other hand, the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen was too spicy, as I thought the spicy broth just overpowered the overall taste, which did not make a good bowl of ramen. As I see other Yelpers rave about the spicy garlic broth, it didn't do it for me. 

I also tried a few of their sushi rolls, which were good, but nothing far from the usual. If you do dine at Saiwaii, I suggest sticking to the ramen and seeing which you like from there.

Overall, Saiwaii is a decent Japanese ramen restaurant in the Outer Sunset neighborhood. While not up to par, it is a good alternative to other popular ramen spots in the city - including the tonkotsu ramen at Izakaya Sozai.
author: Mari S.

description:
I am so glad that we ended up coming, after being told by the hostee at Izakaya about their one hour wait...
This place is way better than Izakaya! People, stop waiting outside Izakaya. Walk a few blocks and come in for a yummy hot bowl of ramen!
the fried chickens were well marinated. It was slightly spicy
The ramen, omg, we ordered the one that was highly recommended on yelp. We were not disappointed. The flavor was just amazing! Note: we ordered the extra spicy one. It was indeed very spicy. So just know what you get yourself into.
Overall, we were very satisfied with our bellies filled with yummy ramen!! 
Definitely coming back!
author: Jojo L.

description:
Their spicy garlic ramen is delicious. I also like their gyoza 
with homemade sauce. Service is great.
author: Pimpaphon S.

description:
Spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen is SO good here!  I wanted to drink up the whole bowl of broth.  It is perfectly spicy and the ramen was cooked al dente.  YUM.  This ranks as one of the best bowls of ramen I've had in the bay area!

I didn't like the broth for the spicy mala ramen as much as the garlic tonkatsu.

The kobe beef salad was yummy, but the beef was a little bit overcooked for my preference.
author: Jenny L.

description: The ramen here is not bad for being in the Sunset. The broth is savory, noodles are pretty Q, and meat is tender. I try to not have much sodium intake for my heart health, so I would definitely recommend getting a lighter broth if you're concerned about that. The staff here are friendly and attentive, and the restaurant has a cozy atmosphere. During busy times, the room can get a little boisterous which just means you ether gotta talk above the din or slurp happily away at your ramen :)
author: Vivian W.

description: My current go to ramen place ! I went during the day for my last visit and didn't have to wait in line and got a good lunch deal! My favorite is the spicy garlic tonkotsu. The staff is always friendly too.
author: Lauren L.

description:
I have come here a decent amount of times to confirm that the ramen is pretty average. I have tried the miso, spicy garlic tonkatsu, and soy broths. I am actually a huge fan of ramen and crave it all the time, but I found myself to never really want to eat here that often.

Today, I gave the spicy garlic tonkatsu another go and my ramen craving was surely fulfilled.. but it didn't taste all that great. The cha siu or pork pieces were pretty dry and not as tasty as other ramen places that I've been to. 

Overall, I'd like to say that the location of this place is quite convenient if you're ever craving ramen, but don't expect top notch ramen~
author: Mel T.

description:
had to wait a while for a table on January 1st. I'm guessing it's also a popular weekend spot. maybe everyday? 

the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen was delicious and SO FILLING! 

warning to vegetarians and pescetarians: ALL the ramen soup broths are meat-based (either pork or chicken)
author: Adrienne C.

description:
This place delivers on value, and taste for ramen.

So far I would come back here over and over again.  Less than $10 for a bowl of ramen, always packed.  The broth was heavy, but tasty.  Get the extra egg, soft boiled.

I would recommend my friends to come
author: Tony T.

description: The spicy garlic tonkotsu was pretty good. However, the noodles were too chewy even after letting it sit in the hot broth for a few minutes longer before eating it. Added braised pork belly, corn, extra black mushrooms and fried garlic which made it more tasty and creamier. They serve sushi rolls here too which is a plus if the ramen doesn't fill you up. I know there are plenty more ramen places in San Francisco but I would definitely come back here. Customer service was great!!
author: Myra C.

description:
Updating review: we've been back a few times and it's been consistently good.  We must've had poor server first time.

This is our go to for spicy ramen near our home...going to Japan town can be a pain.
author: Charlie B.

description:
A friend took me here for  lunch/brunch since I just got my braces and needed something soft to eat. We came around 1ish almost 2 and waited for a bit before we were seated since it was quite pack. 

Upon being seated, we had to wait awhile for the menu, utensils, and napkins which I thought was quite weird since that's usually the first thing served. (I would say the service on that particular day was mediocre.)

However the garlic tonkotsu ramen was great. I definitely enjoyed it despite of the fact that I had a hard time chewing due to my  braces. I really love the flavor of the ramen especially because it wasn't too spicy nor too mild in other words it was just right. 

I would definitely be checking this place out again despite of its mediocre service because the ramen is just delicious.
author: Julie C.

description:
I drove right by this place because I didn't notice a sign for the restaurant. But I eventually found it and was immediately greeted by the wait staff. I ordered:  

Spicy Baked Mussels: Overcooked but the mussel is cut in half for easy eating and is topped with a yummy cream/cheese kind of sauce that has a bit of a kick to it. 

Spicy Garlic Miso Ramen: Broth wasn't as creamy as I typically like so it tasted more "clean" but it had good flavor and good spiciness to it. The pork was delicious and noodles were good. It wasn't overpowered with garlic. 

Service was nice and courteous. I like the simple decor and openness of the restaurant. However with it being cold in the city right now, that door which doesn't shut easily can be quite bothersome when people come in and out.
author: Maya S.

description:
tl;dr

Really solid ramen joint in SF. Firmly in my Top 2 of SF Ramens (and who knows that it would be a little corner in the Outer Sunset?)

----

I don't like to write Yelp reviews for neighborhood joints until I've been to an establishment around 5-10 times*, because I am a firm believer that first impressions can be misleading either way (*yeah, yeah, I know, I can't afford to go to Chez Panisse 5 times before I write a review for it, but that's different!)

DISCLAIMERS: I have never been to Saiwaii other than for lunch, and I have never tried any of their fancy sushi rolls with salivating descriptions on the wall and outside the store!

I'm specifically reviewing for their lunch special and their many flavors of ramen.

IF THIS IS YOUR FIRST VISIT:

Pay the $2 surcharge and get the Spicy Tonkatsu. That's what they're famous for here, and it's worth it. They make this very well, and although after awhile you can "graduate" to one of their other flavors, this is definitely worth it. I think this one deserves to be on the 7x7 top 100 in SF!

IF THIS IS A REPEAT VISIT:

Try one of their other ramens if you don't want/need such a flavorful burst/spiciness. I'm personally very partial to their Shio ramen. It's a soup that's delightfully lighter than its tonkatsu cousin, but I think just as savory in its own way. I prefer lighter ramens like Shoyu and Shio as opposed to Tonkatsu and Miso, so this works out great for me. 

Their Shoyu has been solid, but I'm starting to prefer the Shio more and more. They're both on the lighter side (as above). Miso is good, but not fantastic. It comes with quite a quantity of corn (haha), so you'll be fishing for corn at the bottom of your broth after you're done. If you enjoy just the tonkatsu flavor, their non-spicy version is still very good :)

The pork on top of the ramen is very good in a non-pretentious way, which I thought was really commendable. In the era where "novelty" and "designer" chashus and pork bellies are being blown out of proportion by ramen joints, the simplicity of Saiwaii's ramen is great.

As for your side sushi, I recommend the salmon avocado and the spicy tuna. I've actually never had their CA roll here, because who gets a CA roll when you can get a fish maki? :P The spicy tuna is quite spicy, but strangely addicting. Salmon avo is always great :)

The bill will come out to be just under 11 dollars including tax (not for the spicy tonkatsu), and you will leave with a full belly and a happy smile. :)

Keep up the good work Saiwaii!

ps. They're open for lunch till 3 PM!
author: Chris S.

description: I ordered the extra spicy tonkotsu ramen.  Now, I can pretty much drink most hot sauces.  This ramen is inedible it's so spicy.  It tastes like noodles in liquid chili.  Like I it's in pureed habanero.  I'm actually crying.  Boo.
author: Shannon S.

description:
Slurp, slurp, slurp..."what?" "I'm done?"  

I'm a big eater, but let's be frank.  I can tell when a serving size is too marginal.  Let me give a few examples.  My girlfriend, Bun, who is significantly smaller than me says the serving size is kind of small, it tells you something.  If the skinny Asian dude (weighing a buck twenty at most) on my right at the table next to us asks for extra noodles, it tells you something.  If you're wondering, it was not Kobayashi, the former hot dog eating champion.  Hate to start off on a bad note, but it gets better (Better to an extent at least).   

Sawaii's interior has a very stern and modern look.  The only thing missing is a water fountain or some kind of flowing water.  For some reason, I can imagine that.  There's one television hanging inside; it was on mute, and I didn't pay much attention to it as it ran.  Serving ramen, sushi, some rolls, a small variety of appetizers, and a few yakitori, the menu is very straight forward.  They have combinations with their ramen and add that extra punch to fill you up.    

The spicy garlic tonkotsu is the best here; while not really spicy, there's a touch of creaminess to the broth.  I tried the shio last visit, and it was bland.  By far was it from great.  Bun usually orders miso everywhere, her selection was no different.  I took a sampling of the broth and it was OK.  It tasted like miso at least.  I would have to order it to judge fully.  With the spicy garlic tonkotsu obviously on top, the extremity of taste ranking between the spicy garlic tonkotsu and any other choice so far is a drastic one.  The second best is probably the spicy garlic miso (go figure).

My suggestion, order the spicy garlic tonkotsu and close the menu.  Final answer!  Shouldn't even be a choice.  Get the extra noodles, save yourself the late night hunger pains.  Looking for a small bite to add to your order, the hand crafted gyoza was a pleasant treat and grilled with a nice balance.  Served with a dipping sauce, yet was delicious without it also.  Enjoy your spicy garlic tonkotsu, because that's the way to go here.  Trust me.
author: Arnold T.

description:
Service was ok. Atmosphere was alright. Food was edible. 

Nothing really wowed me. I had a ramen craving so I went to a restaurant that specialized in ramen. But I was disappointed.

I agree with other reviews, the broth was quite good. but the noodles were kind of bland, but at least they weren't soggy?

I got the spicy mala, which wasn't spicy at all ): It came with fried chicken and cha-su?

Unfortunately there weren't a lot of vegetarian options as well ):

In my opinion, It was a little pricey for the quality of food you get.
author: Cindy C.

description:
I have dreams of the Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu. You can order this at three different spicy levels; I got the regular and was pawing for more tea. However, it wasn't so spicy that I couldn't taste anything, but it sure isn't for the faint of heart. It definitely cleared my sinuses up-great for when you're feeling sick and congested! Be sure to order with pork belly; the combination is divine. I was indifferent towards the karrage (fried chicken) with the tonkatsu-go for the pork belly instead, especially since the additions cost the same ($3).

Dinner for two without appetizers or rolls was under $30. Awesome. 

It's a very small restaurant and extremely tight quarters. I essentially awkwardly sat with another family, but it was worth it. 

There will be a wait; dress warmly because there sure isn't any room to wait inside.
author: Diana N.

description: My lips are on fire and my eyes are burning from a small splash from the broth of Saiwans spicy garlic ramen. Excellent.
author: Julia F.

description:
On a cool Saturday afternoon, it was a noodle soup kind of day. Ramen was the perfect fix, and Sawaii was the restaurant of choice.

After putting our name down on the wait list, we waited for about 15 minutes for a table. We both ordered tonkatsu ramen. It took awhile for the ramen to come out, and when it did it looked good...BUT there was no egg! We were both very disappointed that the ramen didn't come with an egg. We should have read the menu more closely, but I think one egg should always come standard in a bowl of ramen - it's the best part!

Besides the lack of egg, the broth was tasty, and the noodles were cooked well, not too soft. 

I would definitely come back, but will have to remember to add an egg next time!
author: Annaliese D.

description: I always order the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen MILD. One time, I ordered the regular spicy and it was so spicy that I was dying.  My tolerance for spicy foods are very high and I could not handle the regular so I recommend ordering mild.  The place is small and at times has a very long wait but if you're craving ramen then it's an easy fix .
author: Mauricia L.

description: The spicy mala is one of our comfort food favorites - love it!  Looks and tastes amazing
author: Thomas B.

description:
3.5 stars just like the average.

Came here because my family friend raved about it. I had the miso ramen with an egg. I replaced the char siu pork with wood ear fungus.  I thought it was rather annoying I couldn't trade a protein for a protein like the egg, but I knew that was coming.  

I'm glad I got a simple broth and the vegetable selection in there was quite nice.  The noodles were decent and my family friend mentioned that it tasted like it was less MSG-ful.

At $9, it was a little steep but hey, I'm not from California so maybe this is normal to them! haha.
author: Ninette C.

description:
Any Ramen is good Ramen.  During a recent visit to UCSF I decided to search for Ramen and found this on Yelp.  Decent nearby parking enabled my visit.  I found the small restaurant quite full when I arrived for a late lunch.  Nevertheless, service was prompt and friendly.

The Ramen was what I would consider "average" by Tokyo standards.  Meaning it was pretty good.  I tried the Garlic Tonkatsu (Regular) and it was flavorful.  The Cha Su (Pork) was more like pork belly strips than the pork roll style I prefer, but it was still good.

I'll go back if I'm in the area.
author: D.J. M.

description:
The ideal neighborhood noodle spot. The food has a very home-cooked feel to it, which is comforting and savory. Also, they don't add any msg or other harmful flavorings or preservatives to their food. It is clear that they care about their food and their customers. Prices are extremely reasonable.

In terms of the price range, I think this is a winner. 

Highlights to try:
- Mala Ramen
- Pork belly kakuni
- tonkotsu ramen
- ika maruyaki
- kara age
author: Devin K.

description:
Being that I've had some of the best ramen of my life in Kyoto, Japan I was skeptical. My aunt and I did our research and this place was one of the shops that kept turning up. We went on Presidents day, and thank goodness we made reservations! It was PACKED by 6:30. 

Anywho! Of course we ordered the Spicy Garlic ramen, and goodness! Was it spicy. We opted for the mild version and we're spicy kind of people! But, too spicy and you lose the flavor of the beautiful broth. I'll start with what I liked least about my dish, the noodles. In Japan the noodles are slightly thicker and there are few of them, so of course in this sense it has been Americanized. All together that was the ONLY complaint I had about my ramen. 

Now, on to the good stuff. THAT BROTH. Any ramen lover knows the importance of a good broth. Creamy, slightly thick but not soup altering thick, and of course the add ins were helpful. This broth is the best one I've had in America yet! On to the fixin's. What comes with the ramen is traditional. Seaweed, roasted garlic, mushroom type paste incorporated, pork, and welsh green onions. While the pork that came with my ramen wasn't my favorite, it also wasn't the worst. ( I saw a man eating the pork belly with the ramen and that looked fantastic! ) I had to add an egg. Why? Because it's ramen! It was perfectly cooked. 

All in all this ramen joint rocks and I'm sad that the rating on here isn't better. Service was a little eh, but the food shines brighter than a diamond. If you're in SF, you MUST eat here!
author: Remi P.

description: Spicy garlic katsu ramen. Nuff said. Get it with a side of chicken kara age and it's awesome. For the faint of heart, I suggest ordering it mild and adding heat to taste, but I go straight for the lava level which comes with a glistening layer of chili oil that's sure to break a sweat! This spot is great for lunch as it's less busy. Smaller venue with limited seating, get there early, or be prepared to wait (and it's well worth the wait)!!!
author: Nicholas B.

description:
Very tasty ramen. Huge portions. Very filling. The ramen is a bit salty -- not so much so that it's hard to eat, just feel very salt-filled after eating. Or maybe it has MSG. Regardless, felt kinda icky the rest of the day, which is unfortunate.

Had the tonkatsu ramen with the fried chicken. Yummy. Next time will have to get the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen, though, had a taste of it and it really took the ramen to the next level. Will also get with extra seaweed for a bit more green.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Pretty damn good. My ramen wasn't spicy enough for me and I ordered the spicy one. I had, of course, the spicy garlic tonkotsu. I was talking about how it wasn't spicy enough and a kinda creepy but cool dude sitting tat the neighboring table offered me a bite of his. I took a chance and did it. 

It blew my mind! I don't remember what it was called. Sorry, but I'm going back to find out. I'll update my review then. Boom!
author: Kelly C.

description:
Passed by here on my way to find a small rice cooker on Irving at the hardware/kitchen store on the corner (my Hello Kitty one has just died), it was cold and I felt like hot soupy noodles and Saiwaii Ramen beckoned.

I chose the spicy (mild) garlic tonkotsu ramen and wanted to try the karaage but that will have to be for next time. 

Noodles came out in a reasonable time. They weren't kidding about the mild spiciness, it had a slight kick which was pleasant. I was expecting the broth to be milkier and It didn't have the depth that other places like Orenchi (hi Omar!), or even Ramen Dojo has. The noodles were also a little bit soft and not as chewy as I'd like them. 

Maybe I came on a bad day but the next time I'm in the neighborhood I'll try the tonkotsu ramen again and the karaage.
author: Nette T.

description:
A "cutesy" neighborhood ramen shop in the Sunset district of San Francisco.  Sai Waii surprising has decent ramen and other cuisine, mainly sushi and fish items.  Additionally, they have a decent selection of bier - Sapporo as well as Asahi (on draft) nas well as a decent selection of Japanese sake.  We ordered the Sapporo (big bottles) and the hyaku tsuru (100 cranes) sake.    We also ordered some fresh fish - monkfish liver, saba shiyoyaki (grilled mackeral), poke, and some ramen.  All was tasty and outstanding...except for the poke.  Growing up in Hawaii, my buddy and I grew up eating real, authentic, tasty poke (diced aku/ahi, green onion, ogo/seaweed, sesame seed oil and soy sauce/shoyu).  Unfortunately, the poke at Sai Waii consisted of diced tuna and salad (greens) and salad dressing, not so great to "local boys" from Hawaii.

Atmosphere is cozy, classy - clientele (other than us) were mostly youngish 20/30ish folks stopping by for snacks on the way to a night out on the town.  A bit pricey since we did not limit our appetite to just the ramen,  but tasty and good.

Would I return?  Definitely ...not too many places in the area that serves good ramen and sushi (bier and sake too
author: Mark N.

description: Despite its flaws, this is still one of my favorite bowls of ramen in the city! I ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu, and it has been hands down my favorite ramen broth yet. So ridiculously flavorful! I also particularly liked the bamboo they use. The noodles were thick and had a good texture. The rest of the bowl was OK. The meat was the only thing that really detracted from it - it was soo fatty! To the point where it almost wasn't worth biting into it because there was barely any meat on the piece anyway. But I will be back!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
So I tried the ramen & it honestly was sort of blah to me. I got the spicy garlic tonkatsu and it didn't have a lot of meat. In fact I can only remember two pieces of very thin, very fatty pork. It was just okay. I probably wouldn't have it again.

The sushi also got a bit lower in quality. The rice tasted a little stale and they were stingy on the fish. Idk Saiwaii, you disappointed me a bit. I'm probably going to have to find another ramen place - I'm sure there are better ones.
author: Junel S.

description: The best ever. I come here from LA white my son whenever I'm in town. Wish LA had this good Ramen. Best ever !!!
author: Leslie M.

description:
This is my favorite neighborhood Japanese place. All of the ramen varieties are fantastic, and their sushi is also quite good! They let you add a small donburi for $4 to a ramen order, which is always nice when you want a little something extra. 

I've never waited more then 30 minutes for a table, and even when busy they get people seated quickly. 

Great ramen, at a great price.
author: Aaron P.

description: Decently priced and portioned ramen! I love adding all the little goodies that they have available. My ramen is usually the most expensive because of all the extras. Love the garlic tonkotsu broth. YUUUUUM. Add the pork belly, enoki mushrooms, egg, spinach, and corn, please! Haha, I add so much stuff that I end up taking half home. :P. Tried the sushi here too, not too shabby! Service is consistently good when I come here. :D One of my go-to spots, close to home. :]
author: Mariel A.

description:
Love love love love love this ramen house!
The service is excellent and attentive and the food itself is great, as well as the nice and comfy ambiance of this restaurant. 
My favorites include the tonkatsu, spicy garlic tonkatsu, and the shio. Soosososo good! Perfect for the chilly weather that the Sunset district has. The ramen noodles have the perfect texture and the toppings of seaweed, menma, cha siu, green onions, and the kikurage were a splendid mix to be put into this dish. They provide additional toppings, but you'll have to pay extra depending on what you want. The broth of the tonkatsu is perfect and just the way I like it--creamy, flavorful, and not the right amount of saltiness for me to be able to slurp it up in satisfaction. Just thinking about it makes my mouth water already. 
Oh yess, this place is definitely a must try!
author: Katie G.

description:
The ramen here is pretty solid, especially the spicy tonkatsu.

Everything else, DO NOT GET. My unagi don was just a few thin slivers of unagi over a small cup of rice. Our rolls were small, very small, and of average quality...
author: Jingxi Z.

description: Excellent ramen noodles - great flavor and consistency. Definitely the best ramen in the sunset. The sushi is also delicious. Service is fast and friendly, lots of free hot green tea refills. The chicken ramen is good but my favorite is the miso ramen - spicy or regular, with corn, seaweed, bean sprouts, green onion, mushroom stalks, and pork belly ( which I tell them to leave out cuz I don't like pork). The broth is so flavorful, and you can get some spicy sauce on the side. I eat every last bite, every time!
author: Athena K.

description:
Came here with a friend who loves this place. I had my share of amazing ramen mostly from LA but this place was pretty tasty! Pricing is alright. Kinda cramped in there. Tasty broth (try the spicy garlic miso or tonkatsu). Surprisingly, sushi was pretty good too. I had the ramen+sushi lunch special. 

I'll return if I'm ever back in the neighborhood and craving some ramen.
author: Tracy N.

description:
SO dang good. I love love love Ippudo in NYC and was looking for a Frisco spot that is comparable.. saiwaii is vastly different.. totally chill, relaxed, small spot but the food is crackin! BROTH is on point for sure! 

spicy garlic chicken ramen
Miso ramen with pork belly. 

SO delish..
author: Amber M.

description:
It was a cold windy night in SF and B and I were on a search for a bowl of noodley goodness. 

Thanks to our fellow Yelpers we found Saiwaii. I'm not sure how long they've been there, but must have passed by there a gazillion times on my tapioca runs. The staff were friendly and quick! 

Food we ordered :

Ankimo - ($6 I think) we always order this if we see it! Great pâté / fish buttery flavor that just melts in your mouth. My only issue was that they cut it into three large pieces. Imagine that split between two starving people...a Hunger Games (Irving street version) may ensue. Joking aside, if we weren't a couple it may be bothersome to ask for a knife to go halfsies. 

Tonkatsu Ramen ($7.95) + pork belly ($3) - I'm not a soup fan but this place is tasty! Extremely flavorful pork broth. Not enough to cause the osmosis (maybe a little) but its not over the top. The pork belly was of the sweet braised fatty pork break apart to the touch variety. 

We both enjoyed our ramen ! We're so glad to find a decent ramen place in the sunset! 

-yum(M)
author: Brilissa T.

description:
Made a reservation and hour before I came in on a Sunday night, anticipating there would be a wait. Didn't need it as they had a few tables open, but it didn't hurt to have one. Service was a bit slow, but we weren't in a rush we didn't mind too much. It was a bit odd that the appetizer came out after I had already received my entree.

My boyfriend and I both had the spicy garlic tonkatsu per recommendation of the waitress-- I was debating between the tonkatsu or miso base. We also shared their fried oysters as an appetizers. The boyfriend seemed to like them, and I did as well. I'm not a huge oyster fan, but everything tastes good fried. The broth was spicy without being overly spicy, and definitely flavorful. 

It wasn't mind blowing amazing, but it wasn't bad. It's a great place to get your ramen fix in the city instead of driving out to San Mateo/San Jose and standing hours ahead of opening to get in on the first wave.

I will definitely be back.
author: Jenna H.

description: I'm impressed with the sushi but okay with the the noodles. It was the best sushi you can actually get on Irving street in San Francisco, but the noddles broth was too salty.
author: Tiana F.

description:
I just ate here for lunch with co-workers. We each had a different flavor (tonkotsu, shio and shoyu) and all were very bland with a strange aftertaste. It seemed the broth was watered down a lot and really had no flavor or richness to it. Why doesn't San Francisco have decent ramen?

On the plus side, the sushi roll that came with the lunch combo was ok and the chicken karaage was also ok.
author: K G.

description: Upon coming to this restaurant, I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen. The ramen itself was delicious, however, the broth ruined it for me. The broth was heavy in salt, so be prepared to chug down huge amounts of water.
author: Chloe A.

description: Came for Tuesday Dinner, had a spicy mala extra pork belly, The food is very good. But the service is very slow, no energetic for the waitress.
author: Thancha N.

description:
I heard improvements were made since they first opened, so I decided to come back and give it a try.  I ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen this time....mild. Yes, it's a contradiction, but I didn't want to be dripping sweat into my bowl. 

Service was much better this time and the food came out quickly.  They give you a good amount of noodles and don't skimp on the garnishes like bamboo shoots, bean sprouts and seaweed. The broth was good and not overly salty like my first visit.  I think whatever chili oil or seasoning they use makes the broth look like it has an oily sheen to it. It made me not want to drink much of it, but it is tasty. 

Overall, this place has improved a lot. It's only two blocks from my house, so I'll be back when I need another quick ramen fix.
author: Patra I.

description:
I come here when my friends want to come here. 

I like their food but nothing makes me really crave it. I guess I'm not a huge ramen person. 

I had their yakitori hearts and it was dry, same as the gizzards. 

Their ramen is decent though and the staff was really friendly.
author: Erica L.

description: I always love to come here to get my ramen and sushi fix! It's very convenient for me to come here cause I live like 5-10mins away. It's kind of small but I haven't had a problem with the wait so far and I've come here about close to 15-20 times already. Ramen is not bad at all but I've had better. I am a sushi lover and I always love to order their crunchy roll cause it's just sooooo good! Overall love this place. They have nice workers and they're always very helpful.
author: Kaman C.

description:
I've passed by this place numerous times while I was in the city, and never thought to actually go in and eat, because the outside of the restaurant didn't appeal to me. After studying all day for a midterm, my friend asked me if I wanted to go get something to eat with him. 

This place can be easily missed, if you are just driving down the street. It's a small little hole in the wall type restaurant. 

When we went into the restaurant, I was actually surprised to see that there were so many people. I was expecting it to be a little slow, but it was actually the opposite. The service was very friendly, and quick. We ordered, and got our food almost immediately after. I thought it was a little pricey for a bowl of ramen though, and they charge you extra adding a couple pieces of pork belly (which, I was told is a "must-have" in their ramen).  Overall, my experience here was adequate.
author: Lisa L.

description:
OK, I was not really Impressed with the Ramen (was a bit to hard).
Came in on a Lunch special (9.99  combo of Ramen plus 6 pcs of Sushi roll).

I picked a Miso Ramen with Spicy Tuna roll. The roll tasted even better than Ramen?? (scratches head).

Got the Miso ramen, First of all, I have never expected to have a bowl with chunks of corn (still scratches head).  Second, 3 thin slices of Pork, but they were too lean and didn't have any taste at all.  And Lastly,  The Broth was a tad too salty.

The Spicy Tuna roll was fresh and ok spicy.

Ordered croquetes (comes with 2 big pieces).  It was crunchy with their dipping sauce.

Overall, the place is convenient if you're around the area.  Price is pretty cheap for lunch.  Decor is simple, a bit tight, with 2 flat screen TV's to watch any channels you want. (We were too busy watching US Open Men's Final).
author: Helena H.

description:
Great place even for non ramen eater. 

The GF swears this place is awesome for ramen so she always gets it. 

I prefer the other goods
1) location: not too bad, on irving but far away from 19th you can find parking. Inside is small and can get packed on weekend nights but its never that bad. ITs a cozy mall place

2) Service: AWsome, always nice, polite, and helpful, sometimes understaffed

3) food: i like the sushi, the apps, and he beer on draft. its all decent and a great price. love the tofu as well
author: Benjamin B.

description:
Most of the time when I have my ramen cravings, I go to San Mateo to satisfy it since there are plenty of good ramen shops over there. However when I'm in the heart of San Francisco, Saiwaii Ramen is always the place to go for ramen. I've been here three times already and I haven't been disappointed yet. 

The restaurant itself is very small and the tables are close together so you'll be seated quite close to other parties. I always get the spicy garlic tonkatsu. I read many good reviews about it and I wasn't disappointed at all by it! An order also comes with a few pieces of cha-siu and omg, usually I don't like it in my ramen, but Saiwaii's is perf! I also add an egg to my ramen which is a $1 more. The soup base itself is rich so it makes me feel very bloated afterwards. All worth it though..

I've also tried their spicy baked mussels and fried oysters. Both were really good but I especially recommend the fried oysters if you like oysters! 

Remember to come early to avoid waiting because this place gets pretty packed during peak hours!
author: Judith L.

description: Went to this place late after a long working hours. Looking forward to warming myself up with a decent ramen but I was really disappointed with the flavor. The ramen was... Not good. I ordered soy based ramen, which can't really be bad, but when I had a first bite of the ramen with the soup, I wasn't sure if what I was eating was ramen or some asian fusion noodle soup. It was really weird experience and I do not want to go back.
author: Nana K.

description:
I've always walked around this place and really wanted to try this place out. For some stupid reason whenever I try to walk in the engineer in me kicks in and says "you really want to pay $$ for a bowl of noodle when Pho's just down the block?" I was glad I didn't heed that silly monologue.

We had the spicy pork- and miso-based soup and holy smokes it was good. Absolutely no regrets and it's definitely in the top tier of ramen I've ever had. 

Plus, the niners were playing the packers that afternoon, and I didn't have to worry about missing the game since there are 2 TVs in the restaurant.
author: Kevin N.

description: The Mala Ramen (mild) was delicious. Great service. Brandon, our server, was patient in helping us modify our meals. The female server was quick to take & deliver our drinks. The owner was so sweet. Also THANK YOU for being the only ramen noodle house open on Labor Day. Fulfilled my sister & my ramen craving.  Would definitely return.
author: Angeliza L.

description: Came here with 3 other girlfriends during dinner time so it was pretty busy. Small restaurant so if you don't get seated in the booth side it's pretty cramped.. We got seated on the chair/table side so there was a party of 2 right next to us. They might as well been part of our grouo- that's how close you are. Our waitress didnt really listen or pay attention to our initial order. Got our drinks wrong. Food came out at a reasonable amount of time. I got the spicy garlic tonkutsu. I didn't specify spice level and assumed it would be the middle one, but it came out super spicy-that's on me. So SPECIFY YOUR SPICE lol. Aside from that, we stayed there a while talking and catching up, we have a get together maybe once a month or every other month.
