(Bear in mind at this point, they are no longer busy and there are plenty of seats if other people came) our waitress was super awkward and kept hovering over us, she clearly wanted us to leave. So minus two stars for the rude waitress and messing up our order. Food was good tho.
author: Anna D.

description:
SPICY GARLIC TONKATSU.

If you can't handle spicy, that sucks, I'm sorry. In all sincerity. You're missing out. But tbh, I didn't think "regular" spicy was very spicy at all, so if you think you're tough, go for "extra" spicy.

It's a tiny hole in the wall mom n pop kind of place, so don't come if you expect to be waited on hand and foot. The wait can be a while, especially if a large group decides to idle and chat for a long time, occupying the limited number of seats.  The waiters (possibly related to said mom n pop) are a bit understaffed and hard to get ahold of during busy hours. But you're not here for service, you're here for RAMEN.  You can order tonkatsu (pork), miso, shoyu (soy sauce), or shio (salt) for about $8 and add stuff for extra, but what you really should do is pay the extra couple dollars it costs to get spicy garlic tonkatsu. The broth, as compared to that of an undistinguished ramen joint, has the creamy, almost silken quality that marks good broth, and the spicy oil - miraculously lacking in the heavy greasiness of most oily broths - adds an edge that really opens your palate to the rich flavor. Ingredients are all plentiful, fresh, and well-prepared, notably the noodles and the broth. Sodium is on the heavy side, so stay hydrated with water, the complimentary tea, or alcohol of your choice. If you're a real sucker for fatty richness, adding pork belly is melt-in-your-mouth heaven. And last but certainly not least least add egg! Soft-boiled perfection. Everything else on the menu (and on other tables) looked meh. Maybe the agedashi tofu? But spicy garlic tonkatsu, no excuses.
author: Emily Z.

description:
I remember my first time here - I got the tonkatsu ramen and it was ok. I've had better. My second time and I was disappointed. It was a long wait so I was hoping for deliciousness. I got the spicy garlic miso ramen this time and no add-ons. The broth was bland and the ramen was ok. I also got the salmon nigiri and the grilled ika. Grilled ika was ok. Salmon nigiri was pretty good and cheap. 

My BF got the tonkatsu curry. He loved it. Maybe I'll give it another try another time.
author: Linda L.

description:
Excellent ramen!

The recent ramen craze has been fantastic for people like me who crave delicious authentic ramen. It's also sparked lots of debates about which one is "Best!" After years of travelling around, trying different places, and reading lots of reviews, I've concluded that ramen is a very personal and subjective topic, and people definitely have their favorites. For me, that's Dojo in San Mateo, but that brings me to my point: excellent ramen is excellent ramen; which one you think is best is up to you. 

All that said, Saiwaii is definitely one of my new favorites. I got the spicy garlic ramen (I love spicy and I love garlic!). The broth was flavorful (though quite salty), not overly oily, and the ramen noodles had great texture. The soft cooked egg was cooked perfectly, and the other toppings were generous and tasty. Portion size was generous, and I needed nothing other than a large Asahi to complete the meal. Of course, I disregarded that piece of advice and also ordered the chicken karaage, which was crispy, hot, and delicious.

Give it a shot, you'll not be disappointed!
author: Terry N.

description: There's a reason this is the city's go to place for spicy garlic tonkatsu with pork belly. It's outstanding. The service is a little absent, but you'll be so busy savoring the flavors of your dish that you probably won't even notice.
author: A M.

description: I really like the spicy garlic tonkatsu. A hint of spicy yet so flavorful. Corn and egg is an extra $1 each if you want to add, but I recommend adding because the egg is perfectly cooked! Always a small wait when I come for dinner but goes by quick. Nice workers. Will be back again!
author: Amanda C.

description: Just so happen to cross this restaurant and it was a great decision. Yummy ramen and bbq eel. Will be back.
author: Chris Z.

description: Came here a few times and actually got to try a variety of broths they offer with their ramen. I've tried their seafood ramen with mild spice, miso, mala tonkatsu, spicy garlic tonkatsu. I am a huge fan of ramen, but this place is decent. Their spicy garlic tonkatsu was a bit too spicy which was overpowering; You couldn't really taste the broth. In addition, the seafood ramen with mild spice and mala tonkatsu was perfect with a hint of kick. Their sushi is decent here, with great portions.
author: Pam Ela Y.

description: Have been here numerous times, great service, love the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu with pork belly, corn and egg. Very satiating meal. Small restaurant but wait time is usually not bad. Plus, you could go next door and get boba while you wait if you prefer.
author: Sophia N.

description:
This place is great! The spicy garlic ramen reminds me too much of Bun Bo Hue.. but I'm not complaining!

The wait is long, be warned. So come prepared with an empty stomach and a patience!
author: Christine T.

description:
My friends and I visited Saiwaii Ramen on a Sunday evening around 6:15 p.m.  The restaurant was completely full (with the exception of four open seats)- we quickly took this table.  It's lucky that we got this table, because the place is pretty small and everyone that came right after us had to wait for a bit.  When I say small, I mean it.  Our table was touching the next table and it is really cramped in there.  We were quickly seated and given menus.  I ordered:

Tonkatsu ramen ($7.95): flavorful, rich broth, topped with 2 thin pieces of cha-shui, bamboo shoots, seaweed, green onion, and mushroom.  The broth was quite tasty and I drank the most of it.  The cha-shui was good, but I wish there was at least one more slice.  The noodles are a bit more al dente than I am used to, but they were good still.  The portion was good as well.  They have a whole list of toppings you can add in: corn, pork belly cubes, half egg, etc.- each for a price.  Toppings are tempting to add in, but this can really make your ramen add up in price quickly.  

Overall, it was rather good and a solid option for when I'm craving ramen.  My friends each tried a different ramen and each of them were satisfied with their dish.  The service was helpful and prompt.  The waitress came by to refill our waters about 3 times.  The ramen is very fairly priced- and they even have sushi or donburi options as well.  I don't think I'd want to wait around for the ramen, but it is pretty tasty and I'd say it's worth a try. 

Notes:
-Add extra ramen for $2 if you have a larger appetite!
-Parking in the area may be difficult, depending on the time.  Usually it's manageable.
-Sign-in on the whiteboard to put your name down for a table.
author: Samantha L.

description:
So glad I discovered this place. I live in SOMA and the only ramen around there is Katana-Ya, which is in one word: overrated. I guess that place benefits from its proximity to downtown, as well as it being the only ramen place in the area. 

Since discovering Saiwaii a couple weeks ago, I've driven 30 mins across town at least 5x to eat the ramen, NYAM NYAM. You must add the pork belly, and perhaps extra noodles if you are hella hungie. I always get the spicy garlic tonkatsu flavor, which is not that spicy, somewhat oily, but packed full of flavor. If you add the pork belly, you also get tonkatsu, equating to a favorable mea t: other stuff ratio in the bowl. The soup is also so delish that i drink it all and clean the bowl, erry time O_O!~

.....except for the last one. Went on a sunday afternoon instead of a weeknight. For some reason, fat was the theme of the day. My pork belly was 90% fat, such that I barely ate any of it. Interestingly enough, by the time i was done eating, most of the fat had disappeared. I guess it melted into the soup and I eated dat shit anways, X_X!~ That was sad, but the tonkatsu was also ~50% fat. This most recent experience subtracted a star from the 5 star rating I was about to give Saiwaii -_-. Maybe another time for redemption.

My name is Boris Yelpsin, and I approve this message.
author: Daniel S.

description: The food tasted great! Until I found a hair in my food. The waiter took my food to show the cook, and that was it. I only ate %25 of the ramen bowl, but they didn't offer to replace it or take it off the bill. Ridiculous, and disgusting.
author: Allen L.

description:
Came here around 8pm on a Tuesday night with some girl friends (party of 3).  When we got there, there were about 5 parties ahead of us and we ended up waiting about 30 minutes for a table.

The place is pretty small and looks to be pretty popular, so waiters/waitresses always looked harried.  It took a while to get our food, but it probably seemed like a longer wait for the food than it actually was, since it was almost 9 o'clock at night and we were starving!.

Honestly, I've had better ramen at other ramen houses; the ramen here was just okay.  I got the garlic tonkatsu, and the bowl was smaller than I expected.  The flavor and everything was fine, just nothing outstanding.  It didn't really leave me with any lasting impression, except that I was finally full after being out all day.  I would probably come here again if I happened to be in the neighborhood and craving ramen specifically, but otherwise there are better places to eat in the vicinity.
author: Denise C.

description:
We went for dinner on Sunday night.

Ambience:  Little neighborhood dive.  Small square tables packed tight.  

The manager should be the hostess opposed to letting these sweet nice vapid waitresses seat.  They would seat a table for 4 with only 2 people wasting 2 seats.  So, we ended up waiting another 20 minutes (minus a star). 

Me, I'd say, a free beer to you if you don't mind sharing and get seated NOW and get out of the cold?  I'd do it, and you know you would too.

Food:  We ordered 4 grilled dishes (all over done) but seasoned nicely (so kinda like chewing beef jerky, good but works out the kinks in your jaw muscles.  All tasted the same, but could be that we were mashing all the pieces together in our mouths because it took soo long to break it down. (minus a star).

We also ordered 1 spicy and the other very spicy garlic pork ramen (Tonkatsu).  Pork belly flacid and spice free, just white and looked like pork fat.  The extras like egg and spinach come cold on top of the soup.

Ordered 4 large bottles of beer (made everything better).

Service:  Brought food.  Uneven service, some customers (even though they ordered a feast) they chased and others, they ignored and let them nurse their 1 bowl of ramen.  Weird.

Meh.  Not a destination ramen place.  It's just a neighborhood hang.  So enjoy it for that.
author: S P.

description:
Service: 5 stars
- the service is extremely friendly and fairly quick.   excellent service!
- saved our seats although our party was extremely late
- let us stay for a long time without rushing us out

Food: 3 Stars
- spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen: the broth was delicious, but a little thin, kind of like a watered down version of the one they serve at ramen dojo.  the noodles were just about a notch above top-ramen quality - they were soft and broke easily.  nothing special about the pork that came in there though, it was just plain sliced and boiled. 
- $3 kara age (marinated fried chicken) was inferior to the popcorn chicken they serve at teaway a few doors down

Negative 7 stars for food poisoning:
- It was overall a pretty decent dinner, however, in the middle of the night i broke out in a sweat and woke up with sharp stomach pain, i then rushed to the bathroom and violently emptied my intestines
author: Tina A.

description:
Had I wrote this review months ago it would have been a different story.  I have eaten here several times since the restaurant opened.  I typically order the same items, agadashi tofu, fried chicken cartilage and spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen.  Over the past few months the quality and consistency has slipped greatly to the point I will not go back.  I can only assume there is cost cutting to be quite honest because:

1.  The fried chicken cartilage USED to come with a bowl full of just that and it was crunchy, hot and delicious.  The past two times have been complete opposite.  Half the bowl is now filled with salad like vegetation and the other half with chicken cartilage.  On one of the two recent visits I had a two inch piece of cardboard surprise!  It was greasy soggy on that occasion and overly fried on the other.

2.  The ramen noodles have changed!!!  They are dense spaghetti like noodles now no longer the softer chewy traditional ramen.  The new noodles now have an Italian pasta type texture.  Two of the waiters also confirmed the noodles have changed when asked.  Extremely disappointing!!  

3.  Beef tongue izakaya style is quite rubbery and chewy the last two times I have ordered it as well.

On the plus which is why I gave two stars, the ramen broth is still better than a majority of ramen places in the city.  I really hope and want to give the benefit of the doubt that this place will reverse course and go back to the way things were for the sake of other frequent customers as well as reputation.  Till then I will not be going back.
author: Grubnoisseur Y.

description: SMALL PLACE. I always get the Shoyu ramen! I love the ramen here! The noodles are fresh, the broth is tasty, and the garnishing and vegetables are just delicious! I just wish that it wasn't an extra $1 for ANYTHING extra you would want. I love me some menma, so i always double the extra order; bringing my $8.75 ramen to $10.75 w/o tip. The total is still pretty cheap, but I, personally, would rather spare that extra 2 dollars on a soda! xD Overall, great comfort food!
author: Cana Y.

description: This ramen place was so good. I'm so happy my boyfriend brought me here. I got spicy tong something and it wasn't too spicy (because I'm a wimp) it was just perfect and the noodles were so good!! I'm craving it now!
author: Elaina R.

description:
How could I be at TeaWay and not stop to have dinner at a ramen place?

When I arrived, the tiny restaurant was packed to capacity. Luckily, my friend and I were able to get a table right a way.

And then...we waited for a menu, any acknowledgement, a server, water, etc...and then we waited some more...finally I had to ask the couple next to us for their menu. We could not even get any workers' attention. Very frustrating.

During cold weather like today, which is basically any given day in SF, this place really hit the spot! I enjoyed the Spicy garlic miso with chicken, but was disappointed by the lack of spice. I should have had the Spicy Mama, which seemed to have the patrons near me sweating. 

Overall, I really enjoyed the food, but the service was horrendous. We had to flag them down numerous times just to get ONE glass of water and some napkins. I don't know if I could suck it up and come back for the food. I would opt for a ramen place with better service.
author: Surge C.

description:
I really like this place! 

I'm somewhat of a ramen snob. Chasu ramen at Izakaya Sozai, Ramen Dojo, Ramen Yamadaya... and now Saiwaii Ramen!

This place is really small! My boyfriend and I had to wait for about 20 minutes. It's not that bad considering it was a Friday night. The broth was so delicious. I got the spicy garlic pork broth.. I definitely recommend it.
author: Heather R.

description: Best Ramen and yakatori in sunset. There is the izakaya sozai but this place is great and easy going and for that I give 5 stars!
author: Andrey P.

description:
[M]ona: 3 Stars
[W]ayne: 3 Stars
Average: 3 Stars

+ Open Late
+ Accepts Credit Cards

- Dim Litted
- Chairs Were Too Hard

It was a cold and freezing night and ramen sounded like a good idea to us. A few of my friends have raved about this place so we decided to try it out. We arrived at about 10:30 pm and were seated right away.

I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen. [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=JoOzEe9Se8ZmcRIJuulaoA] Meh, nothing special. The broth could have been more creamy and the cha shu more fatty. Aside from that, the texture of the ramen was nice and chewy.

Wayne had the Spicy Garlic Miso Ramen [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=L2ZkSc0BtAd7vcM8AeePVg] which he thought was a little on the spicy side. 

Our experience at Sawaii Ramen was okay. It definitely needs brighter lights in there. If it weren't for the Led "OPEN" sign, we would have gone somewhere else. The wooden chairs were hard and need cushioning. I'd recommend sitting at the booths.

Overall:
Service - soso
Price - decent
Food - average 
 
3 Stars
author: Mona C.

description:
Let me preface that by saying I have, by American standards, extremely high standards for ramen. I lived in Japan for nearly 3 years and while there spent a couple months working in a ramen shop, making tonkotsu soup from scratch at 7am, so there is my preface. 

Sawaii Ramen has very cheap lunch deals and when I went I got a bowl of tonkotsu ramen with a tuna roll for around $10. The soup was obviously from some sort of prepared stock or instant paste, definitely not made from scratch. It was thin and lacked the deep rich taste that makes good tonkotsu so amazing. The chashu was plentiful but was tough and dry. The noodles were decent, about what you would expect from an American ramen shop, but nothing amazing. Overall the ramen was pretty poor, not awful  but definitely not up to par with a real bowl of tonkotsu. If you have never tried real ramen or just have a really bad craving it will certainly scratch the itch, but please don't think this is anywhere near as good as ramen can really be. 

PS the sushi was average low grade fish, basically just a throw in with the ramen. One good thing I can say is that you get a lot of food for cheap.
author: Nick G.

description: I enjoyed coming here for a late night ramen crave. The broth was extremely flavorful and the noodles were delicious, I couldn't get enough. I had the spicy garlic ramen bowl and my boyfriend had the chicken ramen. He wasn't impressed with his ramen and had said it lacked a lot of flavor and was too simple. As we were eating dinner we noticed a board with specials that they had and we noticed a Halloween roll which sounded a bit odd for having pumpkin in it, anyway, we enjoyed this roll it was very unique and showed a lot of creativity that the chefs had. I live in the inland empire and wish they had another location in Southern California, this place is quiet delicious but needs to have a bigger variety on the menu. I hope the next time I visit San Francisco  this little gem will have a bigger variety.
author: Elba G.

description: Be there around 1pm for lunch or before 6pm for dinner, so you don't have to wait to get in. If you're looking for a regular type of shashu pork, look for somewhere else; they use pork belly here.
author: Yanakon D.

description:
Came here over veterans day weekend and after being spurned by many overhyped ramen places, i kind of expected Saiwaii to be more of the same. NOPE! It was actually, legitimately good. Totally unexpected.

I got the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen with pork belly cubes (I love me some extra meat), combo unagi-don, beef tongue and hatsu. In short -- I got a little carried away and it was too much food. lol oops.

The egg was ooey gooey just the way I like it and all of the ingredients in the ramen were on point. Noodles were the perfect consistency, bamboo shoots were flavorful...the list goes on. 

The beef tongue and hatsu were kindof whatevs but I love that they offer these types of appetizers here! Gonna get the chicken skin skewers next time :)
author: Debra L.

description: Love this place. Closed between lunch and dinner like lots of places and prepare to wait no matter when you come. The sushi, ramen and service are all very high standard for the price! Love it.
author: B S.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for awhile, maybe because I'm always in search for the perfect bowl of ramen. Also, every time I walk by it always looks so busy! Alas, not impressed. I'm saddened that ramen does not come with a soft boiled egg by default, it should! Hence the star rating. Also, the chasu was uber mediocre. Here is my rating of ramen that I've had so far in SF, from left to right with left being the worse:

Doraku - saiwaii ramen - genki - ken ken - katanaya - sozai

Still in search for the perfect ramen, similar to Toto in NYC.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)

1/1 Star: Easy street parking with in 2 to 3 blocks around.  No wait.
_____

Service (Waiter / Cleanness / Ambiance)

1/1 Star: The waitress was very nice.  I was sitting near the door and when people come in, the door doesn't close all the way but the waitress kept an eye on it and went to close the crack in the door every time it was left open for cold air to enter.
_____

Taste (0=Not Edible / 1=Edible / 2=Good (average) / 3=Must Try!)

3/3 Stars: The pork belly (stewed pork) that you can add to the ramen is a Must Try!  
_____


Overall Experience
5/5 Stars 

_____

Pictures

Restaurant Front: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=Sxp5TYXyC6QuJ538ZOslFw

Seating Minus about 8 Seats at 3 Tables: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=qQHAekx2kMQR3qgARS29rQ

Tonkotsu Ramen with Pork Belly, no green onion: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=mphNul_pMLEnOcPrYLxHvQ
author: Elliott N.

description:
We grubbed hard here. Everything was good. Nothing exceptional, but no complains. 

Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen - Good amount of heat. A solid if-not spectacular bowl.
Kakuni - Luscious, Savory
Karaage Chicken - Crispy, curiously luke-warm
Grilled Saba - Robust, umami.
Bacon-wrapped Mochi - Chewy, salty.
Unagi Don - $1!
author: Anthony R.

description: Saiwaii's spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen is the perfect cure for foggy, cold San Francisco days. This place gets packed, but the staff are always super nice and attentive.
author: Jo R.

description:
It was a Wednesday afternoon, and we were in the mood for ramen. It was a little past 1, and most of the restaurants we were thinking of closed at 2. After searching around, we found Saiwai. Then when Bunny and I realized that lunch was open until 3, we decided to head over there.

We were able to find parking across the street. Searching around for coins, we fed the meter. As we enter we are greeted by a friendly server. I noticed that it wasn't too busy and only one table was occupied. We sit down and glance at the menu. After looking for some time, I was about to order the Miso Ramen, but then we noticed the combo, which includes a bowl of ramen with 6 pieces of sushi. I thought that was pretty interesting. Since I'm allergic to seafood, I go with the Veggie rolls. Bunny also orders a combo with tonkotsu ramen and California rolls.

The sushi comes first followed quickly by the ramen. We enjoyed the sushi rolls. The noodles were chewy and the meat was tender. It did however lack some flavor. The toppings were a good variety. There was plenty of corn, onion, bean sprouts and bamboo shoots.

Our hostess was friendly and we enjoyed our meal. However, next time I think I'll just get the ramen by itself since the combo was a bit too much food.
author: Doris W.

description: Awesome local spot.  Incredible, friendly service. The spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen is the best.
author: Kelly L.

description:
Saiwaii Ramen is where san tung once was. Sawaii has both ramen and sushi. 6 kinds of the usual types of ramen on the menu. ($7.95 up. lunch specials-9,95, with cali roll, etc.)

flatscreen: food channel-chinese, japanese cooking

sampling:
tonkotsu ramen((7.95)
-with cha su (actually pork loin, not bbq), menma (fermented bamboo), seaweed, kikurage(fungus), and green onion.
-broth creamy, milky,  and tasty
-ramen chewy, firm, not tender or al dente. 

temaki:
-ramen pretty filling, good portion of noodles
-value rating 3.5 stars
-tonkotsu broth better than most ramen places
-nice japanese tea, refilled many times.
-contemporary decor. tables & chairs not just wood but dark wood. .
-place is cramped. sumo wrestlers should go elsewhere. pandas ok.
(crying kids at next table should go also).
author: Victor G.

description:
Pretty decent ramen. pretty AWESOME WINGS. often times these ramen places make great wings and Saiwaii is no exception. I must note though that the nankotsu karaage were disappointing in that they came with no dipping sauce which makes them taste sort of w/e after a couple.

Also awesome is that they're open until 10. Hollerrrr.
author: Misha T.

description:
Downgrading after subsequent visits. Either the chef changed, recipe changed, my palate adjusted, or whatever... but it just isn't doing it for me anymore.

The final straw was my last visit during lunch where the bowl was downright anemic. As in sparse and lacking.

Bottom line: still a decent bowl of ramen, just does not stand out amongst the crowd.
author: Easwud C.

description:
This newish lunch spot with a mushroom character as their mascot offers for a quick ramen lunch. The lunch menu has 6 types of ramen, ($7.95 and up - miso, tonkotsu, shio, or shoyu) and the option to add on toppings (miso duck breast sounded interesting). They also have donburi.

* Tonkotsu ramen ($7.95) comes with cha su (decent), menma, seaweed, kikurage, and green onion. The broth was milk with deep pork flavor. I liked how it wasn't too salty and had a slight sweetness. Good portion, ample toppings with plenty of slightly curly noodles. 

The décor has improved dramatically from the Macao & Friends days (with those bright orange walls). The dark wood gives it a serene, contemporary feel. Service was very quick.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Somebody please explain to me how you could possibly make ramen soup taste like a poorly made  Chinese dessert after dinner. That's pretty much how their mild spicy garlic ramen taste like here and if you are going to charge more than 10 bucks for tempura  why in the world would you put mango in it they don't mix. That is like putting tylenol and aspirin in a Coke...

Dear God.... Their broth is heavy heavy.
.. I don't know if it was a broth or cake mix..all I could feel and think after I walked out was "fire in the hole!!"

The waitress was  very attentive and polite  and I know its not her fault. If it wasn't for her, you wouldn't be seeing stars  for this review.I have a strong feeling, she's much more skilled as a cook than the current cooks.
author: Eric C.

description: Unexpected good food, their spicy garlic tonkatsu is amazing. Add the kar age and egg.
author: Geo P.

description:
Met up with some good friends for lunch here Saturday morning. 

I got the miso ramen and added the Pork Belly to my order. When my ramen came, it had 3 Big Pork Belly included. OMG, it was yummy. The ramen was good and hearty too. 

If you ever come here, add the PORK BELLY to your ramen order, you will not regret it. Trust me, it was 3 good size meat in your ramen, plus you already have cha shu already in your ramen too. 

PORK BELLY - oink oink!
author: James L.

description:
I would rate this more of a 2.5 stars. It's....ok. It used to be good though. I hadn't been here in a while and finally popped back in. I had the miso ramen with kara age on the side. It was all just kind of bland. Even the chicken seemed blander than normal. 

The broth had no depth and the noodles were lifeless and without any real flavor either. My roommate got the shoyu ramen and also reported blandness. We had been going here steadily for a while maybe a year ago. I guess it's gone downhill.

The service is, as always, very slow. It's friendly, just really slow.

I notice there is usually a crowd of hipsters waiting outside in line now too. Hipsters: it's not worth it (and please don't move into the neighborhood. I know everywhere is saturated and the Sunset is by comparison cheaper, but please don't ruin the neighborhood). Everyone else: it's really not worth it.
author: Albert N.

description: We love this place! There is a wonderful assortment of the traditional broths for ramen and a chicken choice as well. We tried the Kobe Beef salad today and the Spicy Tuna Don and we're super stoked! The "regular" spice level on the Spicy Garlic Miso ramen is a great level of heat!
author: Radsurfbabe L.

description:
I love you Sawaii :)

We come here on days, when boyfriend wants variety from my instant kimchi ramen bowls. 

My favorite is the hearty deep colored red tonkatsu broth with extra pork belly & egg! Boyfriend orders Miso; light colored broth with extra chasu. The noodles are egg noodles, thicker than your bagged ramen and chewy. The bowl has depth and volume, much more filling than Genki Ramen across the park.

Ramen with choice of broth comes with veggies, 1 egg, & pork belly  ~$8-9 

additional sides is $2

Sawaii also offers specialty/basic sushi rolls at an affordable price; we ordered a batch of sunrise rolls, philly cheese and baked spicy cheesed mussels. 

Basics ~$5-6
specialty ~$8-$11

The mango pieces and spicy tuna teamed very well in the sunrise roll and alluded a duality of freshness and a hint of citrus; like what basil does to pho. 

The mussels was too cheesy and i love cheese! It was very rich in cheddaryness to my liking.

In terms of service, I liked how appetizers came one at a time, so we had time to pace ourselves. By the time ramen enter the picture I was 3/4 full. Needless to say, I had ramen left overs. The broth was too tasty to leave behind. 

*Conclusion: fay maow is satisfied and oh so full customer ;)
author: Fat C.

description:
Off the bat, great location!! Finally somewhere in the Sunset with good Ramen!! Although this means i'll have to fight ppl over street parking on the busy Irving street, it does mean that I won't have to go all the way to San Mateo to get some yummy Ramen when I'm in the city. It's good stuff that they serve. Their broth was flavorful yet not too salty or oily. Their Ramen was chewy and not soggy. 

Service was good, the girl that helped us was really attentive. They are pretty small, so not a great place for more than two large groups. We had seven ppl and it was pretty crowded. I couldn't be sure whether this was another one of those Japanese places owned and ran by Chinese ppl, but it's on Irving, so I assume it was. I do have to mentioned that their bathroom was kept pretty clean, which I really do appreciate. 

I would recommend this place to friends.
author: Winnie L.

description:
I Heart Heart! 
OMG the heart skewers are so chock full of energy you will feel spa fresh when you leave Saiwaii Ramen! Everyone around us was having Ramen...and it looked damn slurp-ish...but there is plenty else on the menu to satisfy. If you don't mind the tight quarters (think nearly sharing tables...) then you should try this place. Our server was so friendly and he smiled the entire time. The people who work here are very nice and interested in your good time. They save $ here and there (i.e. the paper disposal for edamame shells, plastic forks for your kid...) BUT it is reflected in your cost so I don't mind! Hey if I can have a tasty healthy meal (avoided anything fried), get my cold  sake on...watch my kid nosh away...husband sling back sake while we chat about life and smile...I'm GOOD.
author: Amy E.

description:
the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen was delicous!! totally satisfied my craving on a overcast SF day - monday lunch time - got seated right away.

the pork belly is tender and the broth is perfect.
the lunch special is spicy garlic tonkatsu + california/spicy tuna/salmon rolls = 
$9.99

the noodles were soft and perfect just the way i liked

definitely coming back here. i'm bookmarking this place :)
author: Vanae W.

description:
This is THE ramen place I'd go to in the city. Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu and add pork belly, an egg, and corn will be my choice. It already comes with chasu and some additions. It is delicious and very filling.

Aside from ramen, they have sushi and other japanese dishes as well. I haven't tried any of these yet since the ramen fills me up.

Staffs are very welcoming and acknowledges your wait. It gets pack during dinner time so expect a slight wait if you have more than 2 people.
author: Nancy N.

description:
Saiwaii Ramen is where I converted my guy into a nearly perfect food boyfriend. And for that, I thank you. (I just need to get him to love with pho, and his transformation will be complete.) 

The ramen here is quite a specimen, definitely one of the best in the city. The Tonkatsu ramen is porky. It's like the essence of pork in liquid form. That's what tonkatsu broth should be like. Noodles were the kind I like - not too soft, not too al dente. Exactly what you expect and want ramen noodles to be like. I got the garlic tonkatsu which was also not overly garlicy. Just a bit, which is great.

The downside is this place is BUSY. We got here at 2 PM and still had to wait about 30 mins for a table. Crazy! It was worth the wait, but still a deterrent. Also, I absolutely hate this neighborhood. Parking is usually difficult and there is just something about it... I don't feel good when I'm on this part of Irving.

Anyhow, the ramen here is delicious, so perhaps we'll venture into the craziness again.
author: Bonnie H.

description: Me and my family felt like ramen so we went to this place. The ramen was good but not fabulous. Other people in my group thought the tempura was to doughy and heavy. I will probably give them a second chance, but I will not suggest this place to others.
author: Will D.

description:
After coming here so many times, I think I can say that Saiwaii has been my recent go-to ramen spot that's not the best but can satisfy my ramen cravings.

my favorite will still be ramen dojo in san mateo but instead of the wait and the difficult parking, Saiwaii's regular non-spicy tonkotsu will have to do. Their broth is pretty flavorful and ramen is cooked almost perfectly. I have never complained about the quality of their ramen noodles, thumbs up!

second, along with the ramen, i usually get the side plate of raw tuna don buri to go with it. it's a nice serving of tuna sashimi over a bowl of rice. DO NOT get the spicy tuna because it is NOT worth it for how little they give you. the regular tuna one tho, good deal.

their baked spicy clams are always pretty good here, i usually get that and maybe their chicken karage as well. their service has always been good here, not the greatest but can pass and exceed for some of the establishments on irving!
author: Kenny L.

description:
Saiwaii Roll is on point, if you're looking for a roll that's been jazzed up a bit (spicy mayo). Spicy tuna roll is consistent and satisfying. Split the chicken Karage with a friend. 

If we're talking Ramen: Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu....as if THAT was a shocker. 

This is my go-to sushi-ramen place in the 'hood. Decently priced and pretty consistent! Make sure to check out the hours though, they close mid-afternoon for a couple of hours before dinner time!
author: Kat L.

description: Long story short, we walked in, ordered 5 mins after seating, and didn't get our ramen until 2 families and a couple were seated, orders taken, and food brought to them. This experience was nonsense..
author: Don P.

description: My boyfriend and I come here like, three times a month. Even when it looks crowded, the line moves really fast, and any wait is totally worth it. Consistently good, hearty, filling food at a really reasonable price. I get the spicy mala ramen basically every time we go -- but I have tried the shoyu and many of their smaller plates. Everything is awesome!
author: Sayre S.

description:
Prices are all raised!!!!

We still love this place. Our go to ramen spot as we live just blocks away.
author: Fay S.

description: I got the Tonkotsu ramen.  It was pretty good, flavorful broth and fatty pork belly.  The best part was the egg though, it was perfectly cooked.
author: Jia L.

description: Came here based on Top 7 Ramen restaurants in the Bay Area, and glad I did. Had their spicy garlic tonkatsu along with their homemade gyoza, and one word "Wow."  I will be back.
author: Brad N.

description:
They serve one of the best ramen in town. There's lots of flavor in their ramen and they serve good portions. Their Chicken Karage is very good as well. The Gyoza was not good at all. It had a thick wrap and stuffing was full of leeks. The service is hit or miss. They only have one waiter or waitress working most of the time, plus the owner herself. 

It's a small place, so I would get there early.
author: Picky E.

description: My favorite ramen place to go in SF! Great ramen and a cozy spot, the hosts/wait staff are all polite and very quick. There's also ample parking nearby :)
author: Alec S.

description:
I've never been a bigger fan of ramen than now. And although my ramen cravings have been few and far between, there's no denying how much I enjoy it when I can. Just like when I meet with an old friend, it seems that I never lose a step and just pick up right where I left off with ramen. 

I had the (mild) spicy garlic tonkotsu with a side of curry don. It's amazing stuff and although I was focused on the conversation, my mind was telling me LESS TALKING, MORE EATING. The pork in the tonkotsu was very tender and the broth very warm. The flavors sparked a salivating party in my mouth. 

But the true triumph came from the curry don. Great compliment with the ramen, just because I likes my rice. I wouldn't say it was a mistake but having both ramen and rice was filling, which gave me another opportunity to enjoy the left overs the next day. 

Service is good because they were very attentive and patient. Saiwaii is very small and quaint. Because of its size, it does get loud. So make sure you're louder than everyone else. 

Just kidding.

Saiwaii just went from bookmark to favorite. I'm giving a greenlight on this place and I hope you do too.
author: Will S.

description:
We went here on New Year's Day, or national hangover day, to counteract the effects of Four Loko the night before. I was hurting and needed something spicy and delicious and comforting.

Went to Saiwaii at about 2pm, and were immediately seated. After a quick look at the menu, we both ordered the Tonkatsu ramen (I went with the extra spicy garlic one), veggie tempura and a house hamachi roll.

The Hamachi roll was not expensive ($4.95) and was very fresh. Good deal. The tempura was also well prepared and cheap.

Then the ramen. Oh man, I'm in love. I went from feeling like... well, like someone who had drank Four Loko -- to bliss. The broth was flavorful with a good balance of creamy to oily, the spices were perfect, good pork, the noodles just right. 

We get the check -- $25. Not a bad deal, at ALL. 

Looks like I found a new favorite Ramen joint -- no Four Loko required.
author: Jonathan M.

description: My friend and I were deciding on what to eat while strolling around Irving, and well ramen sounded good for a chilly night. We arrived before dinner time so we were seated immediately. The servers were both nice. Got the spicy mala, and it was good. The broth was flavorful, and fried chicken was crispy (eat it first and don't let it get soggy by the broth though). The noodle had good texture. However, my friend was not that happy that the egg was hard boiled, hopefully we'd get soft boiled next time. Probably a come back for me!
author: Zisele N.

description:
Came here today for lunch and had the miso ramen and chicken karrage. The noodles were firm and tender but were good. The miso broth was just okay-didn't love the flavor completely but it was not bad. The chicken karrage was yummy! Wish I could've got more!
Prices here are reasonable but cheaper than most ramen joints-$7.95 for a bowl and they have sushi and other appetizers.
Service here was friendly. The restaurant is small and they have a waiting list but we didnt have to wait long at all.
Would return again but still love Genki the best!
author: Miss H K.

description:
Spicy Garlic Miso Ramen -- SO GOOD. With a side of fried chicken (kare age) to dip into your broth, even better!

Small cute place, come during a rush and you'll have a nice wait but it goes by pretty fast as long as you don't have a huge party.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Still on our list for a weekly visit. Spicy tonkatsu ramen with egg....is something that might be what I take to the deserted island. I heard that their roll are good, but I haven't strayed from the ramen.

If you are a ramen fan, this place you find to be high on your list.
author: Gwenn G.

description: Tonkatsu ramen, fried chicken, deep fried soft shell crab - delicious!!  I'm coming back!!!
author: Charlie V.

description:
I love coming here for their Ramen. My favorite is their tonkotsu Ramen. Noodle are al dente and soup base is very flavorful too. I usually will add the egg. My friend told me that the usual way when the egg yolk is a lil' runny like the ones in Japan. That's so great... because even Dojo Ramen or Santa Ramen doesn't have their egg boiled like theirs... My sister usually gets the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen with corn... This is my go to place for a quick fix for my Ramen craving in the city. =) 
Great deal with lunch special from Mon-Fri. Ramen with either sushi or donburi.
author: Selina L.

description:
3.5 Stars. At 5:30PM, the place was super packed already. Finally got a table and the bad thing was that it was by the door. People don't shut the door when they come in, so the wind blew at my head and I was getting a major headache. I think best is if they put the waiting list outside so people don't have to come in every minute. I was freezing, so I couldn't fully enjoy my food. 

I did like the chicken karrage. 
The spicy garlic tonkatsu was good. I really like the flavor of the broth. I need to order more spicy next time. The noodles however weren't that great. The texture can be way better. 

Hubby got the regular tonkatsu and enjoyed the broth, but he agreed the noodles need to be better. 

If I'm in the area, I would come back. Just hopefully nothing by the door again, even though the place is pretty small.
author: Karen H.

description:
Out of curiosity, I found my Japanese-English dictionary and looked up "saiwaii." It doesn't exist!

I have a feeling that if there WAS such a word, it would mean something along the lines of "tasty stuffs with noodles in a tummy-warming broth." Yup!

I ended up getting the shoyu (soy sauce) ramen and, big spender that I am, I splurged and got spinach and egg. The broth was delicious and the cha-siu was totemo oishiii!! Really tender and not chewy at all! I'm glad the broth wasn't super salty like some other soy sauce based ones I've tried. My friends seemed to like their ramen and the sushi didn't seem too bad either. It was cheap for a roll...I believe less than $4! 

The service was OK. Not above and beyond, but decent. My biggest complaint is that they charge for all these extra add-ons ie my spinach and egg. It was a whole $2 extra, bringing my total close to $10 for a bowl of ramen! Boo.

I'd definitely come back here, but I wouldn't bother paying for any of the extra stuff. Heck, I could steam my own spinach, bring it in a plastic baggie, and throw it in when no one is looking! Haha kidding! But yeah, the ramen is good enough to bring me back!

Oh they have really cool spoons too! There's a little dent in it so you can rest it against your bowl. How cool?? WAY COOL. I'm sure it's not a new thing, but I've never seen it before, so it was pretty neat for me :P
author: Kei H.

description:
3.5 stars Review!

The ramen is ok here.  Not too bad but not great.  They have lunch special ($9.95 for a ramen and six pieces of sushi) which add half more star to it.

My friend got the spicy garlic tonkatsu with California rolls ($2.00 extra) and I got the tonkotsu ramen.  Both ramen were pretty good.  The soup was flavorful and not too oily.  The pork was tender.  The noodles was ok but not great.  I like the sushi, not too bad (but the rolls were too basic, hard to go wrong).  The portion of the ramen was pretty good.  Definitely can fill you up.

There was only one staff at that time and he was quick, attentive and friendly.

Am I going back?  Maybe I will try their sushi next time.
author: Liza T.

description:
I guess I always get lucky with this place because I never have to wait in line for it.

The place is pretty small so if you go during a major dining hour then you'll probably have to wait quite a while. I always see a line of people outside waiting whenever I drive down Irving. But it'll be worth it if you're craving ramen!

I always go for the miso ramen. The soup is flavorful, they add plenty of corn, and the pork belly in it is amazing! Spicy garlic tonkatsu is a pretty popular option too.

I would also recommend the fried squid legs as an appetizer. My friend tried the chicken cartilage appetizer once and she doesn't recommend it, and she described it as just deep fried chicken bones.

It's reasonably cheap too - it's around $12.50 per person including tip, and that includes a bowl of ramen and the squid leg appetizer.

If you go during lunch you can do a lunch special, such as choice of ramen with a cheap sushi roll (e.g. California roll) for $10. I probably would do this if I wasn't feeling like getting the other appetizers.

The service can be a little slow but that's because there seems to only be one waitress working here. Every time I'm here she seems like she's super busy and running around all over the place to take orders, set food, or seat new customers, but she does it with a good attitude and she's always friendly when I'm here.
author: Allen C.

description:
I've been to Saiwaii several times over the past couple of years. My overall impression is that the quality of food has been consistently declining.

I recall when I first visited Saiwaii (probably in 2011) I walked away impressed with the flavor of the broth, toppings and noodle. The next couple of times I walked away feeling happy being fed, but indifferent to the ramen itself.

Today, came for lunch and opted for a bowl of Miso ramen with a small bowl of unagi don. So, the Miso ramen comes with ONE slice of chasu pork, and various veggie toppings. I was shocked when my bowl arrived, that the ONE chasu pork slice sitting in my bowl comprised of 95% fat. Yes. FAT. :(

I would have sucked it up if there were more protein toppings in the bowl. However, considering that the one 'chasu' aka fat slice would really yield me one small bite of actual edible lean meat, I had to speak to the server. When I asked about the fat slice, I was told that that's how the meat arrived from their supplier - that sometimes they come very lean, and other times, not so much. That is all?? So disappointing!

I ended up peeling away the fat and slowly savored my ONE bite of small chasu piece, wishing for more. May I add that the unagi rice bowl was pretty underwhelming as well. The 2 thin unagi pieces lacked flavor and wasn't really too meaty. I definitely don't think it was worth the $4 price tag.

Wish I had a better meal. Saiwaii, that may have been my last here.
author: Jing D.

description:
The ramen here is probably one of the better ramen spots in San Francisco. I ordered the spicy garlic miso ramen and it was pretty good. They give you a lot of noodles, so you will definitely be full by the end of your bowl. If you like spicy, you will definitely like this broth. I usually order the medium spice for the broth, and let me tell you, it is actually a medium spicy. Order a mild spice if you just want a small kick to your broth. The pork is tender and also very tasty. Not as great as Ramen Dojo's spicy garlic broth, but it still satisfies my cravings for it. The sushi here isn't too bad either. 

I have always got seated here immediately so wait isn't a problem for me, but during 6:30-7pm on weekends, it can get crowded. Service here is okay; you may need to wave them down if you want a refill of water.
author: Vivian L.

description:
We decided to stop by Saiwaii Ramen last week. It was cold night and I was craving for something warm and soupy.

The exterior of the restaurant is a bit dark, so when we first drove by I thought it was closed. Their menu had a mix of ramen, sushi, rice plates and appetizers. I ordered the Miso Ramen w/ pork belly and my BF ordered the spicy broth (forgot the name!)- we also ordered the special california roll which came with unagi. 

The pork belly was really good and the soup was pretty thick- something i'm not really used to yet. The noodles were a bit undercooked. I'd have to agree with Jason G. and recommend passing on the sushi. It was something that I could have easily made at home myself and the price definitely wasnt really worth it. I remember looking at their sushi menu and the prices were high compared to all other sushi restaurants i've been to.
author: M W.

description: Right next to GG park is the best ramen I've ever had. It's dreamy! Spicy pork tonkotsu for $8. Amazing! I have to drive 5 hours just to get more.
author: Carson J.

description:
Before our weekly boba trip to Tea Way we decided to get some food. Saiwaii Ramen was only a block away and for a blistering cold May day, ramen seemed like the perfect dinner choice.

What we ordered:
*Tonkatsu Ramen with Chicken Karage-broth was really good and the perfect amount of spice. For $3 extra and only 4 pieces of chicken, it felt a little like extortion, would definitely not order the "add on" again

*Super California Roll (california roll with eel)-what you would expect, nothing spectacular but not horrible
*Spicy Tuna Roll-same as the california roll
*Croquette-very good, but then again, i love croquette
*Spicy Crab appetizer-too salty and overpriced

The food here was decent but I would say on the expensive side. If you stick with just the basic ramen though you'll be fine, just don't order off the sushi menu or the appetizers.......
author: Betty C.

description: Pretty good ramen -- got the spicy garlic tonkotsu and it was sooooo filling. Their apps menu looks super legit too, will need to return. Staff's very nice. I hear it's usually packed but early weekday for me was quite empty.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Saiwaii is my forever go-to ramen place!! It won my heart after I ate the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen. That is a must get!!! It's broth is super rich and almost buttery. It's creaminess is complimented nicely by the spicy, garlicky broth. Mmm...

 I'm drooling just thinking about it.
author: Chia W.

description:
We got the pork based ramen. It was pretty delicious. It was nicely seasoned and not too salty.

However, it would be even better if they didn't charge for every side. Bamboo shots, corn, etc all cost additional $1. The ramen also really need a nice hard-boiled egg.
author: Margaret R.

description:
I have gone here twice and I like the the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen. I have tasted the spicy miso, it's good but not as savory as the tonkotsu though I'm biased because I'm not a big miso fan)

The first time I opted for the regular spice due to advisory of a friend, but I knew she was a weenie and I definitely wished it was a little spicier, and as you guess it, the spicy was the perfect level for me!

I thought the topping portion was a nice size since there is a lot in there. The pork belly though fatty is delicious, it melts right in your mouth and there is enough fixin's of seaweed and bamboo to go around in every bite.


*NOTE! the cons!

I do however think $1 for additional toppings is a bit much especially because some toppings def don't add up to that amount. I didn't get it but butter as a topping for $1 more that's kinda nuts!

Also, there are no vegetarian options, so it sucks that I would not be going here with my boyfriend. They definitely should try and have one ramen dish or at least featured vegetarian once a week or something.

The other thing is I have noticed a long sitting wait for food. The second time I didn't get a roll and it we waited 40 minutes for just our bowls or ramen. we were maybe the third party of two to arrive since they just opened for dinner. 

~~~
Overall though, I thought they were very nice, lots of water refills and checking in on us if we needed anything. I definitely enjoyed my meals and would come back again
author: Chloe A.

description: I ordered the tonkotsu ramen here and the broth is SO GOOD! Along with the kelp, everything was fresh and super yummy!
author: Ivy T.

description:
Delicious! Best shoyu ramen I've had in awhile, and I've been to a bunch of spots! 
Everyone else at the table got the spicy tonkatsu and looovvveeddd it! 
Decent prices, and the spot is kinda small (maybe 30 seats total) but great food!
Another thing I like is the Ramen combo, where you can get a mini donburi of tuna, curry or unagi on the side. 
Also everyone is very nice with good service!
author: Miss F.

description:
Striking this off my list of Ramen spots in the city. I'll admit I'm pretty fussy since I used to eat at Ramen Dojo all the time, and in my opinion have never had ramen anywhere that comes close..so!
This was really lacking in flavor. We ordered the Spicy garlic tonkatsu, hamachi nigiri, chicken hearts, chicken gizzards and fried soft shell crab. We were hungry. Every single dish apart from the nigiri which was good, was underflavored. Even the soft shell crab was too oily and lacked flavor. The chicken heart and gizzards were the right consistency but so under-seasoned that we had to dip them in soy sauce to just add some flavor. Meh. Not worth a visit.
author: Koshika S.

description: That's a Chinese operated restaurant, not a Japanese ramen restaurant. I ordered a pork favor ramen. The soup is not the traditional Japanese pork ramen soup. It cooks by the soup powder which just likes the one you used on Asian style instant noodles. Also the  noddles is really bad. It is not supposed to have in a ramen restaurant. I won't go there again.
author: Kent W.

description: Love this place! If i could I would give it 6 stars. I used to live in the area and it quickly became a favorite spot. Awesome ramen and fabulous sushi! What else can one ask for?
author: Mali E.

description:
Small, reasonable priced ramen. The "regular" spicy garlic tonkotsu broth is actually really spicy. If I'm back again, I'd probably try the mild version.

They also have a sushi menu and surprisingly, they have uni and ankimo! The uni was okay quality. I tried a california roll & I think they use real crab in it, so that's a plus.

They leave the door open so there are kind of a lot of flies & bugs that go inside. Kind of gross while you're eating.
author: Alysha K.

description:
Decent tasting ramen for San Francisco.  I would come here if I had a decent ramen craving.  It wasn't too bad on a Tuesday night, but I did notice there was a wait shortly after we arrived.

I got the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen, with corn.  Like 2-3 pieces of meat, and ample noodles.  Haven't tried the rolls but may next time!
author: Adele Z.

description:
So i come in on a Sunday afternoon, not a long wait. Told the waitress 'This is my first time here, what do you recommend'.  I had two appetizers and pork ramen (add corn). Few mins later the ramen comes out first, I say to the waitress 'where is the appetizers?' She says it's coming...of course i'm hungry looking at that bowl of ramen.  

Surprisingly, the two apps never came out...stupid First impressions! 

Good news is the waitress stayed calm and smiled and i felt held her tongue. Yes, if it wasn't for her...i would have not consider coming back a second time. Ramen was ok. Broth was good not too salty but the corn i can taste was a little frozen - YUCK! 

Most likely will give this place a 2nd try in the future...hopefully the cooks will get a clue...appetizers first before the entrees!
author: Thomas C.

description:
I love ramen. Let me repeat that. I Love ramen!

I heard this place was good. Some good comments here and there about not having to go down to Santa (in San Mateo) or other great ramen spots in the south bay. No more long drives to get my ramen fix, ya know. I was excited to know that there is a good ramen place located close by.

I went there with my Mom and Sis on a chilly rainy day. No better time for a nice hot bowl of soup made of pig juices and meat, yummy toppings, and oodles of noodles. Nice place, clean, kinda cozy, nice waitress. There's even anime playing. The menu has good selections, as it also has sushi or donburi if you like, though ramen is the main thing there of course.

The ramen. It was good, solid, but to me...just O-K. Nothing more, nothing less. I dunno, I just didn't taste "it" when you sip that nice pork broth. When I think of ramen, I think of all the love that goes into it. The hours and hours and hours of boiling the piggy parts with other ingredients to get that nice taste in the soup. I like to see at least a little oil blotches floating in the soup. Some sort of slight weight in the soup. With this place, I didn't see any, nor did I taste anything special.

Mind you that I am not bashing this place. It's a good place for ramen, and I'll probably go here every once in awhile. But I'm just saying that I had much much better. I just wasn't impressed is all.

What is cool is that you can add things that I have not seen at other ramen places, such as the duck. Kudos for that. Kudos also for the noodles...this place does it the way I like..aldente.

What I ordered: typical chasu with the miso base. I added the miso duck and corn. I think I ordered extra noodles(?) also.

Paolo says: Solid ramen. Make a trip down the block to Teaway afterwards. Yummers.
author: Paolo V.

description:
Spicy Garlic Miso Ramen! 

Delicious! Tasted better than Ramen DOJO! 
Not as fancy but still tastier! 

Saiwai Roll- tasty as well, fresh tasting scallop.
author: Helen Y.

description:
A friend of mine mentioned to me that a ramen place was opening up in her hood so naturally i had to go and check it out because i love ramen and am always on the hunt for new Ramen places. We got there around 7p and there was a handful of people but it was not overly crowded and we didn't have to wait. I was a bit skeptical since i admit i read some yelp reviews before i came in and didn't really have high expectations about Saiwaii. 

She got the miso Ramen and i got the Tonkatsu Ramen, we also got the tori kaarage for an appetizer. The Tori Kaarage was good, lightly fried and very hot on the inside, while the ramen left me wanting something more. What i mean is that the broth had a decent flavor to it but it was missing something....that something to make me go WOOW now this is some good broth. I did like the texture of the chewy noodles but this ramen was only average to me. My friend didn't like her Miso Ramen very much and she ended up not finishing it. Service was good, they came around to fill our tea and water as much as they could. 

Overall this place was only average to me, i would be willing to come back if they improved the flavor of their broth and stopped charging so much to add in extras, i mean 3 bucks to add pork belly??
author: Jonathan W.

description: Is it weird that I rate a ramen place by their karage? Well not only is the karage yummy but the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen is soooo good! We got our food pretty quick and the service is awesome. Friendly waitresses and clean restaurant... All around goodness! I'm satisfied, full, and very happy!
author: Shirlene M.

description:
Yum! When i woke up after a night of drinking, I was craving something soupy. So we Chose the closest ramen place near us that was open. 

We were seated immediately. But a few minutes later, it started filling up. 

I got the spicy garlic pork ramen with corn. Yum! I didn't go too spicy though bc my tummy was still feeling unsettled from the night before. the flavor was great though!! 

My bf got the regular pork ramen with egg but I thought the broth was too salty. The egg was good though! 

I would come here again.
author: Elaine L.

description: Ramen was good. Better the next day. Wings were good.  All in all a 4 star restaurant. But when we asked for a bag to help carry our 3 leftover containers they said it would be another $0.25. We said sure, even though there is a clear exception to the bag law which states that it doesn't apply to doggy bags (only take out). But they don't add the fee to the credit card and instead come yell at us for a freaking quarter. We had to dig all over the place to find a quarter for a shitty cheap $0.02 bag. The experience ruined the meal.  They need to work on their customer service big time.
author: reza n.

description:
I'm always down to try new ramen shops even though a few of my friends warned me of the ok broth.  I wanted to see for myself what this place was all about.

It's rare to find a ramen shop in the Sunset so I didn't have high expectations, but am super happy that it's something different from the usual Chinese restaurants on Irving.

It looks small and not that inviting on the outside (but that's the entire block), but it's really warm and cozy inside.  Nice wooden decor, big flat screen tv in front of the kitchen.  

We sat two tables back from the TV and it was the perfect spot to watch the Giants game (I'm an A's fan, but I got love for the Bay!).

Our server was really nice and attentive.

We ordered the grilled Ika, gyoza, EXTRA spicy garlic miso, tonkatsu, and one miso with extra half egg.

I LOVED the Ika!  It was smaller than I'm use to seeing at izakayas, but none the less still better than my last experience at Ippuku in Berkeley.  It had a perfect char flavor, and was not over or under cooked.  It was served with a side of fresh grounded ginger and lemon.  I'm not a big fan of ginger, but it went perfectly with the Ika and a squeeze of lemon.

Gyoza-I didn't try it, but my friend ate the entire order himself lol

EXTRA Spicy garlic miso ramen-it wasn't as spicy as I thought it would be and it was just missing something.  The noodles were curly so I had my suspicions as to whether it was fresh ramen, but nonetheless it had a nice texture.  The broth was so so, but it got better and better as I took each bite.  Finally at the end I felt a wave of spice hit me.  I guess I should have mixed my ramen first instead of digging in right away (I was really hungry!).

Tonkatsu broth-it was ok, it could be richer. 

Miso-It was ok.  But my friends mom said it was too salty for her.  I told her that it's just the way ramen is.  In Japan it's even saltier!

*for side of egg, it's only half an egg so that was kind of a bummer :(

Overall the experience was 4 stars, decor 4 stars, service 5 stars, food 3.5 stars because I know the broth can be better.  I'll definitely give it another shot, but I hope I can give it 4 stars for the ramen and not just the service next time.
author: Michelle S.

description:
I've wanted to try Saiwaii for a couple of weeks now, but each time I drove by, there seemed to be some sort of line or group waiitng out in front!  Normally, I don't have a problem waiting in line for a place, but admittedly, it's a little harder when it's frigid cold out here in the Sunset.  In other parts of the city, it gets warm, but it doesn't happen all that often out this way.  Generally, we have rainy/foggy, cold, and colder.  It's actually not that bad, and I like it at times...provided that I'm not standing in place for too long.

Finally ended up coming here last night for a late dinner with my coworker though, and it was de-licious!  Their menu looks somewhat modest at a glance, but they actually have a lot crammed in there - ramen, appetizers, donbori, and sushi.  On a related sidenote: agree that it seems there are a lot of tables squeezed in (which makes me wonder if those were lines I saw or just people loitering), but I've seen worse.  A LOT worse.

As for the ramen, you actually have the choice of four basic types, each with a different type of broth (shoyu, miso, shio, and tonkatsu).  However, they also have a list of assorted items you can also add to make your ramen just like how you want it (half an egg, pork belly, etc).  I opted for the tonkatsu ramen since I don't see that broth on menus as often as the others, and my coworker did the same but with half an egg in hers.  I thought the broth was really good...not really greasy or overly salty, yet flavorful.  To me, that was the best part of it...the noodles are fresh, and I liked all of the ingredients, but the broth won me over.  The only knock I can find is that the meat is slightly dry, but not something I would hold against them in particular.  It's bound to happen any where if you let the meat sit in the hot broth too long, so it's not something unique to just this place.  Sidenote II: Heard they tweaked their ramen recipe since they first opened, so if you've been already and are reading this, might want to try it again...

Feeling pretty hungry, I decided to make it a combo by adding a mini unagi don for another $3.  I thought it would mean getting a smaller ramen, but I was wrong.  Their bowl of ramen is pretty generous by itself, so my unagi don was completely unnecessary (other than making me look like I eat a ton).  The unagi don came in a neat little bowl (for some reason, I really liked it), filled with a good sized piece of unagi, sauce and rice, with a bit of ginger on the side.  The unagi was cooked perfectly for me, and I didn't notice any of those thorny bones you tend to find.  There's maybe a little too much rice, but for $3 it's worth it if you're pretty hungry.

Service was great, as not just one person tended to our table and they were always on top of filling our tea cups.  I'll definitely be back...cute and friendly waitresses, tasty tonkatsu broth, close proximity to home, and a load of options to add into my ramen?  Why yes, I would like some more...thanks Saiwaii!
author: Mike L.

description: The spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen is really delicious! The noodles are very filling and firm. Cute place, I would definitely go back!
author: Tammy T.

description:
Um, does anyone else think that this place is a fire hazard? I swear they pack SO many tables in here, you're doomed if a fire breaks out. Our table of 4 was literally 6 inches away from another table of 2 so we were able to hear everything and anything that was discussed. I should have made new friends this way but I was way too annoyed to even begin to think about anything but "GET ME OUT OF HERE!!"

A regular bowl of ramen is $8. If you add an egg, that's an extra dollar. If you add pork belly, that's an extra $3. if you add corn, there's another dollar out of your pocket. So really, if you want a normal bowl of ramen w/ all its normal fixings, you're looking at a $15 bowl. Really? 

I got the tonkatsu ramen combo. Combo = ramen + some kinda rice bowl (unagi don, ten don, etc). I wanted to switch out the bamboo shoots in my tonkatsu ramen for corn, but the lady said she could take out the bamboo, add the corn but still charge me $1. Really? Woman, the bamboo and corn cost the same on the menu so why can't I just get an even exchange? Sheesh!

Here's why I gave this place 2 stars.
- Tonkatsu broth was pretty bland
- My friend's katsu curry was dry
- Felt rushed by the servers
- The flavor of the canned bamboo shoots over powered the soup
- WAY TOO PACKED IN HERE
- WAY TOO PACKED IN HERE
- WAY TOO PACKED IN HERE

Since this place just opened, I'll give it a few more months to work out it's kinks before returning.
author: Heidi C.

description:
Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu is the best one here! This is a good ramen place in SF by far because I've have tried many ramen places in SF and some were not that good. Every time I go here, I always tell myself to get something new instead of spicy garlic tonkatsu. LOL. The broth is so flavorful and delicious. 

Aside from the ramen, they also have sushi and small dish. I love their chicken karage. It is so crispy and so good! 

I will definitely come back to try their other ramen flavor.
author: Nhung C.

description:
This review is only for the one thing I tried on the menu because I listened to yelp reviews and Foursquare tips, which told me that their other items were just okay.

The Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu ramen is really good.  The noodles are softer, not that chewy if care about the type of noodle you get.  I typically prefer a little chewier, but this wasn't bad.

There are bits of fried garlic that garnish the bowl of noodles.  The smell of garlic just permeates every nook of your nasal passage and make you feel like you're steaming in a room of garlic.  I loved every bit of it.  I got regular spicy and didn't find it too spicy, so don't be afraid to try the regular spicy!  The broth was very flavorful and rich, but not oil.  

Add the soft boiled egg for a $1 extra!
author: Anna T.

description:
We were able to get reservations for this location so we essentially walked in and were seated within a few minutes rather than having to wait 20-30 minutes for a seat.

The appetizers we got were: karaage, fried oysters, and some sushi. Here's the order our meal came in:

Karaage, sushi, ramen, ramen, fried oysters. Huh? Everything arrived fairly quickly and out of order, which was a little strange. 

The karaage was definitely over breaded with flour instead of panko and the first piece I bit into had a temperature of "warm" or "cooling off", which was really disappointing. Subsequent pieces tasted hot off the deep fryer, but I couldn't help but notice that every piece was undercooked and was very pink on the inside. I'd probably skip the karaage next time and just go to Quickly a few doors down for some popcorn chicken.

The oysters were tasty and consisted of four pieces -- less than we expected for the price paid. Breading on the fried oysters was definitely better than on the karaage.

Sushi was alright, nothing stood out.

The ramen was OK. I had the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu and my girlfriend had the regular Tonkotsu. Though mine was ordered 'mild', I really couldn't taste anything in my broth other than garlic and spices. My girlfriend's, on the other hand, was rich with bone marrow. She wasn't a fan of the garlic taste in her broth, however.

The eggs were completely overcooked for my taste. I usually expect eggs with my ramen to be softboiled, the way Orenchi makes them. Here? Not so much. Definitely hardboiled here.

The pork in our ramen was thinly sliced (love it), but was very slippery and fatty (felt like fatty bacon slices, not good). Noodles are a bit thin for my liking, but to be fair I've had much thinner ramen noodles at other places before.

We live in the Inner Sunset just a few minutes' walk (or just about a minute's drive) from this place. It's nice to know we have a fallback in case neither of us feels like cooking, waiting for delivery, eating at other places in the city, or even making the drive to Orenchi in Santa Clara.
author: Richard K.

description: I love their ramen!!! The soup is good and I like their chewy ramen. But sometimes they are under staff so they have tables open but people are still waiting outside
author: Carmen M.

description:
I still have yet to find that great ramen shop (so if you recommend one, let me know!)

Though we came relatively late for lunch hours on a weekend, we were seated pretty quickly. I ordered a Tonkatsu Ramen with no additions. Service was pretty quick, but the flavors of the base and quantity of the ingredients were slightly lacking.

The lighting's very...dim, but it's a calming type of dim. Seating is very cozy here, and it tends to get a bit loud in this small shop.
author: Bonita K.

description: Saiwaii Ramen is decent but isn't the best, I would come here when I'm in the area but I don't crave for it. I had the tonkotsu ramen (pork flavor), and it looked great but the soup was a little bland. I added a lot of chili oil and chili powder to make it more flavorful.  I added pork belly for $3.50 which took the ramen to the next level.  I was glad that I added the pork belly.  My friends also ordered the chicken wings (4 pieces) but I didn't get to try one because there wasn't enough to go around. =(
author: John S.

description:
Just wanted to let you know that I did get 10% off because I have known the owner from before.

Stick with the ramen because everything else was just not that good.    I would actually come back for the ramen.  The servers were slow and inexperienced.  Borderline, very awkward and uncomfortable.  The sushi was a little pricey.  12.95 for a Dragon roll.  After tax, it comes out to roughly 2 dollars a bite.  I would probably lower that cost or just don't serve sushi at all.

Lets break it down

I had the combo shoyu ramen with chicken tonkatsu curry, my friend had the tonkatsu curry, and we shared a dragon roll.

Shoyu ramen.  This by itself will not fill you up.  It comes with 3 pieces of pork, seaweed, and green onion.  Very simple.  Broth was good, not the best I have ever had and the pork was ok.  They have an option for you to add more stuff like eggs, noodles, bbq pork, etc.  They will try to ala carte you on everything.  Smart for the business owner............bad for the consumers.  I'm personally used to having an egg and all the fixings accompany this 7.95 bowl of ramen.  

The chicken and tonkatsu curry was good.  Breaded very lightly but the curry sauce just didn't work for me.  Very light, no heat, and sweet.  I don't like sweet curries.

The infamous 12.95 dragon roll.  I remember these things use to be 7 bucks and I was still complaining.  If a roll cost more than an entree, then you figure it should fill you up right?  

Bottom line..............stick with the ramen.
author: jason g.

description:
Returned after having been contacted by the owner. Was impressed by the sincerity of his communications and decided to give it another chance.

This time, my experience was the complete opposite of my first visit. The owner's lovely wife came to the restaurant specifically to look after us and to oversee our meal. The chef, Yo-san, came by a few times to see if our food was fine. Actually, I was a bit embarrassed by the extra attention lavished on us. But this just goes to show that they pay attention to what their customers are saying and that they take a proactive approach to correct operational mistakes.

Now on to the food: had the spicy garlic miso ramen. It was apparently well-prepared, had depth of flavor and, very important to me, no MSG. (I didn't feel thirsty or woozy after the meal.) The noodles were good, but I prefer mine on the al dente side. But very tasty and sizable portion. 

However, where they shined were in their appetizers. I really enjoyed the succulent chicken karaage, the seaweed (?) with fish cake and something they had just concocted that evening - unagi wrapped in pastry. In other words, they're trying to create a quality menu that isn't merely focused on the ramen, trying their hand at experimentation and actually succeeding. 

Not bad for a "neighborhood" restaurant.

I live on the other side of town so I probably won't make it here as often as I'd like... but I could see myself coming out of my way to come here just because of my last experience. (It was on a weeknight so they weren't so busy.)

This time, I'm glad I was proven wrong.
author: Es E.

description:
The Ramen is A-OK here, I find it pretty salty and overpriced IMO. Don't know why the wait for this place is long, it's not that good. You have to go to Japantown or San Mateo for better quality Ramen. However, staff is friendly but Ramen is Meh.

- Spicy garlic tonkatsu - dry meat, salty broth. Over priced.
author: Julia K.

description:
I went there today right after the lunch rush and there happens to be one waitress. She told me that there is no need to sign up to wait for a table but we waited for a good 10 minutes before I decided to leave.

There were some empty tables. She would avoid our gaze to help them with their bills but not seat my boyfriend and I. 

Sooooo.... like a hungry hippo I am, I decided to leave because I despise waiting when there are empty but dirty tables around. Plus, a party of cute old Asian American ladies left right after us as well. 

We brought the party to a Thai restaurant instead.
author: Karry D.

description:
I'd give 5 stars, but I pretty much only order one thing, so I'm hedging a bit.

Anyway, that thing is the spicy garlic tonkotsu (note: tonkotsu and tonkatsu are two totally different things).  I order it mild because I have nothing to prove, and because it's more delicious that way.

I also get an extra egg because there is no food that cannot be made more delicious by adding egg.
author: Ian S.

description:
I am on a huge ramen kick right now.  And Saiwaii did not disappoint.  I liked that they had a wide variety of items, just in case you weren't in the mood.  I would have given 4 stars but once we sat down and got situated they asked us to move, and then their beer was flat.  don't order a pitcher, there's something wrong with it.  All head and then flat. 
The ramen was good though, and i ordered pork belly extra for it.  YUM!!  All a little pricey but i was satisfied and it hit the spot.  I can't wait to go back to try their sushi or little dons.  yum!!
author: Susan Z.

description:
A Tuesday evening right around 5pm (opening time) isn't too busy to try out Saiwaii; my brother and I were running errands along this stretch of Irving and saw that Saiwaii finally opened. So, we went inside.

The service was very kind and accommodating. Our teacups were filled regularly and they took away our empty plates in a prompt manner. 

Saiwaii's menu is simple yet still emphasizes the unique offering of ramen on this side of town. There are also sushi (makimono), appetizers, and salads. 

The shoyu ramen was pretty tasty with firm noodles and a crisp broth. My brother tried the Tuna Poki Salad, which looked delicious to me. I liked the heavy bowl the ramen was served in.

Saiwaii's atmosphere is chic yet casual with the large-screen TV broadcasting the Food Network and local radio playing over the intercom. The place definitely has an American feel to it, but the food is distinctly Japanese.

Cards are accepted. 

I'll be back soon!
author: Helene K.

description:
I am a fan of ramen, and Saiwaii did not disappoint!

Try the tonkatsu spicy ramen with pork belly if you're looking for a shotgun blast to face worth of flavors.

Try the spicy miso if you're more into the subtle, lighter tasting ramens.

Lots of ingredients you can add, plus they offer a pretty decent menu for sushi!

Their togo option is sweet; you get plastic soup containers which you will probably need unless you want to drill new holes into that leather belt!

Place does get crowded though, expect some wait time and zero parking.  But hey, it's San Francisco, so tough titties!
author: Christopher N.
