description: I ordered the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen in an extra spice version. It was amazing. I eat of LOT of spicy food (like real spicy) and I had tears in my eyes. So only order the extra spicy tonkotsu if you are ok with that or (in my case) were dying for that feeling! The tonkotsu was great too. Exactly what I had in mind
author: Malvika A.

description:
3.5 Stars seems spot on for this place. 

First the ambiance - It's another one of those crowded tiny SF places with communal seating. There are 3 sets of tables that can seat 6, 1 set for a couple, then a long table that can fit maybe 10. 

Now the food:

- Shoyu Ramen w/egg - I wanted something lighter than tonkotsu so I went with Shoyu. The noodles itself was chewy and good. The Chashu pieces were buttery and delicious, but a bit overwhelming after a while. Lots and lots of fat. The broth was good, but too "deep". I was expecting something a bit more clear and refreshing, but it felt a bit too heavy for shoyu.

- Tonkotsu ramen w/egg and pork cubes - Unless you just really love pork fat, I would recommend against this. Not only if the broth super fatty (but pretty good) the chashu is also fatty and the pork cubes are EVEN FATTIER. On top of that, they are marinated with a sweet flavor which kind of throws off all the other flavors. I know it looks good in pictures but I thought these were way too rich considering all the ramen already come with super rich chashu. 

-Chicken Karaage - Standard chicken karaage. Good. For comparison, Himawari's in San Mateo was better though.

- Add on small Unagi don - Disappointment. In the pictures they look like http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/saiwaii-ramen-san-francisco-3?select=VfF1fmlw6gF6r-P4UmQGbA#An46_qfa37VN0-XmSoGBEQ, but what I got was little filets that they probably use for unagi sushi. If that was the case, i would have just gotten the unagi sushi since it's cheaper. The texture and taste was all off and I felt jipped. I don't know if it's a fluke since all the other yelp pictures on here look like how it should look, but that is not what I got. 

Overall the meal was pretty good but left a bit to be desired. I think with time they can become one of the better ramen joints in the city.
author: Julie K.

description:
Pretty disappointed with the ramen here. I ordered the Tonkatsu, and tried the Spicy garlic Tonkatsu broths. The tonkatsu broth had a really strong pork smell/flavor, but not the good kind. It wasn't the kind that was full of flavor, rather it was like a stinch of pork broth that maybe was from not so good meat, or had been sitting out for a while and reheated. The spicy garlic tonkatsu wasn't much better, was the same thing with a garlic flavor and some spice. The noodles were done well, however with the lack of a good solid broth, it didn't help the entire ramen experience.

Strangely, the california roll (that comes with the $10 ramen lunch special) was decent. It had "real" crab meat, although it seemed like it was mixed with some imitation crab meat. The spicy tuna cut rolls were just whatevers.

If you want good ramen, go to Izakaya Sozai... which is down the block.
author: Alex R.

description: Ordered the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu and it only came with two slices of pork and no egg! Come on! Really, for over $12 including tax at least give a few more slices! Two slices, that's just terrible! Never coming back here again.
author: Lyn B.

description:
Wavering on a 3 * or 4* review. I like that the location is near a bunch of other fun shops, so it gets a retail boost. Short story--ramen here is not bad, other fun things to eat too. 

While waiting outside for a table for two, I read the article taped to the window. It mentions the American city bastions for good ramen -- Los Angeles, New York...why isn't SF one of them? A good question. Why do most people say "eh...ramen you say?" I wish i knew the answer. I've tried to look for good ramen all over the city, but most of the time it falls short of my wildly high expectations. A lot of the tonkotsu broths have that collagen-rich thick flavor to the soup, but they lack a brightness that keeps you wanting to devour more. The same goes for this joint. I tried the regular tonkotsu ramen (maybe different if i had gotten the spicy garlic? may need to return), and it was above average. the pork belly bits were good...but I didn't jump up and exclaim '~uMaaai!'*

The tempura donburi had an excellently fried up shrimp, though I wish there were more sauce and crisper vegetables. The sushi was alright, not bad, not great. I'd go back if I was in the neighborhood and felt like some hot ramen on a cold day. Still, probably in the mid-to-upper tier of ramen for SF.

*i have this vision of jumping and just yelling "taaaaaasty" and drinking up the broth in both hands, but it's probably better that i don't as i would likely burn myself
author: Jade L.

description: This place is good, but the flavors are quite different, well at least for my palate. I wouldn't say this is the best place, but definitely not the worst. There was a reason why we waited for an hour to sit on a weekend.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
Came here because a friend said this place was comparable to Santa Ramen, it isn't. The place is small like when Santa was still on B street. We had kids so we all just squeezed in. 

The place calls it's self a ramen place, but their selection of ramen was limited. They were selling sushi and everything else. They had only a limited amount of ramens to chose from (miso, shio, shoyu, tonkotsu). I got myself the which was OK, the Miso was lacking in flavor.
author: M C.

description:
Wow!  The flavors were spectacular.  Definitely a place to keep coming back to.  I haven't had ramen this good, ever!

They have a mushroom appetizer that is a perfect start to some really good ramen.
author: Anthony R.

description:
My favorite local sushi/Japanese restaurant. The owner Cindy is awesome and the new place in south city should be epic. 

Ramen is great. Went full apps tonight. Mushroom Torio is highly recommended. And I hate mushrooms. This dish is awesome. Their special tako salads the make from time to time or awesome.  Can't go wrong with any menu item. Great service. Friendly to both familiar and new guests. GO!
author: Patrick W.

description:
We came here as a group of 3 not knowing what we wanted to eat so decided to try this place. 

Spicy tonkatsu ramen - ok. Hubby had this and didnt say much about it
tontatsu ramen - friend had this and said it was Ok
Spicy Mala - I had this and thought it was a little too spicy. Don't get me wrong, I love spicy food. But to a certain degree.

Chicken karaage was not good. It had too much batter. All I tasted was batter.

Soft shell crab: different, but nothing to write home about. It was soft shell crab over a bed of salad with spicy sauce. All you can taste is the heat. I could not taste the crab for the life of me. I question if its even soft shell crab!!?? Ok it was cuz it looked like it, but I really could not taste it.  I think this is the same with my ramen. I feel like they overused the spiciness to hide the flavor of everything. I couldn't taste anything except spicy. 

The boys' final verdict for the night was not good.
author: Mai H.

description:
What the fuck! The spicy tuna has no tuna. It's just hella spicy sauce and cucumber.

The ramen was alright, I guess. After the spicy tuna, you kind of give up hope on the rest of the food.
author: Stacy C.

description:
Great! We had the lunch special so got sushi and ramen for a couple bucks off. I added the pork belly and oh my gosh- it was amazing. 

Not only was the food great- the service was great. The woman serving everyone was friendly, polite, and attentive. We had a wonderful experience. Loved it :)
author: Krystal P.

description:
very small place in the neighborhood that gets the job done. they turn tables around so fast here. the karage is quite good, as is their garlic pork tonkatsu ramen. izakaya sozai and ramen parlor are still my favorite places for ramen, but you know, when i have the opportunity to walk somewhere for dinner, i appreciate it. haven't had their sushi at all or any of their donburi. i eat at other places for quality sushi. can't be that bad though. especially since their other food items normally hit the spot. they also have this fried calamari that looks soooooo good! must order next time. 

good for a quick dinner on a cold night.
author: Thao T.

description: I had the spicy garlic miso ramen for lunch, perfect amount of heat without taking away the favors... Corn, pork belly sliced thin, seaweed and green onion w/ add on egg ^o^
author: jonathan h.

description:
FOOD
1.) Tonkatsu = yum! Pretty good mmm pork nice n soft, soup yummy, finished the whole bowl to the empty bottom
2.) quail egg tobiko - yummyy who knew raw quail egg would taste so good

SERVICE
Very friendly n attentive :)

ATMOSPHERE
small basic casual nice
author: Angela L.

description:
So of course San Francisco isn't really gonna give you those nice warm summer nights... So what better way to deal with a chilly night in August than with ramen?

Ordered the tonkatsu ramen based off of what yelpers had recommended and was not disappointed at all. The only problem I ever have with ramen is that sometimes, the noodles are really long so I end up eating big portions at a time cause I don't have the control and patience to cut up the noodles on my own. Pretty sure I ate that ramen in record time... Whoops! 

Also got the gyoza as an appetizer and that was really good as well. 

Bonus points goes to the waiter cause he was super friendly and just gave a very warm vibe. Service was also quick.
author: Steph W.

description:
Has never really been the biggest fan of ramen but the spicy garlic tonkatsu definitely has won me over. The broth that comes with this ramen soup is so deliciously intense that it comes out of your pores instantly. I believe that this soup beats pho after a night of heavy drinking the night before. 

Aside from it being a little overpriced and a very long wait for a ramen to go, I definitely recommend coming here even for take out. Also place is very small and cramped.
author: Kristoff F.

description: Ramen was good and broth was flavorful but a bit too salty for our tastes. Yet the portions were generous, it was well priced, and the pork belly was good! That bumped it up to 4 stars
author: Michael Y.

description:
Good -- not great -- but good. We've been here multiple times now and so can speak from experience. Service is quick and usually pretty pleasant. Ambiance is casual; you may have to squeeze past tables a bit to get to a booth seat.

Ramen: Loaded with toppings (yay!). Decent flavor, though not as rich as I'd like. Noodles, while good, aren't stellar.

Sushi: Decent. Rice isn't the best. I recommend the Alaska roll (CA roll topped with salmon) -- those carefully cut wedges of lemon on top add a burst of freshness. I would steer clear of the poke salad; the dressing was way too salty and sour (almost like straight-up soy sauce). Overall, it's the type of sushi you'd expect to get for the prices you pay.

There are some nights where it's exactly what I want/need, and other nights where it's just alright. If you have a ramen or sushi craving, this place will hold you over.
author: Julie D.

description:
Came here by accident on a Saturday night. The 3 things that I look for in ramen is 1) broth, 2) soft boiled egg, and 3) thick noodles. It hit home on the soft boiled egg but the broth and noodles didn't stand out. 

We had the ika fry and chicken karage too and that was pretty good. But anything fried is yummy so... 

Will prolly try other places before coming back here.
author: Cynthia C.

description: Got the spicy miso tonkatsu ramen. Great flavor all around. First time trying any ramen.   The garlic chips were way to burnt for my taste. The spicy tuna rolls was good!!
author: Jesse D.

description:
Sometimes, just typing in "food" on Yelp and going to the closest appetizing restaurant turns out to be the perfect choice. That's exactly what occured to my girlfriend and I as we walked down Irving on a cold, windy night. We both thought some hot ramen would thaw us out from a typical SF night, so we found ourselves here at Saiwaii Ramen. 

On a street crowded with restaurants, Saiwaii actually had a waitlist. That was probably my first sign that Yelp wasn't leading us astray. Didn't have to wait long though, as we were seated within 5 minutes. I ordered myself the Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen, while my girlfriend got her usual Shio Ramen. Although the wait time for the food was longer than usual, I can excuse them for that since the restaurant was crowded at the time. I'd rather have a well prepared meal, than something hastily prepared and flung out the kitchen. And well prepared it was. It might have just been the cold weather, but I swear I have never seen a bowl of ramen with so much steam pouring out the bowl. The taste itself was amazing. Perfect broth that was not over saturated by spiciness, and some of the tenderest pork that I've had to date. It was literally breaking off of my chopsticks. In comparison to the taste of the many other ramen shops I've been to around the Bay, Sawaii definitely ranks among the top.

The portion size could be argued as small by some, but for me, it was perfect. I felt that if the portion size were any bigger, then I would have felt overstuffed, and if it were any smaller, then I would have been hungry still. I finished my entire bowl and most of the broth, and I felt just fine afterwards. The service was really nice as well, although everything was a little rushed due to the crowd.

There are a few negatives though. First off, the front door is heavy, and it slams pretty violently. The first time it happened, I was the one to let go of the door, under the assumption that it would just slowly fall into place. Nope, it crashed. I probably jumped a good foot. Although, the good part is that I got to watch the same exact thing happen to every other person that came into the restaurant that night. Another thing is that since the restaurant itself is small, they have to cramp in as many tables as they can fit, as to accommodate the most amount of people. There was around a foot of space in between our table and the table right next to us, and I had the displeasure of trying to squeeze my way in that gap without bumping tables. I kind of failed at that all night, and I'm just an average sized guy. I'd hate to see how someone a little bigger would manage. 

In all though, it's nice to finally get to try out another ramen place in SF. Good ramen is hard enough to find when looking for it, so for being a random Yelp search, Sawaii turned out to be one of those chance encounters that I won't soon forget.
author: Sean H.

description:
Decent Ramen especially their lunch specials. 

quality is a 3.75/5 but definitely worth trying if you're in the neighborhood!

Had to give them a 3 stars, here's why"

I got here at Noon one day waiting outside for 20 minutes and finally decided to call and see if they were opening on time and they replied,"we're unable to open for lunch and unfortunately, we'll  only be open for dinner tonight!"

Bao's were pretty tasty and texture was delish 4/5.

Spicy Miso Ramen was pretty good too and noodle quality was great. 4/5
author: Michael B.

description: Awesome! The broth is always so satisfying. I usually get the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen with extra pork belly yum!
author: Seema K.

description: Mala Ramen is so flavors, so good. They have lunch special ramen and sushi rolls in reasonable price. I will recommend my friends to try this place.
author: Danny L.

description:
This place is criminally underrated. I kind of like it that way - it's my own little spot. But It deserves a better overall review. Let me preface by saying I love good ramen. From Ichiran in Tokyo, Ippudo in NYC, Santouka in San Jose, Boxer in Portland, and many more - I've had my fair share of quality ramen. 

This place deserves to be on a best ramen list. But ONLY if you get the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen. Everything else I've had here is good, but the spicy garlic tonkotsu is amazing. The broth is incredibly flavorful and makes the dish, nay, the restaurant, worth five stars.
author: Niko D.

description:
Tried Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen with side sashimi and it was ok. But next time, I don't think I will order sashimi. Not worth it. Two slices with old sushi rice.

I think I am looking for a more flavorful soup base since the name is called Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen. And I don't like it they don't serve half and egg with the ramen. I also don't think their choice of seaweed is good for the soup bowl. Their seaweed is too slimey.
author: Janice T.

description: I am addicted to the spicy garlic Ramen extra hot! The soup is very tasty and I like the crispy bacon wrapped around the asparagus and Mochi.
author: SJ L.

description: Overall just ok, not SUPER amazing but nothing bad either! Only thing though is that I ordered the spicy soup, and asked for extra spicy. it wasn't spicy at all. srirarcha is spicier. I was a bit disappointed that it wasn't spicy but the noodles still tasted good overall. Service was decent, they came by when they could.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
This is now one of my top spots to take guests from outside of SF. I don't know what it is, but for some reason I immediately loved this place when I entered. It might have been because of their ramen menu or their donburi... or it might be because of them having two TVs on the game and food network. Both of my fav loves. 

But to be honest, it probably was the food. They were good and tasty. I had a tonkatsu ramen and unagi donburi, which were both really good. The prices weren't too bad either.

So yeah next time I am coming back with a group. 

FYI they also have an Asahi dispenser so if you love that beer and want to go in a group, I rec for that.
author: Sonlay V.

description: The wait here is always ridiculous whenever I go, but totally worth it! Spicy Garlic Miso, sooooo good! The food is always worth the wait. Sushi is fresh, ramen has good portions and very filling. The noodles are good, not soggy or too hard and definitely doesn't have that instant ramen taste to it like some other places do. My favorite ramen place in the city.
author: Enya B.

description: This place is great! The spicy garlic tonkatsu was really tasty! There was a lot of flavored and just the right amount of spice to it. I also tried the Fred oysters they were pretty good as well which I was surprised.
author: Cassandra G.

description: Can't say I'm a fan. I am feeling under the weather and needed some soup as part of my (read: everyone's) recovery from illness. Unfortunately, I was served with old and expired pork that was over-cooked in my ramen. The ingredients were NOT fresh. Sad...but at least the staff was friendly
author: Ed O.

description: Spicy Mala Ramen lunch special with 6 spicy tuna rolls for $13. Good deal. Not too spicy for me but maybe for others. Very filling, I think next time I will just do the Ramen. If it was a little bigger I could split it. This place gets crowded but is worth the wait.
author: Jamie S.

description:
A popular ramen shop that certainly delivers on flavors but friendly prices. Just $7.95 for your basic tonkotsu, shio, and shoya ramens. For a little more you can fancy it up and go with the signature dish which is the spicy garlicky tonkotsu ramen and optional pork belly. You can indeed get ramen with more complex broth, tenderer cha-shu pork, or better pork belly elsewhere in the city, but you'll also be paying a little bit more.

The sushi is great too. Well priced, fresh and good cuts and good fish to rice ratio.

There's easily a line out the door starting at dinner time at any given night. In my opinion it's one of SF's best cheap eats and you'll be racing the budget-conscious diners to Sawaii's door.
author: Rina W.

description: I ordered a tonkatsu ramen with 6 piece cali rolls. The noodles were chewy which i really liked. Broth was bomb! Sadly, there was only two pieces of pork belly but those two pieces were delicious. Also ordered chicken karaaje but thought it was too fried. It came with rice and salad but wished it came with curry or another sauce. Will return to try other ramen!
author: Vivian L.

description: Went there for lunch today with my boyfriend and it was fantastic as usual! We hadn't been there for a while and forgot how great everything is. We had karaage, spicy salt, and spicy mala. It was all delicious.
author: Jessie L.

description:
I've tried ramen at a lot of ramen shops in my life
and this place is good, but i think the prices could be lowered just a tad..
other than that this place is great!
author: Dennis L.

description:
My roommates brought me here because they said it was so close to Teaway. My house is pretty much dedicated to all things milk tea. Yes, we are all Asian! Haha!

They mentioned how this place was always few but when we came around 9 pm, it was empty! Woot! 

The inside is nice. The seating is made up of several wooden tables on the right side and booth- like seating on the right. It is very TIGHT so beware of your neighbors or get to know them ( aka get off your phone!) 

Also, this place does sell SUSHI. They have nigiri and specialty rolls at decent prices. 

Anyway I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen ($8) and added corn ($1 extra.) I also ordered the meat stuffed mushrooms as an appetizer. The flavor of the ramen was okay. The noodles were good but you only get 2 pieces of cha shu. Shame, because the meat was really tasty! 

The neat thing is that you can order rice bowls along with your ramen for $1-4 extra, something I liked because I always want to eat everything.

Don't get the mushrooms! There's nothing special about them and you only get 3 pieces for $4. 

The waitresses are really attentive and the owner even came by many times to check if everything was okay. 

I might drop in later but Saiwaii isn't my first choice for ramen. Sorry!
author: Joy L.

description:
This is definitely a solid place for authentic ramen with a tasty, rich broth and noodles cooked al dente.  For $8, you can get a hearty bowl of tonkatsu ramen.  However, the portions of toppings, such as slices of chashu and strands of wood ear mushrooms, are a bit skimpy even though they are fresh.  If you like pork belly, get the gigantic cubes for $3 more.  

Service is fast and friendly.  The ambiance and decor is simple and clean with the look of a small mom 'n pop shop.  Parking is tough on the street.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Came here with my friends for dinner today, and Uhhh..... not impressed. Being spoiled by the better ramen places in San Mateo, I didn't expect much of the ramen here, so I went a different direction and got an unagi-don. 

Overall, not impressed at all. First, the portion of the unagi was small, nothing special. And their rice.... can it be any more horrible? It was hard and it didn't taste fresh at all. A ten year old kid could've cooked better rice, I mean, how the hell can you mess up on rice????? 
They also forgot to give me the miso soup that came with all the donburis, so I had to ask for mine. Also had to grab the waitress once again for a spoon for the miso soup. And honestly, I could've gone without the miso soup altogether. I believe I didn't even drink a whole spoonful.

All my friends got ramens and they just said their food was average, but hopefully it was better than my donburi. 

Definitely won't see me coming back here again.
author: Harriet W.

description: Best ever! Roasted Garlic Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen!  Great service, parking and hours as well.  I agree with the tip, "last meal".  It is a Devine bowl of soup!
author: Mels B.

description:
Pretty good ramen place.
Affordable price with super big portion!
Yummy taste!!!

I was suspicious of the taste in the beginning because the shop looked like owned by Taiwanese/Chinese instead of Japanese, but man! this Ramen place rocks!

I'm totally coming back here when I go back to SF.
author: Jun C.

description:
The ramen tastes good, but the service is so slow!

It's a very small restaurant, so you most likely have to wait for a table if the place is packed. There's a clipboard located at the entrance for you to put your name down. We arrived around 7:30pm on a Tuesday and waited about 10 minutes for a table for two. Later on in the evening, the wait seemed longer because more people came while others were still dining.

The service is slow. It took them a while to seat us, to take our order, and to bring out our orders. I was disappointed they never refilled our tea. Regardless of the service, the ramen is actually good here.

My recommendations:
- Tonkatsu ramen: The broth was very flavorful. The cha su was good, but I wish there was more of it. I ordered an egg (+$1) and I loved how they left the egg yolk runny.

I would return, but I hope they work on faster service!
author: Jenny T.

description:
For a ramen place, it's perplexing that we had to hunt on the menu to find the ramen items - perhaps there's a little too much of the other standard Japanese items - sushi, small plate appetizers, salad (?), etc.  The $6 hot sake (large) was cheap and pretty good for box sake - perfect for our threesome on a cold night.

We all ordered the $10 Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen with varying levels of spiciness (none, regular, extra spicy).  FWIW, my regular was just mild, and the extra spicy was just right - not enough to leave a burning sensation throughout the meal.   The bowls only had noodles, "cha-shu," bamboo shoots, green onions, and wood ear fungus - a bit disappointing when other ramen joints are adding eggs and generous helpings of other exotic ingredients (extra side fixings run $1-3).  Sadly, there were no chunks of roasted garlic for that great post-dinner date breath, although I could faintly taste the garlic in the broth.  The slices of "cha-shu" were a bit fatty underneath the pork skin and moist, although not very flavorful aside from soaking in the soup.  The bamboo shoots and wood ear fungus gave a nice crunch with the noodles, and the broth flavoring was decent - not too salty.  Overall a decent but not amazing bowl of ramen for those cold nights in the Outer Sunset.
author: Kevin W.

description:
The ramen broth is rich.  You get a few options for broths and a few options for extras (at a charge) including uhhhh Butter??? I went with enoki (mushroom) and menma (fermented bamboo).  It also came with spinach, corn, and green onion.  

The miso broth was the highlight though my boyfriend was pretty pleased with himself and his meaty tonkotsu.  The noodles were a little thin and dull.  I like'em fat and chewy and that ain't Saiwaii.

The curry donburi looks like someone took their hangover out on your dish of rice but it actually tastes really good.  Very rich and salty but I'm into that.

We also got an order of Maguro which was fresh and flavorful and only 4$ for two pieces.

The place is tini tiny so you're practically sitting with all your table neighbors.  That's for some and not for others.  Very hole-in-the-wall chic.  Friendly service.  Tables turn around really quickly and you'll feel guilty staying long because the line starts tumbling out the door.
author: Meg M.

description: If you're still looking for a GOOD ramen house in SF, look no further. This place may just have the best ramen in the Bay Area outside of San Mateo/San Jose. Don't believe me cuz I'm white? Try the Spicy Mala (i.e., Karage & Pork) and the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu, and then we'll talk. The place was already full at 5:30 on Weds night, but that didn't prevent the service from being quick and friendly. Other trendy ramen wanna-be's in SF (looking at you Mission) take notice - Sawaii is setting the bar.
author: Andy L.

description: I ordered the lunch set, the Tonkotsu ramen and California Roll.  The roll was OK and the ramen was good.  The broth was flavorful and the noodles were good.  The service was a little slow and the place can get crowded. They need to clean the condiment containers such as la-yu chili oil.  It was very oily when I touched it.  I felt like wiping my hand every time I touch one of the condiment containers.  It took something away from the dinning experience.
author: Hiroshi K.

description:
I've eaten here before and it was pretty good and would like to go back but looking at the operating times on this site: 

I don't think I'm smart enough to eat here.  I don't understand the times that they are open. .
author: lily l.

description: It's kind of funny for me to go from 1 star to 4 stars on an update review for this spot. Came here last Sunday with a couple friends. We knew that it'd be hard to find parking in the area on this particular day of the week and also most likely a wait to get seated. Well to our surprise.. we actually didn't have to park too far.. we parked on Judah .. so a few blocks away and the wait was less than 10 minutes. Good so far.. we got seated and waited for the other friend to arrive.. ordered hot sake and chilled. We each got the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen and a grilled whole squid. The squid was okay, wish it had more grilled flavor to it.. the ramen on the other hand was delicious. I love garlic and the spiciness was perfect. Noodles were good and I added pork belly and it was BOMB! So goooood. I'm glad I decided to give this place a second try... now I'll be back for sure. It's kind of pricey.. but isn't everything now a days.
author: Tiff C.

description: I had the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen and it was so delicious! I always go to this spot for ramen within the city because I personally enjoyed the ramen here the best out of all of the ramen restaurants I've been to in SF including Izakaya Sozai. Although if I really want the best ramen, I would get it in San Mateo.
author: Kevin L.

description:
This place always seems crowded when I walk by, so on a cold Saturday night figured I'd stop in with the girlfriend and give it a try.

This place does not disappoint, that is for sure. However, be warned as I would give this place 3.5 stars if possible, as the service is pretty horrendous. The food is great, but I judge on service and it sucked. It took maybe 5 minutes to get a menu, another ten to have someone take an order, and a full 5 minutes after that to get our waters.

The food though, luckily, is pretty amazing here. The shoyu ramen is really good, noodles have a great bite, and delicious melt in your mouth pork belly. Also got some sushi rolls, which were some of the better tasting ones I've had in my time here at the city. Food comes out pretty quick, and it's a decent sized portion. The broth does get a shade salty near the bottom of the bowl, but I feel like that happens everywhere I go.

Pros: Good food, decent prices

Cons: Slow service, and get ready to elbow bump with the tables next to you
author: David H.

description:
The most appropriate in the infamously foggy Outer Sunset neighborhood is a ramen place, so Saiwaii is a big relief to fulfill all cravings for hot spicy garlicky  flavorful bowl of tonkatsu ramen anyday!! 

*** Spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen -The STAR. Noodles in pork broth, appropriately spicy with sharp flavor of garlic which is so mouthwatering. Every now and then one's sure to get the unstoppable craving for this super broth, can have bowls of this in a go! has a nice crunch of the bamboo shoots on top. An extra add of pork belly for $3 may be a good option.  $9

But minus one star for being so stingy with the pork/meat serving with the tonkatsu bowl and charging extra for that half portion of egg compared to other ramen joints!! DISAPPOINTING!!  

NOTE- The regular tonkatsu ramen is very bland and lacks flavor, so would suggest  the * Spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen * only!!

** Spicy Maya ramen -  A bit too overpowering spicy. However this had a good serving of meat in it. Served with fried chicken, a slice of pork, seaweed, green onions and half egg. The broth lacked flavor compared to spicy tonkatsu or spicy miso. $10

*Chicken hearts - YUCKKK!! My first time trying this but sorry to say this tasted pretty terrible. $4

Service is fast and attentive.
Ambiance - Lacks any special touch of ambiance as the space is small and the adjacent seatings are way too alarmingly close.

But a definite place to fulfill the ramen cravings in cold Outer Sunset neighborhood!
author: Payal B.

description:
Surprisingly, not bad Tonkotsu ramen at all, for a Chinese establishment (I'm assuming) in Chinese store district. A ramen/japanese restaurant trying to cover everything from sushi to ramen - I usually don't expect much from these all-in-one places, because there is no such type of Japanese restaurant in the home country. If you are Ramen chef, you don't serve sushi.

We went there a week later came back from trip to the ramen mecca. The tonkotsu ramen at sawaii is pretty good textbook-good-tonkotsu ramen, with all the side ingredients you would expect from a bowl of ramen, and none of those unexpected condiments like carrots or cucumbers etc, when you go to a bs ramen shop in bay area. 
Their spin on spicy ramen work very well. Not overly done I could still taste garlic and tonkotsu soup. 
Despite the sucky parking wars in the area, this place is worth visiting at least once. Not a horrible wait nor waiting time after you place an order. 
The sidedish we ordered wasn't great (Croquette or Korokke), mitsuwa or nijiya does it better.
author: Another R.

description: Great Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen without the crazy wait of some of the other popular ramen places. The sushi is decent too! This is my regular place to go now when I need a ramen fix!
author: Russell W.

description:
This is my first time going to Saiwaii. I came here unexpectedly with my mom, her co-workers, and one of her co-worker's daughter. 

Ambiance: 
It is a very small restaurant, which has around 6 tables or something. We were seated right by the table. 

Service:
I thought that the service was good.  I do not remember the server's name, nor do I remember if he told us. The server looked really familiar (and I actually might know his name), and that is not surprising since many students work in San Francisco. He was very friendly and kind. 

Food: 
The server recommended the chicken karage for an appetizer. It was alright, the pieces of chicken were big, but I did not enjoy the sauce that came along with it. My mom's co-worker's daughter let me try a piece of her Paradise roll, which was topped with fried onion strings?, was really good. I ordered the spicy mala ramen. It included half an egg, strips of green onions/ scallions, a piece of nori, spinach, pork belly, and a few pieces of chicken karage. The soup was spicy, and really good. I gave the egg to my mom because I don't really enjoy eating eggs. The karage was crispy and delicious even though it was in the soup. which I later took out. I thought that the scallions gave it the perfect fresh touch within all the meatiness. I wish the noodles did not stick to each other so much though because I had a bit of a trouble trying to break it apart. 

My ramen costed $10.95, but me and my mom paid a total of $25-26. It was a good meal and a nice little restaurant to try out, especially since I am always near Irving.
author: Vivian Y.

description:
02.07.12

Saiwaii is quickly climbing up the charts as one of my favorite ramen places in SF (probably behind Izakaya Sozai and Katana-Ya).

Not having to wait definitely boosts this joint.

It's been a long while since I have fully finished a bowl of ramen (spicy garlic miso FTW!).  I had no trouble yesterday.

The lunch special ($9.95 for regular ramen + six-piece sushi, or $11.95 for spicy) sure fills you up.  I had a four hour food coma/nap afterwards.  It felt great.

Total damage for two: $29
author: Jenny L.

description:
Good ramen broth at this place. They do not use MSG. it may not be as good as the ramen at Izakaya Sozai (that one sure looks delicious) but this is also a more casual place with a lower price point. We came hoping to see Yo-san but apparently he takes Saturday lunch off as well as all of Sunday so we missed him. We were able to get some of our favorite aji and ankimo (both prepared in advance by Yo-san and put together by the shift sushi chef that day) but the ankimo was a bit old, and the sushi rice was a bit dry. But that's okay because I had no expectations about anyone other than Yo-san. I will be back and will update the review once I get to say hi to him. :)

4 star ramen, 3 star sushi = 3.5 star
author: Josh K.

description: I tired their miso ramen. Pretty good for the price and service. Place is small. Always a line!
author: Jasmin T.

description:
I went back here because it had been so cold in SF that I wanted to eat hot noodles.  It was almost 3p (which is their closing time for lunch) and I was lucky to slide in.  Only one other table occupied and total peace and quiet.

I ordered the spicy tonkotsu with no char siu and extra menma.  I think not being busy is a plus here.  The noodles were cooked perfectly and the soup was just right on the spiciness.  The server told me that they are also not busy when they first open at 11am so that is the trick to get the perfect bowl of ramen.

Yay!  I am glad I can get good ramen in SF finally.
author: Janette F.

description:
SF is freekin' cold.  I haven't eaten so much ramen, pho, and jigae in my life... but it's the best way to survive the bitter cold Siberia that is SF -- with a belly full of hot soup.  Warm belly, warm smile... that's my life credo.  

The ramen is solid, above average stuff.  Definitely more than capable of satisfying my hunger cravings for ramen.  The various other items are good too.  I kinda need to temper my comments because I've been spoiled by the wonderful Japanese food that is downtown San Mateo... oh how I miss thee!  But that's a story for another time.

The waitresses are really nice and friendly... extra star for them.  Definitely a cool place to hang out, catch a game on the flatscreen, and even have a beer or sake, if that's your desire.  All in all, a nice place to warm your belly and warm your heart... and leave with a smile.
author: Bryan K.

description:
when hunger pang strikes and the fog rolls in, thats when the ramen sounds fantastic! standing out in the cold and eating steaming hot ramen is the best way to satisfy this little belly of mine. Ordered the Spicy Tonkatsu (regular) my oh my, not only my eyes were satisfied, but my wallet and stomach did, too!! my mouth was salivating and it was muy delicioso to the maximus awesomus! Also ordered for their special roll saiwaii roll, with that price and that yummylicious rolls? it was more than bomb digity!
Also, had ninja it was also good.

Over all dinner, it was excellent like the way mr burns from the simpsons would say...
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
My family and I stopped here on a spontaneous trip into San Francisco.  To be honest, we came here because of the decent rating and it was one of the first ramen places that was opening up at 11am on a Sunday.

The place is small, but that shouldn't be anything to be concerned with.  If you're a foody, you probably know by now that some of the best hidden gems are found in small places.  While I wouldn't go as far as calling this place a gem, it is very good.

I had the Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu.  The broth was flavorful and the noodles were cooked right.  The staff was pleasant.  We had a party of 4 (including a 1 year old and they were very kind)  Because of the size of the place, we had another couple of guys join us in the adjacent table, they too were nice and this was appreciated.

While I wouldn't call this the greatest, it certainly was good and we'll probably be back to try the other dishes.
author: M P.

description: My short review: Very small, but ramens are very good... A bit of a wait, but the food makes the wait well worth it. Will definitely go again! If your not a SF person, get used to walking and poor parking spaces.
author: Binh D.

description:
I enjoyed the everything about the Ramen at Saiwaii. I'm a fan of both Izakaya Sozai and Katanaya and feel it is on parr with both places. It's a great value too. 

My only complaint is that the Tonkotsu broth seemed to have quite a bit of chicken stock in it. I don't like chicken so it bothered me. Overall the noodles were nice and chewy and the sho-yu tamago that I added to my Tonkotsu Ramen was delicious.

If you want to drink beer, bring some yourself. They do not have their liquor license yet.
author: Maïa Cybelle C.

description: My spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen & chicken karaage was beautifully prepared. Ive never had ramen this good. Ample portions & spot on flavors. Cannot say enough about this place. The best!
author: Carrie K.

description: The lunchtime Tonkatsu Ramen was lacking in flavor and very uninspiring...very disappointing especially after having truly excellent, rich Tonkatsu ramen at Waraku on Post. The California rolls were also mediocre...I was surprised that they could be so bland.
author: M Z.

description: Do yourself a favor and stick to the ramen. The sushi rice was soggy with some old salmon in it, and the stir fried vegetable with pork belly looked like a home made salad with a couple pieces of cut meat on top. It doesn't look or taste as good as it sounds. The ramen on the other hand was delicious with an excellent blend of flavors. That's what everyone comes here for.
author: Tim S.

description:
Warning - I've only had their ramen, and absolutely nothing else.  So this review is only about the ramen.
I love the ramen - I appreciate that I can add extra toppings etc.  The broth is amazing. The choices are great. The service is fast and friendly.
I've only been here twice; I would love to return here as much as possible.
I used to eat at this location when it was So Noodles in the early '00s, so I already have very fond memories of this location.  I'm glad that they changed the interior.
Price is roughly $15/person.
author: Michael S.

description:
So what can I say about Saiwaii that hasn't already been said.

Our first encounter here, a little post-it taped onto the menu whispered to me, "order the chicken ramen".  I mean, its probably new on the menu and it should be good, right?  Wrong, wrong, WRONG!  Dang, if I wanted my bowl of ramen to taste like this, I would've just spent the $0.99 and purchased a package of Maruchan or Top Ramen.  So our first visit here was a bust.

I approached the second encounter with much caution.  We were seated at the dreaded "table by the door" on a cold night.  But I wised up and kept an eye out on what the other diners were ordering and eating.  I kept hearing "Tonkatsu, tonkatsu, TONKATSU."  Okay, so I ordered the Tonkatsu ramen, with a side of egg.  Sheesh.

Oh man.  This bowl of tonkatsu did not disappoint!  Slices of pork, and egg and ramen cooked to perfection!  I was in ramen nirvana.  The hustle and bustle of this tiny restaurant just faded away behind the steamy tonkatsu ramen haze.

So, lesson learned, wait and observe those around you first before you order yourself.
author: Rochelle D.

description:
Need to update this review since Sawaii has just been really less-than-mediocre lately. They've been inconsistent and one time my boyfriend got the miso ramen that tasted like water. 

This past week I was served meat that had definitely gone bad. The owner was very nice and said she would take off one order (we had two), but said that we were the only people who said there was anything wrong with the meat. I feel bad but the quality of the food is not up to par.
author: A Y.

description: They are super friendly and service is great. Food is ok. Not super delicious but good enough to keep you satisfied. I usually eat here out of convenience more than anything else.
author: Diane M.

description:
Great portion and affordable price : )

Only ordered Ramen so no comment on Sushi. The Ramen is great, so far in my top 3 list.
author: Jiayang H.

description:
For some reason I feel like Sawaii is a secret ramen place because I think people don't realize how good it is yet! 

I would say it's up there with the ramen leaders (ie: katana-ya, izakaya sozai, santa ramen) it's just different. When I crave Sawaii it's because I'm craving something a little spicy, something kind of soupy and garlic/miso-y. I imagine the crunchiness of the bamboo shoots and green onions they put on top and the egginess of the noodles just perfectly cooked. It's also just the right amount of spicy for someone who is a spicy wimp, not intolerable like it is at Ramen Dojo.

Oh man, Spicy Tonkatsu Garlic Ramen, I want you NOW! For $9 it's quite a deal considering how full you will fill afterward. 

Ramen lovers - do it, try it, come and get it!

Plus side: TeaWay for dessert a block away to cool your insides down :)
author: Nicole L.

description: I had the spicy garlic tonkatsu broth with extra egg and extra cha Shu. Noodles were a bit over cooked and broth lacked the kick. The burned garlic was also slightly underwhelming. All in all though a satisfying meal for a hungry patron.
author: David C.

description:
Wish I could put 3.5 but yelp doesn't allow that. 
The spicy garlic tonkatsu is what I normally get and it's delicious! Sushi is okay but I wouldn't get it here. The spicy garlic tonkatsu is the thing to get. The only reason they get one less star is service isn't so great but doesn't matter too much, I guess. There was one particular time where service was pretty bad.

Example of not so great service: I went with a group of friends, we somehow managed to screw up and forgot to leave a tip.  (honestly, with how nonexistent service is here, they don't exactly deserve one but it's the polite thing to do and we always leave tip)
Instead of just letting it go the lady basically cornered my friend who was the last to leave, demanding a tip and saying we HAD to leave one. Last I checked, tip isn't required and it was an honest mistake. As long as you don't forget to tip or don't mind being harassed for one, this place is pretty good.
author: Jay A.

description:
Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen - Not spicy at all, and I got extra spicy. I would grade extra spicy as maybe mildish medium if you have a decent tolerance. Gotta man up on the spicy The garlic was insanely strong... but in a way that masked the tonkotsu broth.  The actual pieces of pork were decent, not the best I've had or the worst. Noodles were good. I guess I really wanted a good mix of garlic and pork flavors with the heat to back it.

Real Crab California Roll - very good. If you've ever had a real crab california roll, you'll know there is a HUGE difference flavorwise. Saiwaii's was very much of what I expected. Not too much mayo, and a good crab flavor.

Spicy Garlic Soft Shell Crab - very interesting. I would best describe this as a spicy garlic pepper seasoning similar to PPQ but with softshell crab instead of dungenous. This was chopped on top of a slight bitter green salad, which was a nice touch. However, it  looked like they only used half a crab? It was a lot smaller than what I am normally used to when seeing soft shell.

Overall, they have decent food. I would recommend lunch, because of their ramen and roll deals.
author: Marc T.

description:
- This review is only about the ramen & the buta kakuni, I did not try anything else here.

- I just moved back up to SF from San Jose area & I'll be the first to say that I've been spoiled by the quantity & quality of good to GREAT Asian food in the South Bay. My favorite ramen place (for a white guy) is Halu Ramen, because of the rich porky goodness of their broth. The firmness of their noodles.

- I tried their Special of Spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen (tan-tan men) w/ a side order of buta kakuni: pretty decent ramen for $9.95 + $3.00 for the buta kakuni (braised pork belly), unfortunately the pork belly came not very hot & it was a little sweet for me too, so I added it to the ramen. 

- The broth was pretty good & had a nice level of spice to it too. There wasn't very much roasted pork loin in the bowl, so I'm glad I got the side of pork belly too.

- I would go back for sure!!
author: Dan S.

description:
This is my go-to ramen place in SF when I can't (or don't want to) wake up in time to drive to San Mateo and wait in line at Ramen Dojo.

I only get the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen - mild when I'm not feeling up to having my nose running too badly, medium when it's super cold out. Soup is delicious, noodles are perfect - not too soft, not too chewy. Their sushi has always been fresh but nothing amazing. I usually get the 49'er roll (or whichever one has the lemon on top) for that zesty zing to complement my ramen. They also have a bunch of tapas plates which I have yet to try but the chicken cartilage is next on my list.

Cute, friendly staff; fast service. I have never had to wait for a table in this tiny place. I love it here!
author: Liana L.

description:
Nothing bad to say about this place! It's a small little place that serves big bowls of hot broth with noodles and meat and veggies... ;). On a foggy day in the avenues (wait...it's always foggy over there. Even better) go get yourself a hot bowl of ramen. They have other things on the menu too like sushi and some yakitori but the true shiner is the ramen. 

Ok, some people hear ramen and think of the .50 cent packages of hard noodles that college students supposedly love. NOT! This is the total opposite of that. I get just the plain miso bowl and its so savory and has such an umami flavor. WAIT, did I just use the word "umami"? Well it fits for this dish. Never thought I could use that word to its full extent. 

Everyone must try this at least once. But don't go there a lot because then it will get too busy and then they wont have room for me to eat! :( like I said its a small place so I hope you don't mind rubbing elbows with your neighbors while you are slurping noodles and splattering broth all over your shirt.
author: Lizzie D.

description: Came for dinner on a Saturday night. The place was full which is nice to see and there was maybe 1 or 2 groups in front of us. We were seated pretty quickly despite all of that. It was a cold night so ramen was going to be perfect to warm the soul. I got the spicy miso and my girl got the spicy garlic tonkatsu. I got my broth extra spicy while she got hers normal. I dont' know if this is always the case but it felt like my girls normal broth was spicier than the broth I got purposely more spicy. Maybe I was already a goner from my spice that when I tried hers, my taste buds were compromised. Anywho I like spicy so that is not a problem for me so maybe next time she'll have to order mild. The ramen is cooked well, good broth and the fixings were on point. Very good combination of everything and I ordered mine with extra cha shu which was well cooked and accompanied the ramen and other ingredients perfectly. My girl complained of a stomach ache after eating hers, It just might have been the spice so if you are sensitive to spice you may have stomach issues eating here but I don't so I might have to come solo. lol jk baby. Good place to get your ramen fix.
author: Jeromy G.

description:
The best ramen I've had in the city yet. Perfect for my bro-tastic man dates haha. No, but a friend and I eat here all the time now. Perfect for those overcast days in SF...so like 75% of the time in the sunset. Add the pork belly for a couple extra bucks into the spicy garlic miso ramen and you won't regret it.
The sushi is quite good and they have a lunch special that gives you a crazy amount of food for the price.
Add in just a nice feel with a simple look with a nice staff and I got myself one of my top lunch spots in the city.
author: Chris D.

description:
The wait seemed too long when I got here so I asked if they'll allow for me to order Ramen ($9) to-go.  The total came out to be around $16 after I added Chicken Karaage, Spinach, and Egg.  

Their Spicy Tonkatsu Garlic Broth had just the right amount of kick for me.  I kind of like their broth slightly more than Ramen Dojo's (because you can see the amount of sodium in Ramen Dojo's garlic pork broth more than theirs).  But Sawaii doesn't have much of a variety of add-ons like Ramen Dojo does.
author: Wendy T.

description: Me and a buddy of mine wanted to give this place a try so we stopped by this afternoon. First impression, the name of the place screams Chinese owned ramen shop. It is on the Chinese side of Irving after all. We sat down and ordered their lunch special where you choose your ramen and a side of sushi roll. I had their spicy garlic tonkotsu and a side of tuna sushi. The sushi arrived first and it was nothing special, the rice tasted like rubber, just like supermarket sushi rolls. Approximately ~5mins later the ramen came. I would give the presentation 4 stars but other than the appearance I'd make better ramen at home because it's exactly what it tasted like, instant ramen. The soup was WAAAAAY too saltly, felt like I was sipping MSG. Tastes like the flavoring packets you find in instant noodles, sorry but I am here for ramen, not instant ramen. The noodles were not al dente, over cooked and NO EGG? Not even half? Seriously? A Chinese owned ramen shop that charges more than a Japanese ramen shop doesn't include a egg? The two thinly slices of meat tastes dry and stale. $13 for a bowl of salty MSG ramen with overcooked noodles and no egg? Wow! This is just another reminder why I never go to any Chinese owned Japanese restaurant. If you're gonna do ramen, focus on ramen and make it the best ramen on the block. Don't spread your menu out and included everything like sushi, rolls and yakitori. This "ramen shop" tries to do everything but in the end gets nothing right. You guys may want to look up what TONKOTSU is because obviously I tasted no pork at all in your SPICY GARLIC "TONKOTSU". You may fool non-asians or people that don't know any better but this type of practice is unfaithful to the cuisine and just down right shady.
author: Panchali S.

description:
Unbelievable!!!

Food:  Grade B.  The ramen was decent, I ordered tonkatsu ramen and added pork belly and chicken karaage.  Pork belly was good.  I can't comment on the Chicken Karaage because I think they are still cooking it.

Service:  If you make a mistake, just let the customer know that you forgot to put there order in and move on.  My 40 week pregnant wife and I sat down and we got our food ordered quickly.  After 20 minutes, we looked around and we are the only table with out our food.   At the 30 min point, our ramen was brought to our table and the server advises that she will bring our chicken karaage out next.

50 min point... Ramen done, but no Chicken Karaage.

60 min point-  Check please!..  and very unhappy customer.

I still left my 15% tip because a 1 star on yelp is satisfying.  Please let me know when my chicken karaage is done... 

Definitely Do not TRY!!
author: E T.

description:
BEST ramen EVER. My husband introduced me to this place a few years ago, and I've introduced my sister, mother and a few friends as well, and we just can't get enough! 

I usually go with the Ramen Miso, with spinach and corn added.  I've also tried their spicy garlic miso (which can be ordered mild as well), and their chicken broth miso, all very, very tasty. 

Their appetizers are great, we usually go for this fried chicken dish with the most amazing dipping sauce, you'll want to drink it! Their rolls are fresh, and very tasty.

I'm telling you, this place hits the spot time and time again!
author: Michelle R.

description:
Went here for the first time a few weeks ago and made it back again in less than a week!  This is a great ramen option.  Somehow the fact that it is located in the chilly Outer Sunset makes the warm ramen even more satisfying.  

The spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen is delicious, and my husband got the fried chicken ramen, which I plan to try next time we go.  Good amount of noodles, which I feel is frequently lacking in a lot of ramen.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
I have been on a search for the best ramen in the bay.I'm also lucky enough to have recruited a couple of other ramen hunters and we decided on saiwaii  based on yelp reviews and photos. We were so stoked that this might possibly be the spot.
Well. I was not impressed at all...in my ramen training I would givevthis a mediocre rating. The broth wasn't flavorful nor rich which is one of the promineint characteristics of tonokotsu broth and I asked for pork belly as an extra..the belly was cubes with this lasagna like pattern of fat, grisle & a little bit of meat. norcimpressed with the quality of the meat. Service was okay.the egg could have used another day in the marinate. The noodles were Chinese. If anyone has any leads on a good ramen house in the bay.. Let me know! Maybe we can meet for a meal!
author: Jasmine L.

description:
This place is pretty good. Authenticity aside, it's a pretty filling bowl of ramen for around $10. I've been here several times, and I normally order the Tonkotsu ramen, and it's been pretty consistent. Although I don't drink the broth of any noodle soup dishes I order at restaurants, regardless of cuisine (I want to avoid excessive MSG consumption), the ramen and broth itself had a very nice creamy flavor to it). I've also ordered some sort of combo during lunch with a roll of sushi. Sushi wasn't bad, wasn't outstanding, either. 

I'd say though, that this place is somewhat underrated. Unlike other restaurants like Katana-ya, when I've been here, lines haven't been too long. 

Anyways, it's a good place for a quick bowl of ramen and most of the time I leave pretty content!
author: Jared L.

description:
Came here finally, heard they improve greatly from the grand opening.
I ordered the spicy pork tonkatsu ramen, extra spicy with mushroom trio, panda roll and beef tongue.
The ramen came quick, broth looks promising, no egg unless you add and pay extra for. It came with 2 cha shu (pork), fatty and delicious, not as tender as I'd imagined but still good. The broth was definitely delicious, extra spicy is pretty darn spicy, so perhaps reg spicy is good enough. This ramen was overall a A- or B+, definitely worth trying, good overall.
The panda roll, while it sounded very tempting with fried asparagus and butter fish, it wasn't that great. Flavor wise, you can taste the asparagus, but still a bit bland. For over 10$, you may pass.
The mushroom trio was good, very simple and for 5$, you can definitely make it yourself.
The beef tongue is also a good appetizers, several small pieces with enough flavor and fat to make this worth it.

Overall i had a great experience from this place, ramen is good, appetizers are good, just not sure about sushi. Try it out-
author: Hao B.

description: Small place, tends to have a line but I think it's worth it.  Ramen & eggs are to die for; cha su was a little fatty for my taste though (reason it gets 4 stars)
author: Kelly T.

description: Pretty good ramen. Nice tonkotsu broth but definitely better with the miso added. One star off for the hurried and careless service. After first bringing the wrong order to the table, our correct ramens were mixed up at the table as the server practically threw them at us.
author: Anthony B.

description:
Not bad ramen if you are in the outer sunset area. I got the spicy garlic tonkatsu mild spicy and it could have used a little more kick. I might get the medium spicy next time. I have tried the regular garlic tonkatsu and it is way too creamy with no spice. My bf got the spicy miso and we did not like the flavor at all. We also got the karaage chicken which was very good. It was crispy and mostly dark meat. 

On a busy weekday night, there was no wait but service was pretty slow.
author: Diana N.

description:
Slow and service - well at least our server (the other older gentleman was busy hustling around and serving others better than ours).  - messed up our order.

The tables smelled like wet dirty rags.

Both types of ramen we ordered seemed more on the salty side - with no depth of flavor or complexity - just the taste of salt.

One plus to this place is that they served the ramen with a wonderfully done soft boiled egg where some other places cook it hard boiled.
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
- not 2B confused with the FiDi version which serves only sushi; neither nor the AjiRamen place in the basement of Westfield Center.

4 of us skipped Lunch so we definitely WENT TO TOWN tonight-

Kara Age
California Roll
Hawaiian Roll
Unagi Avocado 

Spicy Seafood Ramen (NEW)
Spicy Miso Ramen
Miso Ramen, Kara Age on the side
EXTRA Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen

Everything was perfect, some MORE perfect than usual.

Amazingly overly 1/2 of the room were Chinese diners like us!  The staff does speak Chinese . . .  and über Family friendly!
author: Clifford L.

description: Got there around 9:30pm and they were happy to have us. The service was great to the end. We didn't lag around long after closing time, but all the same I appreciate good service. I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen and it was tasty. My date ordered some spicy ramen and asked for the spiciest option yet had to add more spice anyway. Not sure if that means it's not all that spicy?? I'm happy with this spot and will come back.
author: Kris F.

description: No complaints here! Please bring back the ramen sushi combo!!! Food is consistent and service is on point! Bf and I are regulars here. He loves the big chunks of pork belly. and I love that I can get sushi rolls! We both win!
author: A b.

description:
I should have read other reviews before I try. I didn't know this was run by chinese people. I ordered Seafood Ramen and I confirmed the soup base is Tonkotsu broth before I order.
But I was surprised that its broth is very bland and didn't feel like a typical Japanese Tonkotsu flavor at all, but typical Chinese style broth.
It's not really bad, I think it's good for Chinese style ramen, but you will be disappointed if you expect a Japanese style Ramen here.
author: Toru M.

description: This place is just picking up. It has lots of competition in this neighborhood. The ramen was fairly good, probably the best part was the tasty pork slices they put in the soup. The service was still working out the kinks (waitress had a little difficulty working the credit card machine and the chef didn't seem to want to do teamwork). If it's cold outside (when you normally crave ramen), don't sit by the door- it has a tendency to stick, and stay open and the cold breeze gets annoying. I'd definitely go back here again and see how things are working out.
author: Naomi K.

description:
My boyfriend and I arrived just as the waitress/hostess was flipping over the Open Sign (they close in the afternoon). We wanted to grab dinner before heading over to Nightlife at the California Academy of Sciences. It was really cold that day too...well it's always cold in San Francisco. I was really craving something warm and ramen was calling my name.

There was only one waitress there and I remember reading numerous reviews complaining about the horrible service so I was a bit worried. However, our waitress was DA FRIGGIN BOMB! Maybe because there were only a few people in there at the time since it was still early and the dinner rush hadn't hit yet. Anyway, she was super sweet and I've never had someone so on top of my tea refills. She was literally on top of it. After a sip, she would swoop in and refill my tea. I didn't mind too much because I love hot, fresh tea. So I loved her and she was very friendly and patient. We took a while with ordering because I can never decide what to get (I wish I had four stomachs sometimes).

OK, now to the ramen! I decided to order the tonkatsu ramen (thank you fellow Yelpers!) and my boyfriend wanted to try something new so he ordered the miso ramen. It took pretty long for our orders to come out, considering  that the place wasn't packed. When our ramens came they were smokin' hot and just hit the spot for me. I actually liked my boyfriend's miso ramen more and he liked my tonkatsu so we ended up trading (YAY, that's what bf's are for!) The tonkatsu was great but the miso had a distinctive taste that was addicting. The miso came with bean sprouts and corn (my favs), seaweed, green onions, bamboo shoots, and cha siu (pork). I found the broth was very tasty and the noodles were perfect (not too firm or soft). They were pretty yellow too which was a first for me, but I'm not going to discriminate ramen based on its color. However, we were both a bit disappointed because about 70% of the cha siu (pork) was fat. I just gave my boyfriend the fatty part (again, what bf's are for). That is my only gripe with Saiwaii. Other than that, the service was lovely and the ramen was delish! My boyfriend thought it was good but he wasn't as enthusiastic about it as me. I've been to Shinsengumi down in SoCal a couple of times and they have awesome ramen. I think Saiwaii is just as good and perhaps even better than Shinsengumi (this is blasphemy if my bf sees this review).
author: Judy H.

description:
I LOVE this restaurant!  

Even though I am so very fond of Tazaki sushi and remain loyal, Sawaii has won my heart due to four wonderful things on the menu that I can't get anywhere else: Their wonderful spicy garlic tonkatsu (ooooh - savory, spicy yumminess!), and three kinds of sushi I seem to crave at least weekly: hamachi belly, sake belly (they sort of sear them under a broiler and put a thin slice of pepper and a bit of hot sauce on them - divine - and also the spicy hotate.  This is not to mention the very complete menu of other marvelous items like seafood ramen, hamachi kama and multiple imaginative rolls.

The owners and staff are friendly and accommodating, and the restaurant is clean and pleasant.  You should really give it a try.  You'll probably see me there.
author: Angela M.

description:
Nice to see a ramen joint on Irving, and I have to say that I do enjoy the set up of this restaurant. Its small but not tiny and crowded. And amazingly for such a small place it didnt get very hot.

The ramen is not bad, its not really good either. Kind of in between I guess you could say. Its good for a lunch time meal but its not a place I would want to spend one of my dinners on.

The spicy is good, strong enough to have me sweat a bit and give me that burn I enjoy. They have a few too many things going on in the bowl but its nice to have a variety here and there. The egg is always an enjoyable item of mine. 

Service is nice, and I was suprised they only had one waitress working during that time. She moved quick.

Overall its about 3 and half and but I wouldnt go as far to give them a 4. There is something missing about this place but I'll see how it is after a couple more visits.
author: phillip w.

description:
This is definitely tasty for ramen in SF. Noodles are forever long and tasty, tasty fried chicken. REALLY WELL SEASONED cha siu! So well seasoned with mirin, sugar and soy sauce. Way better than flavorless chasiu from Santa/Dojo (which I normally DRENCH in soy sauce). 

However, cleanliness is questionable here and they use salem oelek in the spicy tonkotsu broth. The flakes get stuck in your teeth.
author: Margaret S.

description: So luckily, we totally beat the wait to eat here. But if I had to wait, I wouldn't have done it. I'm not saying Sawaii isn't good! It's just nothing extraordinary. I tried the spicy garlic tonkatsu because it seemed to be super popular, but it wasn't anything special. Also, there were like 3 little slices of the tonkatsu and that's it.. But my mom ordered the spicy mala which I have to say was a lot more worth it and better. It came with chicken karage AND tonkatsu and it tasted pretty good. Also ordered the Sawaii Roll which was alright too. But yeah, Sawaii is pretty solid, but just not as worth it if you have to wait IMO..
author: Holly P.

description: Spicy mala is to die for! Come during the afternoon on a weekday to take advantage of their lunch special. :)
author: Michelle H.

description:
A cozy little place that surprised me with its' ramen goodness! Great attentive service + good food = a happy customer! 

Pricing is very affordable and it's open for lunch (Most ramen places I know of don't open until at least 5:30pm)! 

Ordered a croquette which was cooked pretty well. Crunchy outside w/ pork fillings on the inside. +1. 

Also ordered the Shoyu ramen w/ extra Cha-shu. The cha-shu was very tender and simply perfect! Broth was not overly salty and tasted just right. Fantastic! Will come back for more!
author: Killah K.

description:
This place is as "fun" as Disneyland like a coaster ride experience with mixed reviews & services. I came here w/ my lovely lady craving for a nice hot bowl of ramen.  Having to experience a cold cold SF night after a rainstorm I wanted something hot and spicy so I got the Spicy Garlic Miso Ramen + pork belly in mild and a Spicy Miju (Spicy Tuna over bread).  Now the ramen was pretty good, nice portion and for $3 extra pork belly I got a lot of belly~ broth was decent, but a little thick and mild spice seems to have no spice at all.  

The appetizer was meh~ I had better, it was kinda pricy for $4.95 for 3 pieces of mini pizza bagel bite size portion.  Here's were I deducted 2 stars....Now the menu price and their whiteboard prices around the room DIFFERS.  The Spicy Miju was $4.95 when I ordered from the laminated menu, later I got the bill it says $5.95.  I asked the waitress saying they overcharged, the lady came back and said the price is right, and she told me to look at the menu.  I went HA and pointed the price right at the item and then she said oh sorry the price is different from the whiteboard which is right behind me.  Hmmm gee I did NOT think to look BEHIND my back and make sure the PRICE IS RIGHT!  So I urge everyone to look around for their signs and double check the price before ordering.

If you have a price change then you should simply cross out the price from the menu, use white out or sharpie and rewrite the new price. I mean $5.95 round $6 even, I pay $2 per spicy tuna on top of a small bread that looks like a mini pizza bagel bite.  Even bagel bite is twice the size!  A total rip off.  The price is totally not worth it, so F+ for the management!!  Never again am I ordering your scamming appetizers again. Ramen I'll give it another go.
author: Willis L.

description: My go to for ramen. Their spicy garlic broth is exceptional and addictive.
author: M. D.

description:
Great place, small but always filled. we came in for a late dinner so decided to have the drinks and food to match the happy hours.

I was amazed..more so amazed after the third glass of Sappiro at how yummy the soft shell crab tasted. arranged in a spicy sauce spread over greens, the crab just rightly crunchy. and not forgetting the house special ramen after all the side orders. we left happily.
author: Van V.

description: Delicious spicy garlic tonkatsu! Very flavorful broth! Along with my ramen, I also ordered the spicy chicken wings and tempura geso. The wings were a little too saucy for my liking, but that didn't stop me from finishing it. The geso was rather bland by itself, but with the dipping sauce it was just right. I would definitely come back for more tonkatsu!
author: Jack S.

description:
We had the Mushroom Torio (three kind of mushrooms) as an appetizer and it was very tasty. Both my BF and I ordered Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu is delicious, especially if you get it extra spicy. He sprang for the pork belly and mentioned that it was good. His sister got the Shoyu, which she liked. Good portion, good ramen, and I loved the mushrooms. 

It is fair to mention that if you're aiming to go vegetarian, mention it to them beforehand since all the dishes come with a bit of pork it seems.
author: Shauna S.

description:
For the first time yesterday, I did NOT burn the roof of my mouth and my tongue while eating this ramen.  The mystery of fire is contained in this earthenware bowl, graced by a spoon, garnished with food.  

My fiance and I have come here about once a week for the past few months.  It is always the same thing: He gets the tonkatsu ramen, I get the spicy garlic tonkatsu.  Occasionally, we'll add on a small don.  Usually a ten don.  Once or twice the then-BF got the japo-fried-chicken add-on.  

Ramen AND fried chicken, together?  What's not to love?  Well.  I think some of the other cooked foods are questionable.  I would not order curry don here.  The tempura (ten) don is laced with some kind of sweet teriyaki sauce and I keep forgetting to tell them to hold that sauce.  It could ruin the dish.  

But the ramen is a swift and merciful god.  It has this super fire red glaze at the top.  The bamboo shoots are just slightly pickled and remind me of the Taiwan countryside.  The countryside filled with rice farmers and earthenware clay jars full of pickled things.  

Yes, there could be more toppings.  But typically, I don't finish my bowl so I cannot in good faith claim that there was not enough food.

Oh, one time I got the uni nigiri here.  It was pretty generous.  

However, my sage-old advice is to stick to the glorious bowls of ramen.  Inhale deeply of the fire.  Wait a moment before shoving it into your mouth.   Because they don't make band-aids for the tongue.
author: Christina C.

description:
I was so excited when I saw that this place had ramen! Is it just me or is their storefront logo a but ambiguous? Sure, that little girl is cute and all, but I don't know. 

Came here with Edgar G. probably about a month ago. It wasn't too busy when we came in so we were seated at a table that could seat 6 people. I guess the workers didn't realize it was lunch hour and that there might possibly be a lunch time rush? I got the miso ramen. When it came with corn, seaweed, bean sprouts, bamboo shoots, and cha siu. The soup base wasn't the best-- I've had better. It would have been nice to have 1/2 an egg in there but you have to pay an extra dollar to have that. $1 can pretty much buy me 1/2 dozen of raw eggs at safeway! Well, I guess I should have known since this place is run by Chinese people-- another thing that makes me weary.... 

I don't think I will be returning anytime soon. But if it comes down to it, I might give it another try in the future. But for now I'm happy going to Japantown for my ramen.
author: Eugenia G.

description: First time dining here, waited for 10 mins then  got sat super close to a couple and their kids. Then got moved to the table behind us with more space.  Ordered the Hamachi &  Hotate Nigiri., and Spicy garlic ちんかつ (tonkatsu). For a small place the ramen was pretty darn good, the noodles and broth are fresh, the service is awesome.  Haven't had ramen like this in awhile. Overall 5/5.
author: Alvin N.

description: Super packed & waited 30 minutes, ramen was delicious... just wish their spicy ramen was spicier
author: Hana L.

description: Was here Monday 1/12/15 and I must say its pretty good. Others might be way better but I like sawaii because they have their own taste while having the great ramen taste.
author: Ken L.

description: This is by far me and my Wife's favorite ramen in the city. We drive from Russian Hill at least 2x's a month to come here. The spicy garlic tonkatsu is bomb, and I always order a side of extra noodles. If you're feeling adventurous then you can add fried chicken and toss it in your ramen which is amazing. I also love how they have two TV"s, just because I was there during the 18-inning Giants playoff game and the whole restaurant was going nuts. The TV's are not in your face so you're not distracted but if there is an important game then you'll catch all of the action.
author: Rory K.

description:
Ramen cravings continued...

I stopped in here Saturday afternoon and did not have to wait.  I've been wanting to come by ever since they opened last year and finally got the chance to.  Keeping it short, the ramen was just okay.  I appreciated the bamboo shoots and the consistency of the noodles, but sadly the flavoring was pretty bland.  I got the tonkatsu flavored broth and it only came with maybe 2 slices of meat.

So why 3 stars instead of 2?  Cuz I also got to try the chicken karaage and the Paradise roll.  Both of these items saved what would have otherwise been a very disappointing meal.  The chicken karaage comes with some house sauce and it's pretty good.  The chicken alone is very tasty and I dropped some into my ramen once I ran out of pork.  And the sushi roll was pretty impressive.  I thought it was on par with sushi you might get at Ebisu or some other similarly good sushi place.

I'd go back to Saiwaii, but probably not for the ramen.  I really want to try out more of their sushi and get some of that tasty chicken karaage again.
author: Joe M.

description:
SPICY GARLIC TONKATSU RAMEN - 4 stars. 

SERVICE - 2 stars.

TBH, it's more of a 3.5 star kind of restaurant. But hot dawg, that spicy garlic tonkatsu was pretty darn delicious. The broth was extremely tasty - pork flavored with a hint of garlic and spice - best part of the ramen for sure and in itself deserves 4 stars! I liked the meat, which was also really flavorful, but there was only 2 pieces. Booooo!

I don't like nit-picking on service, buuuuut I just have to say that the waiter that served my friend and I didn't seem like he knew what he was doing. I think he might have been new or just really flustered. When we were seated, it took him a while just to give us menus, and we felt awkward just sitting there and waiting. Then, my friend asked him what he recommended and he basically just read the menu to us. NO DUH man, we can read! But he obviously maybe has never tried the food here and thus had no opinion. Not helpful as a waiter.  

I'd come again for the spicy garlic tonkatsu - but I wish the service was better. Food always wins though at the end.

Saiwaii should upgrade their menus too, that printed out piece of paper isn't cute.
author: Stephanie B.

description: Having read all of the great reviews, and many critiques on Sawaii being able to satisfy my ramen craving, my wife and I walked away disappointed after our experience. The 2 stars aren't for the ramen, or service, but for the huge portion of delicious & crispy Chicken Karaage appetizer. First, after having our name called and seated, the waitress seemed to have forgotten that she seated us, and we ended up waiting for quite some time before having our order taken. My wife stuck with her guns and went with the Tonkatsu Ramen, while I went for the Regular Spicy Garlic Ramen, and a Chicken Karaage appetizer to share. My wife says the first couple sip of her Tonkatsu broth was delicious, but by the time she was done, she thought it lacked flavor and noticed her store bought noodles had an odd texture. My Spicy Garlic Ramen tasted like burnt garlic, and eventually I couldn't taste anything after my tongue went numb from the building heat. I wanted to enjoy the broth, but simply couldn't, because I kept choking on chili flakes that got stuck in my throat. Additionally, my store bought noodles were mushy, kept breaking, and falling back in the bowl causing the broth to splash me. Not to mention the waitress who kept avoiding eye contact when we were trying to wave her down for a water refill.
