I'd be willing to come back when it's a bit less busy, in the hopes that we get a quality meal on our next visit. If you're a ramen connoisseur, avoid SF unless you're going to Ramen Yamadaya, visit San Mateo for any of their ramen joints, or hit up Santa Clara for Orenchi to get your 'legit' experience
author: Gerald B.

description: I've eaten at Saiwaii Ramen several times over the past year and can't say enough good things about it. One of the owners, Jennifer has always been friendly and inviting when visiting. I will definitely be stopping in the next time I'm in the area.
author: Jim G.

description:
This is a good ramen spot that I like to go to when I am around the area. I never had to wait to get a table here unlike some of the super busy ramen places. It also is not as good as the other places but it is still good ramen. I have been here a few times and always enjoyed my food.

Food:
Spicy Garlic Pork- Very spicy and good

There are a few other flavors I tired but cant seem to remember which ones there were. However they were all good.
author: Elliot T.

description:
So I came here for the first time a month ago with my sister and her boyfriend since they kept raving about it.  

Service 2 1/2*
When we got there it was packed so we had to write our name on the clip board and wait. So we walked away for about 20 mins and when we got back we clearly saw that it was our turn next to be seated. We waited for the waitress to clean up. When she started walking towards the clip board we thought she was going to call our name but NoOo she totally skipped us and seated the people under our name. So we had to wait another 10mins.  =.=

Food 4*
I ordered Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu w/ Corn and Pork Belly and it was NOM NOM NOM what more can I say LOL  reason why I'm giving 4* instead of 5* was because the soup base was a little too powdery for me =/ 

Besides the the waitress forgot about us.. I think I would come back for another round when I have a chance =]
author: Erisa W.

description:
Finally tried here after always walking past it to eat pho.  Felt like ramen, so went for the spicy tonkotsu ramen + for $3 more, you can add a side donburi, i went for the tempura.  A small bowl of rice with a piece of shrimp, carrot, sweet potato and one other thing i can't remember tempura.  For $3, I think it was worth it.

The ramen was good, it was pretty spicy, which I liked.  They put these slices of pork belly inside too, which was good!  lots of fat!  Next time, I'm going to just try the tonkotsu ramen and see how it goes.

Service is good, super friendly and fast (though it was fairly empty when i went).
author: Jason Y.

description:
Ramen was mediocre and greasy, some bites left an unpleasant aftertaste in my mouth. 

The unagi donburi  was good, it probably saved this restaurant from receiving no stars. I will not be returning anytime soon!
author: Deanna W.

description:
The boyfriend craves ramen all the time while I crave tom yum soup. We compromise and switch off every now and then. 

One time sitting in the car outside of Teaway and trying to find a place to eat, we read on Yelp where a woman said she often eats at Sawaii and then walks to get Teaway. We both laughed and decided to find this place on foot. It was literally less than 200 feet away from us. 

Anywho, the broth is super delicious. I've had the miso ramen and the spicy garlic ramen. The miso wasn't salty at all like I have encountered at other places. The spicy garlic ramen is definitely spicy so tell them to make it mild if you can't handle spices. 

The staff is sooooo sweet! My bf and I called in 15 min before they were closing (since we just finished our date at Nightlife at the Academy of Sciences and were super hungry) to ask them if they could accommodate us and the friendly waitress said yes. The owner chilled at a table watching the Giants game to wait for us to finish and to say goodbye. 

I think this is our Ramen spot now since it's so much closer than Genki's!
author: Vikki K.

description: Delicious ramen! I got it with pork broth and fried chicken, but better than a ramen I got in Oakland, we made it there right before closing time and the employees were still very attentive and patient.
author: Monica C.

description: Not a big place, food is fresh, Ramen is likely to become one of the favorite, liked it a LOT!!!
author: Keltt W.

description:
Sawaii Ramen is usually pretty packed with people at lunch time and it can be difficult to get a seat.  I have been here many times, and it has been very consistent every time that I have been here.

I usually get the Shoyu Ramen with Unagi Don combo which comes out to around $10.95 + tax and I can say its a pretty decent deal because I do feel full after eating that.  There are times where I have substituted with pork belly, and I do not think that is necessarily worth it because the pork belly portion itself is small and it doesn't strike me as worth $3 for like 2-3 pieces.  The ramen quality itself is okay, the noodles are nice and chewy.  The broth is pretty standard with their Shoyu which is kind of a testament to their ramen (nothing really stands out to surprise me at Sawaii).

As far as the ambiance/environment, it is pretty tight quarters between table to table and that ruins the dining experience a little bit.  On occasion, they have had new/in training waiters and they have been flimsy about getting orders completed and served in a timely manner, but usually service has been pretty good at Sawaii.

Overall, I would say its about average, and I would come back if I wanted a quick fix on ramen for a good price.  Not the best ramen I've had.
author: Lawrence E.

description: This is some pretty solid ramen at a decent price. There are a handful of different ramen bowls, some spicy some not. They all have more or less the same ingredients, but vary in soup base. There's tonkotsu, shio, shoyu, and miso. The miso was good and not too salty. The noodles were a good texture, not too soft or hard. The croquettes had corn and pork. The potato was a little too dense and not fluffy enough, but delicious still and served on a large bed of shredded cabbage. There's also a sushi menu aside from the ramen menu. The fish looked pretty fresh as far as I could tell. The nigiri was a good portion of rice to fish. Next time, I would want to come back to try that pork belly and more of the side dishes like the grilled squid. Tea is complimentary. The decor was nice and contemporary, trying to be classy. The restroom was clean. There was one flatscreen tv and it was showing cooking shows. Service was great.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I've been to genki, men oh, izakaya sozai, ken ken, katanaya, and none of them even come CLOSE to how good the ramen is at Saiwaii. Get the spicy Tonkotsu + soft boiled egg and DO NOT PASS UP THE PORK BELLY. It'll make you weep, it's so good.
author: Shayan S.

description: OMG love the ramen here. The spicy garlic miso soup is so flavorful with the crispy garlic bits, I don't even care if I get garlic breath after. Noodles are cooked to perfection, and they come garnished with a variety of random things like bamboo shoots and some green vegetable. Spicy mala karaage ramen was also really good with a nicely-done soft boiled egg and tastyy chicken. Honestly, I don't even realize that they have sushi here because I just come for the amazing ramen. Heck I just come for the ramen broth.. I could consume a few bowls and be happy.
author: Sarah L.

description: Service was good, but Ramen was just "A-Ok."  Ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen, and I thought the broth was a little bland.
author: Joshua P.

description:
ramen... eh... average...  

I've been on a ramen binge ever since I visited japan.  I decided to give saiwaii a try.  now I can say I tried it.  in my opinion it's like eating instant ramen.  

I can honestly say I won't be coming back.
author: Samson M.

description:
Just came back from dinner @ Saiwaii, it was my second time there.

We were gonna go to Izakaya Sozai for ramen, but it was soo packed when we got there (Friday 7:30pm) and the wait was more than an hour. We were starving by then, so we just went to Saiwaii Ramen down Irving to fill our tummys. 

We were the last table they seated immediately before they started a name list. We sat down, ordered, talked for a bit, and then we realized that the table sat down after us got their food first. We were a bit annoyed, but were calmed down as soon as we got our food.

We got an order of Unagi Avocado, Sake Avocado, and Ebi Avocado each. There were 6 pieces in a roll, and they were okay; not spectacular, okay for 4 dollars. It was food, and we gulped it down.

I ordered Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu, regular spicy, and it was actually delicious when I first started. I love my ramen scalding hot. I always start a bowl of ramen with a sip of the broth; a good bowl of ramen is deeply depended on its broth. Like the normal Tonkotsu ramen, the broth wasn't thick and creamy, but it does have a nice tonkotsu flavor, and it was rich and spiiiicy. There's not really a garlicy flavor to it, which I didn't really mind (no smelly breath after!). The noodles were the normal yellow noodles, nothing special about it. 

My friend got the same thing, but he got his super spicy. I had a sip of his broth and it was indeed spicy. It's got a nice strong kick at the end, it's got a spicy aftertaste. He eats spicy everyday, and he couldn't finish the broth. (but he eats more of a Mexican spicy than Asian spicy)

My boyfriend got the normal Tonkotsu ramen that's not at all spicy. It was mild, kind of thick, definitely not cloudy. Each bowl of ramen has 3 pieces of chashu, I gave my boyfriend my chashu, and he said it tasted better when it soaked up all the spiciness in the broth. 

It was really good when you first dive in when you're all starving, but half way through it got kinda bland. It wasn't like ichiran where you finish the whole bowl and you want to fit another bowl in your stomach. Go get some if you're just a few blocks away and craving for brothy savory food in a cold foggy night!
author: Erica L.

description: I went for the garlic ramen for lunch one day, and really enjoyed it. I'm not a ramen expert, but I thought it was delicious and something I would definitely return for. Service was prompt and extremely friendly, and I thought prices were alright (a little higher that some pho places down the block, but I guess you get more in the soup).
author: Eve D.

description:
We always have to give ramen joints a try. They last two places we tried were Ajisen Ramen and Ramen Doraku, and the ramen at both were horrible! Let's put it this way,  I didn't even finish the bowl of ramen while eating at both and I hate wasting food! Anyhow, due to my bad ramen experiences, I was a bit reluctant to try Saiwaii Ramen, but since a few people recommended it, I had to try it!  I have to face the fact that I will never have the flavorful ramen I had in Japan in San Francisco.

We went to Saiwaii Ramen with an open mind. We started with the Kobe Beef Salad, featuring slices of lightly grilled fatty and tender Kobe Beef, on top of the spring salad and onions, with a hint of ginger. Yum, yum, yum...I highly recommend this if you go! Since they offer combination meals with the ramen, we added the Spicy Tuna Don, it was not the best, but it was not bad either, it was a nice cold side dish.  And then our ramens...my hubby ordered the Tonkotsu and I ordered the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu. Both tonkotsu were served with chashu, bamboo shoots, seaweed, green onion and kikurage (also known to us Chinese as 'wood ear'). We both added the Pork Belly, I didn't realize that I forgot to add the Egg until I was halfway done! I heard their egg is marinated in soy sauce and the yolk is runny, I will have to try it next time.

The outcome? The Tonkotsu (non-spicy) was milky and flavorful. I then tried my Mild Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu, oh yeah, this is what I'm talking about, it was very flavorful and the spice was perfect, not spicy to the point where I couldn't taste my food. The ramen was actually good too, the texture was crunchy chewy, it didn't get soggy right away. The soy sauce Pork Belly was extremely fatty and the fatty part melted like butter, but I do have to say that the meaty part of it was not that tender.
author: Eva L.

description:
I didn't expect to find a decent bowl of ramen on Irving that wasn't from Izakaya Sozai, but I was pleasantly surprised by the spicy-garlic ramen from Saiwaii! 

I'll concede now that the best bowl of ramen I've had is at Ramen Dojo in San Mateo, but if you can't wait an hour for ramen, why not go to Saiwaii? My boyfriend and I were seated immediately during dinner time. Not bad.

I've yet to try the sushi, but we shared the chicken wings and beef tongue as appetizers and they were pretty darn good. And if you still have room you can stop by Teaway a few shops down for self-serve boba. Yum.
author: Patricia Q.

description: I always see people waiting in a line during the lunch time on weekend. I finally got a chance to try the Ramen there. I went to there for a quick lunch on Thursday; the restaurant was not packed, so I didn't spend any minutes for waiting. The restaurant is neither big nor fancy, but I feel quite comfortable with everything there. People continuously come and go, I believe it is a good place for quickly grabbing a lunch.  The lunch special is a good choice, my hubby liked it. I ordered mild spicy garlic Miso Ramen and a sushi Roll with (eel, real crab meat and avocado$ 6.75). The Ramen was very flavorful especially the fried sliced garlic that gave the Miso broth more zest. Will be back soon to try more dishes.
author: Wendy W.

description:
I ordered the Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu ramen lunch special with the salmon avocado 6 piece. It was $10, but extra $2 for the Spicy Garlic ramen, so basically two dollars extra for a sushi roll since the ramen is normally $10 without the lunch special. 

The ramen was really tasty! I got the mild one, but it still had a good amount of spicy taste, and the garlic flavor was really strong and delicious. Usually, I don't really care about the little foods in the bowl and just eat it, but the bamboo pieces and mushroom or tree ear, whatever it is, tasted really good. Everything was great together. I wish i ordered a boiled egg though; I did not know it didn't come with one, but that was my mistake. The pieces of pork were mostly fat with a little bit of meat, which was tasty, but I prefer more meat than fat. The broth was delicious, and the noodle texture was chewy and fresh tasting. One other thing I didn't like was I felt the portion was pretty small. I usually eat half of my meals and take the rest home for another meal, but without the sushi roll, I don't think I would have been that full. The sushi roll was pretty good, just a normal roll with avocado and salmon. 

The service was good, our server was very nice. The place is pretty small and feels a bit cramped, but good thing there were only two little tables being used when we walked in. We arrived probably around 12 on a Monday. During our meal time though, most of the tables were filled. 

I would come here again! Although, since there are so many different ramen places in sf, I would probably check out a few first and see which one is my favorite.
author: Rorie L.

description: This is really one of my go to places when I crave for Ramen. Price is reasonable  and staff is friendly. I can't say I tried everything on the menu, but if you are a first timer here and not sure what to order. My suggestion is to try the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Or Miso and get an egg on it.
author: mrhustler h.

description:
I have been here a couple times already and really enjoy their Ramen on a cold San Francisco day. I have tried their Spicy Miso and Tonkatsu, both very tasty and pretty okay priced. It is really hard for me to judge ramen since I didn't really grow up eating it too much but its a great filler. Typically my guest and I will get the Combination which I have tried Tuna Sashimi with rice and also their Unagi Don. 

This place is a bit small so expect to be hearing the conversation (or kids) of the people around you. It does get a little cramped during the busy hours but I have no complaints about it! I think the service is acceptable as well. 

For how many times I have been here I would call myself a fan and would recommend it to someone who wants a good bowl of Ramen!
author: Tracy Joy K.

description:
Three things I look for in ramen, Broth, Noodles, and Meat. I ordered the Tonakatsu Ramen and the broth was OK. Flavor was not too rich, but soup base was creamy. The pork was tender. The only thing that ruined the ramen experience here was the noodles. They were way too soggy. It was almost as if they had left the noodles in for too long? Maybe it was an off-night with the noodles?

My hubby ordered the Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu and his broth was very oily. I liked my broth a lot better.
author: Lilmisslisa W.

description:
food: 3/5 (ramen)
service: 3/5 average asian service
decor/atmosphere: 4/5

Came here several times with a small group. The wait on weekends are long, but weekdays the place is hardly ever packed unless you just come at the wrong time. This is a chinese owned place, but they do decent ramen. I usually have the tonkotsu ramen or shoyu ramen here. I would say the broth is good but not the best I had.
author: Cecile S.

description: Not bad we thought.  I had the spicy seafood noodles which wasn't too spicy (good thing).  Mid-size but tidy place.  We came in before the big rush, so that was lucky.  Good service with mid-market prices.
author: Joel M.

description:
Best tonkotsu broth in the city!! Add to that some scrumptiously decadent pork belly cubes? I'm in ramen heaven.

For me, the most important part of ramen is the broth and they nail it here. It's flavourful, collagen-y, and not too oily. To make the already rich and porky ramen even richer and porkier, the perfectly braised pork belly cubes are incredibly tender, sweet, and full of flavour. I mean, just look at this beauty: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=9D5FbB5TFH5GQ_khRhWwOw. I'm normally not a fan of fatty cuts of meat like pork belly, but I *always* get them here. They really are *that* good (I especially love the chewy skin on top) and indubitably worth the extra time at the gym I'll have to spend to work them off. The noodles are cooked well and have a good chew to them. Of course, there are also the standard ramen toppings: chashu, bamboo shoots, wood ear fungus, seaweed, and green onions (though I wish they didn't charge extra for the egg). The chashu is decent, but pales in comparison to the marvelous pork belly. I take my time composing each spoonful so that I get a little bit of everything in each bite. It can be a little tedious, but so worth the time.

In addition to their fabulous tonkotsu ramen, they also have a pretty wide selection of very reasonably priced appetizers and sushi too. My favourite is their hiyayakko (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=C9Gzg4J5sEBKtknaK4yIcA). I've eaten my way through SF looking for the best hiyayakko and it's here at Saiwaii. The large blocks of silken tofu is topped with a generous portion of bonito flakes and green onions (most places don't give you enough). They also serve this with ponzu sauce, which I prefer to the standard soy sauce since it's not as salty and has more flavour.

I'm also a fan of their California special roll (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7Cl-sZlymEjhxm0MJTR7nw?select=EhfFjJjXhdBHqtHH6MujjQ), which is basically a California roll with unagi added. Yum!
author: Steph L.

description:
I've been here before a couple of times and I thought the ramen was pretty good, filling and reasonably priced. Service was friendly too.

I came back about 3 weeks ago and boy did it change. I ordered the shoyu ramen with my gf and when it came....I was speechless. As soon as the waitress put the bowl down, I could smell the noodles and it smelled like WONTON NOODLES. Seriously? I couldn't believe it. I confirmed this after my gf and I tasted and we both agreed. I seriously can't believe a ramen restaurant is using wonton noodles as their "ramen". Other than the horrible, the service was pretty bad too. I had a hard time getting the attention of the waitress while she helped other tables and ignored us. 

This was my experience and maybe others had a different experience but I would not recommend this place anymore. I came here expecting ramen, not wonton noodles. If I wanted wonton noodles I'd go to the chinese restaurant a few blocks down.
author: Jae C.

description: The pork tonkatsu is really good! It's so flavorful and you get a lot of food.  They usually have really good specials on apps and their sushi is pretty good too.  But don't come here for that, definitely get the pork tonkotsu! :)
author: P N.

description:
I got the BBQ pork ramen and my sister the spicy garlic ramen. Both were delish, and the BBQ pork was so tender that I was confused whether I was eating meat or fat.

The food is very presentable, but portions are, arguably, a little small.
author: B H.

description:
Two visits, both for tonkatsu ramen: one not bad, one less than mediocre. 

The pork-based broth is flavorful without being overly salty- you can tell they use genuine pork/bones.

The pork meat is on the rougher side, not tender.

The noodle itself is average, the second time I came here it was actually slightly undercooked and there was a giant clump of noodle in my bowl. It can't be that hard to cook noodles right? There's no clumps in my ramen when I cook it at home.. 

The bamboo pieces are not so great- kind of stinky taste-wise (only when you eat it).

The black fungus, seaweed, and green onion are normal, nothing special to mention.

Would probably come back, but only for lunch, since they do make a nice broth and play either football or Kung Fu panda on their tv.
author: K. N.

description:
I'm definitely a happy camper with this place. 


The restaurant is a little small, typical SF, but on a saturday night we were able to get at able comfortably.

Ramen is nice and tender. Doesn't get mushy. Broth is delicious, not too salty. I'm a big fan of the miso ramen and it came out just how I like it! I definitely want to go back and try other things they have. They offer quick polite service. My friends and I were holding up a table, but they didn't give us any problem for sitting around a little longer after we finished our food.

Definitely will come back!
author: Christine B.

description:
It was a Saturday night at 8pm and hubby and I decided to have a quickie.. meaning we wanted to find a restaurant, get in, eat ramen and get out. Thus.. a quickie! 

Out of the decent ramen places in the city, that means Katana-Ya and Izakaya Sozai is automatically thrown out of the equation because the wait would be 45+ minutes. I called Sawaii and they were able to save a table for us which means no wait. 

We had the garlic spicy miso ramen for me and a garlic spicy tonkotsu for the hubby. 

Both soups were flavorful and rich. After a few sips of the spicy soup (regular spicy, mind you), we both couldn't feel our lips and our noses were running from the spice. I thought I had a high tolerance for spicy but boy, the "regular" spicy is really spicy! Next time I'll just go mild or none at all. 

On that note, I believe the owner is the same as "Sawaii Sushi" on Kearny , another "quickie pseudo-japanese" lunch spot in the FiDi. I saw her give the sushi chef the stare down to make sure he was doing everything right. The waitresses were very sweet, but the owner lady's intense eyes made my experience not so pleasant, hence I deducted a star because I can't stand micromanagers!
author: Nancie T.

description:
I came here for lunch and ordered tonkatsu ramen, miso ramen, and a dynamite roll. 

The waiter was nice and service was good. 

The ramen was good, but I didn't think it was amazing. The tonkatsu broth tasted better than the miso. 

Now for the dynamite roll, the waiter asked us how it was because it was a new item, and we told him it was good, because it was. 

Dynamite roll is usually deep fried spicy tuna roll at most restaurants, but here, it was deep fried california roll with spicy mayo sauce. 

We didn't know that when we ordered it, but it was still okay. But I feel a little ripped off because it was 9$. Come on now, 9$ for... california roll... It's like we paid an extra 5 dollars to have it deep fried. 

I like this place though. I'll just have to read the menu more carefully from now on.
author: Christina X.

description: Was craving ramen today and ended up coming here for lunch. Luckily when we got there, there was an open table so we were seated right away. I had the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen, which I thought it was was okay, but nothing special. My friend got the hamachi sushi and said the rice tasted below average and the fish was very thick and warm. Overall, we probably won't be coming back.
author: Angela F.

description:
There was literally no wait when we came in on a Saturday night. I ended  up here with the boyfriend because I was craving Ramen like crazy. Upon walking in, we were seated immediately, given menus and waters to drive. the waters were consistently filled throughout the meal and plates cleared as we finished dishes. very good service. The layout of the place is cane be a bit uncomfortable because the place is so small. its literally just a rectangular area. There s so little room some parties who didn't know each other has to sit together.

Now..on tot he food. The boyfriend and I ordered two ramens, fried oysters and fried gyoza. The fried gyoza was bland and too oily for me. IT was definitely a skip in my book. THe fried oysters were delicious to me. The boyfriend didn't like it, but then again he doesn't like oysters ( i know, he's crazy). Now..on tot he RAMEN. SSOOO DELICIOUS!!! I got the spicy pork one and added egg. THe boyfriend got the regular pork and added egg and extra pork belly. BOth of the broths were DELICIOUS. The noodles were just perfect for me. IT wasn't too hard or too mushy. I thoroughly enjoyed my ramen and felt it was worth  every penny. 

OVer all the restaurant is very good. Im totally a fan. Im planning to come back and try some other dishes but will definitely have the ramen again. :) Oh and just incase anyone cares..the owners or at least the servers seem to be cantonese.
author: Samantha H.

description:
This place is not that bad. 

I had a Spicy Tonkatsu with Pork Belly and an egg. I thought the soft boiled egg was a a little way too runny. It was almost to the point of watery consistency. The broth has good taste and the pork belly was very flavorful. The noodles had a firm bite which is the way I like my noodles. I did notice the noodles were a bit long and was difficult to get into the spoon with the throw-away chopsticks.The chashu also was a little bland. 

Overall this place was okay, but it wasn't wow factor. Service was great and if I was in a pinch for ramen close-by, I would definitely consider this place again.
author: Derek N.

description:
Love this place. I've never had their sushi here, but their Ramen is super authentic (I think so anyway, I've only been to Japan once). I always get the Cha Siu Ramen with Corn and Egg and never EVER do I order it without the Pork Belly. The Pork Belly is SOOO Delicious, it melts in your mouth. Its $3 extra for 3 big pieces, but you will not be able to stop thinking about it once you've had it. I definitely find myself craving it from time to time. 

If you haven't tried this place, I highly recommend it.
author: Ping N.

description:
Eh. Sorry, no bueno in my book. 

Tried their signature spicy garlic miso ramen, and it was fairly subpar. The broth was super salty for my tastes (and I love salt), lukewarm, and too heavy. The bowl was crowded with raw sprouts and the noodles were just average. My mom and I also shared a roll, its name I can't recall at the moment, but it was your standard bastardized cop-out roll with some kind of sweet unagi sauce/avocado garnish combo on top that overpowered the whole thing. All six tiny pieces that we paid nearly a dollar each for. 

In an especially trying attempt on my part to love this little neighborhood (for us Sunset folk) joint, I walked out of my experience here with a heavy heart and a somewhat unsettled stomach and appetite.

It also doesn't really help that the entire strip of Irving holds more Asian noodle joints than I can't count with my fingers and toes. Maybe if Sawaii Ramen were the only Asian/noodle restaurant in the area, it'd garner a higher score from me.  Shrug.
author: Betty W.

description:
I finally tried this place and I have to say that it was just mediocre. I ordered their spicy ramen and the broth was not as flavorful as I was expecting.  Nothing to get excited over.  Just your average meal on a 
weekday night.  
Overall I rate this place 3 stars.
author: Janelle D.

description: Love love love the food here. Always fast and friendly service. I don't live in sf anymore and drive 2 hours just to eat here.
author: Yolanda E.

description:
Note: this review is based off comparisons with my favorite ramen places in California (Santouka, Orenchi, Daikokuya, Ramen Dojo)

*Pros*
1. No wait or weird hours!  Came here on Sunday around noon and didn't have to wait at all for a table.  Throughout the meal until the end, there may have only been 1 party waiting?

2. Great broth.  Thicker spicy broth reminds me of Ramen Dojo.

3. Pork belly option!  This is hovering over the *typical* section though since it wasn't as tender as I hoped, though it was packed with flavor.

4. Kalbi appetizer!  Who doesn't like kalbi?  With that said though, it was a tiny bit more fatty than I prefer.

5. NOM.  The bowl was packed full of stuff.  Saiwaii definitely doesn't skimp.

*Typical*
1. Noodles weren't any special or up to Orenchi/Halu quality, though they weren't soggy either.  

2. Price was about standard ramen price.  

*Cons*
1. Their attempt at a soft boiled egg kind of fizzled.  $1 definitely should give me something gooey and semi warm.  Theirs was more solid than anything and cold :(

2. While it was more endearing than anything, I still prefer to sit farther than half an arm's length away from the neighboring table.  It was endearing because my neighbor was an adorable baby girl that was fascinated by me.

Overall, I'd come back here, if not for the convenience of a lack of a wait and good price for ramen in the city.  However, it doesn't quite deserve a 5 star rating to the likes of the aforementioned.
author: Jeff N.

description:
This place is hands down my favorite place to have ramen in the area. Having lived in the sunset for a couple years I was excited to have found an awesome place for ramen. I used to think ramen places were a joke cause I always kept thinking of Top Ramen. I guess the joke was on me.

I'll take a Spicy Garlic Miso with Extra Pork Cube and an egg please. 

I recommend this place to everyone I know. Oh and they have two tv's in there that usually has the game on. Bonus Points.
author: Joey T.

description: Sushi here is always fresh and tasty! The ramen is delicious! Customer service is great. The workers are friendly and helpful. The place is clean and the bathroom is sanitary. I usually never have to wait to be seated but dinner time gets really packed.
author: Charlene T.

description:
As the name indicates, this place sells mostly ramen. During lunch, they offer a set menu with your soup choice of ramen and choice of 6 pieces of rolls for approximately $10. 

The place was at 70% capacity at 3pm with only one waitress. However, the service was quite fast because the sushi man also ran the tables. 

The soup base could be better and the noodle quantity bigger. My friend felt that the ramen was a bit hard, but i personally like the noodle to be "qq", so just a matter of preference.

The rolls were quite tasty and recommended.
author: Jaime S.

description: Came here for ramen, sushi, and don. The food is pretty good we got Tonkotsu Ramen, Chicken Katsu and Curry Chicken Don and the sushi combo. The food is pretty good but it came a little slow but the service was pretty good here. The funny thing was that we ordered don and mistakenly thought it was udon when the server said the don't serve udon which was sort of embarrassing. I would be coming back here later on for another try.
author: Peter C.

description: Great flavor in the spicy garlic tonkotsu. Get the Kara age on the side to maintain the crisp.
author: Jennifer S.

description: The Tonkotsu Ramen was good, not bad, not excellent. We were seated straightaway and the service was efficient. The soup was a little slow in coming out, but the smells from the kitchen were appetizing.  If I come back I will check out the other things on their menu.
author: Susan B.

description: My wife & I got the spicy garlic soft shell crab and then spicy garlic Tonkatsu & normal Tonkatsu ramen bowls. They were all very good. Tight space for a stroller, but we managed. Service was also v good.
author: Paul K.

description: I ate a spicy tonkatsu ramen and was sick for 3 days.  This place is danegerous do not come here.
author: Jim J.

description: Always packed but we didn't wait too long to be seated. Ramen was delicious and sushi rolls were really good!
author: Evin A.

description: I liked this place. It was busy on a random week night. The food was good and the ramen filled me up. I'm not the most experienced ramen connoisseur so don't take my ramen knowledge as a word from god. The hand made gyoza was delicious too, highly recommended.
author: Michael S.

description:
My wife and I were planning to meet some people in SF to sight-see a bit and have dinner, so we came down a bit early to have a ramen lunch and enjoy some sights on our own.

Food: My wife ordered the miso ramen and I took a tonkotsu. I liked the tonkotsu broth much better: It was more unctuous and flavorful. I almost feel like they use the same base for both broths, which, given the difference in style between the two, was probably a poor choice. The noodles came out already overcooked and too soft. My wife added egg to her order and she was not disappointed (egg is her favorite part), but I don't think she was over the moon either. The chashu was very good.

Service: Wait staff were great and refilled my water promptly and cheerfully.

Ambiance: Sports on the TV, lots of tables full of happy faces. Typical ramen joint.

Bottom Line: It's just nothing special, sad to say, but I would come back if I were hungry and in the area.
author: Jake L.

description:
Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen.

with Braised Pork Belly add-on (Buta Kakuni)

HELLA GOOD.  flavor. FLAAAAVVVVORRRR!

in terms of the pork-based broth and braised belly---the closest thing I've had so far in SF that SOMEWHAT resembles the flavors/texture of the Akamaru Moden ramen from Ippudo in NYC.  The noodles were not that awesome (i like Katana-Ya's better), but the broth and belly really are the stars of this ramen.

=8)
author: Grace M.

description:
This location has changed hands once again.  I didn't care for the prior restaurant.  The present restaurant is a pleasant addition to the neigborhood...it did lack a good ramen place.  I only gave it 3 stars not because of the food but for the ambience...there is none.  Imagine 36 people in a mere 200 sq ft room...each table speaking louder than the other so you can be heard.  If your looking for a quiet atmosphere, this is not the place.  Tables are jam packed to each other...fire marshall no likey.

The menu was plain and produced in-house.  It was printed on logo paper and place inside the menu folder.  Even the hole-in-the-walls around them uses a professional printer.

The ramen was good but pricey.  If you like it spicy, it will cost an addition dollar.  That's right...a dollar for extra spice.  A dollar is not much but it's the principle of getting ripped off.

The poke salad was extremely salty with raw onion.  The raw onion over powers most of the favors.  Once you taste the onion...game over.

Million dollar question...would I go back.  Only when its not jam packed...so what does that mean with a very same restaurant that only seats about 36.
author: MickYee M.

description: To me personally, it is always frustrating seeing one star reviews based entirely on one bad incidence with the service which does not necessarily reflect the true quality of a restaurant.  While Saiwaii does not by any means have top notch ramen, their price range (which is low and very reasonable) relative to the food, is excellent.  10 bucks for a roll and a bowl of very decent ramen for lunch special is an awesome deal. Less than 7 bucks for the tonkatsu over rice with salad and miso soup was also a very nice deal. Salad dressing tasted homemade and delicious. Tonkatsu was quite tasty too.  This place is easily above 3 and a half star. I have been to this place over five times and the service was never a problem. Wait staff is nice and polite.
author: Mike S.

description: This place has the spiciest Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen ever. And I love that! But the thing I didn't like was the noodle. It's a weird level of tenderness.. and it has a weird texture. Seems fake. I can't really explain it, but bad noodles can be a deal breaker for me... even though the soup is soo good! Come to think of it though, I don't think their noodles were always that way. But sorry Saiwaii, can't come back til I know you've replaced those noodles!!
author: Athena L.

description:
Yay, Ramen!

Got some katsu ramen and loved every delicious spoonful.
author: Christopher B.

description:
Parking is easy on the street after 7 PM.

Wait for a table for 3 was about 20 minutes.

Miso broth is bland.

Tonkatsu broth was more tasteful but still less flavorful than other tonkatsu broths I have tried.

Ramens start at $8.45. It is cheap compared to other ramen parlors but nothing I'd ever come back to.
author: Derek N.

description:
Price for ramen is expensive here. My ramen pork tonkatsu bowl, adding the fatty pork for $3 and corn, came out to about $16 w/o TIP! 

Wanted to give the local sunset ramen place a try, since DOJO was on vacation. Service was slow - not enough employees? that the sushi chef had to bus tables and seat others at the same time.  Tables are packed and really close to each other.  Just didn't enjoy the feeling of people breathing down my neck and ease dropping on my conversations.  

It was difficult to flag a waitress down to get a refill on tea/water and our ramen bowls didn't come out until 20mins later.  My coworker and I did arrive during prime dinner time, which can explain the lengthy time for our meal to arrive. 

The soup base WAS flavorful and spicy.  Still not as good as DOJO's broth/noodles,. but it was def different than choosing PHO for dinner. 

The ramen came with bamboo shoots, ground meat, seaweed, onions and those spicy threads that tops it off. 

Although there are certain downsides of the restaurant, but if i was in the area and didn't want to eat boring pho.  I def don't mind coming here and eating another $16 bowl of ramen.  I may hold off on the fatty pork, I just didn't think it was worth $3 for 3 pieces. eh?!
author: Chanel L.

description:
I've only been here once a few days ago. My friend posted photos of the ramen on his FB and it looked good, so I thought I'd give it a go even tho other friends have told me it was just "ok". 

I ordered the spicy pork tonkatsu ramen. MSG!! and tons of it. My friend and I were thirsty all evening and had that tingle in your mouth you get from too much MSG. So needless to say the soup was too salty and wasn't too flavorful. (Maybe because my taste buds were numb from all the MSG.)  However, I have to say that the pork belly we added ($3) was delicious but obviously very fatty. You get 3 pieces to the order. 

The restaurant is very small and noisy. The waitress asked us to move to another table after we were already seated to accommodate a large party, no big deal. A couple next to us ordered there food and one of them received their food and nearly finished it before the other party received their food. They seem very disorganized as they forgot part of our order and still charged us for it. So check your receipt before paying.
author: Terri Y.

description:
Rainy day haven!!!
Saiwaii Ramen has some pretty good noodles although I prefer ramen with a teensy bit more al dente quality to it. However, the BROTH is where the real party's at!!! 

In my couple of visits so far, I've tried Miso, Tonkatsu and Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu in both mild and medium. All have been pretty full bodied and hearty broths that warmed both my tummy and my soul. The Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu in medium was like boiling lava for me but I couldn't stop eating it! However, if you are not a garlic lover or you're on a hot date, this is probably not the broth for you. You will definitely smell like what you ate afterwards :P

The ramen lunch specials is a pretty good deal; $9.95 for a steaming hot bowl of ramen (spicy garlic one are $2+) and a 6 piece sushi roll (sake and avocado anyone?). I want to try more of the menu, so I think I'll be rolling back the next foggy city day (which will probably be.....every day this summer).
author: Rayna L.

description:
Always in search of some competition for my top noodle slurp joint (orenchi) I made it here just in time for the end of the lunch rush.  I think this was the old location of So yeah??!!  Alright so based on great revs from friends- Nobu, Wakako and Aaron.. I was ready for some greatness.

There are numerous staple choices to go with for the soupbase and creative concoctions that include crab, which I might have to go with next time.  Since this was my first kiss I went at the spicy garlic tonkatsu.

This truly lives up to the name as it was soo spicy my head was like I threw some soul glow in it, you know- drip, drip, drip!  I ate up like a whole bulb of garlic in the bowl which for some is a negative but I say the more the merrier.

The bamboo shoots and corn were all flavored but crispy and also ordered a side of buta kakuni and tori karaage that made my stomach smile.

In the cold ass, freezing Bay Area weather my diet has transformed to a doobu, ramen, pho and sol gam tang diet.  Though sawaii did not break my top 3 spots for ramen I can make room for it in the rotation.  Prices are great, service is choice and though no sake or beer avail, you can bring in ur own alco which totally meshes with the hood.
author: omar b.

description: This place was my very first ramen house I've ever been to and trying ramen. I ordered the spicy garlic tonkotsu with a side of pork belly. The ramen noodles were good but as for the broth I didn't think it was spicy enough and lack of flavor but eating with the side of the fried chicken made it better. As for the pork belly I didn't like it so i traded with my bf for his fried chicken. Overall I would come back unless I find somewhere else that's better. So it's pretty decent but nothing special to me.  I don't have much to say cause I have nothing to compare to other ramen house since this was my first experience.
author: Sabrina P.

description:
Affordable ramen that is not in Japantown!

This place is really good and has great customer service! I had the shoyu ramen with a small tekka don. Shared a kara age.   The broth was really good and not too salty. Delish!
author: Melissa T.

description:
Its been a few months since my initial visit - so time to go back and see if things have improved. 

It seems their menu has expanded a bit and they have daily specials listed on the board. 

I tried the spicy garlic miso ramen and the bf had the miso ramen with pork belly.  When our ramen came out - i noticed how hot (temperature) the broth was and i LIKE that! I hate eating lukewarm soup. I thought the broth was much improved and more flavorful than last time. The spicy miso taste reminded me of the Korean bean curd sorta taste. Either way delicious - I drank all the broth. The serving size of the noodles is quite generous and I tried the pork belly from the bf and it was delicious. I like how they have you 4 or so pieces. 

Good job Saiwaii for improving -- keep it up!!
author: Julie F.

description:
Got here on the weekend around 2:30, only a few people in there at the time, went and got a seat the window to people watch, soak up some sun and fresh air. 

Ordered the spicy garlic tonkotsu, the broth had good flavor and little heat but was just lukewarm, maybe he misunderstood when I say medium, he applied to the temperature and not the spiciness?? Anyway I was disappointed but was too hungry to send it back. Cha shu was on the chewy side, and noodle could be better, didn't have the springiness I was hoping for.  

It did fill my belly, but the price was a tad much for doing just that, I guess being in SF has high overhead, so they have to charge accordingly.  

Decor is nice and the server was friendly, maybe I would stop by again if in the neighborhood, but I won't make a special trip just to come here.
author: Jim C.

description: The spicy garlic tanksu is the most amazing ramen I have ever had ... Best sushi rolls are the las Vegas and the 49er.... I come in beds weekly and so do all 6 of my roommates
author: Angela L.

description:
It's true - I am really am not that adventurous when it comes to food. Honestly, I ate a lot of Italian food when I visited Japan and despite growing up next to Japantown, I  really don't know Japanese food very well.
So when a friend suggested Ramen for dinner,  I just told myself, how bad can noodles in broth be, right?   I decided to jump in and get what my friend's husband recommend and was glad I did. 
I ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu and asked for it spicy.  Even though the waitress seemed to doubt I'd be able to eat it, I found the spicing enjoyably  hot. Though I didn't know what all the bits were in the soup, it was delicious and warming and just right for a cold Sunset evening. (And since it almost always  cold in the evening   it's a perfect soul  food for its locale, if you ask me.)  I couldn't finish my noodles but did manage to finish all the unctuous pork and bright, fresh spinach. 
The sushi and miscellaneous appetizers looked intriguing - I'll have to come back for the bacon wrapped asparagus and the fried chicken bones(?) 
We arrived about 6:45 on a weeknight and were able to get a table without a wait but the line had definitely formed by the time we left.
author: Marie K.

description:
I had been wanting to try out this restaurant and i was extremely happily surprised!

They make a pretty decent tonkotsu ramen, the standard in San Francisco and the Kyushu province signature ramen!

They also have izakaya items. We tried the nankotsu-age (deep fried chicken soft bone) and it was pretty yummy, a bit heavy on the batter but still tasty. 

Their chashu pork was da noms... add an egg and make it spicy if you like. It's all really good.

Definitely coming back here..  (^__^)V
author: Tomas V.

description: Local ramen shop.  This noodle place can get packed! The go-to here is the spicy garlic tonkatsu.  It is a good blend of a lot of flavors and noodles had a very good texture.  They also show Giants and Niner games, so +1!
author: Brian C.

description: Quick and easy place to satisfy your ramen craving. I fell in love with ramen in Japan, but have had trouble finding satisfying ramen restaurants elsewhere. So far, this is one of the best that I've found in the US.
author: Jay S.

description: I absolutely love Saiwaii Ramen. I have come here many more times than I have checked in. Every time I come here I always get the chicken ramen and I add corn, enoki mushroom, and spinach. The broth is so delicious. When I am with friends, we tend to let each other taste all the broths and each one is tasty. I have gotten sushi here as well and that is also very good. Their appetizers are also tasty. I have had their oysters, and their mushroom torio appetizer. I definitely recommend Saiwaii for ramen any day!
author: Diego L.

description: I really like their miso and spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen! The broth is super flavorful! The price is really decent here compared to other ramen places. The only downside is that the place is tiny and it gets really crowded in the evening so the wait can be pretty long.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Overall, I would say this place is average.  Don't get me wrong, it was tasty, but I have had much better.  It's a tiny joint, but was full of people.  There was no wait, which is alllllways a plus!  I love getting seated and looking back to see a slew of people lining up to get seated.

My boyfriend and I both got the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen and a sunrise roll.  The sunrise roll is spicy tuna and mango and yummmmmm delicious.  The ramen and the chasu was perfectly cooked and chewy, but the soup base lacked a bit of flavor initially.  Maybe I was expecting too much, but I expected my taste buds to dance when I took a sip of ramen soup base.  A whole bowl later, no dancing taste buds, but I was satisfied.  I've had better, but I've also had a lotttt worse.
author: Betty W.

description:
I love this Ramen place!  Their spicy garlic ramen is the best but the regular, non-spicy versions are excellent also.  

We got the extra pork belly topping and it was awesome!

Definitely hits the spot for a cold, rainy day.
author: Arlene M.

description:
A and I dropped in for dinner on Thursday night.  It was pretty empty, but I noticed that most people just came in to get take-out.  They serve sushi as well as ramen.

I ordered the miso ramen and A got the spicy garlic miso ramen.  We also ordered the spicy garlic crab salad, tekka maki, and tako negiri.  The ramen is about par with the ramen at Genki Ramen.  So good, but not fantastic.  I LOVED their spicy garlic crab salad.  If you like soft shell crab, definitely order this.  It's super flavorful and really really good.

TWO YUMS UP for the spicy garlic crab salad.
author: Kris L.

description: Great service & probably one of best ramen restaurants in town. This has been our ramen place!! Will come all the time!
author: Gogo W.

description:
Yummy.... The spicy pork ramen was delicious, love the creamy soup and the good news is that there were no butter nor cream added to make the soup so rich and creamy   

The Kama Hamachi was delicious, although it is on a pricey side consider the small piece per order.

The wait staffs were very friendly and attentive.  Food were great plus service with a smile even though they are super busy.  We had come here numerous times,  pretty soon we might become a regular customer!!
author: P C.

description:
On a cold San Franciscan day, my friend and I visited Saiwaii. We both ordered the Spicy Garlic Ramen! 

It was pretty darn good, the soup was super garlicky (my favorite flavor!), slight bit of salt, bits of corn and over all really good. 

The only downside was that I wish there was more food for the price... But then again, it could have just been my manly appetite! My guy friend didn't finish his... but I still wanted more... hahaha
author: Julie T.

description:
Very convenient that there's a ramen joint in the Sunset area. The food is pretty decent in taste and price. The ramen is pretty standard store bought ones, tasted like the one you can find in the supermarket, but the soup on the other hand, tasted homemade. It's not very rich or hearty, but tasty enough to go with the noodle. The portion side is good too. I also like their adegashi tofu. They give you lots of bonito flakes, which I really like with the tofu. 

The service is pretty good, and everyone was pretty nice. I love how they played pop music and have tvs on sport chanels.
author: Mandy C.

description:
Tricky review here. If you're looking for a great Japanese restaurant, this is not your place. If you're looking for a good ramen house, this may do the trick. But, If you're looking specifically for ramen with pork belly, THIS IS YOUR PLACE. 

Only been here a couple of times. My first experience was near perfect. Ordered pork belly in shoyu ramen. Almost died, it was so good. Big, thick chunks of pork belly that fell apart into sweet layers of heaven in my chopsticks. Noodles were al dente, perfectly chewy and substantial. My experience with the other dishes however, not so hot. Stick to the ramen with pork belly and you'll be very very happy.
author: dan t.

description:
Prices are ok, but the portions are on the small side so don't come here if you're crazy hungry or something. The tonkotsu ramen was ok, tons of MSG and the chashu was pretty much just fat with little bits of meat here and there.. My boyfriend didn't particularly enjoy his miso ramen either.

Service was great though! Our waitress was very polite and attentive, and was prompt in refilling our water/tea quite often!
author: Charmian W.

description:
I came here with a friend for dinner, it's a nice place to grab a quick bite in sunset.
Parking is very easy to find, we got VIP parking right in front. But I guess it depends which hour and which day you go to Irving, because Irving can be STUPID PACKED.
Nice brown interior with perfect lighting, they even have 2 television screens where you can watch television, TOTORO was playing!

We were seated immediately right when we got in, maybe about half the restaurant was filled. What I didn't understand was why the waitress seated my friend and I in a cramped up corner when there were so many other spots. I felt a little claustrophonic sitting so close next to a party of 4 women enjoying their rants. It almost felt like I was a part of their group, as I struggled to squeeze in between tables and guests and my leg brushing up against the lady's purse....

Anyways.

I drink a lot of tea... and the waiter/waitress refilled everyones tea in the restaurant on time. Loved that. Usually I have to eye my waiter down and wait for him to notice that I need something, and I'm sure it gets annoying when a customer constantly wants their tea refilled....

I had the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen and added the fatty pork, corn and enoki mushroom and my friend ordered the same except with extra cha su and egg except I ordered mine extra spicy, which was a good idea because the soup came out PERFECT.

The fatty pork was a little too well done, the fat kind of just melts away but I prefer mine to be solid and a little chewy. There wasn't much corn, and I didn't find it to be worth $1... Enoki mushrooms were fresh!

Everything was good, except the fact that our bill came out to be $31... for just two bowls of ramen! I don't know if it's just me, if I'm complaining too much about the price for food in my reviews lately... but $31 dollars for 2 bowls of ramen, like seriously?

I would consider coming back, if I was down to waste that much money on ramen...
author: Jenny Y.

description:
After watching Tampopo I was craving Ramen. So I decided to give a new place a try in my neighborhood. My expectations for this place was not high, but I had to fulfill my ramen fix. Compared to all the different ramen places in SF, this does stack up pretty well. It is no secret that SF does not have great ramen, but this place does pretty good for SF.

I decided to try their Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen (regular)

The noodles are okay. The texture is good. The noodles have a good chewy texture to them, not over cooked. On the downside the noodles taste a little too salty. You can tell they are not high quality like some of the top ramen places in San Mateo (Himawari, Santa, Ramen Dojo). But for SF Ramen it satisfies.

My first impressions of the soup was salty. But as I kept eating and drinking the broth, I was able to get use to it without it being too salty to the point where I could not finish the broth. The spicy garlic tonkatsu flavor was good. The spice was perfect. It was not too spicy to overwhelm the broth, but left my lips tingling a little. Another big plus was that the spice was not an overload of chili oil, but had good flavor combination with the garlic and tonkatsu.  They put whole cloves of garlic inside, which surprisingly did not overpower the broth.

The ingredients used was plentiful. Good amount of bamboo shoots, sliced pork, ground pork, seaweed, green onions, etc...The presentation was very nice, and all the ingredients  blended well with each other. 

Overall, this place offers pretty good Ramen for SF, and is a good choice to come and try.
author: Nick C.

description: My go-to ramen spot nowadays. The Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu ramen is my favorite bowl to get and if you go during lunch hours they have a special that adds sushi as well. The baked mussel appetizers were nothing too special though. It is a small spot off the street and service is really nice, so I do advise to give it a try if you are in the area.
author: Danny P.

description:
Tonkatsu broth: creamy and not too salty.
Pork belly: melts in the mouth
Sushi: pretty fresh with a good size-able menu
Interior: clean
Also kid friendly - I even saw a kid passed out at the table next to me. The other kids were transfixed by the large televisions.

Will return.
author: Judy L.

description: The ramen was pretty good. My regular spicy garlic was more spicy than I expected for the regular but it was still good. However I was very bothered by the fact that when we paid, we tipped a little less than the suggested 18% and the waitress told us that we were $3 short and treated the tip like it was mandatory. I know $3 is no big deal but it made me mad that she would act like we were shorting her on the bill when we in fact were still tipping well. We ended up paying it because my friend didn't want me to make a scene.
author: Jessica W.

description: Went on a Saturday night and got seated right away.  Ordered the garlic ramen with a 49er roll.  The broth was good but pork belly was chewy and not tender.  Ramen did not come with an egg which was a disappointment.  The rice for the sushi roll was soft and mushy.  Probably not a good idea to order sushi here but we jus gave it a shot since we knew ramen wouldn't fill us up.  Nothing spectacular and would not be back.
author: L E.

description:
I've been here twice now and both times the food was satisfying and delicious. In the chilly, foggy, and downright ugly Sunset weather, a hot bowl of tasty ramen is just what I need. I come into the restaurant cold and grumpy and leave warm and happy. 

They offer customers the choice of shoyu, miso, tonkotsu, or shio ramen. I've only had the tonkotsu one and it was really flavorful.  Not too salty and overall had a really good taste. It had a creamy consistency to it too, without being overly fatty or greasy. After adding corn and 1/2 of an egg for an additional $2, I had my perfect bowl of ramen! mMMmmm. They also have ramen combos where you can add stuff like a mini unagi don for an extra $3. Never gotten the combos yet, but my friend did and he seemed to enjoy it. 

Never been here during normal lunch/dinner hours...so can't really speak for how crowded it gets. But, at 9pm it has never been too packed. Service has always been fast and friendly, and waitresses are hot according to my male friend. While the restaurant is on the smaller side, it's cozy and nicely decorated. Clean bathrooms too! Overall, I had a pleasant dining experience. 4 stars!
author: Natasha H.

description: Mmmm good ramen. I ordered the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu ramen based off recommendations, and I'd order it again. As a person who can't get enough spicy in her life, I went for the extra spicy broth, which is essentially just chilli pepper dashed on top. Scored a 6.5 on a super-spicy-burn-your'mouth-off scale. One downside is that it is a smaller portioned ramen bowl than other places, but then again much can one person possibly eat? Bottom line, I'd come back here again!
author: Teresa C.

description:
I'm not a ramen connoisseur (although I can whip up a mean cup of noodles).  But I might add that I firmly believe that my brother (who dragged me here 3x in 1 week, during his visit to SF) is within the boundaries of an aficionado.  Of all the places that he has claimed to traversed, this is by far his top SF pick.  

The Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen is pretty tasty.  But, the broth is heavy in oil, and it's not spicy enough for me to even pretend it's spicy at all.  As a result, I appreciate the Miso broth more, and maybe the Spicy Garlic Miso will fare better next time.  Nevertheless, the PORK BELLY is BOMB in the bowl!!  The pieces are pretty big, tender, and have thick fatty skin (if you are into that type of thing).  Although the add-ins can turn a cheap bowl into a pricey one, Sawaii is more generous than other ramen joints that seem to skimp on standard mix-ins (ahem* I'm sorry, a couple pieces of wakame seaweed does not suffice).  Last time I was here, every bowl included several pieces of pork (not pork belly) and vegetables.  

The restaurant accepts credit cards, which is a plus, and it's in a great strip of neighboring stores, boba shops, restaurants, and groceries (info for all the non-locals).  They also have a lunch special, which is basically a $2 sushi roll.
author: Diane N.

description: The only drawback is that they have no vegetarian options. If you're not one, go for it! Really excellent spicy garlic ramen and excellent sushi to boot. It's really nice that I can walk to it from my house too! A great local ramen spot.
author: Claire K.

description:
Looking for a decently priced, not overly crowded, and most importantly, delicious ramen joint?? So was I and here I found it !

Kobe salad was fresh, flavorful, and definitely had a wasabi kick to it.
Tonkotsu definitely hit the spot.  Delicious soup and noodles were perfect.  Added the pork belly for $3 and comes with 4 pieces... melts in your mouth, it's like heaven!

I was so full by the end of dinner but I couldn't help but finish the entire bowl completely. Yummy and definitely satisfying.

I recommend it !
author: Maxine C.

description: Very good for your ramen fix!  Prices are as expected and their appetizers are good as well!  If you ask for spicy and you really really like spicy... It prob won't be spicy enough so ask for extra spicy and then put a whole bunch of white pepper and chili oil in it lolllll. Enjoy~
author: Stephen H.

description: Very good ramen place do close to my place. It also has sushi and sake. The food is fresh and well portioned. I try to come here more but they are closed in the middle of the afternoon so its lunch or dinner only. The basic ramen is bomb with a load of toppings. If you want to get bad breath try the garlic ramen. Very tasty and It is slightly spicy and leaves you smelling like Gilroy. The perfect dish to end a bad date!!
author: Jake C.

description:
I had the ramen here and it was actually fantastic. It's one of my favorite ramen places in the bay area so far (the other place is izakayu soya). 

the broth was really good, with lots of flavor and not too oily. The noodles were just a tad soft but still very good. The piece of pork that was included was juicy, tender and not chewy at all.

The sushi was very good as well, pretty fresh ingriedients.

Service was fabulous as well, they even said excuse me when they picked up our plates...even my waiters at olive garden yesterday didn't say that!
author: Wilson T.

description:
It brings me great dissapointment to put down a new restaurant that has so much potential.  But its true, I did't like it at all.  The place is a nice spot, the waitresses, well, just need some experience in, but they're working on it.  As for the food, it cannot even compare to the big boys of SF like Suzu or Katanaya or even the mediocre ones like Oyaji, and Sozai.  Good luck with the adjustments as I think much is needed. 


-Tonkotsu ramen with ten don (tempura)  - tempura was good, but ramen was too thick and too mushy.  It tasted like a little bit better than the make at home ramen, but that's not a great comparison either.  The  meat was ok but could be sliced thinner for more surface area flavoring.
author: Vincent K.

description: So I really like this place!  It's close to my house and we always sit right down (which is extremely refreshing in SF).  Ramen is the thing, and it's good, but I always end up getting small plates and nigiri.  The portions are good and the sushi is fresh - and so much cheaper than other places, so I can actually fill up and it's not $80.00 for two!
author: Rachelle P.

description:
It was definitely the chef, that funny, charming Yoshi Fujita from Yo's Sushi Club (recently closed this past summer) that brought me and my friends here. We were so sad that he closed his doors but we were excited that we wouldn't miss him for too long because he was going to be the chef here. The sushi offering is limited to combination rolls and basic nigiri (salmon, tuna, hamachi, etc) for now but at least they have his oh-so-yummy and creamy ankimo (monkfish liver). If only they had aji and uni....

Oh yes, I didn't forget that this place is a ramen restaurant. The first time we were here, we weren't too impressed with their broth. This last time, they revamped their menu a little. We had the spicy garlic miso with chasu ($9.95) with the side of the unagi rice bowl for an additional $3 (such a great option!) and it was the ultimate comfort food. The hubby loved their chicken wings; I thought it tasted a bit burnt. 

Great service. We love Yo so we will definitely be back for more.
author: Tina T.

description: I don't eat meat, and this is one of the best places that makes good ramen without meat. If you are looking for chunks of vegetables, this is not a place for you. It has a flavorful broth with garlic and other goodies that doesn't make a vegetarian feel bad about her ramen when her husband is having a same spicy ramen tonkotsu with Fried chicken, thinking he got a better deal than me just because he eats meat. Anyway, worth a try! If you like a lot more garlic like me, ask them for extra fried garlic flakes.
author: Bhoomi B.

description:
I had a shockingly wonderful weekday lunch special here. (I was originally going to have Chicken Katsu Don from the dinner menu, but it turned out there was a lunch special not posted with the regular menu in the window).

For $6.95 (!!), I had the following:

-- 6 (more than single bite size) pieces of California roll, which included REAL crab, with artfully arranged wasabi and pickled ginger on the plate.

-- Miso Soup 

-- Green Tea

-- Chicken katsu, salad with house made dressing and rice. The chicken itself was moist underneath a crispy, yet ungreasy panko crust. A tasty ginger-y katsu sauce was provided for dipping. :-)

Everything was really top-notch, a lot of very well thought out and prepared food for very little money. The waitress was gracious, cheerful, and efficient.

It's no wonder that during peak times this place is crowded. I was lucky enough to go before it was packed. 

Both kitchen and front of house work wonderfully.
author: Martin F.

description:
Tonkatsu ramen ...not worth 10$.

The services didn't impressed me too.
I would rather somewhere else.
author: Jirawat S.

description: I come here all the time and order the spicy garlic ramen. I always get great customer service even when I bring my kids. Wish it was closer to my neighborhood but totally worth the drive.
author: Dawn B.

description: One of the few only ramen places in Sunset district of SF , but I actually like this place and come here often , Their best ramen would be probably be the Tonkotsu ramen, Comes with bamboo shoots, seaweed, 1-2 slice of chashu , and etc. But the thing about this place is the soup! The soup here is often creamy! Which is great because Tonkotsu soup base should be creamy so the flavors syncs with the noodles!  , the portions are moderate in size but I dont think it will fill a person up compared to a bowl of pho, a bonus is that they use thicker ramen noodles than the other places! I also enjoy the sushi here , its often very fresh and I would highly recommend the Spicy Scallop roll! They also have a lunch special here where you can get ramen and sushi ! Overall 4/5 stars
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
Ooh. cute trendy logo. must enter and consume things in my path now.

I was craving ramen one day, and by chance i stumbled onto this one. The ramen here is definitely good. NOT GREAT. I had the special of the day, and for its portion size and taste, i was very satisfied. Everything was priced very reasonably, so this would definitely make it on my go-to usual places in the city.
author: Michael L.

description:
This ramen is better than Genki's but nothing compared to ones I can find in the South Bay or Socal. Four stars for the convenient location though! Five minute drive and a bowl of ramen is always good. 


Egg. Get the boiled egg! Love how it's still undercooked and runny... The way all eggs in ramen should be!
3.5 stars for the tonkatsu broth. I enjoy its creamy consistency, I would enjoy it if it was a bit saltier. On the other hand...
Shoyu is normally my favorite, but this place is salty! Seaweed was salty, bamboo shoots salty, noodles (although very great and chewy texture to it) salty. 

I'm so dehydrated right now...
author: Rosanne L.

description:
Not bad.  We had dinner here on a Friday night and had a good experience.  When we got there at 6, the place was totally empty, but by 630 it was packed with people waiting.  impressive.

we got the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen and the spicy miso ramen.  both were solid but nothing blew us away.  service was good and price was typical for ramen.

I would come back here if I wanted Ramen in the city, but ramen dojo in san mateo is still way better.
author: Lisa C.

description:
This is a decent place for ramen but I've had better. I'd definitely come back but there are better places for ramen.

Pros:
* Easy street parking; no wait for lunch on Sun.
* The spicy tuna don was quite good. For $4, it was the right size, the tuna had good flavor and I appreciated the seasoning added to the rice. I will definitely add this to my next meal (esp if the portions don't increase).

Observations:
* Noodles were just average. Nothing special.
* "Extra Spicy" Miso Ramen was good but IMO the level of spiciness actually detracted from the flavor of the stock. This isn't necessarily specific criticism about Saiwaii as I feel the same way about Shalala Ramen (Mtn View)'s highest level of spicyness. Dish vs. Dish though, Shalala's stock, noodles, and toppings make it a better dish than Sawaii's.
 
Cons:
* Small portion for the price. I really expected a larger portion of noodles or at least an egg for a $10 bowl of Ramen outside of japan.
* Roast pork wasn't very good. It was a bit firm/chewier than I like -- as if it could have been roasted a little longer.
* Any sushi restaurant that serves butter fish is always suspect for me -- esp considering what butter fish can do to unsuspecting people's GI tracts. It's a flavorful, cheap fish but there's a reason why it's slang name is "ex-lax fish". 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escolar
author: Gunn S.

description: Finally tried this place after living around the corner for a couple months.  The Seafood Ramen was decent, nothing spectacular.  The Miso Soup bowl actually just tasted like a corn soup due to all the corn they had in it.  It wasn't bad but it certainly didn't satisfy the craving for delicious Miso.Bacon rapped asparagus was very tastey but the Beef Tongue appetizer fell a little flat.
author: Juan Z.

description: I thought this place was really good.  This place was nice and cozy.  We didn't had to wait and got seated quickly, but got pretty packed by like 8pm.  I ordered the spicy garlic miso and it was delicious.  I also ordered a side of pork belly and wow they were sure tender and delicious.  My friend ordered the special, which was the spicy garlic tonkatsu with more toppings in it.  It was good, but not as good as mine.  I will definitely come back here again for the spicy garlic miso ramen!  Oh and the price were average.
author: Len L.

description:
Wow.
After I visited here, all the ramen places in San Jose was a waste!
Saiwaii has flavorful, delicious broth!
The spiciness! Yumm!
The noodles are not too hard not too soft!

Though the restaurant is crowded and small, that makes the perfect experience of having such a great and famous ramen.

FYI, Japanese culture and the style of living is totally miniature and small. So can make sense of Saiwaii's interior. Also, San Francisco is super expensive to keep a big size property.
author: JS H.

description:
Random craving for ramen and this hit the spot!
It's really not that pricey, especially when you're here for the lunch special- a bowl of ramen and a side of sushi for about $10! I got the pork flavored ramen and spicy tuna on the side.. it was divine. Only thing is that the place is so small and cramped, but otherwise the food is good.
author: Ruth R.

description: From all the nice reviews, I carried good hopes walking in this place.  Husband and I ordered Tonkatsu Ramen, Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen & Hamachi Kama.  Both ramen were way to salty.  So points deducted on taste already.  Portion of our order was normal size, meaning no special attraction.  Hamachi Kama (appetizer) didn't come till we were both done with our ramen (main course).  Our last hope of this place was gone. Hamachi Kama came out dried & over cooked.  Plus tips, we walked out the door paying $40.00 ordering 3 things that didn't taste right.   Every restaurant deserves a 2nd chance.  I may give this another try few months later.
author: JLcam T.

description: I found a perfect bowl of ramen. Almost reminded me of Kyushu Janggara Ramen.
author: JK C.

description:
The spicy garlic pork tonkotsku is awesome.  This is my favorite ramen joint in San Francisco.  It's not quite as good as the ramen in San Mateo or San Jose, but it's solid and I will definitely be there again.  Get it with pork belly instead of cha su.

The regular tonkotsu is kind of uninsipiring.

Don't get the sushi.  But you probably already knew that, otherwise you'd be going to one of the excellent sushi restaurants in the neighborhood and not a ramen joint.
author: Nils J.

description: One of the best ramen I've had in the city. I got the spicy garlic miso ramen in regular spicy and my brother got the tonkatsu ramen. Both were delicious and the perfect amount of spiciness. The broth was not too oily or salty and the ingredients were plenty. We also got the rainbow roll and spider roll. Both were delicious, the fish was fresh, and price was reasonable. Only downside is the long line.
author: Peggy L.

description: Very nice little restaurant. I've tried a couple different kinds of their ramen, and they're all delicious as well as satisfyingly filling. I like to get the lunch combo that comes with a side of sushi, which is better than most restaurants I've eaten sushi in. Friendly service and nice atmosphere. All of this for a  fairly cheap price.
author: Dennis B.

description: It's a really tiny place. Expect a wait, but it is totally worth it.
author: Marlon T.

description:
I'd been eyeing this place for weeks before it finally opened.  I happened to go on their first official day of business and did not have to wait for a table.  The owner is very nice and was very apologetic.  I think I heard more apologies coming from the staff than anything else.  It took awhile for us to get menus so we could order but we finally got our ramen and ordered sushi and gyoza.  I thought the gyoza was good, sushi was okay but had a lot of rice.  Ramen tasted okay.  I ordered miso and it wasn't too salty but still had flavor.  The cha-siu had a lot of fat on it.  I think one of the pieces was just fat and no meat.  Overall, I was still satisfied.  But they don't add a lot of extras to the ramen.  I think it was just corn as the main vegetable in the broth.  You have to pay $1more for an egg, $1 more for corn, $1 more for everything else extra.

I noticed the table across from us did not get what they ordered.  They forgot to make one of their appetizers.  Again, more apologies and they did offer to make their appetizer on the house if they wanted, but the customers left.  At least they offered.

When the bill came I think I had slight sticker shock.  $31 for ramen?!   Wow.  I didn't even have any tea.  Big difference from my cheapo $.15 Costco packs that I used to eat daily back in the day.  But I guess our appetizers must've cost a lot.  Somewhat expensive lunch for us.  Our experience was okay and I'm sure they'll get tons of business in their location.  I'll be back anyway because I can't resist ramen.
author: Stacey C.

description: The staff at Saiwaii are so polite all the time, regardless of how busy they are and how hectic things get in the restaurant. It's a little tiny, but it feels like home once you sit down to a nice, hot bowl of spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen (don't forget to specify your spice level--I forgot once and was drinking gallons of water the entire time I was there).  Their fried gyoza is also very good! And their spicy tuna rolls are great as well! Don't forget to order the house sake!
author: Alexa A.

description:
I probably ate here at least 5 times within the past year. I always get the Tonkotsu ramen! Too good! 

I came here last week during their lunch special. It was pretty packed, so we waited about 10 minutes for a table for 2. Once we got seated, we ordered the Ramen + Sushi Roll special for 9.95! What a deal!  After we ordered, the waitress seated other customers and took their orders as well. 

We waited about 20 minutes...and our food never came. We saw bowls of Ramen and plates of sushi in the kitchen about to be brought out, so I thought they were ours. But nope, they went to THREE OTHER TABLES THAT WERE SEATED AND ORDERED AFTER US. Sorry about the caps, but I was so mad because they ordered the same thing as us, but they got their food before us. If they gave it to ONE table that came after us, maybe it would have been fine, but nope. They gave it to THREE tables that had parties varying from 2-6 customers each. I don't get it. 

We still had to wait an additional 15 minutes until our food came. The other tables were already done with their meal. I understand that it was pretty busy, but please, give us the food in the order we got seated and ordered. It's not fair.
author: Olivia L.

description:
Ranked #5 in 7x7SF so decided to give it a try.  Ordered the spicy garlic tonkotsu (pork) ramen with pork belly.  The noodles appear to be freshly made and were al dente which is the right texture, but I didn't think the noodles were flavorful enough.  The broth was perfect for the cold evening - the garlic wasn't strong,  the spiciness was just right, and it wasn't too salty.  Adding the pork belly is a great addition and my bowl came with 3 large and flavorful pieces.  The standard char siu on the other hand was bland and rubbery.  So I'd give this a 'good' rating, but not outstanding.  Of course I'm comparing it to the bowl I had at Momofuku in NYC so the bar is a bit high.

Service was a bit off so the rating takes a little hit there.  The server didn't know his dishes and got confused.
