We ordered goma ae (steamed spinach in sesame sauce) but he called it seaweed salad when he delivered it.  I don't' know if you can expect authentic Japanese food here based on the goma ae, so you might want to stick to the ramen.
author: Brian Y.

description: Overrated! I ordered the spicy tonkatsu ramen hoping to satisfy my noodle soup fix and after being seated then reseated because they wanted our bigger table I was ready to grub. I was super disappointed when the only tonkatsu I saw was two slivers of what seemed to be extra wide slices of bacon. I know times are tough but REALLY! Overall flavor was decent but nothing that blew my sox off as I had my share of ramen experiences. Also be carefully when slurping, it will burn the back of the throat going down so if you can't take heat this is not your thing. Best part of the meal was the Agedashi appetizer we ordered but who can mess that up? The place was clean and in a good area with street parking. With so many places to eat in the city and the service being mediocre at best it's a no return for me.
author: T L.

description:
I've been here a few times and every time the ramen is pretty good or pretty bad. The quality is a hit or miss depending on what day you go I guess. This time it was a miss.

I had the spicy miso ramen. The ramen noodles were good, the cha siu was a bit thick and it was super chewy, and menma was hard and crunchy. The soup was alright; can't really tell with the spiciness masking it.

The service is good and quick.
author: Steven B.

description: Came here for the first time.  It was very good. I had ramen of course,  took my sister here she liked it too.  Its kinda small tho .
author: Miss V.

description: It's been a while since I came here but I remember clearly that the ramen wasn't impressive. That explains why I only went once and I'm a huge fan of ramen so I would remember if it was a delicious one. Not quite remember what I ordered, it was something Garlic. Anyway, I would probably go back and give it another try.
author: Lovetoeat A.

description:
Yay Saiwaii! I loved it. I've been waiting for it to open since I saw the sign up saying it was to be a ramen place, and I was not disappointed. The Cha-Su I had was great, the pork was tender and incredibly flavorful. 

I went there on a Thursday evening it was packed, one of the parties was huge though.

What is better on a cold foggy sunset evening than a piping hot bowl of ramen? I don't know!

As for the slow service that others noted, I got my single to-go order of ramen in less than 10 minutes, during (as I noted) a full house. 

They also have some sushi, the CA rolls looked promising (if that is your thing). They also had huge heaps of red tuna over rice...
author: Imran K.

description: Standing in the sun at Alice's Summer Thing, followed by a few drinks at Chug Pub can stir up quite the appetite. I was definitely excited to pop my ramen cherry here. The mild garlic miso with egg was incredible: tasty broth, semi-firm noodles, corn, bamboo shoots, garlic, and a whole egg. Perfect. The portion size filled up the tumbly in no time flat. Never thought ramen could be this good. Kick rocks, Maruchan!
author: Rhia R.

description:
I came here with my good friend/roommate and my girl friend for lunch and needless to say, there were mixed reviews...

My girlfriend and I had...

Spicy garlic miso ramen (ordered it "spicy") - There was definitely garlic and spice in there but no other flavor that could be picked out. the broth tasted like... spicyness (and not even that spicy). Needless to say, I was a little disappointed. The char-siu was alright but sliced on the thicker side. It would've been nice if I had twice the cut at half the thickness.

My roommate had... 

The tonkotsu with kakuni (braised pork belly) and the maguro don (for an additional $3). He wouldn't shut up about his ramen (he kept moaning every 3 min, nodding his head in approval while letting out a "mmmmm, this is solid"). He even raved about how fresh the maguro was in his tekka don and how the rice was fluffy and seasoned perfectly.

Our lunch seemed like night and day between the spicy ramen and the tonkotsu. My roomate is a seasoned vet when it comes to eating and is a self-acclaimed foodie, and if he said his ramen was really good, I believe him. Then again, he can drop $50 on some charcuterie plate, heirloom salad, and a ny strip sandwich for a tuesday lunch to himself and eat a hungry man salisbury steak frozen dinner on the same day and be one happy guy...

...I think I'll order the tonkotsu next time...
author: Brian L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place since it was so new and clean... and really want to see a ramen shop in the sunset succeed.  Driving to san mateo sucks.  However, i have to judge this place on it's execution of it's ramen, especially with the namesake in the title... and this case it was left really wanting..

I ordered the Tongotsu broth ramen with the "special" pork cheek and combo'ed with the tekka don (tuna sashimi over rice).  For 7.95 + $4 for the don...it's pretty reasonable.  Also had the chicken karaage and grilled squid.   The fried chicken was good...and the grilled squid came out well... However, the most important judging is the ramen...

The Tongotsu Ramen broth... was terrible.  It felt watered down and lacked depth and flavor.  Was tempted to add soy sauce to mine..but the watered down taste was too prevelent to help.  I really swear they watered this broth down... to the point that it no longer had the creamy texture of tongotsu broth.  Also, the special pork cheek... wtf.. taste like the bbq from a roast duck shop.  The cha shu was okay...and the noodles was chewy, with a decent texture..but the broth was too diappointing to overcome. This is no where close to Izakaya Sozai's Ritsu tongotsu broth, which is amazing.   

The tekka don was nothing special.  

The wait staff was friendly but very slow and lacked experience.

For the city, I'd stick to Katana-ya for their miso and shio broth ramen.. and Izakaya Sozai for their tonkotsu broth.

Saw the note from other reviewer on the stirring... trust me no amount of shaking or stirring will help.  We had two orders... one was split.. so no need to stir... and keep in mind tongotsu broth is emulsified..you do NOT need to stir.. see Ikazya's as an example.  It's almost velvety in texture.. where as here, it had the texture of water.   "Cup O Noodles" requires you to stir but definitely not real Tongotsu ramen.
author: Vien C.

description: I loveeee this place omg! i really like the tonkotsu ramen !!!!! Its really really good. I mean sure other places have tonkotsu ramen too. But this place's is just different and natural and really good. The soup is really good! We alwas come here to eat ramen wenever its like a happy day or something hah.a. The soyu ramen isnt that bad either .SHOULD DEFINITELY TRY TONKOTSU RAMEN HEREE!
author: N S.

description:
3 words: Fried California Roll
3 letters: OMG
author: Sophia C.

description:
good food, good service, good price - what else I can ask?

we got the ramen with pork belly which is delicious, and our son loves the mochi with bacon.

anything that we tried from the menu is not dissapointed.
author: Lena N.

description:
Friends and I came here for a lunch one day because the pho places down the street were closed. We decided to give this place a test. My friend yelped this place and saw some reviews that gave it the A-OK review and after trying this place out, I have to agree. It was not great, but not horrendous. 

We all had the ramen with sushi lunch special. The sushi rolls were somewhat small and though they use real crab, I can't help but be left wanting a bit more from a good sushi chef. They seemed somewhat bland, the crab was plain in the California roll and there was no avocado and the spicy tuna roll lacked a kick. 

The ramen we had were the Miso and the pork tonkatsu. The broth was average, but was rather fatty, a thin layer solidified anytime we stopped eating to chat for a minute. The meat was somewhat boring, though it was offered in good portions. The toppings, seaweed, etc. gave a nice feel to the soup, but it wasn't enough to make me want to go back. The noodles were pretty average. My friend had the miso ramen and to me, it was pretty bad. I was under the impression that miso was not supposed to be sweet, but it was. My theory was that the corn that had been added to the soup was from a can and they didn't think to drain the corn juice that comes in the can which is often sweet. 

In general, nothing stood out, and nothing drew me back.
author: Larry Y.

description: Good food, friendly service, small place but it has a lot of tables. Probably some kind of fire hazard though. The miso ramen was delicious. Add pork belly and an egg and it's amazing.
author: Joe Y.

description:
After seeing my friend check in there time and time again, I was expecting this Ramen place to be much better than it was. Came in here for lunch and got the lunch special for $9.95, which include my choice of a basic Ramen and a 6 piece Spicy Tuna Roll (can also choose California Roll). I decided on the Tonkotsu Ramen though I wanted spicy, because I wanted to try the broth base first. I have to say, I was disappointed. Being that I've been enjoying Ramen houses for so long, maybe my expectations were too high?

What makes this place a 2 star is the slow service, they would've gotten 3 if they were a bit quicker. 11:30am for lunch, and people are starting to fill into this small place. They cram every available spot with a table, so you feel really cramped when it gets full, then there's only one server and that person is also expected to clean up, bring your food, take the orders, bring the checks and collect money... I mean, really?? 

The sushi also is disappointing. Not sure how the "special sushi" comes out, but the basics are something that anyone can make in their own kitchen... Maybe I'll come back and try the rice plates? But I wouldn't count on good service unless the place was quiet. Not worth the detour, unlike Santa's in San Mateo.
author: Jason L.

description:
So I got the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen while my gf got the regular.  Both were very tasty, though I think I may have made a mistake in that the extra spicy, while not overwhelmingly so, is spicy enough overpower the flavor of the tonkatsu broth.  If you're a real ramen fan, you'll understand how many subtle flavors work together to make the broth so special, and in turn respect the craft and care that goes into making it.  It's for that reason that say I may have made a mistake.

That said, it was still very good, particularly the pork which was sweet, tender, and overall fantastic.

The staff was friendly.  The food was good.  The price was inline.  

Recommended.
author: Mystery V.

description:
It was a muggy Sunday afternoon and it felt like having noodles. So after a lot of waiting and checking this Yelp page, I felt it was time to take a dive. I should have gone with my first instincts and go to Turtle Tower in the TL but I felt lazy. Serves me right. It was pretty packed around lunch time but we got the small table in the corner right away. A lot of people were walking by and checking it out so I assume most of them are first-timers as well. 

We ordered the Tonkotsu ramen and I added egg and stewed pork. Hoon got the Miso ramen, and we shared an Agedashi Tofu and a order of gyoza. 

First to arrive was the Agedashi tofu which was pretty bland. The portions of tofu pieces are about half of what you get at other places for the same price. There was nothing particularly special about it at all. It's fried tofu in some sort of bland dashi stock.

Second to arrive was the gyoza. Now this was a total what the fuck. The gyoza came to us not golden brown, not even brown, but the bottom crust was black. Now I'm all for carcinogens and burnt stuff because that stuff tastes good, but this was ridiculous! Any cook who willingly sends out black, charred, overcooked anything should be reconsidered. We looked at it on arrival and then looked back at the waitress who looked at the gyoza and had this astonished look on her face. Needless to say she ducked out pretty quick. I didn't even like the sauce they give you. It was really sweet and didn't compliment the gyoza at all. 

The ramen arrived and I was very upset from the start. There was no aroma. The broth was warm, not hot. And most of all, it was bland and tasteless. There was no delicate flavors or anything special about it. In fact, I can easily attest that the ramen you buy fresh with a soup base paste tastes so much better. The noodles didn't have flavor nor were they springy. They were a bit overdone, and reminded me of spaghetti. No "kansui" flavor or even flavor of egg. Speaking of egg, they charge you a dollar for half an egg and it doesn't even come close to the one up at Izakaya Sozai. It's soft boiled, somewhat, but it doesn't yield any flavor. The cha shu is dry, but that may be because it was rather lean, but dry nonetheless. For $3 they give you a decent amount of buta kakuni or stewed pork, but even that was bland. 

There was a lot of woodear fungus and really alkaline tasting bamboo shoots. 

The miso ramen broth tasted like water and miso paste, which basically means miso soup but there should have been some sort of stock in the background to support it.

We felt rushed by our waitress. She came and took away our plate of gyoza when there was still 1 left and didn't even bother to ask us if we were done yet. Sure, it was all burnt and charred, and she probably didn't expect us to finish it, but at least have the courtesy to ask. 

I might give this place another try in a few months but right now, I'm going to pass.
author: Derrick L.

description:
mmmn YUM. 

I was definitely craving ramen last weekend when it was rainy and cold. I felt like every other location in SF was completely packed so I decided to just go here. I'm glad I made this decision! It wasn't packed at all (that does not mean the food didn't taste good...it was DELISH!). When I first came in, I even recognized my girlfriend working there! So cute! 

Anyway the place is a little small (but most ramen places are). My boyfriend and I got seated and got edamame on the house. I practically killed it because I was so hungry. I got the Miso Ramen which was so tasty. The noodles were so freshly prepared and I got a lot too! The broth was not too salty at all. I really liked that there was corn in my ramen and the pork wasn't dry or tasted old. Since my boyfriend was still hungry after the ramen we also ordered the Spider Roll. That was GOOD. I mean, this place isn't known for their sushi, but the sushi they made was decent. I love that there was Soft Shell Crab in it. They weren't even stingy about how much crab was in there. There was large amounts so I can actually take a bite into it. 

The only crappy part is they really need to fix their door! It doesn't close all the way on its own and customers don't push it close either, so if you're sitting near the door like I was, you're gonna freeze! The staff usually makes sure it is closed all the way so we're all warm though, but it's hard managing orders and a door!
author: Katrina T.

description: Get the tonkatsu ramen. It is amazing! Service was friendly and quick. Need to try the other flavors next!
author: Dhruv L.

description:
I like this ramen shop. It's not the best but decent, good enough for me. If you see buta no kakuni on the specials board, get it. It's different from the regular pork belly topping. I like the ramen and appetizers, not crazy about the donburi.

Many yelpers used incorrect words in their reviews:
Tonkotsu: milky white broth made with pork bones and pork fat.
Tonkatsu: breaded and deep fried cutlet.
author: George M.

description:
My coworkers & I paid a visit for one of our "Friday Fundays" & stopped by around noon. Only a couple tables were occupied, so we were seated immediately. We all ordered variations of the lunch combo (choice of ramen + spicy tuna or california roll). 

I ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu, which was pretty flavorful! The toppings were pretty abundant, with bamboo, green onions, seaweed, mushrooms, chasu, & 3 roasted garlic cloves, but I'm a little disappointed that an egg wasn't included. The noodles were cooked well & had the requisite springiness. The chasu that was included in the bowl tasted very strange & rubbery, so I didn't even bother to finish it. Aside from that, it was a solid bowl of ramen & I'll definitely visit again to sample other flavors of ramen.
author: Ruby H.

description: I ordered a Spicy Tuna w/ spicy sauce donburi for $12. The portion was practically for children. Very unsatisfying meal.
author: Matt A.

description: Delicious ramen , large selection of appetizers, fresh sushi, close to home, cold foggy sunset district, cozy environment, friendly staff... what more can I say? Awesome spot. (:
author: Annie Y.

description:
Mmmm their spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen here is so yummy! I ordered mine spicy and it was the perfect amount of flavor :) 
The bowl is filled to the brim with delicious broth and the noodles are piled in with additional yummy goodness. I can really drink their ramen for days, the only thing I would change about it is the salt level, it was a bit too salty for my liking but is easily cured with drinking multiple cups of water! 
I will definitely be coming back here to satisfy my ramen needs.
author: Michelle W.

description: Beautiful, tasty ramen, smooth & fresh sushi- this place has become a favorite of mine.
author: Yola N.

description:
I am a Ramen freak and I had this amazing life changing salt soup ramen at the ramen museum in Tokyo and been on search ever since returning to the states. Sadly, I could not find it anywhere... so I was pretty excited to try it here when I saw it on the menu. 

I checked in here yesterday for lunch with a group of friends and we ordered all 4 types of Ramen on the menu. I, of course, had the Salt soup base ramen. .. it was pretty good. It wasn't as good as the one I had in Japan but I've got to give it some props. The price was reasonable and  the services was great. 

I think it would taste much better if the soup was hotter but either way it did not disappoint. A lot of Yelpers complained of the lack of content in the Ramen but in my experiences, a lot of traditional Ramen places don't add too much extras in the bowl because after all, we are suppose to enjoy the noodle + soup. Next time I will try their other dishes.
author: Mishi W.

description: The spicy garlic Tonkotsu ramen sushi combo was delicious and a value. The ramen I've had in the city so far. Will be going there again. The service and the price are fair, but the Ramen is worth the stop there.
author: Grant O.

description:
Really simple, cute decor. 

Came here for lunch with the bf, not busy at all.
Sat by the window and ordered
spicy garlic miso ramen
spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen
the lunch special version so it came with california rolls, and spicy tuna roll.

also ordered the kobe salad? i think it was as an appetizer.

food came out pretty quick, it tasted okay.....i had the spicy garlic tonkatstu one and it was sooo oily O_o, after i was done, and it sat a bit, and i moved my spoon....the top thickened and was like a glob...EW that made me kinda BLAH.

im not sure if i'd come back or not....but the waitress was really nice
author: Christine M.

description:
Good Ramen! Not great, but good.

I got the Tonkotsu (pork) for $7.95 and my roommate got the Chicken Broth $9.95.

I really wanted to try the Beef Tongue and Chicken Heart appetizers, but didn't have gusto.

The tea was very good.

Overall the quality didn't warrant the price. You can get much better for less down the street.

The atmosphere was pretty, but had the radio on. Like commercial radio.

PLEASE FIX THE DOOR!
author: Brie P.

description:
3.5 stars rounded up to 4.

Pretty clean looking restaurant.  Some of the side dishes can be kind of small.  Spinach with sesame sauce came out too sweet for my taste.

Tempura was excellent.

Noodles are done well.  Soft and still chewy.  Broth creamy and flavorful even though it was really salty.  The pieces of pork that came in the ramen was kind of tough compared to some other ramen places I've been to.  The egg we got as an add-on for the ramen was REALLY salty.  I know they tried to make it unique and must have marinated it in sake and soy sauce ... but it's way too rich and salty.  It's a good start though.

Friendly place.  Parking's a little easier on this side of Irving than other areas.
author: Winnie C.

description:
Miso Ramen + California Roll (Lunch Combo)

Tasty broth. Not overwhelming and just a solid part of the meal. Noodles and chashu are pretty average. The chashu is pretty lean. They also include corn with the ramen. Not quite my thing but the other toppings were nice. The rolls were actually pretty good. They use real crab meat which is a plus in my book. For about $10 for the meal, this is a pretty good deal for what you get.

Service

Our waiter was pretty good and attentive. Keep in mind it was about 1:30pm on a weekday so business was slow. 

Overall

Good ramen shop in the part of the Sunset predominated run by Chinese restaurants. I could see it as a place I go to often. 

4 stars.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Shoyu ramen, mmmMMMMmmmmMMM. I just recently tried Tonkatsu flavor but I found it just wasn't salty enough. For a ramen fan, I'm definitely glad I found a place dedicated to ramen. Their noodles taste so good, it's easy to devour the entire thing for a small person like me. The staff are very friendly and the food got out in a timely manner despite it being fully packed. 

The parking for Irving is atrocious, I average 10-15 min circling the place to find parking. So if you want to go, I recommend going for dinner time or if you can, take the bus.
author: Darline D.

description:
2.5
I got the tonkatsu ramen with stewed pork belly (+$3). The noodles were kinda hard, the broth was kinda watered down and it tasted like they added msg. The stewed pork was pretty good although not as good as santa ramen but they did give me 3 pieces which is a bargain. The cha shu that came with the ramen was bland and unremarkable. The total came out to be $13 after tax and tip. Ill probably not come back here for ramen as for the same price I can get better quality ramen elsewhere.
author: Robert Y.

description: So my new thing lately is to go look for the perfect ramen place. A place that blows my socks off lol. This place came close to it! The thing that sucks about eating ramen is that they charge you $1 for everything you want to add to your ramen. For example you can't have ramen without egg and I love corn in my ramen so my bowl of ramen will be $12. So until I find a bowl of ramen that comes with everything my socks won't be blown off. However this place was good. Noodles wasn't over cooked and the broth was flavorful.  That's all I really ask for.
author: Ann C.

description: After many failed attempts of finding amazing ramen in America. I give Saiwaii ramen 4 stars for having amazing broth and every bite of satisfaction that I get from their fatty melty pork belly. You know the food is good when you literally widen your eyes and kept eating because you got no words of how amazing it is, Saiwaii is doing it right and good. Great work!
author: Chi L.

description: My new favorite ramen place in SF. I love the Chicken Cartilage and the Tonkotsu Ramen! There seems to always be a wait though so come early!
author: Annette W.

description:
After a really long day @ work, there is nothing I like least than cooking & there is nothing the boyfriend likes least than waiting for me to cook.  This creates many opportunities for eating out.

We shared a California roll which was tough & had an overall weird texture.  I got an Unagi don which only had 1 small piece of eel.  The rice was chewy & super sweet.  He got a Tekka don but the fish was not the freshest; the rice was tough & it didn't have much vinegar flavor.

The bill after tax & tip was above $30.00 which I thought was quite expensive for not only the quality but also the quantity of food received.  The service was fine but I don't feel that it's enough for me to come back here again.
author: Karen S.

description: I went here with my hairstylist on 3-29-14 8:30pm'sh, originally wanted to go to santung, yummy yummy, Nanjing bistro, or durty nelly--but all were crowded, hence SR.  We ordered two asahi small sized beers $3.50 each, also poki salad around $11'sh, beef tongue $6'ish, gyoza $6'sh and fried chicken $6'sh---surprisingly good, Service is attentive.  In the future, may try their ramen.
author: Jer W.

description:
This place is going to become a favorite haunt.

It's been open 3 months.  Walk in the door, sat immediately.  Given hot green tea immediately.  3 or 4 other parties in there, service was fast! and friendly.

Ordered bowls of ramen and $3 pork belly.  the pork belly was ridiculously big and tasty--we couldn't finish it.  The Ramen easily rivals Katana-Ya in texture, with a bit more Americanized taste.  Ingredients fresher than Katana-Ya, service faster, and no hour wait.  I'm in love.
author: Lauren J.

description: Ramen was average, but I enjoyed their Paradise Roll and Soft-Shell crab way more.
author: B F.

description:
We went here last weekend and the Tonkatsu Ramen was excellent.  The broth was amazing and the pork seemed really fresh and not tough, overcooked or approaching stew-meat. It was an amazing bowl of ramen.  We also had the Kobe Beef salad appetizer and although it was quite tasty the beef was very tough... so I sincerely doubt it was truly Kobe Beef (because the fame of this beef is that it is extremely tender, milk fed, and the animals are given frequent massages).

Went again this weekend and the broth didn't seem nearly as fresh nor was the meat.  Very much a let down. =(
author: Fredricko B.

description:
I love Japanese Ramen, but I'm beginning think it may not worth $12-$14 for a bowl of noodle soup.  If any Chinese or Vietnamese charges me that price for wonton noodle soup or Pho, I may have to throw a huge fit.

And this is where Sawaii comes in.  The regular flavor ramen are all $7.95.  The spicy versions are all $9.95??  What da hell do they put in there? 

Anyways, I ordered the tonkatsu flavor and paid $3 extra for a bowl of unagi don.  The ramen was cooked al dente and the soap was delicious.  As long as the soap and the noodle was done right, the ramen will get a B from me.  I can't give this an A simply because my slices of pork were extremely lean.  It was pretty horrible since I expected a couple slices of fatty pork belly that's semi-melty from the hot tokatsu broth.  GIMME MY FATTY PORK SLICES!!

Aside from that, this place can definitely be a go-to place for ramen in SF.  It just seems like all the good ramen places are located outside of SF.   There are Ramen Dojo and Santa Ramen in San Mateo.  Santouka in San Jose.  Shinsengumi and Daikokuya in LA.  Oh well!  I do recommend coming here if you feel like $12/bowl is a ripoff.

3.5 stars
author: Ricky N.

description:
Extremely inconsistent. Went here a couple Sundays ago and had an amazing bowl of tonkatsu ramen with tender pork, super-fresh veggies (including some outstanding mushrooms and bamboo shoots) and flavorful broth. Food porn. After that meal I would have given this restaurant 5 stars, easily. 

All week long I thought about that bowl of ramen and couldn't wait to go back for another bowl. 7 days later, I ordered the same exact thing and yet it was completely different -- weird flavor to the broth, all the veggies and pork seemed really old, even the noodles seemed off. It was like they'd served up that bowl at the same time as the first one, let it sit around all week and then reheated it. Really, really disappointing.
author: Val P.

description:
I am Japanese and kind of foody-ish.. I guess,, 
but I am not RAMENexpert. 
I know there are many crazy people for RAMEN including my brothers and father.. 
I thought the RAMEN of Saiwaii Ramen was not too bad. 
(Three of Japanese girls tried Tonkotsu, Shio and Miso Ramen)
They were not super great but acceptable. 
The soup was not HOT. They should improve unless they are afraid to be sued by someone who would be burned by HOT soup...  
The soup was very light.. it is ok to me, but my friends who work for ramen restaurant in Japan town... they were not satisfied with the soup..

Topping, like Buta Kakuni ($3), and slices of the pork berry ($2) are good. I really liked them. 

The prices are decent (any kinds of Ramen such as Shio, Shoyu, Tonkotsu and Miso are apprx. $8). 
Their karaage and gyosya were good but I did not like dipping source..
it was way toooo sweet.. I did not want "TERIYAKI source" for gyoza and karaage.

Well, end of the day, 
I still see a lot of potential for this restaurant. 
The service was really good. 
Now they are waiting for Liquor License.. 

I definitely come back for dinner (Izakaya style) once they can serve beer/sake/shochu..
author: Miho O.

description:
This is a pretty good ramen place, not the best I've had but it hits the spot if you're craving ramen. I ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen. Ordered half an egg for $1. The broth was flavorful and the noodle was a good texture. The chasu was tough, making not enjoyable to eat. The egg was half way cooked, making it very delicious. An extra dollar for half an egg is pricey! They also charge more for making it spicy. I dislike the price at this restaurant.

As for the waitstaff they were attentive and nice. The decor is alright it feels cramped.

I would recommend this place for ramen if you're the sunset. Sozai a few blocks down is better option for ramen, but it is crowded there.
author: Chatree T.

description: Always a good bowl of ramen.  It's get packed sometimes but service has always been good despite it.  Try getting their extra hot tonkatsu ramen.  You won't be disappointed if you like it spicy!
author: Paul G.

description:
A pretty good ramen noodle place if you order the spicy garlic ramen.  The broth and nice and thick and I'm a garlic fan so the fried garlic cloves in the broth really did it for me.  I also tried a little of the regular spicy miso ramen and the broth just didn't have the same kick.  I say stick to the Spicy garlic ramen if you don't mind garlic.  With an extra $3, you can make the ramen a combo meal and they give you a small donburi.  Not too bad. 

The place is a bit small and you might feel like you're eavesdropping when it's crowded but other than that it's quite ok.  They also serve sushi however the price for those seems a bit on the high side.
author: Shirley T.

description: Love love love this place!!! Spicy garlic miso ramen is my fave!!! The gyoza is good as well! So is the spicy garlic crab!! Sometimes service can be a little slow, but it is a small place and when it's busy, it's busy!!! All in all I still give this place 5 stars!!!
author: Stephanie F.

description: One of my favorite local ramen places as it is walking distance from home and I can easily place an order for pick up. They're quick to serve and the spicy miso ramen with a side of karaage chicken is all I ever order cause it always hits the spot!
author: Tiara R.

description: Great service but I didn't exactly love my ramen.  I had the tonkotsu ramen, and while the broth had a strong flavor of pork taste, it wasn't salty enough for me.  Decent amount of cha shu and toppings but the ramen was not the perfect texture for me.  Croquette was a bit disappointing. Their stuffing is potato with pork and corn, and while i saw a few pieces of corn, I didn't notice any pork at all.
author: Karen L.

description: Spicy garlic miso ramen is good.  If you can't handle spicy, I highly recommend asking for mild, which is gives you a kick, but doesn't numb your taste buds.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Updated Review: I lived around the corner from this place for almost two years and had consistently good food every time. The staff is very friendly also. I miss being so close and I long to go back across town and sample my favorite ramen noodle place. Definitely a hidden gem!

I upped my review from 3 to 4 stars based on how much I love and have patronized this restaurant.
author: Graham W.

description:
Heard about Saiwaii from some friends.  One said it was hella good, so 3 friends and I came by on Thursday night around 8 ,to check it out.  There was no wait whatsoever, but I think if we got there an 30 minutes earlier, we would've had to wait.  
First off, I've tasted a lot of ramen so I'm a little picky and strict when it comes to eating ramen.  I wish my friend didn't hype it up so much cause we were all a little disappointed.  The noodles are okay, but I prefer the fresh chew kinda noodles.  Three of us got the spicy garlic miso, the other got the tonkotsu,  Spicy garlic miso was definately garlicky, but not spicy.  Tonkotsu tasted a little like chinese wonton soup broth.  I got the spicy garlic miso cause it comes with corn :P  The soup is mild so if you're looking for really rich broth with bits of fat in it, you won't find it here.
Although the ramen is just ok, the service was great.
author: Cheryl Q.

description:
i walked by when this place was still remodeling and i found out recently that it was open already. i came here today to try out the place with some friends. once i walked in, we were greeted immediately and were seated. we were given menu right away and the waiter came back with green tea. the tea was luke warm, i guess i expected to be hot? so that was the first thing already.  the decor was nice with a TV showing anime on the wall. there's also a board with specials on the wall also. 

we ordered the following: 
- tonkotsu ramen ($7.95) + pork belly topping ($3)
- teba shioyaki: grilled chicken wings ($4.50)
- ramen & combo: tonkotsu ramen ($7.95) + curry don ($3)

the tonkotsu ramen was good. it has cha-shu, menma, seaweed, kikurage, and green onion.  the soup base is creamy color but not as creamy as it looks. it has a good flavor to it, i also taste a little chicken broth in it also.  the toppings were ok and the noodles were ok.  the noodles were a little harder than i m used to but not bad. 

the grilled chicken wings were bad. no flavor. no salt or pepper. it was just thrown on the grill and that was it. maybe the cook forgot to throw some salt/pepper on it? 

the curry don was ok. they gave a lot of curry sauce compare to the amount of rice they gave in the bowl.  the rice was kinda more mushy than what i m used to. the curry flavor was good, a little sweet in the beginning then the spiciness kicks in then it goes away. not bad. 

the waiter was really nice. he asked for some feedback on the food and we told him about the chicken wings.  i don't think i mind coming back for the tonkatsu ramen but not sure about the other appetizers.
author: Kapo T.

description:
My first time here and I enjoyed it very much.

I ordered the Lunch Special B: Shoyu Ramen with 6 piece California Roll, both were delicious. Next time, I try something else even the pork belly.

The waitress was attentive but not overly so.  She checked on us a couple of times and refilled our hot tea also.

Recommended place for ramen.
author: Allen C.

description:
I've been here about 5 times in the last 6 months - I'd say their ramen is consistently good. If some place else is better, my palate isn't sophisticated enough to tell the difference.

Giving 3 stars because they were kind of stingy with one of my takeout orders - for around $10 the tonkatsu ramen only came with two pieces of pork. I mean, c'mon. All that soup and noodle, two pieces of pork. =)
author: Anthony W.

description:
Besides Sozai, there isn't any decent ramen in the Sunset. Sawaii fills this void. It's like a Genki Ramen for dwellers south of the park.... not the most awesome ramen you'll ever eat, but cheap, delicious and fast.

We tried the tonkatsu ramen with pork belly, chicken karaage, and gyoza. 

Ramen was a decent size.... lots of noodles, sparse garnishing, but totally fair for $8. The broth was creamy white, but definitely not as sludgy rich as authentic joints. I still finished the entire bowl ;) Pork belly addition was excellent as well -- gelatinous and buoyant. 

Karaage was nicely fried, but the sauce served with it was more Korean in flavor than Japanese. In fact, they served this same gooey garlic, soy, sugar, chili pepper sauce with the gyoza and that was kind of a nasty combo! I wish they had vinegar on the tables, so I could make my own soy/vinegar sauce instead. 

Overall 3.25 stars...rounding up, so this place gets some bizness and sticks around!

P.S. Is it Sawaii or Saiwaii, Yelp?! I couldn't decide between the double listings for this place, so I went with the one that has more reviews.
author: Lauren H.

description: There spicy garlic ramen is really good! I gave them four stars because they are lacking with there service.
author: Vanessa B.

description:
Before my experience last night I would have given Saiwaii 4 stars. Last nights delicious seafood Ramen can not make up for the terrible customer service I received. 

I was hung over and sick with a cold, long day at work and a 10 mile bike ride home...I was craving salty, brothy goodness. My husband and I have eaten here many times before, and  have gotten to-go a few times. We have also brought out of town family here because damn the have have good ramen! Always great food and excellent customer service.

Last night:

I placed my order with a nice woman, the owner maybe? Said it would be ready in about 10...went to Walgreens and back to Saiwaii 10 minutes later. When I get back a waitress is now at the counter saying my food to-go will be done shortly. (2 orders of seafood ramen, one for me, one for my husband and an appetizer) Great! I ask her if she can please give me 2 double bags, one ramen in each double bag. Helmet in hand I tell her I will be taking the ramen home on my bicycle handlebars about ten blocks away. I have done this before with no problem. She tells me I will have to pay for the bags because it's the law. I totally understand and search my backpack for 40 cents ( I paid with a card when I ordered) I couldn't find any money and then thought, "huh, it's "to-go" shouldn't my total have included bags?". I ask her about this...she says,"yes, we will give you one bag but we did not anticipate you needing 3 more". I keep searching for change at the bottom of my bag, obviously a little annoyed. Finally I ask her if there is a minimum for credit cards. She says, "no limit" and happily takes my card to charge 30 cents to it for the to-go bags because "it's the law". I over hear the woman who took my order asking the waitress what's going on. Waitress says she's charging me 30 cents because I need more than 1 bag. The woman (owner maybe?) says, 'just give them to her she spent $30". The waitress gives me 3 bags and says, "she said it's OK". No apology, no helping me bag it up no nothing. 

At home the ramen was good...but damn I just couldn't get over that bag thing!

This used to be my go to ramen place but it's not good enough to go back after this experience. So many other restaurants in the hood serving ramen...I'll be taking my salty, brothy goodness cravings elsewhere.
author: S. C.

description: Best ramen in the city, period.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
YAY! I've been eye-ing this place before they opened. I finally had a chance to come by yesterday with my friend, and we left happy! 

The place is really small, but it's cozy. I think the soup is solid, so I will definitely come back here again. YEE! No more long muni or drive to a decent Ramen shop.
author: Tina T.

description:
Decided to go here today and got started with the chicken kara-age. Fantastic! Good sized chunks of chicken, not over battered and didn't feel super oily or heavy. One of the best i've had. Will definitely order this one again. 

Next came the miso ramen. Relatively good, but I didn't feel that it was amazingly good compared to other ramens I've had in the past. The noodles were a little softer than I prefer, but I think preference is pretty subjective. Not overly unreasonable in terms of price at $8 for a bowl. Good service and an attentive wait staff but a small place with a bit of an odd table layout. You'll definitely be getting close to your fellow diners here when it's busy.
author: Justin S.

description:
pretty small place. was crowded when i got there so must be a good sign. i had the miso pork ramen. it was ok, but kinda dry. i had to ask for extra soup, which still wasnt enough. egg is considered extra so that's a bummer. also ordered the bacon wrapped asparagus; the portion was small for the price. best ramen is still daikakuya in little tokyo, los angeles. 

LOS ANGELES HAS THE BEST ASIAN FOOD IN GENERAL, FOR SURE!!! (pardon the non sequitur.)
author: p f.

description:
3/4.. I've driven by so many times and they finally caught me. Getting myself to go here was overcoming a huge mental barrier... Ramen + outer Irving St...Say what!?

Needless to say, my expectations were VERY low. I was going to go home happy if I didn't find something dead in my ramen. However, I was super surprised...

The ramen was decent. Not the best by any means but there was no ridiculous wait and it was clean inside. It's also much closer than the main ramen places in the SFBA if you don't want to truck downtown/San Mateo. Had the spicy garlic miso and although it didn't have that rich broth I crave, it still tasted good. Chicken karrage was 'OK'...Little dry. I'd pass next time. Small restaurant like you're sitting in someone's garage and the service was ok - Normal and not memorable which is a good thing in this instance.

To sum it up: Would go for a quick ramen fix but I wouldn't recommend it if you're searching for 'the best ramen ever' or anything like that.  +orenchi +katana-ya +santa +dojo
author: Con L.

description:
Service is super attentive and friendly. The ramen? Meh....The Grilled Squid? Too chewy and should've been more crispy and burnt.

My ramen adventure continues....
author: Soozie H.

description: I'm bumping the rating to four stars. Giving them kudos for the improvement. The broth is way better than my other two visits. There are new additions to the menu: spicy ramen.
author: hello k.

description:
friends of mine wanted to find a place that takes amex and i wanted ramen and saiwaii satisfied both criteria.  we got there on a saturday night around 8:30PM and the wait was less than two minutes.  score- since we were all pretty hungry by then.

we ordered several orders of uni nigiri, unagi don, green salad, and beef tongue to start.  all were really tasty.  the beef tongue was particularly hitting the spot for me because it was nice and tender and for those who are gagging at the thought of eating beef tongue, it seriously just taste like really beefy beef. :)

we each ordered ramen and i got whichever one it is with the karage, pork belly and half an egg.  i asked for it to be very spicy but they mixed up the order and made my friend's very spicy (poor thing).  we told them about the mix up and she was more than happy to make mine the heat level i originally asked for, but my poor friend suffered through his meal. :(

all in all a good satisfying meal.  the mistake was a little let down but i'll definitely come back again.
author: Sally T.

description: The pork broth was flavorful and rich and the pork belly was just great! The staff was friendly and the atmosphere was pleasant.
author: T W.

description: Reasonable and appropriate short (10 minute wait).  Quick service and incredible ramen (the grilled squid and sushi was awesome as well).  They didn't rush us out at the end either.  SF level quality of food but without the typical SF wait and scene.
author: Suvi N.

description:
We visited Saiwaii Ramen last night after our first choice restaurant had run out of noodles. It wound up being *really* tasty - better than we expected.

We shared an order of pork gyoza, which I liked but he didn't care for much. He had the Tonkatsu Ramen with pork belly, and I had the Miso Ramen. His was amazing, mine was good - not as miso-y as I like, as though they'd added miso to the tonkatsu base. Not a bad idea, just not what I had expected.

In any event, everything was great. The staff were very friendly, and the environment was warm and welcoming. (Having Tonari no Totoro on the TV didn't hurt!) We will definitely return to Saiwaii Ramen!
author: Karen C.

description: Mediocre. Compared to other spots in San Mateo i'll pass. Won't be back cuz it don't satisfy my spicy ramen cravings.
author: Larry L.

description: Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen and the Ten Don were delish! The broth from the ramen was so flavorful that my friends kept smelling it, and asking for a taste. It made my night. On a cold San Francisco evening, there's nothing quite like hot delicious soup to warm you from the inside out. The Ten Don was very good as well. I especially liked the unusual sweetness to the rice. Exquisite! Good decor. Excellent service. Cheap prices. Great value.
author: Vanessa M.

description:
Just ate here for lunch because my friend really wanted some ramen. I hesitated to come here because last time I came it was just...not a good experience. It was when they first opened and there were a lot of people and its a tight squeeze in there. But, I believe in second chances so we went. 

I ordered the Lunch special for 9.95  which gives you ramen and a choice of roll (5 simple choices). I got the miso ramen (because it comes with CORN) and sake avocado roll (salmon). My friend ordered the tonkatsu ramen. 

It was nice during lunch because not too many people in there and i was enjoying watching our SF GIANTS on the tvs (tie game when i got there and when i left). 

The miso ramen is a heavier broth compared to the tonkatsu...but still yummy. The ramen noodles are thicker and harder than most places I've been too, but I actually like harder noodles. Their bamboo is from the can, and...you can tell because the flavor is quite strong. 

The sushi was...ok...the rice was dry...which is not fun.  BUT...the salmon was yum! One of the fresher tasting/feeling salmon I've had around here.

Overall...it was an ok experience. I would go back for lunch because its quieter and I like the ramen...pricing is..a little more expensive than I would like...but...such is life...haha.
author: Melody G.

description: Ramen was ok, overall it just seemed like nothing that special. Tonkatsu broth was decent.
author: Alex H.

description: I give them four out of five stars because they (and my friend) put up with my drunkenness while I ate my ramen. Apparently I kept confusing the soy sauce plate with my cell phone.
author: Neil G.

description:
I came here on a Sunday at the beginning of service. I ordered the Chashu Ramen and California Roll. 
Food: Ramen was great. Price is very reasonable. The broth was quite salty on its own but balanced out perfectly with the noodles. The noodles were slightly firm, which was just right so that there wasn't broth flying around everywhere. The chashu was savory and tender. The fresh crab california roll was pretty tasty as well. 

Service: There was only one waitress at the time, which was perfectly fine as I was the only one in there for most of the time while I was eating. She was attentive, friendly, and efficient. Something that happens at times when you're the only person in a restaurant is you can be checked up on TOO often. My waitress did not do that at all, which was very pleasant. 

Overall it was a good eating experience. Good food, good service, and good atmosphere. I'll definitely be going there again next time I'm in town.
author: Invent C.

description:
Laura L., Auntie and I wanted to go to Let's Roll, but it was closed so we went to try Saiwaii Ramen instead. We were greeted by loud calls of Irashaimasu and were quickly seated. Decor is dark wood tables and chairs with long benches. Anyplace that shows Totoro on the big LCD tv is always a plus.

I ordered the Unagi Roll (Unagi, avocado, 6 pieces), and the California Special roll (crab, avocado and Unagi, 6 pieces)...the Cali special was really tasty and much bigger than the Unagi roll. I wished they used more unagi sauce since it was used very very sparingly. Laura L. ordered the dragon roll which had 8 pieces but at double the other order's costs. The tempura shrimp was still crispy inside and I love the big giant pices of unagi and avocado. Nicely done! Auntie ordered the Katsu-donburi. She really liked the flavors of the carmelized onions underneath the crispy pork cutlet pieces. Although she didn't finish the rice (but who usually does?), she really enjoyed it. The miso soup it came with was also made well, not super salty and not watered down to bland dishwater.

Water service was very attentive (actually to the point of every 5 minutes), our server was very nice. We had only 1 mix up at the beginning where they served us just regular California rolls instead of what we wanted, which they apologized...I did eat one before they took away the plate...it tasted okay but I was surprised that the seaweed was so chewy. 

I'll come back next time to try out their ramen selection...from the size of their bowls, it's going to have to be when I'm super starving to eat that much food.
author: Pauline L.

description: This was my first experience with a real bowl of ramen. I chose the miso soup base, and overall it was pretty decent. I did feel that it lost its exciting appeal rather quickly though...the flavor and texture gets very repetitive. I don't know if all authentic ramen is like this, or if their ramen is a little lackluster. I also wish they offered something other than pork in it. But the place is cozy and very small, which I liked. I also ordered one of their sushi rolls and that was delicious, and fairly priced. If I go back I am sure I will probably stick to the sushi, perhaps ramen is just not my bag.
author: Katie S.

description:
I would have given it 5 stars.  We had the spicy ramen but the side order of  buta kakuni (pork belly) was not heated through.  My preference is to have the ramen and it's ingredients piping hot.  

This is definitely a go-to place.  I'll ask them to heat up the pork belly the next time I'm there.
author: Debbie T.

description: Comfort food comes to mind when I think of this place. We come here so often since the day they opened that they gave us complimentary appetizer whenever the owner is there. The service can be slow at times due to the high volume of customers especially when its cold outside other than that, nothing to complain about.
author: Farrah R.

description:
We were roaming around on Irving Street last week and were debating where to have lunch. So we came across Saiwaii Ramen and then I remembered I bookmarked this place ages ago. 

Peeked into the window and noticed they weren't too busy so we figured might as well try it. We ordered the spicy garlic miso ramen and the tonkatsu ramen. We also tacked on a ten-don (small tempura don) for a about $4 extra. 

Both ramens were very tasty. The tonkatsu ramen was just right and do I dare say it was almost as good as Santa Ramen in San Mateo? Yeah - I can say it. Very creamy and very good. Good amount of ramen too. 

Now the spicy garlic miso ramen was really good. It had just enough heat to remind me of dare I say Ramen Dojo? Yup - darn close again. I would skip the extra bowl of ten-don. It was just ok. Nothing memorable. 

The only thing that kept this place from a 5 star was that when I went back later in the week for dinner (Yes - ate here twice in one week), the tonkatsu broth wasn't as flavorful. It was honestly kind of bland. Had to keep sprinkling hot pepper flakes into my soup. Also the portion of the ramen notably shrank . So minus one star for the inconsistency. 

Overall I would definitely return...beats having to drive to San Mateo to fix my ramen craving.
author: Cris H.

description:
yummm.....  I just had the spicy garlic tonkatsu yesterday and it sure hit the spot.  The noodles had a perfect chew to the bite, the broth was milky with full bodied pork taste.   It had the roasted cloves of garlic, the right amount of seaweed, bamboo shoots, wood ear, pork slices, and this yummy ground meat cluster.   Excellent on a cold day.  

We had the lunch special which was choice of ramen and a spicy tuna or california roll $9.95.   It was like ordering the ramen and getting a roll for free.   Their salads are good, though a little heavily dressed.   We also have been getting the baked mussles with bacon... yumm....

Also, like their California roll with real crab and unagi.  tasty.  

will be back ....
author: Regi K.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed my visit - Came here for lunch on a Friday.

Food: Good. Really liked their spicy garlic tonkatsu broth. I wasn't a huge fan of the noodles itself, but I'm not holding them against it. Next time, I'll probably add the pork belly for an additional $3, seems worth it. Also had their spicy chicken wings that were, in my opinion, really good.

Service: You had one waitress that held down the whole place by herself, kudos to her. Friendly from beginning till the end, refilled water when needed, and checked on our table from time to time.
author: Kenneth L.

description:
Ohhh... I'm enjoying my exploration of asian restaurants at the cusp of the inner and outer sunset. I have been dying to try a ramen place for a long time and finally found one! Okay, I have to admit that I have never actually had ramen besides the freeze dried noodle packages that I ate in high school, so I guess anything better than that would be fantastic. So I didn't give it 5 stars, because I don't have a reference point.

But heres what really made the place great: 
1. lotus root appetizer
2. patient waitresses
3. quick and pleasant service
4. great price!!

We had the katsu chicken ( the sauce for this was really good) and the unagi on rice side and the miso ramen soup. I really enjoyed :)
author: Sirina K.

description:
Heard from my Hubby's boss that THIS IS THE RAMEN PLACE of all of SF.  Since we love Ramen...we of course had to try it.

It is so YUMMY!! loved the simple Shoyu Ramen.  Of course get the homemade gyoza.  And throw in some Tuna don on the side... SUPER YUM!

I recommend it.  It's small, and you may have to wait...but worth it.

*not the best sushi tho..
author: mochiBrownie I.

description: Get the Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen.. The soup is very flavorful and if you can handle the heat, get the spicy version.. I've been here a few times and I'm sure I'll be back many more.. Add the pork belly side and you won't go wrong..I'll be back soon!!!
author: Kiel V.

description: The ramen at Izakaya Sozai is still my first love but Saiwaii's spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen is creeping at 2nd place.  You can tell the noodles are made fresh which is how things should be done :)  I thought the broth was hovering at a comfortable spicy level--just enough to make your taste buds dance.  The meat was tender but there wasn't enough of it.  I highly recommend ordering extra protein so you don't end up with a bowl of noodles and broth situation.  Oh, you can't beat the price and service was prompt, in my opinion.  I think when I go back, I'll try the sushi rolls because the menu looked appetizing.
author: Lynnie T.

description:
Came here today for lunch with my girlfriend. When my girlfriend asked if we could sit at a table we preferred, the server rolled her eyes at us and refused!!! But other than this, the service was attentive. No major complaints.

We ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen lunch special, and my gf ordered the Pork Katsu lunch special. The rolls that came with the combo were just okay. The pork katsu was very dry and tough to chew. The ramen was not bad overall even though it didn't come with any egg. It came with 3 pieces of pork, and the pork was okay. What I like is the ramen came with LARGE amount of wood ear and seaweed. 

The lunch special (the ramen one) was really worth it. By the way, we both felt thirsty 30 mins after eating here, but many yelpers mentioned that they don't put MSG, so I will probably come back and try again. Yes, I will come back if I am in the area and want to have ramen. Oh, I almost forgot to mention that they open 7 days a week which is a plus!
author: Will N.

description:
Decent soup, sub par ramen. When I go to an establishment with the word Ramen in their name, I expect a damn good bowl of ramen! Sadly I was disappointed. I ordered the spicy garlic miso ramen which was garlicky but not spicy. The broth was good, and the pickled bamboo shoots were tasty. However, my noodles were limp and over cooked! I couldn't even finish half of it.

Our waitress was very attentive and kept coming back to check on us and refill our tea which I appreciated. However, I wasn't impressed with the ramen and won't be coming back here for it if I have a choice.
author: Danielle W.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place.  The reviews were hit or miss but I was hoping they were just working out the kinks.

The Tonkatsu Ramen was YUM!  the broth was packed with flavor and the noodles fresh and chewy.  It could have used another slice of pork.  5 stars!

The Katsu Don on the other hand needed more eggy goodness.  The flavors were there but there wasn't enough egg.  I love me some egg.  Saiwaii, remedy this!  minus one star.
author: Blu n.

description:
Saiwaii Ramen is not to die for kind of place.  The soup base meh and who puts corn in ramen.   The pork had a little gamey flavor.  The noodle itself wasn't bad, it was fresh and had a chewy consistency (the way I like it).  I should've know better as this place is run by Chinese people. So in my opinion, not too authentic.  Those Chinese ppl who are reading this... don't be bent outta shape by this comment.  I'm Chinese myself, not that it makes it any better.  But in my experience there's usually a twist to the non-Chinese food cooked by a Chinese owner/cook.  Maybe, I should just call it 'Fusion".   Plus, my grandfather/aunt has an "chinese-american" restaurant and it's definitely not all the way authentic "caucasian-american" cuisine.  Hence, that's why my family restaurant is labeled "chinese-american".  OK, I'm definitely rambling...

Eh, I had to try it out. Not much good Ramen places in the sunset district and sometimes just don't want to run all the way out to downtown or the peninsula for good ramen. Good service though.
author: Sassy G.

description:
I would vote it as average ramen in San Francisco.

Not-so-Ample ingredients in my tonkatsu ramen.  Service is good.
author: Paulette T.

description:
So I came here new years eve and it was completely empty.  A cold and rainy day perfect for hot ramen!  I ordered the tonkatsu based ramen..and didn't add anything because I am not going to pay an extra DOLLAR for an egg.  I added the side which literally came with TWO pieces of sashimi and rice .  It was really overpriced!

I would never go out of my way to come here...I'd much rather goto katana-ya or even genki ramen..But if in the neighborhood then I would eat here.

I had a mix up on my "debit" card but was really a visa gift card.  I don't understand why the waitress said they don't accept debit? who doesnt? anyway they charged my card and my bf's card.  I had to go back into the restaurant to ask about the extra charge!
author: Joanne H.

description: I'm pretty sure my hubby won't kiss me after this meal, but it was worth it!  My friend and I ordered the the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen (regular spice).  It definitely cleared my sinuses.  The broth was heavy and comforting on this chilly January day.  There was a balance of spinach, bamboo, char siu (a little more fatty than I prefer), and ground pork.  Overall, I was really impressed.  I would prefer a little less garlic b/c the after taste still continues hours after the meal, but regardless, I think I have found a new ramen spot!
author: Steph W.

description: OMG. I tried to garlic tonkatsu ramen with regular spicy and an egg. This is something that you will probably crave after you have it once. The place is somewhat small, but cute. This place has the ability to get crowded, so try to going during times when their isn't a lot of people. Not much else to say other that I'm coming back!
author: Victoria L.

description: One of the most flavorful ramen. For the spicy lovers, I recommend the spicy garlic tonkotsu with egg! I think their lunch specials ( ramen with sushi for about $11) are so worth it. They give big portions too.  Parking is sometimes hard. Staff is usually always nice and welcoming.
author: Jay R.

description:
I'm a ramen nerd - I'll do anything for a big bowl of steamy flavorful ramen, for example, travelling far and waiting in long lines. The opening of Sawaii Ramen is such a wonderful gift to this Asian influenced neighborhood, and it's about time to have a decent ramen place in the "Avenues". 

We came here after our evening run (there goes the sweat and tear), I couldn't resist the thought of slurping down some good ramen noodles, and successfully convinced my workout buddies to be my partners in crime! Yay! 

First thing we noticed was the friendliness of the staffs there. There was a short wait for table of 3, the waiter came out to offer us tea, menu, and apologized for the wait. While they were cleaning our table, the waitress again came out to apologize and invite us in to wait. WOW! A sparkling gold star for the management! We felt warm and fuzzy already! 

We ordered the squid legs, ankimo, miso, and tonkatsu ramen. The squid legs and ankimo were average, although they could be more generous on the ankimo. ;-) Then there was the tonkatsu ramen - mmm mmm mmm!!! I actually ordered the miso ramen, which was also good, not too salty or bland; the noodles were dense, not hard or saggy; however, the cha shu texture was a bit rough and too thick. Well, back to the tonkatsu ramen, after a sip of the soup, I offered to trade with my friend, but she politely and firmly rejected my offer. You could taste the distinct flavor of the pork stock, which has been simmered for hours or days. 

It has been 2+ hours since we finished our meal... I'm not having any thirsty feeling, which usually happens if they use MSG, or, I'm simply refusing to cleanse my pallet, and still savoring that sip of tonkatsu ramen, ahhhhhh...
author: Kai Z.

description: The ramen is filling and soft.  I got the pork flavor soup and the cha su that comes with it is yummy.  The portion size is not bad and the price is ok.  The bacon wrapped scallop appetizer was great.  The downside is that they don't have any desserts like ice cream.  The soup is not too salty or oily unlike some other ramen places.
author: Jennie W.

description:
I have to give this a five star.  I love both the food and the service here.  You can pretty much find us here every Thursday evening.  We come here so often they pretty know what we are going to order prior to us ordering.  

Our standard order:  Ramen combo with Miso ramen and a bowl or unagi don.  An order of Cali rolls and an order of Gyoza and we are set!  

This is a great spot to come for some good ramen.  It is nice and clean, and the service is wonderful!
author: Stella C.

description:
My friend and I came across this one by sheer chance.  Izakaya was closed for the holidays (still?!) and we had a hungering for Tonkostu ramen.  I did a Yelp search of the area and found this spot barely 2 miles away, which was very fortunate as my poor friend was withering away with hunger!

First, the place is a very unassuming spot. No ambiance or decor to speak of, but DAMN the food was good!

 I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen and the broth was divine!  Very creamy and rich with flavor, exactly how I like it! The toppings were fairly generous and the fresh scallions heaped on top was a nice bonus. I'm always surprised at how few places even bother with small touches like that, it shows an attention to detail and care that is quickly becoming a rare thing.  It invokes a fond memory of mama's soup, slurping up some noodles and gulping scorching broth just as the snow begins to fall outside. 

(Well, it was also REALLY cold in the restaurant. Damn guys, turn up the heat!) 

My friend got the Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen, but spicy and even with all that spice you could taste the dimensions of flavor in the broth rather than it being obliterated by the spiciness. It will be my next choice!!

I also ordered a Sunrise roll (?) which was spicy tuna, mango and avocado.  I was skeptical being the place looks slightly on the dingy side, but I was pleasantly surprised.  The seaweed was tender, yet not tough and chewy and the mango was sweet for once!! Usually when I get any kind of roll with mango in it, I can't taste it for squat, so it was nice change. Tuna was fresh, tasty and just spicy enough.  Beautiful presentation and great sushi as far as I can tell, I can't wait to try the others!

It's a pity that service isn't exactly that awesome as I had to call out to the servers twice to get their attention.  Oh, and we were THE ONLY ONES in the restaurant. Also, they don't have a liquor license yet, so no hot sake or ice cold sapporo for you if you enjoy that with your meal.  That was a REAL bummer. 

Also, I really hope they consider putting some thought into the ambiance.  I don't enjoy hearing commercials when I'm eating dinner. C'mon, go whip out an ipod and slap some smooth grooves on it! It's not that hard and it makes a HUGE difference. Either that, or you better ply me with lots of hot, cheap sake until I can't hear that McCorkin commercial anymore!
author: Annie W.

description:
we ordered the pork base and spicy miso ramen.  i'm a big fan of spicy ramen, but this one was not quite what i has in mind. It was okay spicy, but was not the flavor i'm lookong for. 
However, my boyfriend ordered the pork base ramen.  The broth was like homemade soup. I couldn't stop sipping on his bowl of soup.  The ramen was okay, not that chewy. I would give them a five if they have the chewy ramen

i would definitely come back to order the pork base ramen. Loving the broth.
author: C L.

description: 3.5 stars for Saiwaii Ramen. The atmosphere is nice and the service  was prompt. They offer a wide variety menu items... which is the appeal. However, nothing was really that great except the spicy miso ramen broth. The pork was mediocre.
author: Johnson B.

description: The ramen was really tasty and flavorful; we expected that and they delivered as usual. What was surprising was the appetizers were really good too. We ordered Ankimo (monkfish liver), Gyutan (beef tongue), Geso Shioyaki (grilled squid legs), and spicy garlic soft shell crab on a bed of spring mix and they were all good. The service was fast and very friendly, constantly dropping by to check on us. Definitely worth a try if you have not been there. We are definitely coming back.
author: Yelp R.

description:
After knowing a lot of my friends come here for ramen noodle, I had to give it a try myself. We came here on a Sunday right before closing time, so it wasn't pack with people. As a matter of fact, we were the only customer in here.

It's a fairly small restaurant that serves ramen,  donbouri, and sushi. I ordered the spicy miso flavor and it hits the spot right. The noodle was a bit hard for my taste, it was like a bit under cooked. But over all, it was very tasteful. The ramen is served with seaweed, corn, and chu-shu, which is a thinly sliced pork. You can order add-ons of pork belly, which I've seen a lot of people getting. Although I didn't order that I will definitely give it a shot next time. 

I think I have found my go to restaurant in the city to satisfy my ramen craving. They will definitely be seeing me again!
author: Jenny G.

description:
Just a few words of advice -

Extra. Spicy. Garlic. Tonkatsu. Ramen. Go.

Nose-drippingly good.
author: Christine C.

description:
Took us a long time to finally come here, even though it's only 10 minutes away from home (assuming that there's no crazy Asian traffic on Irving and there's no festival / concert / anything of that nature in Golden Gate Park).  

The one thing that I tried (and will get again in subsequent visits) was the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen.  The ramen was nice and perfect (i approve!) and the broth was flavorful without too much oil (i like!).  

The only thing is the ramen plus all the add-ons can easily get to $18... otherwise the $9.95 bowl comes with barely any toppings, and a bowl of ramen isn't legit unless there's a soft-boiled egg and pork belly cubes in it!

Be prepared to wait around 20-30 minutes on a Friday night.  We did.
author: Ange L.

description: The ramen here was so so.  The soup was nothing to rave about.  Let alone my chashu was fatty.  There was barely any meat... BOOO.  The spicy chicken wings were semi sweet then spicy.  Totally not what I thought it would be since it was called "spicy wings".  Definitely not coming back here for ramen!
author: Ann L.

description: After trying more ramen places in the south bay, i have to say Sawaii is only worth 3 stars BUT it is still the best in the city IMO, better than the overrated Katana-Ya.
author: Lily S.

description:
The reason I am giving this 2 stars is many reasons:

1) Donburi
I've been here quite a few times and yes I know they're known for ramen and yes their ramen is good. But I wanted to try donburi, because I really really i mean REALLY like unagi and this time the unagi don was hard to pass up. we ordered two tonkatsu ramen, dragon roll sushi, and the Unagi Don. The tonkatsu ramen and the sushi came fast. I Waited for my unagi don for a long long time. The people at my table finished their ramen and then I got my unagi don. Making them wait and the unagi don was lackluster. The eel was okay and the rice was eh. It just had a lot of the eel sauce on the rice and like this a little bit of seasame and like a teaspoon of shredded seaweed. It wasn't great and it wasn't bad but the wait for it was horrible. 

2) The woman who does the sitting of the table during night time. I don't know if she's the owner or what. But man she makes me pissed. We wait about 45 minutes for our table. Why? Because people called and made a "reservation" and by "reservation" I mean they called it and the lady said okay come on in we'll set you up (how did we know? we asked some people around us what this "reservation" is and they told us that you don't even have to put down your name and you just come say you have a reservation and she'll sit you down) there's a name list as soon as you walk in and it's total BS. We waited freaking 45 minutes for a table because every freaking person said they had a reserveration and they put their names down on that stupid list. Our name was there before them but they said they called first so they got a table first. A group of people who came 15 minutes after us got a table before us because they had a "reservation". and you know the best part? She apologized to them for the table taking too long. But when she sat us down there was nothing. We waited 2x longer than them and we got nothing. 
And when we told her about how we were here before them she just said they had a reservation. it's like really? So if i came in put my name on the list but 100 people made a reservation before me does this mean i'll never get a seat? Ridiculous.

I gave it a two star because that service from that woman was just not okay. You should not treat people like that. and that unagi don was such a dissappointment.  I think if i do go back i'll go back for lunch where it's not crowded and that woman isn't there. Stick to the ramen and sushi. both are yums.
author: Emily L.

description: Decent Ramen option on Irving Street.  Chinese run.  A hang-out place for the 20-somethings in the Sunset.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Ate there Feb 5 for lunch.  I had the miso ramen and it was just what I needed!  Really enjoyed the noodle texture & the broth.  No MSG, from what I could tell.

Service was attentive and fast, except, I noticed that two tables that ordered after us got their food first.

The goyza was delicious too!
author: Yelper H.

description:
If I could, I would give this place 3.5 stars. I was a bit skeptical about this place since its new, it has very mixed reviews and a fren's fren recently dined here and wasn't impressed. So maybe going in with not so high expectations was a good thing. 

The place is small, but its clean and it works. As of now, there isn't an absurd wait to get a bowl of ramen, so a plus! 

We got the Shoyu & Spicy Miso (making it spicy was extra $1, something they recently started) We also ordered the grilled chicken wings, which weren't exciting at all, I wouldn't recommend it. It was tasteless, didn't seem like it had any sorta of marinade, literally...grilled chicken wings split in half.

Our noodles were good, decent portions, neither of us finished our bowl. The spicy miso broth was a little thick, which I guess is common because so is Ramen Dojo's, but still good and spicy. Maybe they should give a little more broth to compensate for that?

The cha su was just ok, they are on the thin side, but maybe because they are still a little chewy? It didn't fall apart like at some other places I've had.

Our noodles did come hot, so it sounds like they're still working out the kinks. It does sound pretty pricy to add stewed pork belly tho, I wonder if it's worth it?! 

I'd come back and give them another try if ever in the area =)
author: Ly T.

description:
I checked out Saiwaii when there were only a handful of reviews.  Back then, there were talks of a watered down broth.  However, I love ramen, and I love trying new food so I checked it out anyway.  Besides, there was some hope: one review mentioned that they were trying to improve their broth.

My first trip to Saiwaii turned out to be a good decision, because the broth was quite good.  I tried the Miso ramen and found that the portion was satisfying.

One thing's strange.  I've been there twice since my first visit, and the broth seems to be a little inconsistent.  Each time I got the Miso ramen they tasted different.  Not bad, just different from the previous times.  I will say that the pork belly addition is delicious.

All in all, I think Sawaiii is a great ramen place.  They also have nice Ramen Combos that allow you to get a half serving of donburi.  I just wish they were more consistent with their flavors.  It's great that they seem to be paying attention to their reviews on Yelp, but at some point they need to find a taste that defines them.
author: Andrew T.

description: When I think of ramen, I think of Saiwaii because of their delicious spicy garlic tonkatsu.  It comes in mild, medium or spicy and it is oh so good!  My husband loves the spicy mala ramen which is also very good.  They also have really good appetizers like the pork belly, an ahi tuna (can't remember the name) and chicken karaage (great for the kids).  It's a small restaurant but the service is fast plus its nice and cozy inside with tv's.
author: Michelle D.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend Saturday afternoon and the place was about 60% full but there was a constant flow of people coming and leaving (not sure if it was because of the festival going on or if it is normally like that).  However, I did notice two people lifting their bowls and drinking every last drop of the soup from their ramen...which I took as a good sign.  Anyway,  my boyfriend and I shared the Miso Ramen, Tonkatsu Ramen and Hot Summer Roll.

The Hot Summer Roll (spicy tuna, avocado and mango) was surprisingly delicious and refreshing.  The tuna was very fresh and the mango added a nice sweetness to it...nom, nom, nom!

Both the miso broth and pork broth broth from the ramen were very flavorful and I enjoyed them equally.  The ramen had a great texture as well.

Overall, we were both very happy with our meal at Saiwaii.  Service was very quick, which was an added bonus.  I'll definitely be back again...and probably very soon too ;)
author: Katelynn L.

description:
I came here on my quest to find mindblowing ramen in the city.  I was surprised that we were able to get seats at 7PM on a Friday, so that was a plus.

Unfortunately, the ramen was not as good as I had hoped.  My friend and I started with agedashi tofu, which was fantastic (although I may be biased because I just love the silky texture of tofu).  The fried crab sushi was so-so.  I thought the rice was a little soggy, but I won't fault them there because Saiwaii is not billing itself as a sushi restaurant.

I had the garlic tonkotsu ramen.  The broth is generally made by boiling pork fat, bones, and collagen for hours until a thick, milky broth is formed - in other words, savory, salty, deliciousness.  The broth here was really savory and salty, but it didn't have complexity or depth of flavor.  The noodles did not seem to have soaked up any flavor, so every bite was this weird, separated dichotomy of bland noodle taste and salty broth.  The garlic was overwhelming.  Maybe that was my fault for ordering the garlic version, which could have drowned out the more subtle flavors.

Anyway, I'd try it if for no other reason than because this is a ramen shop where you can likely get a seat, and you can never really go wrong with a hot bowl of noodle soup.  Prices are really reasonable too.
author: Pearl L.

description:
I came here last night with two friends and we all found it to be nothing special.  Even though the restaurant is pretty small, the design is sleek, modern, and spacious which can accommodate large groups of people.  We all had the Tonkotsu ramen which came with delicious bamboo shoots and plenty of noodles.  However, the broth lacked dimension and felt flat.  I tried adding some red pepper flakes to give it a little more flavor but it still tasted bland.  A shame, really, because I'm a firm believer that broth is probably one of, if not the most, important aspect to a good bowl of ramen.  My only suggestion is to add more salt into the broth.  It definitely has potential; what it needs is some magic here and a pinch or five of salt there to enhance the flavor.

The service was also very friendly and attentive.  However, if you're looking for irresistible ramen with amazing broth, you may want to look elsewhere.
author: Alex L.

description:
The Ramen was just okay. Way too pricey for what you get. There are many other ramen places that taste way better and there is literally only about two slices of meat in the bowl.
The noodles are also really hard. The soup is salty.
author: Jean Lee W.

description:
I think this is my favorite ramen place in the city now. The broth is pretty good, and the noodles have just the right consistency. But what takes it over the edge???

The pork belly. Simply put, if you don't have pork belly in your ramen, you have NO idea what you're missing.

Came here a few times, and watched Game 2 of the World Series with a buddy of mine. Giants won of course. We stayed here for a LONG time, and they did not attempt to kick us out or anything.
