In fact, although they were watching, they also kept refilling our tea cups. Not once. Or Twice. But like a million times over the course of an hour. 

Friendly service, great atmosphere, and good food. It's cozy, but definitely not cramped, and the place is just warm and inviting. I'm definitely going to come here again.
author: Clinton L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place.  I mean, *really*.  But, it was unfortunately disappointing as are many of the restaurants in this neighborhood, my hood.  

I consider myself a ramen lover, for sure.  I've had ramen at many different places around town, and I still haven't found a place that makes ramen as good as the little street ramen places in Tokyo.  I have a feeling they don't exist.  

Well, Sawaii was no exception.  And, of the places in San Francisco I've tried, it was very nearly the most flavorless.  I'm pretty sure they do not use homemade noodles, their consistency is that of dried, and their broth just doesn't have any flavor.  I had the Chashu ramen, and as someone previously mentioned, had to pay extra for the egg, and the egg came out nearly uncooked - the white was even runny.  In light of the salmonella scare going on, it seemed sort of bad taste (not to mention affecting my enjoyment of the meal).  

Sorry Sawaii, I'll be continuing to go to Genki for their amazing Chashu Ramen with the homemade noodles, super tender pork, marinated egg and loads of flavor (under 10 bucks out the door).    

Stars for the really nice staff, and I'll give them the benefit of the doubt that there might be a couple good things on the menu.
author: Cami B.

description:
I've been here several times, and usually the food is good and the service is acceptable. But my most recent visit had been a lot less than pleasant!  It was about a five minute wait for a table for two, which is not bad at all given how small the restaurant is. But once we were seated, we had to wait 15 minutes before our order was taken. We tried flagging the waiter down, but he seemed to lower is head every time he passed us. Eventually, we noticed that the table that was sat after us (party of 6) had already received their food and we hadnt even been offered water! So I turned around and stood up to grab the waiter to take our order. He comes to our table, and the lady at the table next to us tries to order first! At this point, my patience has completely run out, and I say to the waiter, "why are you taking her order? We are not together and my friend and I have been waiting for over 15 minutes!" So he procedes to take our order and then takes the order of the next table (ehich I forgot to mention, just sat down), then he rushes off! So we sit there, drinkless while we wait for the waiter to come back.
 When we receive our food, a female waitress brings it, with tea. I can only assume that we have scared our waiter off because the rest of the dinner was served by the waitress instead. That waitress saved this review from being a one star review! Man, they have to retrain that waiter because it wasnt that busy and he really dropped the ball when it comes to just standard service! 
In terms of the ramen, the garlic tonkatsu broth is great. A little pricey for the amount that you get though. I would say you woukd get a better deal at some of the other ramen places in the city or evem san mateo, with the same or better quality.
author: Randell J.

description:
We always encounter these significant moments in history that affect us all so much that they become "where were you when..." moments. We might have not been together when they happened, but we all had an experience during that event that we can all relate to. Such questions as:

"Where were you when the 1989 Loma Prieta Earthquake hit?"

"Where were you when the news outlets announced Barack Obama as our new President?"

"Where were you when the first space shuttle to the moon landed?" (for our older Yelpers...)

"Where were you when the Giants totally creamed the Rangers in the 8th Inning of Game 2 of the 2010 World Series?"

Well, let me answer those questions...

On the bottom bed of the bunk bed at home with parents, watching the World Series.

In my apartment with roommates, celebrating.

In the Haight, getting higher than any spaceman can dream of... or at least whoever I was in my previous lifetime probably did... or doing mounds of paperwork at work... the only person who can tell me this is Shirley MacLaine. What? Too obscure of a reference? No one saw "Defending Your Life" but me? Fuck.

At Saiwaii Ramen... enjoying a thorough beating of the Rangers and the taste of pork belly in my Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen. 

It was my second time in there, and since we were in the neighborhood, we decided to go. The game was on and I believe it was the start of the 8th inning, or in the middle of the top of the inning. The ramen was great, the service was great, and the atmosphere of enjoying a nice bowl of ramen just made me enjoy watching baseball... and I'm not a huge baseball fan, either. We were done with our meal, having paid and left a tip for the waitresses, but we were so enthralled in the game, which the bottom of the 8th had been going on forever, that we stayed. They didn't try to kick us out (then again, there wasn't a line of people waiting to get in, either.) They even refilled our tea cups, which was very cool of them.

It was so good, that I went the following night... well, another friend decided to overturn our Thai food plans and was all "RAMEN! LET'S GO GET RAMEN!" It was different waitresses, but the service and the food were still great. I had something non-ramen related (an unagi don) and it was still pretty good.

Overall, this place is great. I wish it was a little bit bigger since it is pretty small, but I've never felt uncomfortable here. Knowing of my friends' love for Japanese food and ramen, I'm pretty sure I'll go here again if someone craves a hot bowl of ramen... and I totally wouldn't say no.
author: Chris S.

description: This is by far one of the best ramen places i have been to yet. It is very flavorful has lots of noodles and service is always great!
author: Valerie N.

description: The ambiance is not half bad but I can't say anything good about the ramen. I had the spicy garlic ramen and my boyfriend had tonkatsu ramen with a half egg. The broth was just all msg and no flavor. There was no depth to the broth and the noodles were inconsistent
author: Sara B.

description: i have been on a constant hunt for a ramen spot in SF comparable to ramen dojo in san mateo. and sadly, this place was another miss. i had the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen w regular spice and added corn and an egg. first off, regular spice was like no spice. guess i shlda added more spice avail at the table. and the broth had a weird flavor to it. tasted like garlic was from a jar or was it the bamboo shoots that made it weird? anyhow, i didnt enjoy it as much as i wouldve a smaller bowl at RD. but i thought the spoon that hooked on the side of the bowl was pretty cool. =\
author: Grace V.

description:
The service is GREAT but the food... eh.

Not much selection for Ramen. They don't even have different soups to choose from and the menu is kinda confusing. I think I'd probably give them a try again. They did just open, so they DO deserve a second chance.
author: A W.

description:
Returned to Saiwaii (said like Hawaii with an 'S') last night and was excited to see their new specials. They have expanded their ramen menu to include spicy miso ramen and spicy garlic ramen.  They even have a XXX spicy ramen, which I have not dared to try yet. Its not on the menu, but you can ask the waiter to bring it out for you.  The normal spicy miso ramen is my new favorite. 

I also enjoy their new expanded sushi menu. They have a good selection of fish. Ask the waiter for the freshest fish for the day. Last time I did that, they brought out the most AMAZING hamachi I ever had! It just melted in your mouth. With the new expanded menu, Saiwaii has something for everyone even if you aren't in a ramen mood.
author: Sara A.

description: We have eaten here several times. last night we went for dinner since the hubby was craving for ramen. We ordered the fried oysters, chicken skin skewers, chicken gizzard skewers, and chicken karaage for appetizers. The appetizers came out hot except for the chicken kaarage. It came out pretty fast from the time I ordered it so we expected it to be hot like it normally is. It came out lukewarm, like as if they cooked it for another table who didn't order it so it was just sitting back behind the counter until someone else ordered it. We didn't complain about it since our 2-1/2 year old was hungry and wanted what she call's mommy's chicken since I always order it. We also ordered the tonkatsu ramen with a side of spicy tuna don and the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen.They would have gotten a 4 star if the chicken kaarage was pipping hot like it's supposed to be. The spicy don was on the small side. Ramen was tasty.
author: Trina C.

description:
Every once in a while, you'll meet that one person who isn't impressed by the crowd's favorite. Not necessarily the Debbie Downer of the group, perhaps we'll refer to him as the Hard-to-Please Henry. Hard-to-Please Henrys can come off very apathetic and are easily dissatisfied when presented with something of greatness. They are too consumed in their own high standards and great expectations that by the time this thing of greatness is revealed, they can only see this greatness as being a lackluster performance and nothing more. I sadly suffered a case of being the Hard-to-Please Henry the night I dined at Saiwaii Ramen.

I really wanted to like Saiwaii Ramen, but once those feelings of slight dissatisfaction occurred, the transformation of happy camper into Hard-to-Please Henry was irreversible. It all began when our server told me that the shoyu ramen does not come in spicy. Now I am a spicy ramen enthusiast. I find it impossible to devour ramen if it is not spicy. The only remedy to my problem was to order the spicy garlic ramen because that was the only ramen that came in spicy. So my question is -- how does Saiwaii have a spicy garlic ramen but cannot add that same spice from that broth into the shoyu ramen? Blaspheme! I'm pretty sure the spicy garlic ramen was amazing, but my Hard-to-Please Henry goggles were on and anything substituted for my initial want of spicy shoyu ramen just would never reach my high expectations. The broth was overly salty and the mixture of spice, garlic, and boiling hot broth made my breath hotter than a flaming hot dragon. IMO, you either go with garlic or with spicy but never those two together because putting those two ingredients together create a potent mixture that'll leave your stomach bubbling and your breath reeking for days. 

Despite being quite the Hard-to-Please Henry, the chicken karaage was still delicious. But then again, no one ever fails at chicken karaage.
author: Ally C.

description: They got our orders wrong and made my friends really spicy when he ordered mild. The waitress asked him if he wanted to get a new one or add more soup. He asked for a new one but they just added more soup to it! So we had to ask the chef to make a new one again. But the food was pretty good and the lunch deal is a good deal!
author: Kierstyn W.

description: Food is delicious and the prices are great. I do wish there were fewer people since it can often be really packed, but I just hope that means they'll be around for a long time!
author: Miguel V.

description:
Mmm, ramen! Before coming here I've never had ramen aside from the Top variety, so I gave this place a try. I ordered the shoyu ramen. The noodles were fresh and chewy (reminds me a bit of egg noodles). In the soup was wood fungus, seaweed, thin sliced cha-siu (Chinese bbq pork), and thick pieces of bamboo shoots (freaking. delicious.). It was a bit salty but boy was it filling and yummy. The service was good too, despite there only being two waitresses for an almost full restaurant. Ours was friendly and kept my teacup replenished throughout the whole meal.

Definitely coming back here!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Got here a little after it opened at 5pm for dinner service. I was glad I got there when I did because people started pouring in towards the end of our meal.

I had the spicy pork tonkotsu ramen. I'm actually salivating a little thinking about it to write this review. No, really. The broth was appropriately rich and creamy as a tonkotsu should be. What really blew me away, though, was the spice profile. It served to enhance the complexity of the broth without turning it into a bowl of capsaicin. At the same time, you definitely won't forget that the kick is there.

This place is a definite must for any ramen fanatic.
author: Tony P.

description: Yum! I love ramen and the ramen here tastes great! I love the varieties and that they make the spicy ones very spicy. Service is pretty efficient and fast. The price is pretty cheap too. I haven't tried a lot of the other dishes but the sushi is fine and we usually start with at least one roll and then have ramen as our main dish. Definitely recommend if you are craving pho but want something a little different.
author: Jennifer R.

description: First time I tried the spicy garlic miso but didn't like it too much.  I thought the spicy garlic tonkatsu was good, but the spicy mala was even better! I was a little skeptical about the karage being too soggy, but if you eat it early, you get the perfect combination of crispy and extra flavor from soaking in the broth.
author: Thomas N.

description:
Very good ramen joint on the Sunset side.  Of course, had to try the tonkotsu ramen.  The broth isn't as heavy as those of Santouka or Santa but is still flavorful, especially with the use of seaweed.  Also appreciated the rice bowl as an add-on.  The unagi-don was outstanding and I want to come back to try more things.

Seating was a little cramped.  Service was attentive.  Liked the movie they showed on the big screen TV.  In my opinion, almost as good as Sozai and one of the better ramen places in the city.
author: Re-pley Z.

description:
I ate here twice already, and it is actually not too bad. 

First time I was here, I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen. Soup base is OK. I like how it isn't full of MSG because I am actually not thirsty after eating a bowl of ramen here. I feel like it is actually quite healthy. Maybe so many are complaining it taste bland. But I am fine with what I had!

The second time, I tried their miso ramen, which is not bad. First time having corn in my ramen. 

Service is great, always have my cup of tea filled. 

One thing I don't like about this place is portion is SO SMALL and its like $9? for a bowl of ramen almost. I walk out and I feel like I can eat a bit more. 

Wish portions are bigger so it can last me through my night class!
author: Willa L.

description:
Bah I didn't like it. To keep it short and simple.. as other Yelpers said, broth wasn't hot. Was warm.. maybe because of the noodles. Who knows. I ordered the tonkatsu ramen w/ vegetable roll. The roll was nice. The ramen bleh. I guess I was hoping for more.. the ramen tasted bland... nothing remotely special about it. I tried adding more flavor to the broth. Red chili powder, soy sauce, Chili oil.. I finished the broth just because I was hungry. I didn't touch the ramen at all. 

My friend that I ate said Saiwaii is 3 stars in her book. I don't agree with her, lol.
author: Alice E.

description:
The ramen is not bad! service is good, was a little disappointed in my kalbi.  The sauce it was marinated in, was sour, the beef was good, but for $7, you expect more than one strip of kalbi cut into 10 small pieces.

3.5stars, cant give it 4.
author: kim w.

description:
Always amazing. The ramen soups are some of the best I have ever tasted. A beyond soups their sushi, rice bowl an special dishes are really wonderful, full of flavor and truly unique.

The service is A+. Very friendly, happy to help and just about the nicest aspect of the meal.

Today in particular thru excelled. I called 15 minutes before they close from lunch asking if they were indeed closing at 3p. Apparently she talked to the chef and they were more than happy to stay open and serve us an awesome lunch. And today their spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen soup was needed. My head cold was killing me and the spice of that soup was the perfect medicine.
author: Arthur G.

description:
Very good 
ramen I try the spicy  Garlic chix both ramen  and tori karaage very good too will be back soon
author: Andy L.

description:
i have to say, this is my go to ramen place :)  yay for not having to travel to japantown or anywhere far for great tasting ramen and sushi!!  :D

i ordered the tonkatsu ramen and my bf got the miso ramen with sunrise roll to start. Sunrise roll has spicy tuna, cucumber, and guess what?!  MANGO!  LOL  spicy tuna and fruit, who would of guess it was very yummy combo!  hehe

tonkatsu ramen, two thumbs up!  hehe  creamy tasty broth, i didin't like the miso ramen so much.  the broth was a bit thick and not what i'm used to tasting.   

the salad menu has a variety and i would love to try them all!  actually i want to try almost everything on the menu~  customer service is superb!  very kind, courtesy, and friendly :]  i will come again~
author: mea f.

description:
No, no, NO! This is not a good ramen place, despite having "Ramen" in the name. It isn't authentic and it's not  good. If you're looking for good ramen, look else where.

The best I can say is that the service was prompt and polite, the restaurant itself is clean. If only they had good ramen, then I would be really, really happy. But alas, the soup base has a odd taste to it, the noodles have a weird mushy texture to them that I can't quite place and the gyoza was mediocre at best.
author: Meghan R.

description:
thanks to stacy k for spreading her excitement about coming here last week. 

spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen. DA BOMB! it was all so good i ate the WHOLE.... DARN.... BOWL! 

we also had one of their specials: ready?  it was spicy garlic soft shell crab. fried crab on top of a bed of field greens topped with lots of green onions and fried garlic. DEEEELISH i tell yoU!  

will be back for sure. must bring DH :)
author: joyce l.

description: This place is delicious! There spicy garlic ramen rivals Katana-ya in terms of flavor and noodles. The service is better and there is never a wait. Easily the best ramen in SF after Katana (and I've made the rounds). If you're from LA, this gets close to the great ramen you're used to and is a close second best in terms of what SF has to offer, but overall the best SF ramen experience.
author: Alexi R.

description: I used to crave this everyday when they first opened but the quality has been getting worse over the years.
author: TONY C.

description:
Yelp led us to this restaurant, and it had mostly positive reviews so we went a little out of our way to get out ramen fix with some moderate to high expectations.

The place was crowded and we had to wait about 15 minutes for seating but that's the price of eating at popular places I guess. More positive reviews lead to more customers and it can become a vicious cycle where a place can get hyped and overrated quickly---BUT I digress and that's not the case here... 3.5 stars seems about right to me. 

Service was good and the ramen arrived fairly quickly. I scarfed down my spicy garlic tonkatsu in no time but my wife couldn't finish her miso ramen so I ate the rest of her bowl as well. Usually we'd just order one bowl of ramen and share it but we were both especially hungry and wanted to try different flavors this time. 

I think I liked mine better than the miso, but perhaps the subtle miso flavor was no match for the spicy garlic flavor that was still fresh on my tongue. Both were pretty good though.

The restaurant is in an area with a lot of other restaurants and also some dessert places if you're still craving for more after you eat here.
author: Captain Z.

description:
I LOVE RAMEN!
as Naruto would yell excitedly "RAHMENG!"

I had no idea there was a ramen house a few blocks away from my house. Thx to yelp I found Sawaii with my gf, then pranced in excitedly.
I ordered the Miso pork ramen, which during lunch special came with a spicy tuna roll. My gf's chicken karage came with california rolls.
Nice Deal!

After picking up my bowl and slurping down the rest of the soup, which I usually never do. I knew right away I couldn't wait to return. Plus the server was very nice. He made sure we knew about their specials!

I will have my face diving  in their bowls here again very soon!
author: Tip S.

description: This has become my regular go-to place for my ramen cravings, and it has never disappointed!
author: Alison C.

description: I got the Spicy Tonkatsu ramen with extra noodles, egg, and pork belly.  The soup was full and flavorful, and with just enough spiciness (I got regular).  Great meal on a cool evening!
author: Harold S.

description: I've been tempted to try new ramen places...but somehow always end back here.  Noodles are chewy, broth is flavorful, and lots of toppings.  The ramen combo is worth it since it is almost enough food for 2.
author: Cin T.

description: solid enough. both tonkotsu and spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen are tasty, especially the latter, flavorful and not salty and too fatty. but noodles aren't al dente and chasu is too thin. sushi isn't bad but the rice could be better. service is efficient and friendly and the overall ambience is inviting. they deliver for the price.
author: Alex B.

description: I love their spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen. The chasu pork melts in your mouth and the broth delivers on the spice. I've ordered their bacon wrapped mochi, but it's a one note dish because the mochi and bacon had a similar chewy texture. It would been better if the bacon was crispy. The place gets busy after 7 p.m..
author: CQ N.

description:
Had been curious about this place since it opened a few months back. Went looking for it after I dumped off a prescription @ Walgreen's two blocks away. I was greeted nicely upon entering. There were several tables filled with customers, and most of the clientele were Asian, which always makes me confident that it's gonna be good.

I ordered the Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen with pork, though I thought about getting one of the specials. Pretty good deal on any type of Ramen + six pieces of Donburi for less than ten dollars. Sounded like too much to eat right then though, so I went for the Tonkatsu.

What arrived was nicely spicy (asked for middle-of-the-road spicy instead of super spicy). This is not a place that dumbs down their spiciness for pale whiteys like me. :-)  So, they get points on the spicy scale. Had a good amount of stuff swimming around in the broth, and it was a good size bowl. Not big enough to swim in (sometimes they just look daunting), but definitely enough for a meal.

I'll be going back. Very good food @ reasonable prices, friendly service and in my neighborhood!

Score.

[Edit: I've been back twice since. This place is consistently good, both with appetizers and with the ramen. Yahoo!]
author: Steve R.

description: Decided to try this place of the first time and was disappointed. I wouldn't put this one on my top 10 ramen places. Prices are to the moon!  Noodles didn't taste fresh and the miso broth was just ok!
author: King L.

description: I crave noodles all the time and I needed a quick fix.  Since its close to mi casa I decided to come here.  I ordered the Tonkatsu Spicy Garlic Ramen added pork belly, corn, and egg.  I have to say, it was GOOD!  The broth is very tasty and I love that they have whole fried garlic in it and it wasn't extremely mouth-burning spicy, but just enough.  The cha siu that comes with it was on the salty side.  The pork belly was tender and tasty, must add!  Was not a fan of their egg.  Usually its hard boiled, but theirs was soft boiled and super runny.  Plus for some reason the yolk was extremely salty.  Overall, I would definitely go back.
author: Gina S.

description:
They deserve higher rating!
A really good Ramen place for small company.

I love their ramen and food! best texture, best flavor and best portion. I ordered the spicy garlic pork ramen and the grilled fish. Both are great!!! The fish was hot and crispy, the the flavor was just right!
Will definitely come again! Strongly recommend Ramen fan to come try!
author: Christy Y.

description: Passable ramen, I had the spicy tonkatsu with the unagi rice bowl combo.  The combos are the greatest part of this place - not too pricy and good selection on rice bowls.  The ramen itself is not bad, but not the greatest ever.  I'd come here if I was in the area but won't go out of my way to come here.  No wait, of course.
author: Jeffrey Y.

description:
I was looking for a new ramen place in sf and luckily stumbled into this one driving back from the beach. I am a big noodle soup fan and love ramen and this place in my opinion is the best in the city. The tonkotsu broth is amazing the noodles cooked to perfection and the pork so buttery good.
I also highly recommend the appetizers, I have not had one that is not delicious. The grilled salmon collars are a must as is the adashi tofu. I have not tried the sushi but what I've seen looks great.
Lastly the service is warm and attentive.
If you love ramen go go go
author: Peter M.

description: Its pretty good. Nothing special. If I'm craving ramen, I will go here, since its walking distance from my house.
author: L. B.

description: Came in Saturday for lunch and was seated right away.  My friend and I each got a bowl of ramen, I got the Spicy Garlic, and shared a karaage.  The chicken was very delicious, and I loved the dipping sauce it came with.  My Spicy Garlic ramen was a lot spicier than I expected, especially since I had ordered mild.  The bowl was smaller than most other ramen places I've been to, but I prefer this because then I actually had a chance of finishing it.  I thought the broth was oilier than other shops, so if you have a sensitive stomach beware! The large pieces of pork belly in my ramen were a very nice touch.
author: Naomi Y.

description:
great place to get ramen in the city.  the sushi is alright, but we go for the ramen and the  fried soft shell crab salad.

we also like that it's open at 11am which allows the wifey and i to grab a bite before i start work at noon :)
author: Radbert C.

description:
I have to be honest - I don't come for the ramen - I come for the sushi! And it's not just any sushi - it's Yo's sushi :-)

If you never had the pleasure of going to the originals yo's in the mission - then Sawaii is as close as you can get since Yo closed shop to return to the easy life of being a sushi chef instead of the stress of running his own business...

So while I'm sure the ramen is good - I come for Yo - and the best sushi around - and yes I've been to all those other sushi places - and there is nothing like a Yo's special! Plus the Sawaii folks are super nice & prices are good & parking is easy. What more do you need?

I'm going back right now - writing this review is making me hungry!
author: P J.

description: I enjoy the ramen and the chirashi very much.  Staff are really nice and its just good, japanese comfort food!  Prices are good for a large bowl of ramen, my faves are the tonkotsu (the broth is milky and rich, pork is super thin and buttery) and my new fave is the "mala"...tasty!  Menu says its spicy, but you can control that. Don't let the red broth scare you...having the soft boiled egg and chicken katsu adds wonderful textures.  I love ramen and they have very good noodles, slightly chewy, somwehat salty but not overpowering.  Sushi is also very good, seafood is fresh.   Yum!
author: T G.

description: I decided to go here with my family, and tbh, I was a bit disappointed. I ordered the regular Tonkotsu ramen, my dad ordered the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen, and my sister and mom ordered the Salt Ramen. The salt and regular tonkotsu ramen were bland. No matter how much pepper or chili powder I threw in that soup, it still lacked flavor. The Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen wasn't that great either. It smelled good, but the taste wasn't that great. Service was fast, but the employees were not that friendly, which is why I'd give this place 2 stars. The only great part is that it's near Tea Way.
author: Mira Y.

description:
First visit to Saiwaii Ramen was very satisfying; the tonkatsu ramen broth is flavorful and the noodles are toothsome.  This was the Lunch Special for $9.95 and included 6 pcs of spicy tuna roll - a Good Deal.  The other Lunch special was 4 pcs of California Roll with Chicken Karaage - a generous portion and crisply prepared - $6.95 with miso soup and salad.
We'll return to order sushi and more - and will upgrade the rating to 4 stars with the next visit - without a doubt.

note:  Friday lunch is a busy time!
author: Geri S.

description:
3.5 stars - we called 20 minutes away to make sure we'll get a table.  No problem, more than half of the place was empty - we were a bit concerned...but the restaurant filled up while we were there...there is a list at the entrance.

Instead of just having ramen, we decided to try other items.  What we had:

ankimo - $6.25 - too dense and just a bit fishy taste, too much ponzu sauce, a little salty
seaweed salad - $3.75 - a little salty, missing the nice sesame flavor
chicken heart skewer - $3.50 - a little bland, should have squeezed a bit of lemon on top like hubby did 
grilled whole squid - $5.75 - this was my favorite apps - good flavor and tender, served with a bit of chopped ginger 
spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen, extra spicy - $9.95 - few slices of pork, bamboo shoots, seaweed, wood ear fungus, group pork, a bit of scallion - not bad, the broth has a bit of heat but temp wasn't piping hot, just warm, very disappointing.  the ramen itself is a bit different
aji - spanish mackerel - $4.95 
albacore - shiro maguro - $3.75 
sake - salmon $3.75 
hamachi - $3.75 
fish very good, melts in mouth but rice not that good
low sodium soy sauce, not thin and light as expected but opposite - thick and dark 
tea is tasteless

TV plays Japanese cartoon but background music is current pop.
author: Gloria H.

description: This is my one of my favorite places in the sunset. Great sushi and ramen.  It is a small place and there is no where to wait inside, so be prepared to wait in the cold if it's a busy night.
author: M T.

description: 3.5 if it was possible. Got the tonkatsu ramen and croquette. Ramen was pretty good but wish there was more noodles in it. Other people's looks like there was more in theirs. Croquette was good too. my friend got the spicy mala- mild, however it was a lot spicer than the last time she got it (for something that is mild)
author: serene h.

description: As recommend by others, I went with spicy tonkotsu ramen with pork belly extra. It was delicious but personally I still prefer Katanaya's ramen. The service is slow. My bill came and yup, it's more pricy than Katanaya's. I didn't expect it because of the location but anyhow, good food if you're craving for ramen in Sunset area.
author: Cliff T.

description: Mmmmmmmm.  The spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen rocked.  Super rich, spicy and flavorful broth.  Full of yummy veggies, crunchy garlic chips, and some pretty decent slices of pork.  Warm, spicy, rich goodness.  This will be my new go-to on chilly SF days when I'm craving a bowl of noodle soup to warm me up.
author: Kate S.

description: This place is off the hook.  I ordered the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu ramen and it was sooooooooooooo delicious.  I ordered extra Chau Sui but I think next time I will get the pork belly.  I think this place is the bees knees.  I am pretty picky about my ramen and this place lived up to my standards.  The wait staff is a little on the serious side, but I can appreciate that because they are serious about their food.  I cannot understand what the gentleman says when you walk in the door, I think he is speaking Japanese but I can't tell.  Oh well.  I love this place and I do not love too many things, as I have said before.
author: Mar M.

description:
spicy garlic miso ramen, make it as spicy as you dare. throw in an egg, and get some chicken karaage on the side; solid meal. i've been here a couple of times, and i've requested mega-spicy on both occassions. alas, never spicy enough. but huzzah for the pepper powder on the table. i just load it up and sweat it out, like a real woman would.

i've also had the chicken gizzards, which were just alright, and this shmancy fatty 8-piece roll with shrimp tempura, avocado, salmon (i think), this and that and this and that, all topped with a heaping amount of spicy tuna. this was an absolute beaut. i've eaten my fair share of sushi rolls in life, and this was one fine-lookin' roll which tasted mighty tasty to boot. my dinner compatriot got a case of the gout after consuming this roll. all that derricious tuna. worth it, though.

can't sing no praises for the curry chicken don, though. i've never seen such a measly serving of curry in my life. i don't expect my bowl to be flooded, but at least let half the serving of rice be comfortably soaked in curry. so much plain, dry, white rice was left sad and ignored.

i had food envy sniffing the mushroom appetizer that came waltzing out to the table next to mine. i want.
author: Eliza D.

description: The ramen here is awesome!  It's a tiny ramen place with a few tables but with good ambience.  A friend took me here for my birthday and felt in love with my spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen.  Also had the dragon roll and a bottle of sake.  There was a little wait for 20 minutes on a Sunday night.  I would come back again to satisfy my ramen craving.
author: J M.

description:
I love this place!  All those anime noodle shops I always see and this is what imagined it to be.  This is the way I always wanted ramen to taste! 

It's all about the Tonkasu Ramen with Pork Belly.  It came in piping hot with probably one of the most flavorful broths I've ever had.  Even after I was full I found myself constantly reaching for just one more taste.  All the ingredients worked well to compliment each other.  I added on the pork cheeks and it was well worth it.  

As great as the ramen was, the service was even better.  Everyone was so welcoming and attentive.  You can tell they really care, which gives this place such a warm atmosphere.  I can't wait to go back to this place when it's pouring rain outside!
author: Ben M.

description: This is my go-to place for ramen in San Francisco. I normally order the Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen and the bf loves the Spicy Garlic Miso w/ an order of the pork belly. The broth is flavorful without being salty. The spice is just enough to give it a kick but not too much that every mouthful makes your nose run.
author: Judy G.

description: Love the Marla ramen more than the garlic tonkatsu ramen. Sometime the place is crowded and have long line, on the weekend . So make sure to come early or make reservation.
author: Jacky L.

description: While my friend was driving to Sawaii I was on Yelp looking at the pictures, drooling, but sadly I wasn't very satisfied after the garlic tonkatsu ramen that looked so damn good online. Haha. It smelled lovely, but was definitely lacking on flavor. The label is definitely deceiving. It just needed more BAM. my girlfriend and I also ordered sushi that I also was not a fan of. It tasted okay, but sadly, after finishing dinner we were looking at Loi's next door thinking "damn, we shoulda went there". Oh wells! Worth a try, but dunno if its worth a second try.
author: Jackie M.

description:
the spicy garlic tonkatsu broth was very flavorful and the noodles were cooked perfectly, but spicy wasn't spicy at all and the added pork belly was a disappointment to me. i love pork belly, but i did not like the sweet and salty flavor this particular pork belly had. i thought it was too much and didnt compliment the broth at all. i had read that the pork belly was very soft, but the only soft part of it was the FAT. the rest of the meat was rough and hard to eat.

this place is known for their ramen but we tried out a few of their appetizers. the seaweed salad was whatevers, taste like any other seaweed salad. the texture of the grilled squid was okay, but it was bland. i also tried monkfish liver sashimi for the first time. reminded me of liver mousse even though it was "sashimi" the flavor wasn't bad but not something i would order again anywhere

the biggest disappointment of the night was the tuna poke (and also the most expensive thing as well) i LOVE tuna poke but this one was just disgusting. the tuna "poke" was nothing but cubes of tuna with a weird spicy soy sauce with regular onions that completely masked the flavor of tuna so all you really taste was raw onions. and the choice of mixed greens with this poke were all bitter leaves. 

the warm savory broth and noodles were really good to have on a cold rainy day, but its pricey and i dont think a bowl of noodles is worth $10+ for something that taste like something i can make at home with a pot of boiling water.
author: Katherine C.

description: Saiwaii, I shall miss you.  Though expensive, you were my Middle Sunset comfort food for over a year in SF, and your many rich broths, from fatty tonkatsu (pork base) to fermentastic shoyu (miso base), warded off innumerable influenzas, colds, and tuberculins.  Your generous toppings, including slabs of pork and flavourful eggs and mushrooms, delighted my palate.  You were, at times, drafty, and almost always busy, and your sushi was not very good, but I did, and will, forgive you those few small flaws.  I have added you to the long list of the many culinary things I will continue to miss about SF.
author: Tee Jay R.

description: This place makes a good bowl of ramen. On a cold day this really hits the spot. You will need to get there early or you will not find parking and the line to eat can get long.  I was not a big fan of their gyoza, but the sushi there is not bad. I would give recommend this place if you were in the area or just looking for a nice warm bowl of noodles.
author: Marty M.

description: Maybe it was my high expectations on their ramen because i'm a fan of authenticity and good friendly service. 1 out of two isnt bad i guess. Long story short, i can go to a different place for better ramen and be left more satisfied then i was with this one. or maybe I just caught them on a bad night, but it's always good to try it just for the experience.
author: Sandra T.

description: Not bad. Definitely a good spot to get a ramen fix. I never felt rushed when giving my order so I must be lucky... seeing that some of the other reviews are criticizing the staff. Sometimes the wait can be super long though.
author: Allan T.

description: Sometimes I get a craving for ramen and am too lazy to drive down to San Mateo for Ramen Dojo or Santa Ramen.. Yelp to the rescue!  Saiwaii serves above average ramen at reasonable prices.  I recommend the garlic miso with chicken kaarage.  Service was friendly.  Get there on the earlier side as the place was packed by 6:15 on a Sunday.
author: Toby C.

description: I had never had real ramen before, so my cousin and I decided to give this place a go since it was five minutes from the house. IT WAS AMAZING!! I loved the flavor, and the presentation was adorable. When we arrived the place was pretty packed, but we only waited 5 minutes to be seated! :3
author: Leann C.

description:
What happened?? This joint was not bad when it opened not so long ago. Haven't been back in probably 1/2 yr or more and didn't realize how much they skimp on their ramen. We were seated quickly and given our beverages but when we were ready to order the waiter said he would come back. The sushi chef I assumed saw that we were ready and had to come out himself to take our order. I agree with the other post that their waiters needs to multi-task a little better. After waiting 15-20 minutes for our order (the place was only half full and the waiter came to refill our teacup about half a dozen times) we finally were able to eat. I had their tonkatsu ramen and there was literally only 4 side ingredients as I looked disappointingly down at my bowl. A few pieces of bamboo shoots, shredded green onions, seaweed, fungus & 2 pieces of paper thin sliced pork (it almost gave me a paper cut!) with one having 3/4 of fat on it, so it was more like 1 1/2 piece. I swear they used to give at least 3 decent sized pieces. Now you may say that's b/c I didn't order any toppings but there are plenty of other places that comes with more in a standard bowl of ramen, half an egg for example but here they charge $1 (I'm not even sure if you get the whole egg). 
The pork broth was good and creamy although a bit salty.
All in all the amount of food is not worth the price, I rather head over to Ramen Doraku on Taraval if I'm craving ramen in the sunset.
author: Bunnie L.

description: Pork ramen was good. Not as good as japan town, and I hoped to see a little more ramen. Good service and ambiance.
author: Daniel W.

description: The food and service here is amazing.   I've had the famous spicy tonkatsu ramen and the spicy crab.  If everything else on the menu is as good as what I've had, this will be the only ramen spot I will be coming to.    What I am very happy about is the spicy tuna don!   I haven't found a place that has done this right in 6 years.   I had it tonight and was not disappointed at all!  This place is a must!  The agedashi tofu is also the best so far in many of the Japanese restaurants that I've tried, including ones that are owned by Japanese owners!
author: Ken C.

description: A nice little spot on Irving st for those of you that are looking for a quick ramen fix. I ordered their spicy garlic miso. I definitely agree with some of the reviews that people made about this place, the ramen is not bad at all at a reasonable price. If you're not looking to drive out of the city for good ramen.. i would definitely come here to get my ramen fix, i was overall pretty satisfy with the ramen and service, definitely will be a returning customer.
author: Jeff C.

description: I want to like this place, but I don't know. Something is missing from their ramen. It's close to right, but it's not. The broth looks all full of porky-gobs- of-fat flavor, but it's not. I guess that's what happens when Chinese people run a Japanese restaurant. Something is always amiss. The price is moderate, not cheap, not super expensive. The lunch special is a decent deal, you get a california 4 piece roll with miso soup (i think it's just from a mix), and a rice plate with some kind of meat for 6.95. And there's food network playing on the flat screen. But yeah, the chinese feel of the place kind of takes it down a notch, and they don't make the soft-boiled egg right. don't pay extra for egg, not worth it. OH, and spicy is really spicy, too spicy for me, at least.  maybe if the price of their ramen was less a 1$, i'd think it was more worth it? Not sure.
author: Verna L.

description: Boring ramen with an even more boring rice bowls. This spot must be cursed. I hated when that fried chicken place was at this spot and now replaced by a ramen store it's still bad.
author: Terry S.

description: Came here last week with a friend and enjoyed my ramen.  We went OVER the top with what we ordered (3 apps and a ramen bowl each), but it was worth it.  I liked the fried chicken in my ramen and I enjoyed tasting my friend's pork belly.  The broth itself was OK and the noodles were so plentiful that I felt I barely made a dent in it.  We also ordered a pitcher of beer which was nice, except that the pitcher spout sucked so badly that it would always poor as foam.  We had to get our pour to an exact science to have non-foam beer.  I'll try this place again if I'm around.
author: Noneya B.

description: Week 2,  Saiwaii seems to have worked out previous patron's issues.  Tonkasu ramen was favored nicely and well balanced with the pork.  We had the dragon roll, some may think pricey but it is a nice portion.  Our party of 4 had no complaints and had similar excellent experiences.  We will definitely be back.  Bottom line,Saiwaii is like Hotei on 9th avenue without the attitude.
author: gavin c.

description:
$3 add-on the PORKBELLY!  3 pieces~
the service is fast and attentive.

just recently though, kind of weird...they used to put the pork belly in the soup... Now, i get the soup, a few minutes later i THEN get the pork belly cold and separate... put it in my damn SOUP!...

avoid the rolls and sushi stuff... u'll be left with a bit of disappointment. then again, who orders eggrolls at taco bell?! :)
stick with the Ramen at this place and just add on a crapload of stuff.
the EGG is good too, still raw on the inside, cooked ont he outside
author: Miss J.

description: I had a late dinner here last month. My friend suggested that we go here after looking up some ramen places on Yelp. We got here around 9:30pm on a Friday and the place was still bustling with people. Be warned that it is a small restaurant, so be ready to wait, especially if you have a big group and arrive during peak hours. After waiting for about 15 minutes for a table to open up, we finally sat down and ordered. I chose to try their soy ramen and added an egg to it. When it arrived at the table, it was steaming and nice and hot. I quickly dug into it and finished it pretty quick. It was very tasty and the ingredients were fresh. Nothing like a bowl of hot ramen to warm me up during one of these colder September evenings. Hoping to return soon for my next serving of ramen! Nom!
author: Frances V.

description: Stopped by for a quick bite.  Didn't want to venture too far outside of the neighborhood.  Big disappointment.  Should have driven to J-town or downtown for ramen.  Ramen broth was bland and bbq pork was tough and chewy.  Fried chicken was mostly breading and fat.
author: Eric C.

description: Food is pretty good. I didn't like the gyoza we ordered. Portion size is small. Service is okay. We had to ask 3 times for water, finally we just got up and got it ourselves. Don't think I will go back.
author: Jessica M.

description:
We wanted noodles and finally decided to actually explore our side of town instead of instinctively hoping in the car and taking off to Japantown or Chinatown - after all Irving Street is very well populated by noodle houses! Thanks to yelp we chose Saiwaii and boy are we glad we did! 
It's become a solid go to in our list of "what's for dinner" discussions and we've been four times in three months. 
The restaurant is on the small side but we've only had to wait once and they kept us up to date on the timing, apologize repeatedly for the wait and gave us a yummy fried squid appetizer on the house. I guess we've been there enough and we...ok, I...am distinctive enough (tall, Caucasian female) that they remember us every time and give us "our" table. 
The menu is not huge and we've tried a lot of it, one night we made dinner out of only appetizers and rolls. The stand outs for us are the Spicy Garlic Miso, Chicken Broth Ramen, Kalbi (2 orders every time!), Goma ae, and virtually anything on the Specials Board (hello grilled hamachi collar!). 
They are a bit pricey, hence the 4-stars, and I was surprised at the "appetizer and roll dinner" ($80 for 3 people, including 2 small sake) cost but we've always felt it was a good value, just not one we can return to as often as we may like. 
OH - selling point for the husband and son, they have two large TVs and if there is an important sporting broadcast it's on at least one set, the other is usually tuned to the Food Channel.
author: Us And J.

description:
This review is mainly for my love of the spicy garlic tonkatsu. That alone gives it a place in my heart, and it was the first and now only thing I order.  

I go for extra spicy since regular spicy isn't hot enough for me, and yet, I can still taste everything. The broth is rich and flavorful. Even though it's spicy, the creaminess of the pork bone is still there; it's stronger than other places I've tried (which I like), but not overly salty. I've had friends try the other ramens, and they all liked the flavor of their broths. It has a decent amount of toppings: seaweed, bamboo, wood fungus, roasted garlic (but only one or two pieces; boo) ground pork, chashu and topped with shredded green onion and chilis (the thin red strings). The chashu is okay, but then I've never been to a place that had spectacular chashu, either. I'm no expert on what the "perfect" ramen noodles is supposed to be; all I know is I like how they do them. Nice and chewy, not too firm, springy, and they absorb the flavor in the broth well.

I have tried the pork belly, and it is as good as they say. Tender, melt-in-your-mouthy with a stewed sweetness. When I'm feeling decadent, I'll get it since the ramen itself is already very filling and delicious, and that just puts it over the top.

They have a nice lunch special where for only $2 more, you get a sushi roll (spicy tuna or CA w/ real crab). If you bring a small child with you, that will usually take care of them. I've only tried a few of their appetizers, and they were only so-so. However, I've seen their hamachi and salmon kamas, and everyone who I saw eating it seemed to like it. They offered uni nigiri for a while, and the one I had was very fresh and delicious. They have a long list of appetizers (many of which I want to sample) and sushi available, as well as dons, if you go with a group and are not feeling the ramen (for which you should be ashamed).

Now for the place itself: it's cozy, without being overly small, but you will find yourself sometimes elbow-to-elbow with the table next to you. Dark wood tables and chairs with 2 flatscreens on both ends (it varies what they have playing: sports, Food Network, or movies). There's a specials menu hanging over the sushi bar that also lists the beer and sake selections, but it can be hard to read sometimes. The service is very friendly and attentive. Every server I had was always nice and good about checking in. They are also fast; it always feels like I had only just ordered when they bring out my ramen piping hot, even on busy nights. They have the waiting list whiteboard, but even then, they move pretty quickly. My only real complaint is that the door doesn't close automatically. When you sit anywhere near the door, it can get cold when it opens, but it's worse when someone walks in or steps out and leaves it open.

As long as this place stays open and keeps making the spicy garlic tonkatsu, they will have my business.
author: Myrna A.

description: Not a fan at all of this. Their ramen is too oily and lacks anything that makes it stand out. Go to Izakaya Sozai.
author: Andrew H.

description: I am very surprise that this place taste pretty good though, its not own by a japaneses. I order the mild spicy tonkotsu noodle soup pork base. I didnt give it 5 star because I still feel Kagoo in san jose, ca is still number one.
author: Aniko N.

description: I came here with a friend of mine and we really enjoyed the spicy garlic tonkatsu.  It had a very distinct flavor, but the spicier flavors weren't spicy.  Being half Korean I typically never find any Japanese food spicy, but it was very very very delicious!! Especially with an egg in the ramen, you must have a side of the stuffed mushrooms.  It was delicious and the service was so friendly.  No one rushes you in and out and they constantly filled our waters even though people were waiting in line and the waitresses acted as the bus boys too.  Definitely going here again sometime soon! =)
author: John H.

description: I'm not a ramen aficionado, but I do eat it a hell of a lot and one of my go to places is Saiwaii. They are a great place to grab a cheap yummy meal without lines, they are an easy place to take a baby, and most importantly their ramen is delicious! They have a good variety of soups and you can add different toppings to any ramen you choose, their tonkotsu broth is addictive and the texture of their noodles is spot on. Yummy!!
author: Sara W.

description:
nice little ramen place. pretty consistent and the cashu is flavorful. they need to fix the door though.

a good spot for a quick lunch.
author: A L.

description: love the spicy tonkatsu ramen.. i tried the others and they're all good but spicy tonkotsu is my fav.. been coming here for years.. kid friendly just don't bring a stroller 'cause it aint gonna fit.. good broth.. spicy when you want it.. just right when you don't... super friendly and attentive staff.. can't ask for more... except for a bigger place? when this place is busy wait times can get a bit long..
author: G G.

description: I actually really liked the ramen here!! Better than ALL the ramen places I have tried in S.F (izakaya, halu, oyaji, katanaya, suzu noodle, genki, etc) What I really liked about my bowl of spicy garlic miso was that the flavor was very rich but not salty at all! I really really liked it and will definitely be back. The flavor might be bland to some, but perfect for me!
author: A L.

description: I'm always looking for good ramen joint in sf.  My friend suggested this spot, so I decided to give it a try.  I had the spicy garlic miso w/ pork belly.  It was okay.  The broth didn't have much flavor.  I also ordered the salmon skin salad and that was good!
author: Ren A.

description:
Passed by this place thousands of times but never had the occasion to try it. Finally did this week for lunch.
Pros:
(1) Stuck to their lunch special: Ramen/sushi combination.
Had the tonkatsu spicy miso ramen. Quite pleased: Stock comparable to L.A. ramen shops (the only standard I would abide by, outside of Japan). Very tasty pork belly (extra $2); portion size, decent.
(2) Ordered California roll and spicy tuna roll : Pleased as well.
(3) Service: swift and attentive.

Cons:
(1) Pork Belly slices: only 2 and were paper thin. It does not compare to pictures posted here. Whatever happened? The slices were so paper thin.... still very tasty. I may have to bring my own pork belly next time.

On the whole very satisfied.  And... many daily sushi and other specials on the board.
author: eh w.

description:
This was my first experience of a "Ramen House", and it was AWESOME! I had the ramen bowl with duck ( and lots of other yummy stuff). Sorry, I cannot remember the exact name of the dish. I was so pleased with the service as well.
There was only one delay, and that was the Octopus Sashimi appetizer I ordered was forgotten... the place was packed and I was very content with what I was relishing in already. Then the waitress and I made eye contact and she immediately realized the oversight. I received the sashimi in just a few minutes and it was delicious. Then, without having said a word, The Chef was at my table with a complementary appetizer, smiling, he said that he would tell me what it was after I tried it. 
The secret ingredient sashimi was wonderful - and unlike anything I have ever tasted. I did share it with the other 3 in my party. I made sure to thank the Chef personally and ask him what it was that he gave me. He asked if I liked it and I told him I can't wait to try it again, with an even bigger smile he told me that it was "Sea Hare"!  
I cannot wait to return for more delightful food and perhaps a few more surprises!
author: Robert H.

description: Firm noodles overall with good chewyness and mouth feel.  Miso broth was ok but needed salt.  Tonkatsu broth was better but also tasted like it needed salt.  Was missing the usual half boiled egg (my favorite part!) in both ramens.  Service was a bit slow but it's only the second day so hoping everything gets better in a few weeks.  Not as tasty as Muru Ich or Santa Ramen but good for a quick fix and hopefully it'll get better as they smooth out  the kinks.
author: G P.

description: OMG Ramen!!! Saiwaii is one of the jewels in our neighborhood.  Their pork tonkatsu ramen is everything you would when in ramen.  Don't forget to ask for an egg in your ramen.  It is a softboiled egg that is the most amazing thing you will ever have.  Yum yum yum.
author: Vanessa R.

description: The ramen here is really good, if you like ramen. Get it with an egg in it, its delicious. I wouldn't get the pork belly, as it was fatty and a little tough, but overall the ramen is delicious. The sushi is really good, as is the avocado tuna salad. Best of all, this establishment is reasonably priced.
author: claire l.

description:
went back for their spicy garlic miso pork ramen - YUM ME!

the roll was the one with the pumpkin - kabocha? Mmmm...

Must. Go. Back. Again. Soon.
author: Cat T.

description:
YES! I tried so many different ramen place (pretty much all ramen place in the peninsula side) and i finally have a favorite. As ramen goes, you might find better if you feel like driving down to Saratoga, Palo Alto or San Mateo, but as the city goes this place is the best to me! I used to go to katana ya for lunch, the ramen is good, but the area sucks, long waiting times and the place feels uncomfortable. Suzu has good ramen too, but the waiting time is always a bummer. Tanpopo also has good ramen, but in never tried during lunch or dinner time so i cannot say anything about waiting times, but it is good. Sapporo also has good ramen, but i like all the new ramen places spawning in the area. Genki ramen.... well i just don;t like their ramen. But let's talk saiwaii otherwise i will start listing all ramen places in the area. I got Tonkotsu ramen with extra pork belly cubes. It was delicious. The broth was delicious, flavorful and the toppings were great too, including the pork and the pork belly. I got an appetizer of grilled squid legs, age dashi and my wife got some sushi that she liked a lot. The service was excellent as well.  

I really couldn't be happier with sawaii ramen, which i would put at the same level as the close by izakaya sozai. izakaya sozai offers other stuff as well and it is a great restaurant, but i usually want only ramen, and this is the place. Cozy, clean, good food and service and not packed full of people. 

I bet as it gets known it might end up with long lines, so i will be going there as much as i can before he gets too popular.
author: davide c.

description:
The ramen here is okay. We really come here because of its location, and because my kids loves this place. Certainly not the best, but I've had worse as well. I do wish that some of the extras (like egg) that can be added at an additional cost came standard.

The service is mixed. They are friendly and nice, but not necessarily on top of things. At one of our visits, we ordered the grilled squid legs, and out came the tempura squid legs, so we told the waitress that we wanted the grilled version, and next thing we know, we got the grilled squid with no legs! We gave up after that. Hopefully this is just a one time thing... I mean, those were all items on the menu/specials, so they should get it right. If the waiters/waitresses can't handle it, then don't put so many simliar items on the menu!
author: Chris Y.

description:
When the fog rolls in, what better place to warm up than some hot ramen noodles. Great place to get ramen in the sunset district. Owners are very friendly.

I had the miso ramen and the katsu-don because the food was so good. Just could not stop eating. I will definitely return to this place because of the convenient location and excellent food.
author: Jason E.

description:
I came here on a Tuesday night a couple of weeks ago around 8:45pm and the place was completely full!  Always a good sign.  Once I walked in, I was instantly drawn to the cozy understated dark wood decor and the savory aromas of ramen broth and other home-style goodies.  Bonus points for a clean and welcoming atmosphere.  Service was super friendly as well.  Now, onto the food...

Our party went all out and ordered like starving school children.  We started off with the house salad, which quite possibly has the best Japanese salad dressing ever...perfectly sweet and vinegary with fresh veggies and some tobiko to boot.  Next came the luscious bowls of ramen.  I am not a miso broth fan when it comes to ramen, so I can't comment too much on that one, but my Tonkatsu Ramen was spot on.  I took one sip and tasted the pork bone right away.   It was creamy and had just the right amount of salt.  Noodles were al dente and abundant, and the kurikage, seaweed, and pork toppings were the right balance for my ramen bowl. The buta kakuni side dish is a must-have too.  Have it on the side with your ramen and you'll be one happy camper.  (Love love LOVE the way fatty pork melts in your mouth.)   Oh, did I mention I also added a Tekka Don to my ramen?  For an extra $4, it was a generous bowl of rice with 4 nice slices of tuna, which really put me over the edge, since I cleaned out my ramen bowl too.  I also had a chance to sample my friends' curry don and katsu don, which were equally pleasant.  But what will bring me back for sure are the tonkatsu ramen, fatty pork, and house salad!  I can't wait to go back and try the rest of their menu (they have some great looking izakaya items).
author: Kalista W.

description: I had the garlic tonkatsu and it was decent. Problem was the taste didn't noodle houses on Irving.leave my mouth for hours :/ The broth was ok, actually a much stronger garlic flavor than I expected. Also came with sliced pork which was fairly flavorless and dry. The noodles were all clumped together and a little too firm for my liking. All in all my experience was ok, but I just don't see myself coming back here given the amount of other noodle shops on Irving alone.
author: David D.

description: I really like Saiwaii.  The broth is on the thick side, but sometimes that's what you want.  The spicy garlic tonkotsu was delicious!!! I enjoyed every bite of it, and had to hold back from drinking the soup.  The location is very convenient for me as well, so will be coming back again and again and again...
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
I had the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen mild, which wasn't spicy at all, but supposedly the spicier flavors are REALLY spicy.  I typically prefer my broth a little richer, but it was still good and not too salty.  Would highly recommend adding egg and pork belly (though it's a lot of pork-- share a piece with a friend!)

For ramen in this area I still prefer Izakaya Sozai, but Sawaii still serves up a very hearty and satisfying bowl of ramen.
author: S L.

description:
excited for another ramen place, but it was just average broth.
tonkotsu broth misses the yumminess of orenchi, flavor too mild
rather go to izakaya sozai.  sf ramen doesn't live up to the peninsula choices.  also had some karaage (good), short ribs, gyoza.  ok.
of note, the ramen here gives you much more for the price.  more meat (thick slices), wavy noodle, also note it already has a half egg.  pricey to add pork belly at $3
author: Rob C.

description: I LOVE this place!  The spicy garlic tonkatsu soup base is my fave!  I love that they have more soup base selections than most other ramen places.  The noodles are a perfect consistency, and the portions are generous.  The owners and servers are all really friendly.  I also loved the soft shell crab appetizer- so yummy!  Definitely give this place a try if you're a ramen lover like me!  :)
author: Wendy H.

description:
came in just as they were closing for lunch. glad i did. i'm always hankering for some noodles in broth.

when it comes to ramen, i don't ask for much. shio, if you please. and how. i've had slightly more delicious ramen (setagaya and ippudo in nyc); however, this was solid and satisfying and the server was super friendly, nice and on-point.

next time i'm in town, i'll be back (said in the worst arnold impression you can imagine).
author: Mags L.

description:
I've tried Saiwaii twice in the past month. I'd have to say I didn't have to wait in a long line like I did at Santa Ramen. =)

I ordered the spicy garlic miso w/ chicken karage. Both times it was delicious and spicy enough or me. However, the broth is a little watery and the noodle was firm and a little long as another yelper pointed out. But overall, it was a good experience with good service.
author: Brian W.

description: Every time I past by this place at night , is always crowded and always want to try it. Finally my friend and I try this place for the first time. Waited for 20 minutes for a table. Place is really small and crowded everyone bumps in to everyone in there. But other than that food was good. There ramen was decent and tasteful. Decent amount of variety of food there's ramen, snacks and sushi rolls. Will come back here again!
author: Jaden L.

description: Solid Ramen, enjoyed the Tonkotsu and the Shoyu.  Great broth, noodle texture, pork was a bit chewy, probably would add Belly if I went again.  Only three stars because the atmosphere leaves much to be desired, very cold inside, large tv showing silent MSNBC.
author: M J.

description:
ehh.

thats all I have to say.

Had the tonkatsu and shoyu and the fried soft shell crab.

Soup is okay, but I've had better, cha su was cold until you immersed it into the soup so it wasn't too bad.  Although there was a lot of extra added bamboo shoots and "fungus", I felt as if I was chewing forever.

The crab was okay, flavor wasn't too bad but for the price it was not as big as I would want it.

overall. its okay, but I would rather somewhere else.
author: Steph Q.

description: Very friendly staff, and I loved the ramen here! I ordered the Spicy Garlic Miso Ramen and Chicken Kara-Age. Broth was really good and noodles were chewy and tasty. The Chicken Kara-Age was slightly overcooked and a little too fried for my taste though. Will come back!
author: D C.

description: The only good Ramen I've had in the Bay Area, although I haven't had it homemade or in Japan. This place makes a delicious broth and the noodles are perfect. I don't know why it's so hard to find good ramen. I guess it's hard to make. It tends to be way too salty or sweet and the noodles are always bad or just ok.
author: Ivan N.

description: I have been on a ramen rampage for the past year and since I've moved back to the bay area I've been in search for a ramen place as good as the ones in socal. So far, that hasn't been accomplished. I mean everything here is okay, but not spectacular. I did like the croquette which is a fried potato and meat ball. Don't get the curry don as a side order of the ramen because it's mostly rice and not that much curry sauce or anything else but a few carrots. The service was really quick and efficient.
author: Tossama C.

description: Came here for a late meal with a small group and was decently satisfied.   We ordered the original ramen noodles with Tonkatsu soup base, along with some Kar aga (sp?) fried chicken.  The portions are pretty large considering the price paid and the quality is very well made.  My trouble with the food is the soup base is so strong that I was not sure what else was in my bowl.  It's weird to be complaining about "too much" flavor, but it was getting very salty by the end of the bowl and made me ask for a refill on water.  Still this place is very decent for ramen, just not my top choice.
author: Roger T.

description: The best ramen in the city . I go there once a week the spicy garlic tonkotso is very tasty never feel thirsty after , also the pork belly is better than Santa ramen . They added a lots of special sushi roll " must try " the fish are so fresh and the price are reasonable . Last the service is excellent . I will recommend all my friends and family to Saiwaii
author: Andy L.

description:
Excellent, friendly wait staff. Certainly satisfied my ramen craving
Great combination of comfort food and food that might be new to the non-Japanese among us

A TV on either end of their long dining room made it hard to resist watching, (although sometimes that feels just fine)
author: D V.

description: I went here for the first time today.  I believe I ordered the Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen w/ the California Roll.  I found the ramen pretty good.  The soup was kind of spicy, but I finished it as well.  The California Roll didn't seem to be that impressive to me at all.  Prices seemed somewhat decent.  I wish that they'd give a bit more though.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Though I've never really been to a Ramen joint before, I came to Saiwaii with an open mind.  


Wow.


I had the Tonkatsu Ramen, and Curry Katsu-don.  The broth was so creamy and had a great taste to it.  The meat was fantastically cooked, tender, moist, mmm.  The Katsu Curry was really different to me, I am a huge fan of curry in general, and this dish was quite a great take.  I also had some tuna sashimi which was fresh and simple. 


The service was great and everyone was friendly and looked like they were having a good time.

Out of 5 Stars
Service : * * * * *
For the Price: * * * *
Quality: * * * * *
Time for Seating: * * * * * 
Environment / Comfort: * * * * *
author: Jesse D.

description: The spicy garlic miso w/ their EGG! wow, that egg is something else. It's yolky, runny and they marinate it or something that makes it tastes SO good! Love! Only drawback is that I think their ramen doesn't come standard w/ bamboo, seaweed, sprouts and corn. I think it just comes w/ corn and sprouts, but you might want to double check.
author: Nam D.

description: There are already so many reviews.  The overall 3.5 star rating on Yelp is pretty accurate for this ramen-ya.  Ordered the tonkotsu ramen, shoyu ramen, gyoza, curry donburi and chicken yakitori.  Ramens were ok - not bad but nothing great.  The tonkostu is way better than the shoyu - the chasu in it was ok, noodles were ok but slighty thicker noodles than I prefer.  That's the problem here - nothing is bad but nothing is great.  It's OK.  Gyoza were ok, yakitori had pretty good flavor but they overcook the chicken making it slightly chewy, which is not ok.  Curry donburi was ok - man, I'm done with this review. I can't write anything but "OK" about this place. I will add the service was very friendly and attentive. Liked it better than Katanaya though.  That place for whatever reason gets good reviews it don't deserve.
author: Grover G.

description: I would give this place 4 stars for Yo's sushi, but 3 overall. Yes, we ventured out all the way to the foggy outer sunset to visit Yo after he shut down Yo's Sushi Club. The sushi was great, although I miss my usual favorites - the chirashi and Yo's special roll. The ramen was also decent. I had the tonkatsu and the noodles were nice although the broth might not have had the depth of flavor that some other broths have. Overall, a good choice if i'm in the area,
author: Jennifer C.

description: there is crack in the spicy garlic tonkatsu broth i swear! i usually order regular spicy, which is plenty for the average joe. i ALWAYS finish my bowl of broth, like all of it. and what do i do next? move on to the bf's bowl of course! yes, i'm slightly addicted.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Went here for the second time today. This is probably one of the better places to go to get ramen in the sunset. I don't know if this place is consistent though. Today was better than the first time i went because it wasn't as spicy. But apparently this place is popular bc there is a wait after 7.
author: Tammy L.

description: I quite liked the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen with pork belly. The noodles are pleasantly chewy, if not plentiful. There is a generous amount of ground and sliced pork on top, along with the more "meh" toppings of wood ear fungus and bamboo shoots. I love how the pork belly is the perfect mix of sweet, salty, moist, and fatty. It's probably the best I've tried so far *u* However, the broth was probably the top reason I'll go back to Sawaii. The garlicky broth does not have the sharp assertive flavor of raw garlic, but rather the complex smoky-sweet flavor of roasted garlic.
author: Skye L.

description:
Gloria's review thoroughly breaks down the menu, soooo~one of those days where I'm really feeling the love ... JoJo in my office cooked up another batch of boiled peanuts that were exquisitely spiced, with just the right almost al dente texture and ... oh yeah, this is about Saiwaii.  So after a mission to assist one business friend by taking them to the office of another business friend who is also a dear friend that I had not seen in over a year;  I planned to see another friend, Yo of "Yo's Sushi Club" on Mission fame, who sold that place and now manages Saiwaii Ramen.  I should give them a 5 for attitude, because, with Yo there, you know they are sincerely concerned with your culinary enjoyment.  I was kind of preoccupied with some other business concerns while also catching up with "So what's up Yo?"  Lots.  Suffice to say, I had the chicken stock ramen with the honey marinated pork butt and yes it was good.  I commented to Yo that I really liked the setup, heavy Japanese woodiness, rectangular floor plan with booths, because, it seemed very Ramen "a pro pos."  Business associate had the tonkatsu ramen with a spicy tuna roll.  Service was attentive and I plan to further explore the menu at a later date.  You can't really go wrong with Yo on the premises.
I should go ahead and give them a 5 ... nah, I'm kind of stingy with 5's lately. 
I keep seeing that review on my right that mentions "...and the soup was pretty thick ..."  It's supposed to thick ... ! ... aka flavorful ... long day, felt the love though ... did my good deeds ... Saiwaii worked well into the day's overall sanguine, feeling the love-ness ... Japanese style!   
Solid 4, solid ramen, can't go wrong on that front.  They don't take shortcuts on food prep, quality ingredients and dedication to good product.  If you're thinking about Saiwaii Ramen and you read this far:  Go eat there.  You will enjoy it.
author: Terry A.

description: Awesome!  I've been looking for a good Ramen joint and this is definitely it.  I had the spicy garlic tonkatsu...hot and delicious!  Definitely recommended!
author: Alex S.

description:
Definitely enjoying this new Ramen trend that seems to be emerging.  Bringing me back to my roots as a middle schooler and preparing dinner for myself when my parents left me home.
This place has great options all around, with the Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu definitely recommended.  In addition, there is certainly nothing wrong with adding some pork belly to the mix.
Everything else on other people's tables always looks good as well.
We have been there twice already and will will surely be regulars in the future.
author: Leo S.

description: Just had ramen there for dinner. I had the tonkotso ramen (added an egg). If I had to use one word to sum it up it would be salty. They must have used a ton of salt or MSG to the point that I couldn't really taste any pork in the broth (maybe there was no pork). The egg was THE worst. It tasted like it was marinated in regular soy sauce. Yes. The marinade is supposed to contain soy sauce but not JUST soy sauce. If there were such a thing as solid soy sauce that must be what it would taste like.
author: Kelvin L.

description: I really like the ramen here. It's one of the better tasting ramen places in sf. Their broth is flavorful and yummy. This restaurant is yummy but their sushi isn't all that greatjust stick with the ramen!
author: TinNgai L.

description:
So close yet so far.  Saiwaii is so close being a solid four stars except for 2 seemingly minor but in reality major faults:

1.) The tonkotsu ramen didn't come out piping hot.  Minus one star.
2.) The shari of the nigiri was well-formed but used hard, stale rice.  Minus one star.

They both seem like minor things, right?  Nope.  Although easily correctable, each of these mistakes violated the cardinal rule of their respective food items.  

1.) Ramen is supposed to be so hot that you have to slurp it for it to cool down properly as it enters your mouth.  Because the tonkotsu ramen was not hot enough, an oily pork fat flavor became evident, a real turn-off that could have been easily avoided if the broth were hot enough.  Real shame because the chaashuu was of high quality and of good quantity, and the kitchen was generous with the kikurage, negi, and menma (which was high quality as it didn't have the rancid flavor typical of low grade or expired bamboo shoots).  The noodles were good quality, too -- good koshi without an overwhelming kansui odor and cooked just to al dente.  

2.) Some argue that the main attraction of nigiri zushi is the neta, and others argue that it's the shari -- I'm believe that it's a 50-50 split in importance, and the best nigiri comes from the synthesis of skillfully cut, fresh neta with a just dense enough, properly-seasoned shari composed of toothsome, high quality rice to form a good hitokuchi size to unlock the textural element of nigiri (the other element being taste, of course).  The itamae-san here was able to do all that with quality cuts of well-sliced fish for the neta and a shari that was the right size and density, but the rice was stale!!!  It was hard in such a way that indicated that it had spent too much time in a low-temperature area, a huge no-no!  No matter how well executed sushi is, once the rice gets hard from low temperature (a la refrigeration), the whole sushi is absolutely ruined.  If the the neta is on the cold side, I understand as it would be wise to err on the side of caution with raw fish, but to allow rice to harden due to low temperature is absolutely unacceptable.  Why do such a thing?!

When the waitress asked if everything was OK and I expressed these sentiments to her politely, she seemed a little put off by it.  Well, your loss I suppose.  I just hate to the boss's otherwise hard efforts go to waste for two very easily correctable things.  If these two mistakes could be rectified, I'd gladly give the place four stars and make it a regular destination.  What a shame...

P.S. TonkAtsu (fried, breaded porkchop) and tonkOtsu (pork bone) are two completely different things.  Make sure you know what you're getting into when you order and you won't be disappointed.
author: Ryan D.

description: This place is delicious. My friends visit from Santa Cruz just to have Saiwaii Ramen: they love the pork cubes and egg additions. I love the regular and spicy garlic chasu.
author: Erica W.

description: Had high hopes for Saiwaii - but alas, maybe they are still working out the kinks b/c they are new, but I was disappointed in the ramen - the noodles felt/tasted like instant ramen noodles you get in Top Ramen.  The space is clean and the staff is friendly, but they're not quite there yet with the food.
author: Ricky S.

description: What a great find on Irving!  I was in the mood for Ramen tonight.  The only other Ramen I've had was during lunch in San Mateo at Ramen Dojo, and that place sets a high benchmark for me.  Saiwaii Ramen comes really close. to that experience.  Ramen Dojo specializes in Ramen whereas Saiwaii has a other offerings on their menu.  The flavor of the Spicy Garlic Tonkatsu was amazingly rich and spicy.  I added cubes of pork belly to my ramen, and that added something extra special to the flavor.
