Definitely would come back here, especially since it's almost right around the corner from where I live.
author: Joey B.

description:
I'm not a huge ramen fan, but I've been here a few times and liked it. There are a bunch of sides, but I've only tried the chicken wings so far.

The creamy broth is awesome. It's nice to have many flavor options for broths and ramen add ins. 

I don't use Dave's Insanity Sauce or any other super hot sauce, but I like a bit of spice and kick in my food. However, even the 'regular' spicy level was kicking my butt and making me sweat. I ordered mild next time and it was much better. I fear what may happen to me if I ever dared to try the extra spicy broth.
author: Calvin P.

description: Aw...I should have tried something else, but I got the Tonkatsu ramen again... Nothing change much and there isn't a whole lot of meat. I was tempted to pay $3 for some Pork Belly and disappointingly, I missed that chance. The broth is still good though! I could drink the whole bowl! Then the MSG would stop me... Next time, I'll try something else.
author: Jeremy L.

description: The first time I came here, I would have given this place a five star rating, but my roommate and I had different impressions, so I let it go. The two of us are constantly having ramen dates, perpetually searching for the best ramen ever. As I said, the first time I came here, it was a serious contender for me. Because I'm a creature of habit with all things I find satisfaction in, I ordered the same thing both times--Spicy Mala with added pork belly. I took a picture of the first bowl and Instagrammed it, because that's the kind of person I am. I salivated over the photo regularly and shared it with everyone I came into contact with--the photo not the saliva. The presentation was perfect; the flavors remarkable. This second time felt like a half-assed attempt at half assery, though. The flavors were mostly good, although the chicken has a few bad pieces amongst them. The presentation was sloppy and not in a "we're really busy and we're doing the best we can with what we have" sorta way. The halved hard boiled egg looked like the remnants of an Easter I'd rather forget. The egg must have been pulled into two halves with someone's fingers, because there is just no other reasonable explanation for its state of existence. Everything else just left me longing for the presentation, taste, and excitement I get when I eat at Ken Ken. If only they had better hours. I probably won't return to Saiwaii. I can make better ramen at home. Luckily my roommate didn't go with me this time, so she can't say "I told you so."
author: Shad S.

description:
This is the third best ramen I have tried in San Francisco, and yes, I'm giving it three stars ... which shows you how dismal the ramen options in SF are.  (However, my two top picks, North Beach's Kirimachi and the Inner Sunset's Izakaya Sozai, both offer four-star ramen, in my opinion.)

Back to Sawaii: having done my due diligence on Yelp beforehand, I ordered the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen and added an egg ($10.95, including $1 for the egg.)  Here's the breakdown:

- The broth was acceptable, but not great.  It had a lot of spice in it and too much oil for my taste.  I agree with the Yelpers who found it pleasantly creamy, though, and I did finish the broth.
- The noodles were yellow and on the less chewy side.  I did not come close to finishing them.
- The chashu was very disappointing.  I received 4-5 small pieces, but each piece was mostly fat.  I ate all the non-fatty bits, which were few and far between.
- The egg was acceptable, but was on the cusp between hard-boiled and soft-boiled.  I like the egg to be runny so that I can mix the yolk into the broth, where it increases the richness of the flavor.  The yolk was congealed enough here that I had a hard time doing this.
- The bamboo was good; the kikurage (mushrooms) were okay but forgettable; and the nori was standard, but not as I prefer it.  (Izakaya Sozai gives you a salted sheet of nori, which has possibly spoiled me for regular nori that comes already in the broth.)

Service was both fast and friendly. 

Given that Yelpers seem to think that the dish I had is the best ramen that Sawaii has to offer, I'm not planning to return.  (EDIT: I did return, and I discovered that the spicy garlic miso is much better/less oily than the Tonkotsu, so I updated this review to three stars from the initial two stars I had given.) It's too bad: the reviews had me really excited for the possibility of a good ramen joint in the Central Sunset.
author: B L.

description: My husband and I have visited twice.  Him ordering ramen and me, sushi. He LOVED it both times and I tried four different sushi dishes and they were excellent, fresh and absolutely great for the price!!!! Service is great and friendly.
author: Maddy B.

description: The spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen is soo good, especially on a cold day. The staff are always really friendly, and I like the open kitchen. Definitely a good spot for ramen!
author: Jennie M.

description: I've come here 4 times since it opened a month or so ago, and I love this place!  I usually don't even like ramen because ramen reminds me of top ramen or cup of noodle that I could heat up at home.  But I love the ramen at this place!  I've had the miso ramen, shoyu ramen and the tonkatsu ramen and all of them are amazing here.  Actually, everything I've had here has been great.  Do add the pork belly option... it's buttery melt in your mouth goodness.  If you don't want the extra calories, then the Chashu itself is really good too... tender and flavorful.  I also liked the spicy tuna roll and the kalbi as appetizers.  And the service here is awesome; they're fast and extremely nice.  They have an enormous amount of staff for such a small restaurant!
author: Tyler C.

description:
after power to the peaceful we came here for some delicious warm ramen.  the service was good, the place is cute and cozy, and the ramen is decent.

seems like everyone in sf is now a ramen junkie and critic. i'd go back, but i won't tell anyone that this place is 'good' or my ramen credibility will plummet to nil.
author: Ameer N.

description: Absolutely love this place. I went there for the first time about a year and a half ago, and up to this day the ramen here is amazing. I've tried all the ravens they offer, but the spicy garlic tonkatsu is definitely my favorite. It's packed with flavor and the pork belly they put in there is perfect. I wish they would give u a little more meat, but they are generous in comparison to other ramen places I've been to. Great presentation of the dish, good combination of ingredients, and good service. The spoons with the notch in it is a plus as well.
author: Lee B.

description: This is definitely one of the better ramen places i've eaten at in san francisco. The servers are super friendly, extra attentive, and frequently ask how things can be improved on.
author: Evan K.

description: i live in the sunset, so driving to san mateo to get ramen dojo when i crave ramen (which is often) is not the most efficient way to get my fix. saiwaii is my go-to spot when my ramen alarm starts to sound. i actually prefer their spicy garlic miso ramen (corn and bamboo shoots included) to their spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen. sometimes i add a hard boiled egg. their broth is rich, creamy, flavorful, and has the right amount of umami. beware the spice level -- "regular spicy" will definitely start to make you sweat...
author: Nini G.

description: Spicy garlic ramen was very good and appropriately spicy. I don't eat much ramen, but it was a little too creamy for my liking. I didn't drink the broth at all. I was curious about the bacon wrapped mochi and it just tasted like bacon with the chewiness of mochi. The lemon added some nice acidity. The place is tiny and I almost missed it. Service was lacking and I felt like it took forever to get my check. I'm pretty sure my waitress forgot about me.
author: k h.

description:
Joint:  Small and not good for kids since there is NO room to move around.  Up side:  It has a cozy feel to it with nice warm colors and dark woods.  I wish they paid this much attention to the food.   

Food:  Cold ramen sucks.  The broth was super salty even for this salt fiend and it was luke warm.  The only saving grace was the pork belly.  It was fatty, juicy and sweet.   

Service: The hostess was having a pleasant sit down snack with the table right next to us and pretty much ignored us the entire time.  The appetizer we ordered went to the table the hostess was sitting at even though they were pretty much done with their meals.  We couldn't get a refill on the tea to save our parched over salted mouths.   

My best friend and I went when this place first opened.  We were both excited to try this place but it fell short.  :( We ordered the tofu appetizer and we each ordered a different  bowl of ramen.  Mushroom or 'fungus' ramen for my friend and the special miso ramen for me with the pork belly.  First down side, the table next to us was obviously a group of friends of the establishment.  They received more attention, the hostess sat with them while they had dinner and they GOT THE APPETIZER WE ORDERED.  It took them forever to get another appetizer to us and it was nothing really special.  When the ramen got to our table, we received two pork belly miso ramen specials.  They totally got her order wrong.  When we pointed the mistake out to the hostess sitting NEXT to me, she looked annoyed and didn't offer to return the botched order but just huffed away and brought a little bowl of 'fungus' with no seasoning or perhaps even cooked to our table.  Classy.  She pretty much just grabbed a bunch of stuff from the ingredients bar, put it in a bowl and brought it to us.  When we finally got to dig into our ramen, the soup was very salty and luke warm.  I guess she thought the LUKE WARM soup would cook the 'fungus'.  Anyhow, the luke warm salty ramen is not satisfying in any way.  The only saving grace for me was the yummy pork belly that they served in chunks.  It was sweet and fatty and cooked to tender perfection.  My friend was completely disappointed.  I had such high hopes for this place and sad that it wasn't that good.  I am considering going back hoping it was an off day but I'm too scarred from my luke warm too salty ramen experience.
author: Marie L.

description:
They appear to have taken some Yelper feedback.  The broth is now hot, and the pork belly cubes are now a permanent menu fixture.  They've also added spicy garlic versions of their miso and tonkotsu broths (which can be ordered mild as well), a great flavor enhancement.

This is about as perfect as a bowl of ramen gets in San Francisco.
author: N. P.

description:
My husband really likes this place so he brought me to give it a try.

The Ramen is very good but the sushi is average.

Definitely recommend it for the Ramen though!
author: Victoria L.

description: I've been here three times in the last couple of weeks.  Sawaii has the best spicy broth (I tried the spicy miso and spicy tonkatsu - both are great) I've ever had.  Oh, and don't forget the extra pork belly!  Each time I go, I try and get other toppings, but I keep coming back to the super tender, succulent pork belly.  Can't get enough of it!  Especially in this cold, cold weather - I'm definitely coming back!
author: Leah S.

description: I was here according to article on SF weekly. Tonkatsu ramen was not so bad. It was nice portion + the broth was natural and earthly taste. However, I gave 3 stars due to the fact that the overall meal was decent but not totally amazed me. Btw, gyoza is surprisingly good with unique dipping sauce that is sweet instead of vinegar sour...
author: Yada S.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Saturday. We order four things and they were 0/4. 

This place broke the cardinal sin of serving food to the public - serving raw meat not requested by the customer. The filling for the gyoza was raw. Pork was so raw, it could've been pulsating! Knew something was wrong when I tried to break one in half and it stubbornly stayed together and tasted gooey. Not a good sign when the filling sticks to your chopsticks!! We sent it back and declined their offer for a replacement. Hubby had the big D for the rest of the day. Luckily for them, I haven't experienced anything yet. Or else I would immediately head over the emergency room for IV and fluids and send them the bill due to my extreme sensitivity to food poisoning. 

The boiled spinach (with sesame dressing) was gritty. Definitely not washed thoroughly enough. Spinach was also tough and stringy. Hello- Costco sells pre washed baby spinach leaves which will serve four servings for the price they charge for one which means their profit margin is pretty healthy and they still choose to serve sandy/gritty old leaves?? 

The tonkotasu and miso ramen were so-so. The noodles reminded me of those used by Santa Ramen. Cheap egg noodles with an aftertaste. The stewed pork belly add ons were okay, though salty and half of it was fat & skin. 

Since we were one of three tables of customers, there was no excuse for such lazy and pathetic attempts at cooking. 

This has got to be my worst Japanese restaurant experience ever.
author: D C.

description: Fresh sushi , good service best ramen in the city. Definitely will be back.
author: andy l.

description:
Walked into Saiwaii only because Loi's was closed.  I believe it may have been during the first week they opened.  Let me preface this by saying I have never been to a restaurant when it first opened, but I'm not sure this is ok either way.

We ordered agedashi tofu, shoyu ramen, and ten don. The waitstaff could really use a lesson in table service.  It's obvious that this is their first restaurant job, and if it isn't...man, that's sad.  I count 6 mistakes during our visit. 
#1 - Waitress could not tell the couple at the table next to us the difference between their char siu and pork belly. How do you work in a ramen restaurant and not know the difference?
#2 - Miso soup brought to table next to us, taken back bc they didn't order it, then brought to us. When asked who ordered it, the waitress took it back, asked someone, and came back telling us it comes with the Ten Don.  
#3 - Miso soup cold 
#4 - Next table's gyoza brought to our table
#5 - Our agedashi tofu brought to the table next to us
#6 - My mom's ten don was brought to the table behind us, and when I asked the waitress where he entree was, she responded with "it's coming". We had to ask another waiter 10 minutes later when nothing showed up. The first waitress came by and said, "Your meal still hasn't come?" --uhh, no...do you see her eating it? We ended up canceling it bc by then it was just too irritating to stay.   

Food critique: tofu was good, not the best I've ever had. Ramen noodles were thicker than I'm used to, but the broth was tasty. The meat that came with it was supposed to be char siu but was pretty much fat with thin strips of meat, tasty but fat. Ten don...............no comment.

Bottom line: the ramen is just ok, but I shall not be visiting Saiwaii again.
author: Michelle S.

description: this place is probably aka "santa ramen of SF". Love the spicy garlic tonkotsu! their soup base is very strong and flavorful! definitely recommend!
author: Goku S.

description: num num num. I live a block away and whenever I feel sick or sad I order some ramen to go and this healthy comfort food makes me feel all warm and fuzzy. I usually get the miso or spicy garlic miso broth. The sushi is really good too.
author: Young M.

description: I had the spicy garlic tonkotsu and it was pretty good. Love that I got to choose the level of spiciness. The waitress was really nice and service was pretty good.
author: Lucia J.

description: I think this is a decent place. I had their lunch special (ramen + a side for $2 more). It's a good deal and worth the try. I was so full after I ate the shoyu ramen.
author: Forest T.

description: My fam and my bf went to try this place today. We ordered the Soy, Miso, and Tonkatsu. All three were good - depends on what kind of soup base you like. If you like creamy, get the Tonkatsu. If you like semi creamy, get the Miso. If you don't like too much saltiness but still packs flavor, get the Soy. We also got the Summer Roll which had mango, avocado, and spicy tuna and it was surprisingly good. Overall, its nice that there's a decent ramen place locally. Also, service was pretty good. The noodles aren't my favorite and that's what knocked one star down. If you like noodles that are not soft, then you'll like these. I personally like super soft noodles. Happy eating!
author: Cindy S.

description: awesome spicy garlic ramen. real crab in california roll. great, friendly service
author: Acorn B.

description: My boyfriend lives on Judah and we always walk past this store so one day we tried it out and it was a pretty small menu but still filled our big stomachs. I have to say is that the guy waiter should really know some knowledge about Sushi. I asked him whether they had Hokkigai and he asked me back WHAT IS IT?! I was expecting, oh sorry we don't have this served here. But anyway, besides this part that ticked me off.. everything else was pretty good. The restaurant is actually decorated pretty nice but there wasn't enough room for the customers to walk around. The longer me and my boyfriend stayed, the more people walked in and the LONGER our food took. I felt a bit rushed since I see a lot of people coming, I had to take my food to go and give the customer seats. Besides all these flaws, the food was pretty darn good! =)
author: Jackie L.

description: Noodles are really good and the broth tops it off!
author: Wayne S.

description: yum yum yum!! I absolutely love this place. being Japanese, this isn't the best ramen place, but it sure comes close!! the people are jaoanese and are so very kind and have great customer service. I come here all the time. perfect for a quick, cheap lunch or dinner!
author: Meme R.

description: Spicy tonkatsu ramen with egg. SO GOOD. but i drink alot of water after eating this lol. salllllllllttyyyyy. but so good
author: Cindy L.

description: Was craving ramen one night and came here as a 2nd choice because Izakaya Sozai was packed and I couldn't wait anymore. I got the spicy garlic miso and the gf got the spicy garlic tonkatsu. Both were adequately spicy and the soup was rich in flavor, and the ramen was what ramen is supposed to be. One star off because their CA roll was pretty average and their tv was showing this really weird anime of men in pink tights dancing.
author: Frederick C.

description: i'm from vegas looking for my 'monta' here in san francisco. this place is comparable! with add on's like agedashi tofu and for 3 bucks u can add a mini tempura don bowl to your ramen. sooooooo good!
author: Cin D.

description: The spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen is always good here!! yum :)
author: Ms. G.

description: The food overall is tasty and well prepared, but I think this place is a bit over-rated and rather skimpy on portion size for the prices.  Also, the service can be slow and inefficient as it seems to be staffed primarily by inexperienced students.
author: Eric L.

description:
for sure uses MSG for the ramen stock
long wait and horrible parking

but at least the service is good and the food is pretty okay!
author: Lizzie O.

description: I ordered the tonkatsu ramen with pork belly. It was tasty! The pork belly was sweet but it worked for me. The fat on the pork belly was legen...wait for it...dary.  The broth was good. I also ordered a rainbow roll which wasn't that memorable. Overall, I would come here again.
author: Kit K.

description: i LOVE saiwaii ramen! my boyfriend and i always get the spicy garlic tonkotsu ramen (available in mild, regular or spicy), chicken karaage, seaweed salad, pork katsu don and house salad. i'll add pork belly and an egg to my ramen when i'm feeling extra gluttonous. everything is soooo good and i'm never disappointed. my only complaint is that the level of "regular" spiciness can be inconsistent. sometimes it's too spicy and i have to ask for a side of plain broth to water down the spice. other times it's perfect. nevertheless, it's my absolute favorite ramen place in the city.
author: Robbie R.

description: Service is friendly and attentive here, and its speed has probably improved since the experiences of the earlier reviewers, though it wasn't particularly crowded during the slightly later dinner hours for which I was present.  Its proprietors appear to be Cantonese, and like Macao Friends before it, this small space is a passable option in the Sunset as a family-oriented place to nosh on a limited but thoughtfully targeted menu.  The tori kara-age appetizer was fine - crisp outside and moist inside; reasonably-sized portion.  However I have to agree with the prior reviewers' assessment that while the ramen is nice and firm, the broth (I had the shoyu) is too thin and bland.  Texture goes a lot way with me, so I slurped up all my noodles just fine, but all the while somewhat frustrated by the underwhelming flavors surrounding them.  Hopefully with enough feedback here on Yelp, their kitchen staff can course-correct accordingly and turn things around, as it will need to distinguish itself more on the strength of their primary fare in order to really do well in this area.
author: Aaron L.

description: the ramen is good, but the reason to go is for the pork belly add on.  i am always on the lookout for new and innovative ways to use the magical animal, and pork belly on top of tonkatsu (aka pork) broth does the trick.
author: Patrick M.

description:
Food ***  we had Red crab roll (2) for 4.95 yum, CA roll w real crab which they mixed w mayo and for personal preference, I totally dislike it.  Grilled squid legs (very chewy) but taste ok.  Miso Ramen, the noodle was al-dente and taste good but the broth was another story....totally tasteless.  Also it was not temperature hot enough when it arrived at our table.  I hope they read this and improved upon this very important step of having a flavorful broth after all their rest. is called Saiwaii Ramen.  Katanaya is still the place for Ramen but it is nice to know there is another Ramen place close to my hood so I will be sure to return again perhaps try some other items on their menu.
Service ****is a solid 4 stars.... my tea cup was never empty and all the girls were super friendly and accomdating to all the patrons.
will def. be back and I am hoping they will improve on their broth for the Ramen.
author: Mel T.

description: Let's face it, when it comes to Japanese food, it can get pricey but not here, baby.  Had the lunch Special at $6.95, super hot miso soup, your not so plain Jane green salad, 4 pieces of CA roll, my entree of Chix Kara Age and rice, and that was for lunch. I can only imagine the dinners.  Ambiance is nice and clean, but not sterile.  This place a pleasant find.
author: Joe I.

description: Their spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen is to die for! I enjoy spicy foods but their regular spice level was a even a tad spicy for me! So if you can't handle spicy foods, go for their mild!
author: jess w.

description: noodles and broth was good, but don't have to get the spicy flavor b/c its not that much better than the regular. its expensive here. sushi no good, don't be fooled
author: Boh Boh W.

description: We came to Saiwaii's for lunch and we both ordered the Tonkotsu (pork flavored broth $7.95) which we were told is their most popular flavored ramen. The ramen came with menma (bamboo), wakame (seaweed) and negi (green onions), and kikurage (did not care too much for). They give a good amount of each topping (good amount of pork too) and I thought the ramen portions were overall pretty decent. The bf liked his tonkotsu but I thought it was lacking in taste and could do with some salt so I loaded it with the special spices they provide for ramen. After that it was yummy! The bf also asked for a half egg ($1) but it tasted strange so he gave it to me. I agree it did taste weird but I ate it anyways. I know it's definitely not any type of egg I've had before (not chicken nor duck). I wonder what kind of egg they use...either way we wont be adding an egg to our order next time. We will be back and next time I may try their salt ramen to see if I like that better. So far Saiwaii ranks third among my ramen favorites.
author: Helen L.

description: Definitely recommend the Ramen.  Didnt get a chance to try any appetizers but the sushi was just ok.
author: Andy W.

description: Besides Hotei on 9th Ave & Irving, Saiwaii is my favorite Ramen restaurant.  I dine at Saiwaii once a week. The spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen is the best!  I love spicy food and to have a bowl of spicy broth with ramen, you can't beat that.  It's nice to have a variety of broth to go with your ramen.  The mini don with eel or tempura is a must have!  Service is always friendly and good.
author: Ben S.

description: I was very hesitant about this place but I thought I'd give it a try anyway.  Ordered ramen, a sushi roll and a special tempura.  As mentioned in other reviews, the broth was lacking in flavor and the noodles did not taste like it was homemade.  Worst part was that the broth wasn't even hot!  When the bowl of noodles came, it was just warm/hot.  The sushi was not wrapped tight enough either.  I couldn't even pick it up with my chopstick without it falling apart.  As for the tempura, it was very oily.  So oily that you can taste oil in your mouth when you bite into it.  I feel bad for writing this review, but I hope the restaurant will take in consideration of this review and improve.  The service was nice, but since it was getting packed, I felt a bit rushed...but rushed with kindness.
author: Katniss B.

description:
this place is not bad. way better than genki ramen, but not as good as dojo / santa ramen in san mateo. 

I ordered the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen (its on the special menu written on a chalkboard, not on the paper menu).  The broth was delicious and SpiCy, but a bit too oily.  ramen was too soft, would have been near perfect for me if only the ramen was al dente.

would definitely be back for more next time...
author: Emily T.

description: We frequent the sunset whenever we come home to visit. Our original plan was to go to another restaurant but parking around Irving can be hell and we found one exactly right in front of this place so we just decided to go there because it's Japanese and our son needs to have a meal where there is white rice. This was the perfect place for us. We entered and the waiter quickly seated us. My husband ordered the tonkatsu ramen and I ordered the spicy tuna sushi, which both were phenomenal. Seriously, you have to try it. While still looking at the little menu on the table, we noticed they have a kobe beef salad so we ordered it and my goodness, I thought I liked salad, but now I LOVE salad. Best ponzu dressing ever. My husband is still reminiscing and requested for us to start using more ponzu at home. For $5, there was a good portion of buttery kobe slices in that dish. Our waiter was fantastic too. He saw that we had a toddler with us, and he was kind enough to bring us extra napkins and a spoon for him right away. He was the only server and there were about 5 tables filled at the time we were there, and he did not miss a beat and checked up on us often. Service was quick. We didn't wait that long for our food, maybe 10 minutes. We would go back again and it's a new outer sunset favorite spot.
author: winnie b.
